review_title: IBM Armonk is filled with kleptocrats
job_title: Software Sales Leader in San Francisco, CA
pros: Still a lot of great people are trying to do good work for their customers, their employees, and for IBM.  They're holding out for IBM to return to the type of leadership that made it great in the past. Some of the products are world-class and haven't been too damaged yet by the cycle of corner- and cost-cutting that's taken place since 2008.
cons: IBM HQ in Armonk continues to focus on EPS and shareholder value to the exclusion of all else. Annual resource actions are a torpedo to innovation and morale. The only people with confidence in the leadership in Armonk are the sycophants in Armonk.

review_title: great place to work, great city
pros:
It all depends on the community you belong to and your manager. If your management is professional, you would enjoy working as a professional. 

- Great work life balance
- I am able to take many Home Office days per month (this depends on your manager)
- Work is enjoyable and challenging
- Ability to advance, switch roles. It all depends on your ambition and aspirations
- Being part of a global company that makes a difference
cons:
There are lots of amateur managers that push employees to leave the company. I was so dissatisfied in my job that i wanted to change company asap. however i changed my role, and moved to different team full of professional people. it changed my perspective of the company. The company is great, but many of the people in it are not. Especially if we are speaking about SSO organization

Another con is that salaries are rising slowly. I have thought of changing companies just to improve my financial situation faster.

review_title: Becoming faceless to it's employees
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: IBM's not a bad place to work. Currently most are being moved back to select offices so don't join unless you're looking at being at one of the offices. Many of us are being asked to relocate to one or leave.  This is the current IBM. Management up the chain is pretty faceless and no one down the chain feels like they care about us as people, just resources.  When they have a layoff it's called a Resource Action. They cut resources, not people.
cons: Never knowing if you'll be a part of the resource action. I've known quite a few people who are very good get that. It's because of mandatory head cuts, not because they weren't up to par

review_title: A once great company that has gone down the tubes...
pros: Good benefits with low premiums if only insuring self.  The work culture is good if employees are willing to be located at one of the strategic work locations, but work/life balance and flexibility is starting to decrease from what it was 10 or 20 years ago.
cons: The company has fostered a culture of employees constantly looking over their shoulders  to see if they will be next on the current round of layoffs.  Layoffs (or "Resource Actions" as IBM likes to so eloquently phrase it) occur two to three times a year for the past 8 years.  The company's overall business strategy is unclear and constantly changing, and it is hard to pinpoint just what service or product receives clear priority in their strategy.  Base pay increases (raises) from year to year are very low at 1% to 2% and bonuses (when an employee gets them) are usually no more than about 1% to 2%.

review_title: not recommended for freshers
pros:
-Better than other giants in India like TCS and Infosys
-Good work life balance for mid-level and senior-level people
-Sometimes you get to study code written by teams abroad which is wuite good.
cons:
- Some of the learning is  related to IBM tools, which won't be useful once you leave the company. 
-Mid-level management has a lot of issues. Politics and regionalism is rampant. You might have stayed up for long nights to do the work but in the end your manager can take all the credit and bonuses or give credit to the people favoured by him.
-Learning is not good for freshers.
-Compensation is not good for freshers
-Recognition is not good for freshers. Generally your manager will go places showing your work and you will get little or no notice at all.
-Your work simply is not enough, you need to build a good rapport with your managers to progress within the organization. I have seen a lot of people getting promoted just because they had good terms with their managers and many deserving friends of mine have been denied promotion because they weren't favoured by their managers.

review_title: IBM, still an interesting place to work but not what it used to be
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Managemnt is good about being flexible about the work environment.  For example, I'm able to work from home a couple days a week, and use flex time other days.  Also, there's lots of career paths within IBM although it isn't always easy to switch.
cons: The pay and benefits have been steadily eroding for the last 10 years.  Pay raises have been nearly non-existent outside of promotions the last 2-3 years.  The company is maniacally focused on cutting expenses, to the point that most development teams are very understaffed.  For many of us, it's difficult to ship quality code with the resources we have.  We're also steadily watching jobs move overseas to China and India.  There's still lots of work here, but it's thinning out as mgmt tries to cut costs.

review_title: Slow and Steady wins the race, don't expect $$$
pros: The education a company life IBM conprovide for employees looking to re-tool is powerful - especially in sales and management... but watch out if you're in a service delivery role because it's very challenging to get training there.  The benefits are outstanding, time off for critical family issues is really remarkable but overall work/life balance is better than average.
cons: In theory IBM should have tons of opportunity for growth (different divisions, many countries, etc.) but you get pigeon holed quickly, and find its very difficult to move up.  They are like the ancient roman army or something... they just assume when the first line goes down there's tons of people to step in so you only move up by out-lasting your competition (who probably left for more money and challenges somewhere else).

review_title: Proud to work for IBM.  Work is interesting, Software brands are strong, pay is pretty good.
job_title: Software IT Architect in Columbus, OH
pros: Complexity of work that is rewarding from both a knowledge and money perspective.  I also enjoy working for a company where I can help my clients adopt technology and innovation to solve their most pressing needs.  The diversity of IBM's people and products allow this too happen.
cons: At this point in my career I can't think of too many downsides.  We have a strong portfolio of software products and alot of demand in the marketplace.  Sure quota's are crazy but I'm sure they would be that way at any other place.  Folks who don't make it at Big Blue should reflect on themselves on what they could have done better.  My approach is to always understand the clients issues and identify IBM solutions that can address those issues.  There has to be a fit otherwise we come across as Snake Oil Salesman.  Not good if you want to have a good relationship with your clients.

review_title: IBM: The good and the bad.
job_title: Senior Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
IBM has nearly a century old legacy of being  in the forefornt of Human Resource Policies, it was one of the few major corporations to have a manager of color, to having given benefits to same sex couples to prohibit discrimination. It is one of the few companies which cannot officially donate corporate contibutions ( via PAC) to politicians. 
 IBM has always tried to hire the brightest of the people from various schools or other companies, this in turn has helped the company maintain a very high caliber work force. 
IBM does have some good benefits, one of the very few companies even today offering free medical to employees.
cons: Like some of the legacy companies IBM seems to have too many managers, the hierarchy level is simply too large for it to function in todays day and age esp when it comes to customers requiring immediate feedback. The company needs to have far fewer levels possibly by trimming a lot of fat from the top.

review_title: Grindshop
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
Mostly nice people to work with, at least the ones not scared of losing their jobs and backstabbing people to keep it.  
Many projects to choose from, this company really does do it all.  
Pay is good if you can get hired in at the right rate.
cons:
Management is grinding their employees out, expect to be hired on for a position only to pick up one or two extra jobs within a year of working there.  
Miserable work environment, morale is very low and gets worse with the constant fear that layoffs are coming. 
Difficult to move jobs unless a project falls apart, constantly being told you are either too valuable to move or that you don't have the right skills.

review_title: Great place to start if you are a programmer.
pros:
Starting your programming career in IBM is one of the best starts you can get.  There are plenty of learning opportunities to take advantage of, the technologies used are great and you get to know an awesome group of people.  Overall, it's probably one of the best places to start a career.

I would not be half of the developer I am today if I had not started on IBM.
cons: Compensation was below industry standard.  I was offered a package with a low start, then fixed salary increases at set time intervals.  I never had one increase on time, and the percentage was always lower than what they had stated.  I left because I got an offer for double my salary, and a year after I was earning 4 times more than what I made in IBM.

review_title: Software developer - band 6
pros:
Amazing work life balance.
Flexible hrs
Work from home
Good location.. off from downtown toronto.
Respectable culture among people.
cons:
-Poor salary. Band 6 with masters r hired at less than 65k. Thats is dirt low. What is more upsetting is bonus and salary adjustments are not gurantees. You might be a start performer with 0 bonus.. there goes all ur hard work.
-Promotions are almost impossible. Spend almost 5-6 yrs in band 6 even though u perform very well. That used to be only 2 yrs some time ago. 
-Lay offs every year. No job security. Even good people are asked to leave. 
-PBC rating process is a pain. Hate filling those docs every mid yr and end of year again.
- if ibm is going through such a rough patch, where did the money come from to pay 3.5 million bonus to the CEO ? Probably the salary saved by laying so many people off in 2014. That was questionable !!!

review_title: Not the best place...
pros:
Good "Work-Life" balance, although it depends on your manager and the service you work for. 
In most of the teams home office is allowed.

The company it's so HUGE that probably will stay where it is for next 50 years...
cons:
- The lower salaries on the market. That's it. 
In fact way how to increase your salary is hidden and not really accessible, salaries are not measured on job's role, but only on your negotiation skills, once you get hired for some wage, is extremely hard to get a raise.
- Quality: The worse quality I have ever met in an international company, very poor job's outcome, customer's satisfaction it's a BIG LIE, simply the customer has NO IDEA about what does happen inside the IDC. It can only survive in the market due to the highest prices.

- Employees are "handled" like things. Lying is the usual way how to manage employee's frustration and requests, since the major aim of IDC is to save money, nothing else really does matter.

review_title: Great Company with Bad Managers
pros:
- Global Sales School Training is fantastic
- Being in the Game on #1 Company
- Unlimited Learning Possibilities
- Above Average Personal
- Rewards are really awarding
cons:
- Hidden Costs are put on workers (e.g. Gas, Car expenses paid by Workers)
- Nothing at the company is for free (not even Coffee or Tea)
- Management doesn't care about Talent, they just want to keep the A players under them blocking their promotion paths. 
- No fair Internal Job evaluation, "i know this guy" is enough for a not qualified person to get the job or promotion.
- Very high stress no chance to have long term targets (which sale did you close today and what are you closing tomorrow)
- High value strategic deals are not valued, more over it's all about deal timing.
- Upper management focusses on Quantity and not quality.
- IBM rips of the $$ from employees first, by charging even job required tools back to them. 
- Salary model is too complicated to bargain

review_title: Good place for senior developers
pros:
Relaxed, laid back environment, no micromanagement, 

They drive you to learn continuously

Their customers are not cheap, so you can do good work on projects

Travel arrangements are above decent, even a bit over the top for my taste

Good pay, in my location, nice workplace

Very convenient, although a tiny bit bureaucratic work from home policy
cons:
Not really cons, just annoyances. 

No free coffee! It's the first company in many-many years where I've encountered this.

Their bureaucratic processes can take ages and a lot of your time, and are somewhat awkward, at times.

Not the best health insurance, compared to most other companies in the area. 

Outdated/poor hardware you get to work on - that's my biggest gripe so far

Internal trainings more sales-oriented than technology-oriented

review_title: IBM Will Slap the Golden Handcuffs on You
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Salary is competitive and often exceeds other local employers.  Time allowed for vacation and personal choice holidays is good (if you can actually afford to lose time from work to take it).  If you do not abuse it, time away from your cube during the workday to take care of personal business is accepted without even a raised eyebrow.  Project assignments can be interesting and challenging.
cons: Zero investment in professional development.  Unbelievably low investment in providing employees with the tools necessary to do their jobs.  Physical work environment is substandard.  Poor yearly bonus system.  Ever-deteriorating product quality due to insanely short development cycles and offshoring to incompetent workers.  Low performing employees are tolerated far too much and are often simply passed from one department to another - it's like a government job.   Too many layers of management.  The bureaucracy would make Kafka cry.

review_title: Work for a company where your contribution is appreciated and rewarded. It's certainly will not be at IBM.
pros: TO say you worked for "IBM"
cons: Management didn't care. Open door policies tagged you as a bad employee. There is no ability to move to another division within the company. The only way to work for IBM these days is if  they buy the company you currently work for. Then they weed out almost everyone from the original company and lay off existing staff and move the jobs to Argentina (the new india).

review_title: Stop offshoring US jobs.
pros: Flexible work schedule which is supported by immediate management.  The pay is good; however, you earn it.
cons: Limited opportunities for professional advancement.  Offshoring of US jobs which creates continuous anxiety and makes one wonder "will my job be offshored next."  Matrix managment structure which makes for a stressful/ very ambiguous work environment.  The company embraces a virtual team environment, so you can work in one city but work with individuals in different cities.  This can create a more challenging work environment since you cannot simply walk over to a co-worker's desk to discuss a work item.  Management can also be located in another city.  Bottom line - there can be a dearth of face time which can hurt you during your annual review.  Also, there is a tremendous focus on getting more bang for the buck.  In other words, reduce the number of employees, maintain the same workload, and take on additional workload.

review_title: Iconic American Giant with diverse career opportunities if you can make your voice heard
pros: Not much gives more satisfaction than knowing that you are working for a iconic American Corporation that has so many innovations under it's belly it's hard to list them all. The diversity and size of the company makes for great career opportunities if you can make yourself heard. Whether its different products, markets or professions, IBM can offer almost everything. Maybe not the best place for any particular job but if your going for diversity and general management, it's a great place to be.
cons: There's plenty of competition and as large companies go, plenty of processes and bureaucracy as well. If you can get a strong executive team to drive your career, you can go places. If you don't get support you'll be left in the dust. Compensation is average and the company is leveraging it's reputation and the market conditions to pay below market.

review_title: Great company if you don't care about raises or advancement
pros: Ideology on working from home, immediate & extended team has great culture, flexibility of hours based on client need, health care 100% paid for employees, training programs are mandatory and frequent comparatively. If you have the drive to learn on your own, IBM offers plenty of opportunity to learn from some of the best in their fields of expertise
cons: Getting a raise takes an Act of Congress, they will cap your income even if you exceed expectations, sending feedback to management is like talking to a post, much more internal paperwork/processes than I'd ever experienced at 4 other firms (3 large 1 small), too much middle management

review_title: Great company if you don't care about raises or advancement
pros: Ideology on working from home, immediate & extended team has great culture, flexibility of hours based on client need, health care 100% paid for employees, training programs are mandatory and frequent comparatively. If you have the drive to learn on your own, IBM offers plenty of opportunity to learn from some of the best in their fields of expertise
cons: Getting a raise takes an Act of Congress, they will cap your income even if you exceed expectations, sending feedback to management is like talking to a post, much more internal paperwork/processes than I'd ever experienced at 4 other firms (3 large 1 small), too much middle management

review_title: Witness the decline  - IBM Dubuque
job_title: SQL Database Administrator in Dubuque, IA
pros: Elevators,  good chairs, good lighting, nice view from upper floors,  nice lobby,  a little coffee nook to ponder ones escape.  It is in the nice little city of Dubuque.  IM
cons:
More dysfunctional than most large companies I have worked at. 
Leadership provided  by "professional managers"  with no IT sense.
If you enjoy changing & tracking your passwords youll like it here,  not 5 or 6,  like 40 constantly expiring.
The 10 accounts you ll be supporting all have different configurations,  login procedures,  rules
India coworkers are 12 hours away,  many that are difficult to understand.
Prepare to give up all of your personal digits to anonymous requests from the many clients across the globe to secure your personal access to their data systems.
Remember you will be fired if you share a id or password, understandable.
High turnover,  depressing to see hope fade in the newbies.

review_title: 10 years in
job_title: Software IT Architect in Manchester, England
pros: Working for IBM SWG gives you opportunity to explore your career, manage your own time, make your job your own, you work where you need to be - flexible
cons: there is a lot of reporting done, you have to be a good corporate citizen, you are not well supported when taking a risk on career path exploration, they try very hard to minimise your pay, they do not give you pay rises often even when you change role, work life balance can be an issue, development investment is minimal, they do not supply you with the tools to do your job (BYOD), reviews on achievement focus on the figures only. They talk a good talk on culture and values but this is lip service, senior management do not drive and support it.

review_title: Broken promises - Dishonest Management - No consistency
pros:
There are some great people that venture into employment at IBM. The older staff offer a depth of experience missing in some organisations. Many of these staff have been pushed out the door without receiving entitled benefits however.
IBM attracts the brightest graduates with promises of great careers and long term employment. Unfortunately for most this is not the case and due to the extremely high management churn there is no proper guidance or consistency.
cons: Inexperienced new managers would attempt to reorganise departments every 10-12 months with no real understanding or appreciation for how staff are juggling multiple hats. NZ is managed by Australia and treated like Tasmania - due to the small revenue contribution. IBM NZ management are powerless to support staff and this often leads to broken promises. Cutbacks in 2011-2012 left the business very lean, now IBM is hiring for 30+ staff just to get back to baseline contractual commitments.

review_title: Reached a peak of job satisfaction 5-7 years ago, downhill since then
pros: Work from home arrangements, Name recognition, dealing with a global team... you will meet everyone from everywhere, but only if you travel on business.  Benefits are still good, compared to other places, but being reduced each year.
cons: IBM has a huge work from home culture, however I wouldn't necessarily call it work-life balance, as you are always expected to drop what you are doing 24/7 for conference calls.  Your manager may be in another country and from a culture which is not similar to your own... but you will change managers every year and the only thing the new manager will know about you is what your previous manager tells them in the turn-over meeting.  I probably had 8 managers in the last decade while staying in the same job role.  I only ever met 2 of them in person.

review_title: "Don't protect the past…which seems to include many of the reasons to work there"
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: You have an opportunity to work with some very smart and seasoned people. Benefits are generally good. Depending on your management, you may have an opportunity to move around and manage your career.
cons: Training other than self-study/off-hours is pretty much non-existent due to spending budget restrictions. The internal education site "free classes" are mundane and out-of-date. Morale overall was pretty downtrodden. Every cycle a couple of people would disappear from immediate or matrixes teams in the next resource action, even where no low/mid-performers in revenue-generating roles. No longer a long-term career for most outside of management. Benefits decreasing or disappearing. Managers can limit your mobility within company by identifying you as a "critical" resource based on job-role, but have no means to justify keeping the headcount when the cuts are mandated.

review_title: Lead cross functional team to develop BladeCenter servers, appliances and options
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Durham, NC
pros:
The company is so large that you have a lot of opportunity to have multiple careers at one company.  You have the opportunity to collaborate with a lot of SMEs.  There is flexibility in work schedule and working from home or office.

They have a very good continuing education program.  The benefits package is awesome (health, vision, dental, 401K, pension and employee discount program).
cons: Because there is flexibility to work from home it seems that it is the norm to be expected to always be connected, on and available.  Work life balance is very hard because of all the long hours required to complete projects.  It can sometimes be hard to have a collaborative environment because you are being compared to your peers so most people are doing whatever they need to do to shine.

review_title: Worst Company Ever Worked For
pros: Absolutely zero, unless you count 10% of Sainsburys as a pro?
cons: Complete disjoint between senior US management and the rest of the company, pure short termism in their approach to satisfying their customer(The shareholder not the true client). They erode any value from companies they buy. They do not care about the employee or the client only the shareholder, and who are the biggest shareholders.......the board. They constantly restrict your ability to do your job yet expect you to support the sales guys in selling as much as possible, even if that means giving ridiculous discounts just to get anything even if it means undermining any future market value. They say IBM is a great place to have lots of careers and move jobs, that's because its full of people constantly moving and hiding when they mess things up! what about those who want to do one thing really well!

review_title: For newbies or pre-retired. A point to start or a point to end your career
pros: At least outside USA, IBM is easy to get hired: good for newbbies, old people that want something relaxed although it forces you to live in a cheap country. You can negotiate HO and in general real technical workload is little. Is a good move to start (just for 1 year) or to go there for a relax pre-retirement taking advantage that most of the staff is newbbie.
cons:
A Burocracy hell, with a proportion of  7 non technical roles per technician. You have to deal with painful tools to work and nobody knows in general. Documentation is lost, outdated or never done.

It seems that each team/region works in each own way with the tools they want and are not the same for all offices across the world. Low salaries, low workload, low expectations. Unless is your final stage of your career, leave before 2 years.

review_title: Interviewing and Onboarding
pros:
Very thorough interviews; 4 interviews with 5 different people ranging from UK, Europe and US. 
Willingness to agree to discuss and to tweak the offer (once I had received it).  
The initial onboarding has quite been very good.  There is a a soon to join programme with videos and online content to review prior to your first day, followed by a full induction day at a very impressive IBM campus in the UK, and then a recent joiner's programme with comprehensive videos and online content to help explain the complexities of a global organisation as you begin. Very professional.
cons: The interview process could have been shortened.  From application to final interview took 6 months.  There were also gaps as long as 6+ weeks where I did not hear anything after an interview. Also, the offer then took another month after the final interview, when it was stated that an offer was going to be issued to me.

review_title: You can survive only when you are under a good People Manager
pros:
1. Easy to get work from home(that is the one and only flexibility).
2. You will get easy relocation in case you need it(depends on your manager sometime)
cons:
1. Before joining IBM I heard that IBM has a very good HR policy. Believe me, there will be no HR to entertain you, there will be no HR partner assigned to you. In each and every concern, you need to reach out to your people manager . Most people managers are not even aware of all the HR policies.
2. You will get very low hike, sometimes may be no hike at all even if you receive highest rating.
3. Remember that your people manager is everything for you in IBM so your ratings and hikes will be depend on your manager even if you are performing good or bad. So it's better not to engage in a dispute with your manager.
4. No don't ever think about any onsite opportunity while you are in IBM, it totally based on your luck.

review_title: Review of IBM's Summit Program and Sales
job_title: Sales Specialist (Summit Program Graduate) in New York, NY
pros:
IBM's Summit Program is a world-class sales training program, where you have the opportunity to go through sales school, where you learn the best sales methodology and use them in practice for 6 months before going into the field. Sales school is supplemented by communication workshops (including stand-and-deliver and group presentations), as well as classroom learning on IBM's hardware, software and services offerings. It is a very comprehensive sales and leadership training. The Summit Program prepared me for my current sales role and beyond, into any leadership role I want to pursue in the future.

Not to mention my first year has been a lot of fun, with excellent compensation and work-life balance. It is a culture of giving, networking, support, mentorship, and positivity. I have made some of my best friends working for IBM.
cons: Heavy travel schedule in sales (this is a pro for me, but may be a con for others)

review_title: good corporate vision that unfortunately isn't executed on local level
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- work/life balanc
- leadership has innovative, unique vision
- corporate discounts
- decently nice office spaces
- good brand to have on resume
- "badges"/internal education
- easy to be comfortable and remain in position
cons:
- bureaucratic
- corporate vision not being executed on local level - US full of toxic teams + outsourcing whenever possible to cheaper countries
- complicated organization structure and processes are counterproductive to innovation and operational efficiency
- instead of fixing, another team to address the issue will be added, creating more confusion and cooks in the kitchen
- many toxic teams that are difficult to improve due to their tenure at the company - very common for employees to stay 20+ years
- age tends to be either very young or very old, not much in the middle
- limited to no yearly bonus structure
- always be prepared for restructuring/RAs/firing
- poor morale/culture - people stay because it's easier than leaving
- low pay - also, big differences in salary for the same role
- not much room for upward growth

review_title: IBM promotes the new world order
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Durham, NC
pros: IBM is a company that is very focused on the contribution of the individual to a team goal.  The company has woven in work life integration into its culture and provides an environment where the most intelligent people can comfortably perform and are routinely recognized.  There several career paths for one to pursue and opportunities for growth.  IBM is one of the great companies to work for in North America.
cons: IBM does have many processes.  There are protocols in place that can be stifling and like with any large companies there can be obstacles both large and small and leaders both new and old who struggle to put the customer first.  Proactive career management is the responsibility of the individual for the most part and the company is currently experiencing some restructuring.

review_title: Not a place to work for long
pros: Brand name, enough projects - which means sufficient work for employees.
cons: This is not a company for performers. Career movement in IBM India is tagged to people management chain - which may not be one's project chain. This creates preferential evaluation of an employee as People Manager always prefer reportees of his own project. IBM is also removing all facilities that they used to provide couple of years back - like medical insurance premium. IBM has established lot of processes - but most of them have big gaps into it. It has an utilization target of 98% - which you can't achieve. The same is used as an explanation weapon to prove your bad yearly rating. Computation logic for utilization calculation is also weired. It considers mandatory holidays (like Independence Day, May Day, Gandhi Jayanti) as WORKING day while calculating one's utilization.

review_title: been going downhill for the last 4-5 years.
job_title: STG Technical Sales in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Good work-life balance
Great co-workers
Decent salary (not the best, but not the worse either)
Great technical community
Good place to learn about new technologies
cons:
too many levels of management (executives with no reporting strucutre?!?)
very hard to get any straight answers from upper management
if your on an technical incentive plan, you can kiss any incentive payment goodbye (IBM will make sure you barely make your base salary...)
employee motivation is down the drain.
Lots of very talented employees are fleeing the company because of the above-mentioned reasons.

review_title: Get it all in writing
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Denver, CO
pros: Potential for very dynamic job assignments, always learning something new and exciting.  There is a great feeling of just being associated with IBM, but over time, that fades.  Management can often be really good, but its not always the case.  People generally are highly motivated both personally and corporately
cons: Management - be careful of your leadership.  That can be your biggest hero or your worst enemy.  Due to political nature, if things don't go well on an assignment, management will find someone to blame - it could be you.  Beware of undocumented promises from management.  At IBM, if it isn't in writing, it was never said.  Oh, and by a huge measure, raises suck or are non-existent.  Lots of raises go through lengthy 'dry spells'

review_title: Outstanding Company - treating employees professionally
job_title: Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: IBM institutes a philosophy for keeping its employees by offering them the opportunity to build career experience with the encouragement to move about the company.  Overall this works well although one needs to also cast a wide net which can take quite a long time.
cons: My position pertained to selling the smarter commerce suite of applications which are well accepted in the market place.  If you are a seasoned sales person and truly do not like to cold call then you will fail.  IBM is NOT a marketing company and depends almost exclusively on each seller to build the field product buzz on their own.  You have 12 month to do that and make your numbers before your accounts are thrown back into the hat and you start almost from 0.

review_title: Good to work for, if you're able to stay
job_title: Project Manager in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
- Benefits of a global enterprise with a strong position in the market and the clients
- Salary and benefits are not top, but still competitive
- Work performance is really valued (depends on the management, but it's usual)
- Growth opportunities exist, altough it'll require a lot of extra work
cons:
- Too many directives and standards
- Although it's not a cut-throat environment, there are lots of pressure to reduce costs (meaning people)
- Some people work a lot, others not so much; the first are rewarded if they're lucky, if they're unfortunate they'll be listed for non-renovation anyway, but not all the bad employees are on the leave list
- Not the most friendly environment; not talking about costume parties, or after hours parties, but it tends to be a very neutral environment

review_title: Client Technical Professional
job_title: Client Technical Professional in London, England
pros: Interesting technology, get to meet with and work with some great people. Company well respected in the market
cons: Terrible HR processes - no interest in employees welfare, you are really just a number, education is based on skills you will never need but 'look good' to management, pay rises don't exist, everybody wants to be a manager, no 'team' any more, employees taught to compete with each other like gladiators - only one winner, do what you can to get up the ladder etc..... Actually, not a nice place to be. 15 years ago it was a different place and people enjoyed working there!,,

review_title: The biggest dot-com of them all - it really is a good company to work for if...
pros: State of the art in every respect. Be prepared to work. Be prepared to make IBM an extension of your family, because you will be expected to give it all you've got (and that can often mean work flowing into your time off - like weekends).
cons: Sometimes long-term IBM employees can be a tad condescending. I guess that is an occupational hazard when you work for a large corporation, though. Keeping any negative thoughts you may have about individuals to yourself can help you in navigating "office politics." As  said: occupational hazard in a big corporation. IBM is no exception. But if you resolve to do a good job (and are good at "handling" people and their idiosyncrasies) IBM is a company with many paths for advancement.

review_title: Work Hard and Play Hard
job_title: Cyber Security Advisor in New York, NY
pros: It's a place where you can work hard and see the results of your work and be recognized for your efforts.  This year's recognition award was hosted in one of the finest hotels in Punta Cana and IBM made all of there feel extremely special.  I've never had as much support by colleagues willing to help me than at IBM. You are working among the brightest, most innovative people willing to assist you.  IBM is a company that has reinvented itself so many times to not only remain relevant but to maintain it's leadership position over well over 100 years.
cons: Sometimes the large size of the organization can get in the way of itself.  All the help I've noted in the pros sometimes comes at a price where we have too many hands in things.

review_title: Stripped of every benefit
job_title: Band 10 Manager in New York, NY
pros: You will have good people to work with and a big brand name for your resume. The work load isn't too heavy.
cons: Raises and bonuses are non existent and have been for years. If you perform well and you are not in sales or an executive, your bonus may be $800. Also, as of 2019 IBM eliminated out of network health coverage. None of the plans offer it though they still call the plans PPO plans, but read the fine print. You are 100% out of pocket for out of network coverage. But the costs go up every year while the coverage declines. IBM used to allow work from home but in an effort to streamline that option is gone, so you will pay to commute (not reimbursed) and work in an open plan office with picnic tables as desks and not even a coat closet in some locations. Worse case you end up at a WeWork.

review_title: Great place to learn and than ... to leave
pros: Respected company with high level of innovaiton. A lot of opportunities to improve skills and knowledge: there is also the possibility to change business units varying from application/consulting services to infrastructure services as well as to transactional sales such as hardware and software. Very structured and well defined HR processes, aligned with top experiences on the market. The strongest aspect is the possibility to leverage on a large IT professional community around the world to solve your own problem, sharing experiences and have new ideas. The IT infrastructure supports the information sharing the connection among employees. Good work&life balance with possibity to work remotely form home.
cons: Burocratic and no possibilities to growth quickly in your career even is you are an high performer, working 12 hours per day. Years have to run ... and there is not a direct correlation between  outcomes and career progression and salary. Sometime there is the perception to not have a clear direction to follow in strategy definition.

review_title: Working for IBM is a mixed a bag.  Brand name but low pay, no career path, and extremely matrixed selling environment.
job_title: Software Sales Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: Brand name, experience working for a large corporation, and resume builder.  IBM sales is highly regarded but in order to make more money you'll need to leave IBM.  The sales plans are not generous, and re-organizations and layoffs are envogue.
cons: raise freezes, low compensation, no career path, extremely matrixed, and constantly changing management.  The IBM matrix requires you to have far too many sales cadences.  You'll spend most of your time reporting to layers management and mending internal IBM issues than selling.  Even so, working together as one IBM is a constant challenge as self interest among the brands, and pillars makes the selling process much more complex.  For such a large corporation, there is far too much finger pointing and not enough internal coordination/cooperation, which wastes far too much time.

review_title: IBM - Just Say No
pros: IBM pays its top performers at (almost) industry average.
cons:
- IBM does not invest in its employees.  For example, lip service is paid to continuing education, but there is no support from lower and middle management for keeping your skills current.

- IBM does not want employees to work for the company for more than 5-7 years.  IBM is focused on having the lowest paid workforce (in all countries) in lieu of product and technical expertise.

- There is a complete failure in leadership at the upper management and executive levels.  Rather than gain market share through R&D and product excellence, profit growth now comes from buying companies and layoffs.  This year (2009) is an excellent example;  since sales were flat,  >10000 employees were outsourced and stock buybacks were used to increase the EPS.

review_title: Banker's hours, non profit pay
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Somers, NY
pros:
As you move up in band, you get some cooler projects, bu that will take 4+ years to start getting the more interesting jobs. 

With that said, working from home is a great option, you can work pretty much anywhere in the world. They give you a fair amount of vacation days. My health insurance is essentially free.
cons:
Unfortunately the company is shifting into less profitable business that are driving market shift, and when your bonus pool (albeit small) is tied to profit growth, kinda makes it hard to get compensated well

You get 15 Vacation days a year and 5 personal choice holidays on top of the regular holidays to use whenever you want, unfortnately last year of my 20 days, I used 4.

review_title: Missed opportunitiy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Foster City, CA
pros: IBM is, without a doubt a great company and a good employer. The company is huge, it's decision-making slow super slow and the business is run by the spreadsheet masters. Nonetheless, job opportunities are there for the right people who don't mind mind-numbing bureaucracy.
cons: For people with Silicon Valley DNA - for people who are accustomed to getting things done - its not a good fit. Decsions are made in a vacuum at HQ in New York. They don't get agile, they aspire to be cloud, but severely lack the DNA and relevant infrastructure to make it happen. IBM's CRM system is a custom version of Siebel. What can I say.

review_title: CURRENT & Future employment
pros: Great people in S&D and excellent MGT...  GBS could use some classes in how to treat employees with respect and not verbal abuse - Just a few bad apples and it rolls down from there.  But other manager are great and will help you all they can!!  Some of the smartest people in the world!
cons: You work in your job description and that is about it.. NOT too much room to branch out BUT lots of mobility across the silos after your 2 year commitment. Be sure you manage your our career as it is up to you to get ahead...  Negotiate pay on the way in as in sales... that is where your base stays....  ONE you leave  - you will be labeled "IBM" and the employer will assume you cannot sell without the entire BUS..  so other jobs are difficult to get...  but you will get lots of interviews since IBM has good reputation..

review_title: Great potential but too many blind-spots
pros: So many to choose from.  Ambition and confidence - the Smarter Planet story is a great example - IBM can improve the world, knows it and believes it.  Who else could have created Watson? All those Nobel prizes, and its simple scale and breadth of capability.
cons: Despite all the rhetoric and PR, has still not managed to compete the transformation from product provider to service provider - will not do so until it starts treating its people as human beings rather than stock (the way the UK pension changes were introduced is a perfect example).  Still governed from the very top by a culture of bullying and no trust. May have a female CEO but no real diversity.  Financial controls which were suited to surviving a recession but constrain growth.  Bonus schemes which no-one understands.

review_title: Great potential but too many blind-spots
pros: So many to choose from.  Ambition and confidence - the Smarter Planet story is a great example - IBM can improve the world, knows it and believes it.  Who else could have created Watson? All those Nobel prizes, and its simple scale and breadth of capability.
cons: Despite all the rhetoric and PR, has still not managed to compete the transformation from product provider to service provider - will not do so until it starts treating its people as human beings rather than stock (the way the UK pension changes were introduced is a perfect example).  Still governed from the very top by a culture of bullying and no trust. May have a female CEO but no real diversity.  Financial controls which were suited to surviving a recession but constrain growth.  Bonus schemes which no-one understands.

review_title: Essentially, liquidating its assets...
pros: Worked at IBM for over 30 years.  It used to be a wonderful place to work, with talented people and best of breed hardware/software.  It no longer is that company and the best that can be said of it is flexible work from home and somewhat flexible work hours.  Pay/benefits are average.
cons: Company used to be run by engineers, but now is run by the finance department.  Minimal investment in it's people and R&D over the last 15 years and everything is now spent on stock buy backs.  Most of the experienced and talented people are now gone.  The existing set of customers are really paying the price with the current product set and services now offered.  It used to be that having IBM on your resume was a good thing...  I'm not so sure anymore, as it was harder and harder to get good college talent to come to IBM.

review_title: Company that cares
pros:
A company that isn't afraid to invest in it's employees. Need a course to fill in some skill gaps for the upcoming project? They'll help you cover it.

Every day I wake up and think to myself, how amazingly cool, I work for IBM.

A progressively multicultural company.
cons: The pay isn't as competitive at entry, but if you stick through, contribute and grow so will your pay. Think of this as getting your foot in the door, or being hired by this mega corporation so that you can work your way up from the mail-room.

review_title: Not a pleasant place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Flexible work schedule including work from home as needed/desired
cons:
Management at all levels renege on their promises, from earned retirement pensions and medical benefits to earned comp-time.  For example, at 2nd line management direct request I put in over 400 hours of unpaid overtime over a 3 month period to help get a hot project out and when I went to use the banked time after project completion, per prior management agreement, management denied it and allowed me to have NOTHING.  

Working 60+ hours per week, my raises average 1.1% for the last 4 years.  Insufficient return on investment for this job.

review_title: Service Delivery
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed the SSR work!  IBM had such a fantastic reputation.  Having IBM on your resume still looks good.
cons: I would not want to be an SSR at IBM today. High stress, low reward.  You are expected to actively participate in the sales and leads process, even as a non-customer facing SSR.  The pay raise, IF you can get one, does not keep up with the annual increase in the cost of benefits.  It is all about making the executives wealthier at an enormous cost to you and your family.

review_title: Do not be conned by the Company Name.
pros: Flexibility. This is probably the only reason why a lot of people choose to stay in IBM. There is nothing else that would be considered as a "pro".
cons: Promotions are not based on performance, instead it is based on how well you can brown nose your superior. Most things that you learn in the "accounting" unit of IBM has nothing to do with basic accounting. If you are looking to learn accounting, please think twice about coming here. All you do is repetitive data-entry work here. Something even a Secondary 5 graduate with no accounting skill would be able to do. Also, for medical you would still have to pay RM5 for every visit to the doctor.

review_title: Good for start
pros:
- nice team
- good trainings online
- excellent opportunities to gain a lot of experience
- good pay for people with little experience
- good working conditions and atmosphere
cons:
- management - not looking at positive sides of employees and not doing anything about them in terms of developing talents; not qualified enough in some cases
- promotions based on knowing people, not on competency
- very long time between promotions, even for qualified people - opportunities not made clear for everyone
- necessary training for a promotion is 6 months in duration, max. 3 meetings per month, this i ridiculous!
- extremely mundane and useless daily reporting
- terrible software for reports, mail and IM
- tons of hoops to jump through to get anything done (home office, requisitions)

review_title: IBM - Big and wide ranging opportunities, high expectations
job_title: IT Data Analyst/Developer in Portland, OR
pros:
Pros are that:
* IBM is really big and worldwide, with people doing almost ever imaginable job in IT
* IBM is generally on the cutting edge of technology, and must stay that way to survive
* IBM has a ton of educational opportunities to help it's people move into new areas, and
* IBM pays pretty well
cons:
Cons are that:
* Overtime, including weekends, is often expected and sometimes demanded, and that does not leave much time to live
* Travel to a job site, sometimes takes over 10 hours by plane, and can occur like that every week, which cuts into the time to live some more
* There are so many offshore personnel, and H1 visas, that work for less, that that is somewhat limiting in terms of competition and opportunities, but this is the way of the world now

review_title: Overall an average company to work for
pros:
Decent benefits like discounts at some shops, cinemas, etc.

Good pension contribution by the company - 100% contribution

Most of the employees are in patent groups and getting a patent successfully submitted, company awards you with 1000+ pounds of bonus.
cons:
Graduate Software Engineers hiring process does not involve doing any coding, thus, they hire a lot of poor developers who just waste everyone's time and demotivate the team.

Graduates after getting hired have no say on what they want to work. Most likely you will be put on a product which is not growing anymore and good chance it is losing clients instead. 

Very poor compensation - way below the market prices. Even salary raises are laughable. I got 7.5% raise (+2250 pounds per year) even after completing a huge project almost by myself in a team of 4 graduates, because the rest of them had close to none programming experience.

Employee retention is low - around 13% of people willingly leave every year

review_title: Good company that recognizes hard work well.
pros: Deserved recognition, pretty good remuneration and benefits, employee gets appropriate visibility since the management works closely with the employees, great place for someone who aspires to climb the ladder quickly driven by the hard work, employees get what they ask for if the demand is right and could be accommodated. Most of the managers I met were technically skilled and understood the technical concerns well. Most of the people I worked with had attitude of achieving goals through hard and smart work rather than just talking. Seems like a good operations focused company.
cons: Work environment may get tough at times - driven by deadlines and commitments. Micro management may come as a side effect of management's involvement in the details at low level. Your manager can make or break things - depending on the kind of person who manages you. HR dept. is approachable over phone and email. People manager and project manager should ideally be different but end up being the same person for convenience of management - this reduces employee's options if any situation arises.

review_title: Financial Analyst
pros: No need of much prior experience.
cons: Trust me this section is not long enough to describe the epic failure that this company is here in Bulgaria. Honestly this would be a PERFECT example for university students about how management fails in real life. The managers are with the best words atrocious people, those who are actually working are being pushed to the limit resulting in now social life because you are working too much , or as they put it "you are contributing to the greater of IBM "... even if you are the few who actually graduate and actually have some financial knowledge left in you, do not bother applying, as here bottom licking and asking the manager in the morning if they want tea or coffee will get you more props in carrier development, than your business tasks, absolutely horrible no respect for your work , basically even if you work for the whole team you are still underachiever...managers are bottom lickers they have not a single drop of management in them except for 2 of them. In their views you are no one and the manager is like a beacon of light sent from the heavens above to guide you through life..

review_title: What used to be can be again
job_title: Manager, Marketing in New York, NY
pros: Access to the most incredible minds.  Resources that are built in to the giant machine.  Being a part of something great.  Flexibility in finding lateral move jobs.
cons: You can get lost in the sauce.  Employee upward growth potential is limited once you get 'up there' at least in marketing.  They've been hiring a lot of external agency experienced resources but they don't know anything about how to be and embrace being an IBMer.  The 'new' blood is taking the life out of the passionate IBMers who would give their left leg for the success of the company.  Instead marketers are being shelved or over looked.   Raises are infinitesimal.

review_title: In through acquisition
job_title: Operations Team Lead in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Collaborative tools are a plus. Everybody knows who I work for and I don't have to explain my who my employer is past three letters, IBM. Vacation days are nice, Sick time policy nice, Healthy lifestyle perks such as steps challenges, logging workouts and monetary rewards for keeping an active lifestyle are nice. HSA plan so far has been a positive.
cons: Salary increases are the most minimal, seems they can barely keep up with inflation. Bonuses for anyone in IT seem to be non -existent, banding and layering has diminished my direct reports so now I'm no longer a manager thanks to changes that occurred after acquisition. Travel and hiring bans have been in effect ever since our acquisition took place, nobody knows what the future holds for our team.

review_title: Too focused on hiring from the outside and releasing existing employees!
job_title: Technical Sales Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Decent benefits.
My co-workers are great hard working people that do what they are asked and more.
cons: The current management regime from the Board, CEO, and top 200 executives are too focused on getting rid of pretty much anyone over 50.  They keep saying the following over and over again, " We must focus on Millennials and getting new blood into the organization." ....translation, get rid of anyone older than 50.  They are losing way too many highly skilled employees in the name of new skills.  The very people that they are getting rid of possess those deep technical and highly sought after skills they say that they need to hire from the outside...pure B.S.

review_title: OK entry-level, but going down the gutter
pros:
CbD used to be a slightly better program, but there have been significant management issues that have made it go down the gutter. 
- Great work life balance
- Decent breadth of experience
- Good resources/training
- Much better diversity at the younger level than other huge companies or banks, etc.
cons:
- They pay market rate, but then you cannot get a raise for 2 years (no exceptions). 
- No year end bonuses (I don't count $200 as a bonus)
- Not a rotational program
- No say over your staffing/career goals
- Somewhat diverse but not enough... tons of younger women but not many female executives because no women want to be high up there...
- Ivy league school grads get paid $75k or more to start. Other schools will get $70 or less. YOU CAN NEGOTIATE PAY AND LOCATION AND TYPE OF CONSULTANT. Do it!!

review_title: Don't waste your career
job_title: IT Professional in New York, NY
pros: Got to work mostly from home for 10 years... til they tossed me aside for cheaper offshore replacements.
cons:
As a consultant, you are required to work 106% or more of billable hours in a year, and you have to make up any vacation time that reduces that percentage.
They offer lots of training but a lot of it is garbage, and you are required to take a LOT of mandatory training that isn't even in your area of expertise.
Mgt offers help to get your job done but when push comes to shove they cannot really help at all and all they tell you is "well, we just need to get it done!"
Horrible raises!  Might get 1-2% in the "good" years, zero in others even when you get a good review.
When they terminated me they said they didn't have any more jobs for me yet when I look on their career website they have 15 open jobs... offshore...

review_title: Good place for a programmer in some teams in Toronto Lab
pros:
-- Flexible schedule. Say, you can come around 11:00am and leave at 4:00pm. The key is to deliver result and don't miss important meetings. 

-- Lots of training and improvement programs for employees. Many are useful despite some are superficial. 

-- Compensation is pretty good compared to other companies in Toronto

-- Opportunities to do interesting jobs
cons:
In some departments, "cross-organizational impact" is the only thing that matters because managers have no idea how to evaluate your technical contribution. This may be ok because for large departments, one or two components may mean very little. However, this culture also enabled intense political fight for visibility. Since code doesn't matter, why bother? All I should do is to spend as little time as I can getting my crappy code out of the door, and as much time as I can manipulating other people/team to do things for me and I grab the credit, right? 

Larger team is normally worse. Staying in a team of fewer than 10 people, you'll have much better visibility.

review_title: Flexibility to work remotely is great, major downside is the amount of time spent on laborious and inflexible processes
pros: Life at IBM is hugely influenced by who your direct line manager is - if you have a good manager, you are likely to be treated fairly.  Upside is that remote working is widely available - working from home is seen almost as a right, not a privilege as in many corporations
cons: There's a lot of process to get through - often it feels like you spend more time on completing the various processes than in doing the real job - that's a huge frustration.  Rigid process also means that very few employees consistently get reasonable salary increases - if you want a decent salary, make sure you negotiate before you join because the policy seems to be to pay the very least that they can.

review_title: IBM Software Labs  India - good work environment, not much money
pros:
1. Very wide product portfolio. Can learn almost everything in software world if you wish
2. Good work life balance
3. Friendly environment
4. Switching between roles is relatively easy
cons:
1. Over last few years IBM/ISL has gone down in pay ladder. Below market salary

2. Company prefers Lateral hiring in  senior positions rather than promoting internal people

3. Over the years management is losing transparency and fairness. Still better than market but it's deteriorating rapidly - primarily owning to lateral recruitment in management cadre from  other companies. These people mostly don't know IBM values.

4. Do not expect great salary hike. IBM thinks the flexibility they are giving you must be compensated by low salary. HR simply don't care 'bout high attrition.

review_title: Great Co-Op Experence
pros: IBM was a great place to work because of all the information sharing and availability of all employees through out the company. I was amazed to find out that almost 40% of IBM's software developers work remotely. This being said IBM makes all employees available to everyone for questioning. Don't know Perl? There is an IBM community dedicated to learning Perl where professionals share their opinions. This also follows for many other technologies.
cons: Since I was just a co-op the project was a "nice to have" feature on a main product line. While the work was challenging, engaging, and fun, I couldn't help but feel that this might not make it into a release. And if it was to be released it wasn't going to be for a long while and they'll probably just have to re-write it since a lot of the product will have changed since then.

review_title: Global Business Services: Safe, but poor reward
pros: Safety in Job; consistent long-term projects; Training both classroom, e-learning, and client-site training was excellent
cons:
Poor reward for performance. Partners were forced to dust off age-old PWC policies to reward performance and even that was well below par

Travel policies ruined by long time IBM sales teams taking advantage. Travel policies can't compete with flexibility required by clients of a consulting firm. Need to be separated.

HR policies get worse each year. Impressively bad decisions taken on behalf of 420,000 employees and in no way reflect how a consulting firm should be run. Loses a lot of ground against the private firms (i.e., Deloitte)

review_title: 35 Year Career
pros: More successes than failures and more smiles than cries.  Great career opportunities, skills and experience acquired at IBM prepared me well for life after IBM.  Always remember that satisfaction and success with any company is up to the individual.  I retired from IBM with no regrets.  I actually thanked my manager when I was told that I was impacted by the resource action.  I left with no anger towards the company.  It was a great run!
cons: IBM is slow to react to changes in the industry.  Lack of vision or strategy.  For years, the answer to improve the bottom line was to reduce cost.  Too many layers of management has destroyed the creativity and vision that once made IBM a great company that was the envy on the I/T industry and business community in general.

review_title: Great place to work, but company is overly obsessed with its 2015 earnings goals
job_title: Software Development Manager in Markham, ON
pros: Great, motivated, very smart people. Opportunity to define your own role, and to move around - you can have a quite varied career all while staying at the same company. Work-life balance is pretty good, no excessive overtime except for those who choose it.
cons: IBM set itself the ambitious goal of doubling its EPS from 2010 to 2015 (so-called 2015 roadmap). But since revenue has been relatively flat the only 'lever' they have is to cut expenses. As a result they are cutting positions and making their salary program into a joke. They pay less than most IT companies and recent increases have been in the range of 0 to 2% for top performers, with nothing at all for those who aren't at the top. They are also cutting various divisions in the company so badly that the best people are quitting, leaving mediocrity behind.

review_title: The Consulting by Degrees Program needs a lot of work
pros: The salary is competitive for new graduates, and the healthcare coverage is excellent. There are a lot of great employees at IBM that really want to help younger team members. I've had senior team members set aside time to make sure that I understood what was going on in the project, and that I was really learning something.
cons: The CBD program is set up very poorly and delivers little value to recent graduates. The amount of paperwork that needs to be filled out for project assessments, year end reviews, and promotions is astounding and very redundant.

review_title: Not a good choice for a happy long term career
pros:
Working with technology can be very interesting and stimulating
Flexible working hours - however be prepared for management to stab you in the back over agreed arrangements
Understanding with sickness
cons:
The annual review system (PBC) ranks peers according to your performance perceived by managers who may have little or no involvement in what you have done. If you get put in the bottom 10% you are likely to have to go on a performance improvement plan. In my view this process has caused a generally widespread very low morale and makes it dfficult to build teams whose members trust each other 
Pay reviews are very few and far between
Managers have a habit of issuing arbitrary deadlines with little thought put into what is required to deliver a quality piece of work
Software products are generally badly designed and massively over engineered
Too much emphasis on process and not enough on product quality

review_title: Watson or Bust
job_title: Technical Sales Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Internally IBM is touting their Cloud, Analytics, Mobility, Security, and Social (CAMSS) model as their recipe for growth as a company and your growth as an employee. It feels great to be in an environment where your individual contributions seem like they are aligned to the success of the company.
cons: Most customers invite the IBM team in check a box or add a column to their evaluation template. CAMSS Customers often complain that other firms can offer competitive products and better services alternatives. The IBM Technical bias and Sales\marketing advantage that existed years ago doesn't exist any more.

review_title: Its what you make of the giant!
job_title: Enterprise Sales Executive in San Jose, CA
pros: Fantastic umbrella of team of people to work with.  Within IBM there are unlimited number of opportunities to move around.  People don't step on each other to try and get ahead. There are a lot of talented and experienced folks that you can take advantage of.  Work life balance is awesome.
cons: Its hard to outshine in a large company like IBM.  You constantly have to prove yourself to stay on top.  There are a LOT of folks laying around the company that work maybe less than 20% and everyone around them knows, but still nothing is done about it. There isn't much innovation and out of the box thinking in more than 90% of the divisions.  Being a developer, tester, or product management, you see numerous complaints of people not able to grow.  Leaves aren't accumalated and empire at the end of the year.

review_title: Good Start to a career, not a great place to develop
pros: Good place to start out and get an introduction to the world of business.  Able to take on lots of responsibilities quickly and work with people from all over the world and across many different industries.
cons: When you work for a company as large as IBM the work that you do is part of broader picture.  As a consultant the focus might not be to provide the customer with the best solution, but rather find a way to leverage the relationship in order to sell more software.

review_title: Don't join give it a second thought especially for this one
pros: As of now I can't think of any pros to this job becuase your sleep cycle is gone for a toss and while you're working you'll always be pricked by this extreme urge to get out of the structure as soon as you can. If sovreignity is what you desire thn please don't join even if you have got an offer letter. Try for a better designation with a well paid package rather than loosing your precious sleep for a salry which is worth peanuts.
cons: Do it only if you've the verve to make it big in the Outsourcing and BPO industry otherwise just don't look in this direction. The pay is low and you are literally starving for more but what you get ultimately is not satisfying and not a good feeling to go home with.

review_title: Application Developer Specialist
job_title: Applications Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: 401k matched contribution after 2 years...extra week of vacation time after 2 years...that's it...o, infrequent raises (bi-yearly at most) that are below the inflation rate.
cons: low pay, lack of transparency and trust in management; random firings and lay offs. If you can't find any of the few projects available, good luck staying employed because you will be thoroughly kicked to the curb. IBM Baton Rouge CIC is essentially a glorified call center. Hush hush atmosphere promoted by management. They'll tell you some of what you need to know and plenty of what you don't. Same goes for the training...pshh...training.

review_title: IBM Sales Summit
pros:
Comprehensive training on all different aspects of becoming an advisor to the client in sales
Great sales procedure and methods and frameworks
Access to a lot of training material and expertise
Willingness from other IBMers to help us learn and grow in the company
cons:
Sales organization is incentivized commission-based so it would make it very competitive in some cases. 
It might sometime get hard to find the resources you are looking for, but if you keep looking and asking help, you can do what you and your client need
on the summit program we have not been aligned with specific brands internally, so as tech sellers we had to put a lot of effort in learning technical solutions after the six months, this could be managed better for the tech sales summit.

review_title: Project Manager
pros:
Good clientele base and excellent project management processes.
Excellent IBM learning tools and certifications available  for a keen learner.
Industries best work life balance and flexibility which also shows trust in the employees.
cons:
Company performance has hit the paid certifications and perks to employees.
Very negligible variable package.
Too many hour tracking tools for employees, issues raised, thus reflects clear micro management by the senior management in general, not a good vibe on the floor.

review_title: Swamped by useless middle-managers
pros: Good name on CV, lots of talented peers to work with (at first). Good starting salary.
cons: Too many middle managers who collect a wage for doing very little. Very difficult to move up the ladder. Little to no career progression. No training or development. Old fashioned practises towards working arrangements in terms of uniform, dress code and working from home. IBM con people in with a competitive grad salary then work them to the bone until they move elsewhere. The only way they employ mangers is through outside hiring, there is a lot of buddying between management so often the best candidates are overlooked for the managers pals. After 5 years you will only have had a 1-2% pay rise whilst your peers elsewhere will have progressed a lot further. If you are desperate for a blu-chip name on your CV then go for it but I would strongly suggest avoiding IBM. The company is going backwards.

review_title: Company lacks organization and strategic direction
job_title: Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: You'll learn a lot about how to successfully play your role and operate within a huge company. You have the freedom to move to other roles quite easily. As with any large company, you have resources at your disposal. Good benefits and work-life balance.
cons: It is hard to find a role at IBM for people who would like to work 'hard'. There seems to be a lack of higher level strategic direction of the organization and ithe uncertainty is sensed by the sales reps and marketing teams. I do not think the company does a good job managing early career talent either. I experienced very little direction given since I was first hired or presentation of common options for progression. Sales, if anything, does this development somewhat better than other roles I've experienced through their training program. Workplace demographic is split. A lot of older workers and a lot of brand new employees out of college. Not much presence in the middle, illustrating the lack of opportunities for advancement from entry ranks.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to feel worthless.
job_title: Deskside Support Representative in Austin, TX
pros: They have A/C in the hot summer months
cons:
No training whatsoever since 2000
No pay increases since 2000
Management is not effective in communicating the simplest things to their employees
Customer support = rebuilding systems for minor issues so the bean counters can stay within their ratio of hours per events.
Upper management could care less about IT support for their employees.
No career advancement
No ability to move to other divisions within IBM to further ones career.
Management always asking for more, while removing the resources needed to complete the job.
No cross-communication within IGS to allow for effective support.
Too much time spent on metric, not enough (if any) spent on customer satisfaction,
Out dated process'
Ineffective knowledge bases
Management is NEVER held accountable for failures when layoffs come around, just the staff.

review_title: Once a great place to work, has gone downhill in recent years.
pros: Opportunity to work with highly professional people from diverse technical and cultural backgrounds. Opportunity to pursue many different job roles. Work with cutting edge technologies. Managers tend to actually grok people management and are generally rational folks.
cons: Gradually but inexorably moving towards a services-based "consulting sweatshop." Uncertain future for US based software development. Constant cost-cutting (staff reductions, corner cutting) in prod dev areas, leading to lower quality products. Most innovation is now through acquisitions, as cost-cutting (along with the political turf wars that ensue as middle mgmnt squabble over a a piece of an ever-shrinking budget) and process (i.e. corporate instructions, or the private sector version of "unfunded mandates") make organic innovation extremely difficult.

review_title: Good company
job_title: Software Developer (Package Solution Consultant) in Bangalore
pros:
Flexible working culture. Good work from home options. Good brand value and lot of projects.
good for Women employees. good growth opportunities ( conditions apply)
cons: no transport provided - except for shifts. no free tea/coffee. No outings/ fun activities . Rarely team outings or company outings. Tough to get hikes (almost impossible) and very less salary growth. lot of politics . need to be really good at communication and interaction skills else you will have to take back seat. You have to be innovative because, when you come to IBM, you will find difficulty to find things starting from stationary to documentation and information in your project. work culture here is totally different so it could take time to understand and adjust. You need to be really good in-order to survive in IBM.

review_title: Stagnant
pros: I have worked both in headquarters and brands (GTS/SWG/IGF/STG). Brands are a sweatshop and very few people make it in there. Mine was a horrific experience. In my experience, the ONLY good thing about a career in finance at IBM is that you can expect your paycheck to be deposited into the checking account like clock work.
cons: If you are an undergrad and looking to join IBM I guess it's OK; however, be prepared to get underpaid and overworked. It requires a certain type of personality to do finance jobs at this company, which are boring and mundane. Moreover, I have heard them describe some people at IBM as leaders and I am having a really hard time believing that's what a real visionary should be. At best, you learn how to deal with IBM's definition of an executive. Many are dumb but lucky, others are gestapo style because they don't know any better. Very few executives are pleasant to work for.

review_title: Great....  but declining each year
pros:
IBM hires great people - positive, hard-working and bright so the people, and teams are great
IBM supports and even promotes tele-commuting or working from home which allows for work/life balance
IBM offers lots of training and education and a chance to move to many areas of the business
IBM hires good management who have good people-management skills
IBM trusts its employees and has good policies in place between management and staff
IBM values are excellent
cons: The company has changed over the years.  It used to reward its employees with trips, motivational awards, company outings etc. This has all but stopped completely.   Quotas were challenging but attainable, allowing one to earn a really good income. That has all but stopped and the environment as of late has been driving employees to meet unrealistic quotas.  Lots of pressure on employees.  Junior employees are micro-managed with all actions tracked.  Top-performing senior sales people are not adequately paid.  Job satisfaction has dropped among my colleagues.  The famous IBM culture is not the same as before, sadly.

review_title: A great company that has gone bad....
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Coppell, TX
pros:
Good name recognition
Good benefits and learning opportunities
Great people to work with
cons:
They are laying off people to help their stock price.  I heard employee count will go from 100,000 to 30,000 over the next two years.  Customers suffer because of lack of employee resources and services on their contract is bad.
I got laid off by a manager.  That manager was incompetent and laid off employees to cover that manager's weakness.  That manager is still there.  Managers can have affairs with their employees.  It will be known by upper management, and those managers still work there.  That is unexcusable.  It seems if you are a manager, you are untouchable.
I still have a lot of friends who work there and don't like it.  They feel that they will enventually be laid off.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked for - Sweatshop
pros:
- a good name to have on the CV
- a good place to network and meet new people - and then leave like everyone else does
cons:
