- Resourcing managers make your life hell when you are on the bench and try to push you on whatever project suits them without asking your opinion or considering your personal circumstances
- arrogant (micro-)managers with big egos who are full of themselves and expect to be sucked up to
- no work-life balance; you are expected to put your life on hold  
- number of hours you spend at work matters (face time culture), not the results
- regardless of what they tell you IBM DOES NOT CARE ABOUT ITS EMPLOYEES
- rigid and hierarchical organisation
- they only win projects because of their brand and size, but customers are rarely satisfied due to poorly delivered work by offshore resources
- bad reputation as an IT software implementation partner


If you are a senior consultant IBM UK Global Business Services is not a good place to work. Don't waste your time, go somewhere else!

review_title: Not what I expected
pros: Brand recognition is through the roof, and the talent of people here is as good as you will find anywhere.  IBM has a process called TA-DA-QA that is designed to insure accuracy and quality on large deals, and for certain opportunities the company will do a deal for pure cost alone.  Very aggressive and very focused.
cons: Executive management is insane.  Quotas are unrealistic, they do NOT give a hoot about work/life balance, and they will work you to death... The same TA-DA-QA process that ensures deal quality often keeps teams of employees on conference calls till 4:00 am quibbling over contract verbiage-  I've gone through it many times.  IBM also manufactures very little anymore so we just resold other companies' products, using outsourced labor at higher prices than the industry norm... Makes it very difficult to compete against more nimble, aggressive smaller vendors who can offer the exact same product and delivery subcontractor at a better price.

review_title: Corporate America Policies
job_title: Computer Systems Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: IBM is a recognized name in the IT industry. When people hear it they listen. Everybody still trying to be IBM from old. It just that the old ways have gone out the window. You will have to climb the ladder quickly and bleed big blue. Big blue is your new family now. It is good paying job for management in America, but most other employees are contractors.
cons: The company outsource to other countries to protect their earnings. I am not bad mouth other countries but when the bottom line means cutting American jobs to save a buck. They should really think how they are hurt America instead of profit. Which they claim they never make all year then at the end seem to pull out for the shareholders.

review_title: Some teams have poor culture, and unreasonable expectations. Be wary.
pros: The pay was competitive for the market. On-site food services. Plenty of free parking. Decent health coverage. Occasional remote work is acceptable. Some casual entertainment is available, like pool and ping-pong.
cons: Some teams have poor culture. An expectation to be in the office for 12 per day, and then to log in remotely from home at all times, even on weekends is ridiculous. I've seen many people asleep at there desks and completely worn out. Attrition is very high because people don't want to live in that kind of environment. Even if your extremely productive, leaving after 8 hours warranted critical remarks like "oh, leaving early today?" or " when you get home, can you log on, I want to send you a task to complete tonight". The work life balance does not exist. At least on my team it didn't. Oh, also the extra hours of work are all done with zero overtime pay.

review_title: Senior IT Project Manager
job_title: IT Senior Project Manager in Burnaby, BC
pros: Good place to learn.  Able to work on many different projects and work with many different specialists.  Individuals are very fine people and highly skilled engineers at IBM.  On projects they bring very valuable skills to the table and are very professional at their jobs.
cons: The culture at IBM Canada has deteriorated to the point that there is no loyalty left in the company either from the employees to the company or from the company to the employees.  Everyone is just looking out for themselves now.  Just waiting for a buyout package or retirement.  Everyone's position is being earmarked for outsourcing and this is leading to a loss of the best minds in North America and along with some of the best clients IBM had.

review_title: IT Specialist
pros: Absolutely great people overall. Incredible flexibility on working hours and remote working. Depending on role, you have a good chance to work autonomously. Access to great and varying technology. Diverse environment where you get to meet a lot of people and possibly travel a lot abroad. Salary depends on how you are able to negotiate when you start and depending on your manager, you might get raises till you get too expensive.
cons: Constant resource actions and reorganizing. You never know how safe you are independent of your position and seniority. If you happen to get a manager, which do change often, you don't get along with, it will be difficult to change role. If you get bad review, it's impossible change role anymore and only thing left is to wait for next resource actions.

review_title: IBM is in constant decline
pros: Work life balance is good,  though this is now changing as they force all employees to work full time from an IBM office (IBM used to be much more open to working from home) . Salaries are above market average
cons:
Layoffs, feels unstable, executive make up new policies to make life a little more difficult and push employees out- they don't calling it layoffs but effectively that's what it is - workforce redaction - the side effect of this practice is that the good/strong employees leave and the mediocre ones stay. 

Every other month there is a new big strategic shift, which usually goes nowhere bcz they don't give it enough time to takeoff before they shift again. 
Too much short term thinking, focused on immediate revenue with very little investment in r&d.  

In IBM you are a little screw in a big machine, and they make you feel that way every day.

review_title: Challenging for Support Staff
pros: Easy on boarding with being able to do everything from signing documents to providing your own photo for your badge.  Great training system with admin mentoring new hire. Decent office. Some benefits are good such as medical. Just starting to implement a one day work from home.
cons: Below average pay for the high level expectations.   Many restrictions that make it somewhat challenging work environment.   Still using Lotus Notes  but the last I heard they might be implementing Outlook.

review_title: Awful and sad
pros:
If you’re recently hired at the director+ level they pay well because no one from outside the company wants to work there.
Director+ gets you and administrative assistant which is exceedingly outdated but it’s nice not to have to do your own expenses
cons: It’s hard to describe just how sad it is to work at this company.  It’s collapsing under the weight of overly complicated, inflexible business processes. There are two types of people here: people that actually do some work and walk around looking traumatized and people that fire out emails all day, clogging up everyone’s inbox or sit on 30 person conference calls and produce nothing. It’s pure lunacy. The co-location thing they did was one of the stupidest moves anyone has ever seen in business. In fact it was downright abusive and heartbreaking to watch people struggle with that decision.  Directors and above spend most of their day inspecting or being inspected using these Byzantine metrics reports.Everyone is constantly worrying when they get laid off too.  Within two days of working here I had decided to pull the plug and walked away from a huge paycheck. Seriously I don’t know how anyone works at this company it’s miserable.

review_title: Don't it Make my Brown Eyes Blue...
pros: Fresh out of school, I think it would be a great place to explore because there are so many different IBMs.  There are opportunities to work in almost any part of the globe and in really excellent fields like fractals.  IBM also has a lot of presence in Second Life, which is a lot like having the company's blessing to play games!
cons: If you're acquired later in a career, and there is nothing similar, they don't necessarily know what to do with you, and it's really up to you to try to dig yourself out of miscategorization.  Also, since it is so large, if you're used to a small company where it's easy to make sure everyone knows something, the 'pull' culture at IBM is tough to get used to - w3 is a great mass of information that you're expected to navigate for yourself.

review_title: IBM coulda been great, but blew the opportunity
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent training ground.  Good benefits.  In many parts of IBM, there are good opportunities to pursue wider ranges of skills - both professionally and technically - that you might want to pursue.  Just be sure that those goals and aspirations do not conflict in any way with your current assignment and duties, or it may get you rated lower and put your position in peril at the next cut back.  You can still look for those opportunities, but unless your manager is better than average, keep the search to yourself until you have a done deal.
cons: Long hours - the job will take whatever you're willing to commit to it.  Increased outsourcing also leads to a fair amount of conference calls at odd hours to connect with Asia.  There is a lot less ability for older workers to shift into new positions, even if they are a good skill match.

review_title: IBM India - Great place for the geeks
pros: Great company to work for if you are a real knowledge-seeker and have a flair for research oriented work. The resources for trainings and professional development available in IBM are simply great and unmatchable. The facilities and guidance provided by IBM for research oriented work and patenting are also something provided by very few companies of its kind. Apart from that Ithe service portfolio that IBM's offers to its clients have almost 360 degree coverage and has something or other for almost everyone to learn and contribute. IBM's pioneering work on some of the latest technologies and industry trends and also something which takes its employees at the forefront when it comes to expertise and skills.
cons: Too many employees, so the visibility and other benefits are not so good compared to others. Also career growth also becomes a bit slow. The compensation is though okay for the middle level employees to good at the higher ones, it's not matching with the industry for the freshers.

review_title: Great company, sometimes too bureaucratic
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great benefits package, excellent initial compensation, great management and executives, good internal resources (intranet), lots of technical communities, lots of diversity communities
cons: IBM, being a huge company, has a very rigid promotion structure and it can be difficult to reward employees who excel at their jobs. For example, the promotion cycle runs only once and year and if an employee misses that opportunity for promotion, it is very difficult to receive a promotion out of cycle. A lot of employees move around between companies (i.e. Accenture, KPMG, etc) to speed up the promotion cycle and increase salary more rapidly. Additionally, there is a lot more administrative busy work, certifications, conduct guidelines, etc than you will experience at a smaller, private firm.

review_title: Bad, pretty bad
pros:
1. You learn the art & science of project and program management.
2. You learn to navigate a very large organization, the art of politics.
3. Customers tend to value you and you can (in some cases) bring real value to the customer.
4. IBM's education systems are amongst the best anywhere.
cons:
1. Managers and processes are designed for themselves, not for the people.
2. GBS is not a place for much innovation.  ISL may be better.
3. There are minimal processes in place.  It is pretty chaotic.

review_title: You are a salesman, and a peon at that
job_title: Software IT Architect in Dallas, TX
pros: IBM has a great reputation and good products.  We have some autonomy to do what the customer needs.  If you do a good job, your sales people will come to you and take your advice.
cons: Do NOT believe that you will be able to grow your career easily.  The field technical team is treated like peons who have no expertise and there is little ability to show your expertise to the brand or other managers.  As a result, you are stuck.  Furthermore, we are expected to be (as one colleague puts it) a mile wide and a millimeter deep.  We've become"demo monkeys" who have to follow the script.  Most of us don't know what/how to handle off script questions because we can't specialize in one pert of the portfolio and we get no real training opportunities.

review_title: Great place to work, and flexible...if you are!
pros: IBM is a great place to work, especially if are open to opportunities across different business units. The flexibility it offers is unparalleled in today's industry, be it across functions, business units or countries, for that matter. While the organization is, no doubt, a bit slow in certain areas, it can quite match up with today's demanding technology and business requirements, with unique industry strengths.
cons: Sometimes not so nimble in terms of responding to market and customer needs, not price competitive across all markets, more or less at the 75th percentile in terms of employee compensation, archaic ideas in some pockets of the business/ refusal to change, i-dont-care attitude by some business leaders (even with regard to business problems), file pushers abound in some areas!

review_title: IBM Sales Job: as a TSR (Territory Sales Rep)
pros:
a) ability to convince your cux: why IBM? why NOW? why YOU??
b) a sales he or she need to have very creative view: how win/ how to grow market/ alternative approach to cux 
c) ability to lead brandsales (product sales) to listen your direct: how to win every biz oppty?
d) ability to tell your management a story: your territory is promising & able to achieve quota.
cons:
a) Sales quota too challenging: like my team is at least 150% growth rqst from top down (SMB) 
b) management style: very pushing/ very challenging: drive you to the limit!!
c) matrix sales system often cause conflict & many confusion from the clients
d) sales too short lifecycle: change sales or change territory

review_title: Absence of face to face meetings impede business effectiveness and demoralize employees
pros: Many different types of jobs to choose from giving chance to explore opportunities all within the same company
cons: Employees receive no relocation when move from one job to another within company, there is no such thing as a travel budget, and virtual management impedes development of relationships to get things done.  IBM management has no sense of the employee other than their deliverables.  Many of programs and benefits within IBM are never used because managers have little "sense" or view of employee (which can only be gotten face to face)  beyond narrow sliver of work they happen to be doing.

pros:
1. Excellent process oriented company 
2. Multiple sectors which best suits your technical path

4. Only single Organization with professional staff in over 170
countries globally, where one can get a job in any kind of technology

review_title: Overrated and under promised
pros:
- The IBM brand (Global Business Services GBS) on your CV opens a wealth of opportunities 
- Client facing experience 
- Good benefits 
- Handful of great people to work with
- Better place for graduates
cons:
- Extremely low pay for experience hires, not a place for experience hires
- Not a company that looks after their staff 
- Utilisation is extremely high 85%, which effectively means there is no work life balance
- Ego driven consultants and heavily driven by layers of management
- Promotion process is long and tiring. Everything is driven by your Band, not your capabilities or skill set
- 100% travel and client based
- Negative culture 
- Internal politics and bullying but HR does not care to resolve

review_title: Not so great place any more.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in New York, NY
pros: It used to be a great place to work and that was only because of good quality people in the company. I had the opportunity to work with many people across many nations and it gave me chance to grow in my personal career. The company has good world wide opportunity.
cons: The way this company started treating its good people, I have not much hope in the future of the company. There is no benefit if you work good and lead your team successfully unless and until you please the management the way they want. It has been ages for me since I got a good open minded manager in this company now.

review_title: IBM - the slow decline of a once great company
pros:
Good Benefits
Throughout the company, there are islands of excellence. The ability to interact with some truly brilliant people on those islands. I was able to learn a great deal about some technical issues because of the IBM connections in a day or two - it would have taken a month or more, otherwise. There are a good number of individuals at IBM that *really* know their stuff!
cons:
Their review system is a joke. Ratings are predetermined, have less to do with your personal job performance and much more to do with your managers' personal agenda.
Overly bureaucratic. Management is more concerned with checking boxes and CYA than with actual results.
Employees can and do get blamed for issues that are totally outside of their control.
Unstable work environment - the "Resource Actions" will continue, as will the practice of having employees train their low cost, less skilled overseas replacements unless they want to lose their severance packages.

review_title: There is heaps of scope for a positive turn around
pros:
Great peers to work with, should there be any left after continuous ongoing rounds of resource actioning (work force rebalancing).

Several of my peers have confirmed that the latest rounds of redundancy packages are so poor, that they are no longer worth waiting for, so if you get a better job offer elsewhere do your homework to recheck this statement, and you will find it is a no brainer to leave and start enjoying your life.
cons:
I was working 50 to 60 hours per week continually on a salary with little scope to increase it. 
The salary review process is flawed (or at best designed so that your salary erodes).

I found that Employee benefits were being continuously eroded, removed or sunset (they can do this check your employment contract) and I would be surprised if there are any remaining of significance.

review_title: Passion, Innovation and Engagement
job_title: Vice President, Transformation in Armonk, NY
pros:
The people: IBMers are smart, passionate, collaborative, committed and driven to deliver value to our clients, the company and each other

The work: Meaningful in impact, global in scale/local in design, partnering with clients to solve some of the world's most challenging problems, always an exciting hill to climb...you will be stretched!

The environment: built on a foundation of values, belief in work-life flexibility, inherent learning culture, collaborative
cons:
Change and reinvention is a constant in our industry, with our clients and in our company; if you enjoy status quo or a great deal of certainty, IBM would be a difficult environment for you to operate in

IBM is a large company. If you are not a self starter and path finder dedicated to your personal expertise and impact, it will be challenging for you to succeed.

If you prefer to be highly entrepreneurial, your skills will be valued, but you will need to embrace process and procedure governance to work within.

review_title: LIFE and LIVING @ Ease with IBM.
pros: I believe throughout my career of 7 years. IBM is the first organization, I came across, Where LIFE and LIVING is made simple and achievable without any barriers/roadblocks that one could always look forward from diversity aspect. At least @work you have the feel of being supported, Which makes it a really amazing and wonderful place to work at, rather than make yourself feel as an alien out there in the so called "SOCIETY".
cons: On observational front. I strongly feel the approach for higher management personnel's, needs to be more sensitized. So that any individual from diversity aspect does not feel outcast-ed,  neither has any fear about their choice of orientation, which is a little difficult most of the times, coz of preconceived society stigmas and notions.

review_title: Work at Home.
pros:
The very best reason to work at IBM is that you can find a role where you can work at home.  There are many of them if you stick around long enough and can work the system to vector yourself into one.  IBM name is good too. 

Also, people are very nice.  It's a generally professional and cordial environment.  There are very few abusive managers and the like.
cons:
Advancement opportunities are terrible because paths are so unclear and the company is so large. Also you are likely to be working for someone your parents age, so that means the opportunities come slowly 

Watch out for random layoffs.  Even if you are good, if you are in the wrong spot when the music stops, you're toast regardless of past performance.  It's like musical chairs.  

They've taken away some awesome benefits since I joined.  Now it's much more plain vanilla.

review_title: Good work life balance but poor career growth
pros:
- In hand component of IBM is generally quite high, they dont inflate your CTC by adding figures which you wont eventually get
- Excellent work life balance, you can literally choose your working hours and as long as you complete the deliverables nobody questions what timing you are following
- Good knowledge pool, exhaustive internal knowledge database where you can fish out for almost everything you want to know about your domain
cons:
- Salary increments are almost negelgibe, on an average i had about 2.5% increment over the past 3 years
- Promotions are also sometimes delayed and have a bearing on your performance rating which even if you are working hard you may still not given a good rating
- the performance rating also depends on how much equation you have with your manager/project manager, something which should NOT be there at all.. it should just depend on how you have performed and not on anything else

review_title: Review of IBM's global delivery organizations in India and not of IBM itself
pros: Laid-back lifestyle; good work-life balance; decent money by India standards; easy work hours; employees stroll in anytime between 9.30 to 12 noon; less pressure; one often leaves by 3 in the afternoon and continues work at home (almost entirely due to traffic congestion on Indian roads between 4 in the evening and 9 in the night); processes are steadily getting built; rewards and recognition programs are steadily being put in place
cons: Very slow career growth; Lower single-digit salary hike; very slow promotion opportunities; work is often of no consequence; dismally low opportunities to bag client-facing roles; completely back-end work with no visibility to decision-makers who are usually in IBM's worldwide geographies; IBM has these global delivery organizations in its consulting practice, its market insights practice and its marketing practice - all based in Indian and Chinese cities.

review_title: Worst company I've worked at in 20 years of IT
pros: At least it is a job.
cons:
Very disorganized structure or maybe It's just vague by design.
Products are overly complex and doesn't hold up to competitors.
IBM just barly meets SLAs with customers, or doesn't meet SLA and tries to cover it up. 
No upward mobility for technicians. Several lay-offs a year. Regularly furloughs contractors. No raises and bonuses are very small and rare or non-existant. Yearly training requirements but it doesn't increase upward mobility or reward employee monetarily.

review_title: Very Good Career with Below Average Work Environment
job_title: Solutions Architect in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: There is a solid career path inside IBM; you can plan the next 5 years and you will find the necessary education and work opportunities to meet your career goal. The opportunities are always of a large scale which gives a great experience. You can learn a multitude of technologies inside IBM as well.
cons: The environment is not healthy because the company is so vertical and divided into many silos. That leaves a big room for inefficient operation as well as putting the wrong people in the wrong positions. The general atmosphere is not encouraging to creativity as it is always handicapped by a slow process. The rewards and compensation are not based on competency, and it is so hard to retain people financially

review_title: It's okay depending on your current position

Work from home.
Good career opportunities, if you play your cards right.
Excellent work life balance.
I got lucky that I could work with some really smart people, but that was just luck.
Good work if you want it.
They seemed more ethical than your average company.
Decent job security but not too much. That's a good thing. People behave well here, unlike places where too much job security means people think they can get away with anything. Bad behaviour will get you fired here.
Nice managers usually, they're usually techically sound which is important for a tech company.
cons:
Very low pay
You can't work from office in IBM even if you want to. They're indirectly geared towards pushing employees to work from home. 
Poor office infra, slow internet, no free tea/coffee plus you'll need to walk, climb stairs a lot to get some horrible tea and snacks.
You can't work as a programmer with the cheap 8gb ram  laptops they provide, you'll need to ask for a better laptop. It's a long process.

review_title: Great if you're in the right business unit
job_title: IT Security Specialist in London, England
pros: IBM Security was a great place to work, good working atmosphere and great people. Decent benefits, and manageable work/life balance. You are given lots of flexibility, as long as you get your work done. You get to work with interesting technologies, often at the leading edge of the market.
cons: Not much office community as the work is sporadic, mostly on customer site. Takes time to get promoted, and salary is not as good as competitors. There's always 'transformation' of some sort going on, which can include letting staff go. Some of the other IBM business units are difficult to work with.

review_title: put your money where your mouth is
job_title: Customer Service and Technical Support Representative in Brno
pros:
good health benefits. Possibility to access thousands of online trainings (if your position allows you free time). Chance to train and move internally as long as there is no hiring freeze. Chance of promotion if you are liked by the right people and have a little conscience. Chance to work in an international environment.
Highly structured HR department.
cons:
They are very cheap and stingy. No benefits beside healthcare. Little meritocracy in promotions. Higher ups and team leaders insist on preaching about company values but they are the first to misbehave when it suits them. During hiring freeze you are expected to divide the work of 12 people among 5 with no extra benefit to offset it.
There was so much to do we sometimes barely went to the toilet and were reprimanded when we did. Lots of broken promises.
Disorganization among different departments and lack of communication that resulted in customer dissatisfaction.

review_title: Large corporation that is all about the numbers, IBM is not your father's company
job_title: Procurement Commodity Manager in Endicott, NY
pros: free e-learning, opportunity in other career paths, flexible work schedule, 401K
cons: Lack of job security, disconnect in communications as manager and employees are scattered, hard to focus when no clear objectives defined outside of contract obligations. The raise structure, iwhich is a cost savings for IBM, and does reflect the needs of it employees, it is based on market data from all of North America. It leaves it open for them to always point to an area of the country that is doing poorly and use that as excuse to why they are unable to pay you more money.

review_title: IBM employees want union representation for fair treatment
pros: Average benefits and the ability to work in a good location that provides small town atmosphere with big city benefits of restruants, entertainment, and recreation.  The climate is moderate with an average high temp of 71 degrees, an average sunshire days of 62%, rain fall of 40 inches and only a annual 9 inch trace of snow.  The traffic is moderate and the commute is short.  Housing is reasonable in comparison to larger cities.
cons: Long hours, little personal time off, NO overtime pay.  Employees are required to replace hours for vacation and holiday time-off with additional hours worked to receive any bonus or salary increases. Management receive excessive compensation as compared to the employees they manage.  60 to 80 hour work week are not uncommon with no compensation in pay or time off. Company removes employees who even mention the word UNION.

review_title: IBM
pros:
High Performance Culture that fosters growth from junior employees.  You work with some of the smartest people around and really learn a lot about IBM and other emerging technologies.  They will give great opportunities if you show your ability to lead and are generally good at what you do.

If you enjoy travelling week to week, the allowances can almost double your income.
cons:
Low salary compared to the market at entry and senior level positions.  Management level position salary is competitive.  If you find yourself on a difficult project, work life balance goes out the window.

Not much appreciation for good work, and very little training opportunities.  You are expected to learn on the job and learn fast.

review_title: work/life balance
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Overrall IBM is a workplace where life and work are well balanced. The management is professional and friendly. The technology is new if it's not the most cutting-edge. If you're a person who thinks that life is equally or more important than work. IBM is an ideal place to work.
cons: Career growth is not obvious to everyone. Unless you're quite aggressive. It takes longer time than other hyper companies for you to advance. Plus it's lagging behind in providing competitive compensation than those new companies. As a software developer, another thing I don't like is that the company's budget control is so tight, I cannot get my laptop, my supposed major workstation upgraded in 5 years. It's already an useless junk. Now I'm using my personal computer for company's work. That's right! I'm subsidizing the company to perform my daily job.

review_title: Great company to work for
job_title: Graduate Software Engineer in Hursley, England
pros:
• Loads of benefits, great community, decent pay.
 • IBM give you a lot of responsibility, they expect you to make sure you do your work, and they won't monitor you (they treat you like adults). So if you want to work from home or take a long lunch, you'll probably be fine, as long as you pull your weight. 
 • The Hursley campus is amazing, between the parks and the stately home.
 • Developers get very nice workstations.
 • There is a lot of support available to graduates, you're encouraged to give back to the community, to learn, and to develop skills outside your main business area. This is a requirement when being considered for promotion, and you are expected to set aside work time each week for learning and giveback to the community.
cons: IBM is currently changing from a traditional company to a modern agile one, so there is still a fair amount of bureaucracy to negotiate sometimes. Like any large organisation, you have to learn how the system works.

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: In twenty years at IBM, I have worked with the best and the brightest.  The people are hard working and their blood runs blue.  My job has included travel all over the US on short and long term projects.  My immediate managers have all been remote and only had a chance to meet a few in person.  You are given the freedom to do your job.  Benefits are not bad but seem to be reduced each year
cons: Many changes at IBM and not positive ones. The 401K match was reduced to 3% match, no raises and meager annual bonus.   CEO and Board seek only to enrich themselves by laying off long time employees (older) employees and replacing with off-shore resources.  Limited availability for training and transfer. IBM now stands for India Business Machines

review_title: Where is my IBM gone!
pros:
I bid adieu to IBM (India) after a decade long career - starting as a lead developer, coming out as a senior manager. Putting the pros and cons in few keywords...
 Maturity, technology forefront, liberty, no painful hierarchy, rational (not to confuse with the product!), flexibility,  diversified work culture, interesting assignments,  scope for research, products....
cons:
Over the years IBM perhaps grown so much and perhaps become unmanageable? .  
No one cares no one is the kind of atmosphere prevailing, with not many leaders / visionaries available  who could motivate the teams and get the best out from the people.
Less said about the salaries and hikes (?) - which has resulted in huge brain drain over the years
Wont suggest to anyone serious about the career

review_title: Great co-workers, questionable leadership strategies
job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Lenexa, KS
pros: Many opportunities to learn new skills and expand your knowledge. Great benefits, great team mates.
cons: Bonuses, raises and co-location. They recently implemented the co-location policy within the marketing department, which is expected to expand to all other business units as well. This doesn't just mean that we could find an office closest to us, we were given the ultimatum to either re-locate (in my case halfway across the country, first to San Francisco and then a month later to Boston), or find another job. I think this decision was a little short sighted, and a thinly veiled attempt to reduce workforce costs by forcing those with families and loved ones close by to either resign or essentially start their lives over. All of this with no increase in salary and a bare bones moving package.

review_title: Big!
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in London, England
pros:
Sheer scale of IBM means there are amazing opportunities to be involved in huge, complex, global, multi-million GBP projects that simply don't exist in most other organisations. 

The benefits are very good and the opportunity to develop your career are endless - if you drive it yourself.

The trick to IBM is making it work for you.....if you can master that, then you can do anything in this organisation, the world is literally your oyster.
cons: Size of IBM means it's very easy to get lost. It also means there's plenty of opportunity to hide in plain sight so there's a LOT of dead wood and people hanging about but not doing much. The benefits are excellent so this leads to the 'gilded cage' syndrome with many people there only because they can't afford to leave. It's virtually impossible to be performance managed out - anyone not performing just gets moved to another role / area so their manager doesn't have to deal with them.

review_title: Lackluster
job_title: Software Test Specialist in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
1. Excellent and generous trainings. They provide many slots in training certifications. They also provide MBA scholarship, but I didn't take it because of the 2-year bond.

2.  Lenient - They want to be strict with our core-hours, but the client is output-based.  I have time to sleep after our break.  We are not required to document our time and tasks.
cons:
1.  Layoff - Since I joined last 2016, it's not uncommon for the company to fire employees who are in the bench.   Even  good, competent employees get rolled-off from projects and later on laid off. 

2.  Poor incentives.  Even if I had high ratings, I didn't receive  incentives,  and didn't get salary increase.

review_title: IBM is a good place to work, if you can find work / life balance.
pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, flexibility in hours (depending on manager) and being able to work from home.  The company has an international presence so you'll get to work with people literally all over the world.  Depending on the position, you'll have opportunities for travel.
cons: There is a lot of talk about work life balance but that's not really the culture.  While there is often some recognition for hard work/insane hours it rarely pays off financially.  Also raises and bonuses have dried up despite the company's good performance.  In most departments, many positions get back filled to places like China and India.  This makes people nervous.  Most of the products are not exactly that interesting to work on... but there are some cool things happening.

review_title: Good company to cut your teeth and then move on..
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: IBM is a good company for techies looking to learn on the job. The services organization provides the breadth and depth few service organizations can provide. IBM provides an arsenal of products that are considered the best in the business and used by most fortune 500 companies which opens up the door for advancement outside the organization. Overall it is a very good stepping stone for your career.
cons: IBM is very HR oriented when it comes to compensating employees. So if you happen to below the market reference point, you have a chance of getting a raise. Even when the company does well as in the past year, the benefits are not passed on to the employees. The raise this year was 0-2% for the IT Specialist job category which is pathetic by any standards.

review_title: Think long and hard about working here
pros: It really depends on personality type - it is a highly structured organisation and if you crave structure then it is the organisation for you.   It is great for someone at the start of a career with little or no idea of where they want to go, IBM will have a home for you , you will get training.
cons: If you want automony and dislike structured bureacracy then avoid this company.  IBM seeks to treat all employees the same regardless of career path, experience or work.  In an organisation as diverse as IBM , it fails to recongise the diversity of its people, manufacturing, sales, consultants, call centre agents , the list goes on and on.  How likely is it that the management of call centre agents is suitable for running a manufacturing line or a consultancy arm for that matter?

review_title: Came for the company, not sure if I'll stay....
job_title: Staff Software Developer in Ottawa, ON
pros: there are a lot of telented and passionate people there.overall the technical level is pretty high.a lot of information and knowledge around.
cons: not available for all the teams.if you get to be the wrong team you're just screwed.people who don't give too much about doing a good work, not thinking through.you will be amazed to see that sometime a co-op student does a better job than someone who has been in IBM for quite a while.and sometimes you're just reassigned without even being asked.and as a SW developer I would expect that my work to be recognized as such.don;t have too much time to market myself.very often it looks like only big mouthed rude arrogant people make the calls

review_title: A fantastic place to grow and learn
pros: At IBM, you have the wealth of resources available at your fingertips that only comes with working for a multinational corporation.  I had a wonderful team of coworkers and was continually being challenged with interesting projects that continually developed my skills.
cons: Like many corporations, shareholders are the top priority at IBM, explaining why thousands of employees were laid off in late 2008/early 2009, despite IBM having a record year in 2008.  I was lucky to have been spared (I left IBM to pursue grad studies), but there were many senior positions cut in the layoffs -- people that had been working for IBM for most of their careers, outed to save a few dollars.  It makes you wonder if the same could happen to you if you stayed in the company for many years.

review_title: Work Experience at IBM Canada
pros: If you are simply a task oriented individual then this is the place for you. Each job has specific tasks associated with it and you are only asked to perform those tasks specific to your job.
cons: IBM has recently revoked paying for your Internet access if you are a 'mobile' employee. They have also instituted a new policy of not paying for overtime starting February 2010 except in Manitoba presumably due to provincial legislation. Their stated number one goal is to move their labour force to lowest possible cost. This means that thousands of jobs are now going to offshore countries like Brazil, Argentina and India. You will rarely if ever be given a raise and their 'bonus' structure is such that it is almost impossible to get one. This year only staff with a 2+ or 1 rating received a bonus. You get a whopping five percent discount on share purchase plan which is adjusted semi annually and their benefit pay structure is two years out of date.

review_title: The decline of IBM in the United States
job_title: Advisory I/T Architect in Mechanicsburg, PA
pros: Working at IBM did give me the opportunity to learn a myriad of skills, including professionalism, teamwork, and programming.  I earned a nice salary for the duties I performed.
cons: Unfortunately, IBM wants you to give every ounce of yourself to your work and the company...and then pays off the United States worker by laying them off right before they reach retirement.  They preach quality, productivity, and efficiency...but will brush those qualities aside for the ability to hire 3rd world country employees at ridiculously low wages...who then must muddle through for years trying to support business and application processes.  IBM Senior Management does not seem to understand that they have destroyed loyalty, ownership, and pride in the company and it's employees by accepting big bonuses on the backs of the United States workers who built the company and  on the United States consumer and tax payer who by their products.

review_title: IBM SSR New York
pros: flelxible, easy, the training is good, day go by quickly, mobile offices, as long as you do your job well you will not be bothered, interview was easy.
cons: growth opportunity in the ssr position is practically nonexistent, rasises nonexistent, bonus nonexistent, increased vacation nonexistent, the people you work with sometimes can talk alot behind your back and can be quite rude to your face. unfair practices such as overtime and distinguising the hardworkers from the slackers. unchallenging.

review_title: It's Not Just a Job it an Adventure!
pros: IBM does an excellent job of laying out the corporate roadmap.  I understand our vision, priorities and how my role fits into the bigger picture to meet these objectives.  I have an amazing manager that trusts me and I am able to execute the best way I see fit.  Having the right manager at IBM makes a big difference! Also, must of the US based employees have the option of working from home.  That is a huge perk for me! I have the discipline to work from home.  I probably work longer house because of it but I really like the flexibility it provides.  I also work with some AMAZING people.  Like in every company there are good and bad but overall most people at IBM are top notch.
cons: IBM is a big company and continuing to grow.  It's sometimes difficult to find the right person to assist on an engagement.  Also, there are inconsistencies across brands.

review_title: Good opportunities for learning, very very poor management
pros: A lot of opportunities to acquire exp
