Very Very poor management, no benefits, very very low salary, the only motivation  this company offers is the possibility to acquire experience and run away.
This type of company remembers me of the communism regime, no appreciation for the work you provide, incompetent  people have access to higher positions. The "people managers" have no competency, no basic skills, they care only about themselves. If you have the “chance” to be promoted to a higher position with bigger responsibilities and more workload, nothing will change, still same  salary  and no real benefits beside the experience.
Completely ignorant to the real problems in the company,  all point of  view is imposed, if you want to comment will be banned, isolated and eventually you will have enough and quit.

review_title: Very disappointing, the company/environment just is not like what it used to be.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Markham, ON
pros: You will work with some of the top engineers in our industry from all over the world. It is a diverse company so there are opportunity to do many different things without having to look outside of the company.
cons: Upper management is solely focused on meeting an unrealistic stock target. Consequently, as soon as any revenue target is missed they resort to chopping senior engineers and their salary and bring in junior engineers. Unfortunately, since the senior people are gone it is difficult to train so many new people and work of the remaining senior people suffer because they have to pick up the slack as mentors or take on more duties. It is an unsustainable situation and I don't think they can make this work. Also, give the recognition to the people who have earned it not the ones who are the loudest.

review_title: Getting worse all the time
job_title: Software Engineer in Essex Junction, VT
pros: I've always been happy with how flexible the job has been.  If you need time for a doctor's appt or something, you just take the time.  No one is looking over my shoulder or tracking anything.  Working from home is an option, and also flexible.  I've also had great teams, and most of my managers have been good.  Overall it has been a positive experience.
cons:
Salary - very poor, not competitive with other companies, and getting worse as the Burlington fab has been the anchor on Ginni's plans.
Morale - yearly layoff's have taken their toll.  Nearly everyone I talk to is grumpy and pissed at IBM.  It's really made it an unhappy place to work.  I used to enjoy my job, now I'm mostly putting in my time.

review_title: Careful!
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Brookfield, CT
pros: Some flexibility with normal work hours. Could come in up to 2 hours before or after 'normal' work hours and leave later or earlier, as appropriate. Sometimes could work from home as each person gets their own laptop. Can change jobs within the company after 2-3 years, if you want to learn different areas.
cons: My experience with 99.9% of managers was that if you got the job done, and someone else didn't, they wouldn't spend the time and work with the slacker to get him/her to do his/her job. They would just add it to you to do it. You can complain, but they don't care, because they know you'll get the work done, or you have failed to be a 'team player' - they LOVE that buzz word! But why would it take 3 people to replace you each time you left a job?

review_title: Architect
job_title: SWG Technical Sales (CTP) in London, England
pros: 20% of employees are fantastic
cons: 80% of employees - or in other words most of the management are completely out of touch with employees, customers, technology, etc. Employees are just a number, work life balance is bad, no consistent strategy, no career prospects. Run by career engineers with one interest - getting promotion at any cost. Basically IBM is not a good place to be right now

review_title: Big and a bit old-fashioned, but many options
job_title: Analytics Client Architect in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
IBM covers just about everything in IT, many 'companies within companies'.
DIY attitude to career development, which suits me to an extent.
Technology is big at IBM, you can still have a fulfilling technical career at IBM (getting harder...)
I have me a lot of great people at IBM, and most are still working there eight years later.
cons:
Huge company so...
Lots of process
Slow moving, slow to change
Slave to the stock market, which is tough given how hard it is for IBM to change direction
For a company making a lot of money, they do not splash it around.  Stock market I guess.
Innovation is becoming more and more difficult due to process, but I think that affects all large organisations.
Going through a tough time at the moment, trying to work out what IBM really stands for with all these new IT companies surfacing every year/month.

review_title: Sr. IT Specialist, GBS, Enterprise Applications
pros: You will meet amazing people from all over the world.  If you love being a road warrior, this is the organization for you.  Airfare is always economy, car rentals are always Hertz, lots of hotel options are negotiated rates.  Loads of IBM-related discounts.  MacBooks are now being issued to consultants, for those who prefer Apple to Lenova.  Many, many, many well-defined business processes and supporting IT systems.
cons: Must meet billing targets to remain employed.  44 hrs/week is typical, although everyone actually puts in closer to 60 hrs/week of effort.  Seriously - you may be a rockstar in all ways measureable, but if you miss your billing utilization target, expect a negative review.  Must be willing to use Lotus Notes.  Got kids?  You might want to wait until they're in college before joining Big Blue, assuming you actually want to particpate in their childhood...

review_title: High Stress Job with no future
pros:
The work from home benefit was one of the best benefits IBM had.  Sadly that is now gone as they move to the new co-location strategy and further offshore worker strategies.
Reasonably Good Pay & Benefits
Some Great People left in the company
well recognized brand - good for the CV
cons:
High Stress
Extreme hours are expected with no compensation, or time off in lieu, overtime etc.., often for weeks or months on end
Top heavy - too many mangers with diverse opinions and directions and fewer and fewer technical staff to actually do the work
outdated technology and processes, that slow down the work rather then enable it
no real advancement options or career path.    IBM wants young workers / offshore workers they can work extreme hours and then toss.  No interest by the company in keeping talent anymore.  IBM has become another IT sweat shop that turns over at an alarming rate their people.

review_title: so so
pros: I worked in IBM India for 9 years in GBS, How you grow in IBM depends a lot on which Project business Unit you are in and how passionate you are to get what you want. In IBM you get hell lot of study material like books 24x7, training portal etc where you can learn anything. WFH is very common (some project/PM restrict it).
cons: There is a well known fact that IBM is not a good pay master, moreover starting since 2012 till 2015 (period I have seen) more than 60% employees didn't salary hikes & rest 40% might have got less than 5%. Concept of people management costing the company dear. I have seen people working in a single project doing monitoring activities with no good exposure turn delivery managers and decides others faith. Revenue is getting down continuously from past 4 years. Focusing more on Cloud, Analytics mobile etc, no investment in other areas (Service business)

review_title: Not as good as thought
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
It is a really stable company, people can last years here if they do the right thing. 
Has some good benefits, as transportation, Asociacion Solidarista, private insurance, WFH..
cons: I worked in HR, the differences in salaries are huge within employees with the same role, even my case, a partner of mine earns literally twice than me by doing exactly the same thing as me, since salaries are controlled by managers by discretion. Difficult to grow, again the growth opportunity is given by managers, based on their opinion, although you can be a good employee, you can be in the same position for years without getting the chance to grow nor getting salary adjustments. IBM itself does not spend money in motivational activities, no end year party, no birthday gifts, not even a birthday card.

review_title: Great Stepping-Stone for Graduates
pros:
-Learning opportunities are only limited by the number of hours in the day
-Great community and lots of fun social activities and opportunities to meet colleagues
-Huge opportunities to grow and take on responsibility; you will get recognition but you will not be compensated 
-Very young with lots of people from diverse educational backgrounds
-Very international; primarily Dutch but lots of English-speakers
-Flexible working hours when not on strict client project
-You can turn down a project if you don't think it's an area you want to develop in
cons:
-Below market wages
-No pension options
-Expensive healthcare options
-No company car despite sometimes lots of travel
-No overtime (only "time for time") 
-You can turn down projects, but you have to minimize your time non-billable hours otherwise it will look bad on your annual review
-To find good and interesting projects, you really have to advocate for yourself

review_title: Principles are good to have but hard to do
job_title: Procurement Professional in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: IBM is a good company with great history.  The culture of being an IBMer is great where people are willing to help you when you need it.  The size of the company allows for growth and the ability to move into different fields if that interests you.  It is also a global company that allows you to work with people from around the world and learn how to work together despite our differences.
cons: The challenge of having an amazing history is that you have to push hard to not rely on it.  Too many times this company relies on the greatness of its past to make an excuse of not taking action in the present.  The market changes and IBM must change with it.

review_title: Principles are good to have but hard to do
job_title: Procurement Professional in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: IBM is a good company with great history.  The culture of being an IBMer is great where people are willing to help you when you need it.  The size of the company allows for growth and the ability to move into different fields if that interests you.  It is also a global company that allows you to work with people from around the world and learn how to work together despite our differences.
cons: The challenge of having an amazing history is that you have to push hard to not rely on it.  Too many times this company relies on the greatness of its past to make an excuse of not taking action in the present.  The market changes and IBM must change with it.

review_title: It's a good company in terms of gaining knowledge and cognitive field is the best in IBM .
pros: Work from home is available ,Secure in terms of working in night shifts ,Gaining knowledge in every field in easy as it provides it own learning portal .Cab allowance for those who don't opt IBM cabs
cons: Salary is less, fresher's get 2.9 package and it is increased  by less digits in coming years also other benefits like meal is not provided by company ..One has to buy it .

review_title: IBM Sales
job_title: Services Client Representative in Chicago, IL
pros:
- IBM gives mobile employees incredible freedom to work from home or from an IBM office 
- IBM generally pays fairly well, but most IBMers are on a leveraged sales quota plan that can vary widely depending on sales success. 
- If you enjoy travel, IBM offers plenty of opportunity to travel.
- IBM provides employees with many options for devices: Apple products - including MacBooks, iPhones & iPads; Lenovo laptops, and B.Y.O.D. options for phone. 
- IBM places a high value on mentoring; there are opportunities to get involved with formal mentor programs and IBMers tend to be very open to "unofficial" mentoring relationships for those seeking advice/guidance in their career
cons:
- IBM is a highly sales-driven organization and pressure from the top-down has created an ultra-competitive environment that sometimes feels like "everyone for themselves." 
- Job security isn't super strong: Re-organizations and realignments are commonplace and "resource actions" (aka - down sizing) are not uncommon either.
- IBM talks a lot about "career mobility," but doesn't always "practice what they preach."

review_title: Not  Employee Friendly
pros:
1. The intranet portal has some good learning opportunities
2. Once in a blue moon you will work with a manager who really knows what you do and also has the right balance of empathy and employee respect
cons:
1.  Nepotism is inbuilt in the organization structure making every process inefficient
2. No link between skills , market value and compensation making people run 
3. The appraisal process is a sham. The manager as a role is not structured to promote employee development. The role does not assess you for your emotional intelligence at any levels.
4.Managers do not know how to sell skills and competencies to customers and neither do they train their employees to do so.
5. Cost Savings at the org level means taking away the coffee machine , means of commute like buses etc across routes ,pick up cars that would better suit scrap yards, providing substandard canteen food which reeks of corruption at all levels, and dirty toilets as a bonus.

review_title: An Ever-changing Company
job_title: Gamification Specialist in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: IBM is a HUGE company. Some of my co-workers use to say that there are 18 IBMs inside IBM, considering its size. Due to that, it is amazing to see how many different points of view are present in each team. That diversity is core to adapt, evolve and innovate, also bringing with it a high number of career opportunities. Not to mention that we deal, or know people who deal, with technologies that will be of a great impact in the future of humankind – and that is extremely motivational: to be part of the future.
cons: As IBM is a very old company, there are a few legacies that are not that good: Some people, often in management roles, with old mindsets or internal systems that run in old technology, for example. But I see these things as something already being addressed by the company in different scales: through hiring young talented professionals; investing in executive coaching and other mindset-changing activities; hiring more people to change internal process for something new and better.

review_title: Good in parts
pros: If you are prepared to play the political game, IBM can be a great place to work.  There is certainly opportunity if you are prepared to hunt it out.
cons:
Don't expect advancement purely on merit, you need to fight for it. So a brilliant employee who doesn't push or play politics will likely stay stuck in one role.
Middle management is generally very good, something seems to go wrong at strategic/executive levels. The division I am in had two rounds of "resource actions" within two months - that cannot speak to good management.
There is a tendency for new acquisitions to be treated as blue-eyed boys, but in forcing them into IBM culture they tend to lose all the qualities that made them worth acquiring until they become the red-headed stepchild.

review_title: IBM Romania
pros:
- awesome team
- flexible schedule
cons:
- is very hard to develop yourself as employee, the positions are very restricted,  each position with it's little piece of work
- the increase of the salary is really slow and hard, once in one year and half or two years is the first salary increase
- the salaries are really low compared with another companies in the same area for beginners.
- the internship is payed with minimum salary agreed by the state (around 250 euros)

review_title: Not Recommended for People who wants to Grow Technically
pros:
1. Working from home (Of Course depending on Manager decision and project type).
2. Negotiations are done.
3. Unlimited sick leaves per month.
4. Log in / Log out is not tracked.
5. Team outings/Lunch provided in each quarter.
6. Goodies provided for all festivals (TShirts , Sweets etc..)
cons:
1. GBS, they maximum try to push you to Client place after you join.
2. Hiring PSP are highly unprofessional.
3. No Cabs/Shuttles provided during 7AM-7PM.
4. If you are new to IBM GBS, you need to run behind several managers and PSP for project allocation.
5. Main campus is in Manyata Tech Park, which is considered to be far from other places.
6. Managers follow traditional managerial stuffs.
7. No Hike /Bonus.

review_title: Nice place to work
pros:
Been working in IBM for the last 13 years and here comes the Pros:
1) The best part is most of the managers are easily approachable regarding any problem and they always try to help the employee.
2) You are encouraged to speak your mind and share ideas freely.
3) Always encourage you to learn more via IBM's in-house course materials.
4) IBM has a huge repository of tools and apps and you can easily pick up one and start learning about it for free to enhance your skills.
5) Appreciates employee's effort in various channels.
6) Adapting latest tools and technologies to steer ahead in the market.
7) Flexible to Work from Home
cons:
There is no company in the world without any cons and also it depends on the employee's perspective and mindset. The few ones are:
1) Uses some old fashioned tools but the good part is IBM is discarding the old ones slowly and adapting the latest tools and apps.
2) The turn around time for some internal processes takes more time than usual.
3) Bonus payment can be better.

review_title: Very clear and professional, but with unexciting products...
job_title: Staff Software Developer (Testing) in Ottawa, ON
pros: Expectations are very clear and information about how the company is doing overall are always communicated by senior management on a regular basis.  Compensation always seems very fair and you generally know exactly why the decisions regarding your compensation have been made.
cons:
Many of the software products developed by IBM are less than exciting.  There are very few products that are truly cutting edge.  For someone who wants to be working with the latest technologies I would recommend making sure that you will be working in an area that holds interest for you.

In addition, different parts of the company tend to be very insulated.  Moving from one area to another can be difficult mostly just because you don't really know what's happening in other teams (management has no problem with people moving around).

review_title: Awesome company, awfully managed
pros: flexible work hours, mega accounts, great experience, totally process driven, employee friendly policies,great cross cultural experience, great brand value
cons: biased people managers, sycophancy and not hardwork wins promotions and good grades.  there is an expectancy that an employee will spend money from his / her own pocket to do IBM business.  no recognition of talent.

review_title: Tolerable if you can take the Cool Aid
pros: Tremendous opportunities for learning and personal advancement, but you have to take total ownership of your career. There is no management guidance. Managers are simply there to manage "resources" - and that means "you".
cons: Deep and unyielding bureaucracy. Takes a long time to understand and get to grips with the IBM Way. The company is divided into five major divisions who appear unwilling to communicate and create common goals for the most part. The ability to work across business lines is an art and a skill understood by only a few. Significant politicking is required to keep your job from being outsourced. Layoffs are an annual event. IBM has become a business dictated by the bottom line. There is little to no investment in people development, despite much lip service to the contrary. Human resources are just another commodity to be replaced by the cheapest alternative, most often from non-US sources.

review_title: Services unit (GBS) is just a body shop
pros: Brand recognition is good. State of the art technology company. Broad range of technologies and opportunities to use them. High business ethics.
cons:
Little respect for employees. Written direction that if you take your vacation, you should work extra to make up for it. Documented minimum acceptable work week is 45 hours. Education opportunities are rare, and usually only offered after hours or weekends. Business is managed on an individual utilization model that motivates employees to charge more hours, not to do a better more efficient job for our services customers. Employee year end evaluations are first measured on who has billed the most hours.

Little opportunity for internal innovation. IBM just buys innovation in the form of acquisitions.

Way too much bureaucracy. Every business opportunity has 6-10 people in charge, client executives, delivery executives, business development executives, practice area executives, sector  executives, geography executives, and the list goes on.

review_title: Good front line management, movement within company dependent on contacts (not knowledge), being overworked is the norm
job_title: Security Compliance Administrator in Edmonton, AB
pros: Great team members with excellent experience and knowledge to draw from, good benefits and decent pay in comparison to other companies out there, large spread of jobs internal to the company, good support for other learning (internal training, conferences, external training for courses).
cons: You will be overworked and overtasked, with nobody to give you a hand unless you're very lucky. The company has a habit of undersizing bids for support contracts, and then will expect a single FTE to complete all the neccesary . Enjoy that (mandatory) unpaid overtime. Jobs for hands on IT support positions (ie. system/security admins) moving to Global Resources - meaning, other IT Support teams internal to IBM in other countries where workers make less (e.g. Brazil, Hungary, India).

review_title: Treated well for a long time, but sadly watching a long decay as we abandon the values that made us successful.
job_title: Advisory Engineer in Essex Junction, VT
pros: The legacy company culture from the founding Watson family still lingers, resulting in a typically congenial working atmosphere.  The sheer size of the company means you have access to resources unthinkable in smaller companies.  There are so many careers in IBM, you could switch once a year and never even scratch the surface.
cons: Read Dilbert, and know the absurdity of a large, often contradictory hierarchical organization.  Our new CEO and senior leadership have grossly mismanaged our hardware business into a hole from which it will most likely not recover.  IBM is trying, as much as possible, to offshore jobs to cheaper countries.  We have now become a bellwether for employee benefit takeaways.

review_title: Opportunity for big growth in the people business, but restricted to over specialised work and a segmented business
pros:
- Best practise leaders in behavioural assessment
- Opportunity for high profile project responsibilities
- Learning specialist skills and sharing work knowledge
cons:
- Culture is heavily biased to academic background and work styles; hard if your profile does not fit
- Terrible quality of provided equipment, very poor IT applications and poor IT help and support (ironically!)
- Faked people approach as a stated busienss value; all fluff and gimmicks, no real care
- Poor level of management capability and employee support
- Too much time wasted through heavily bureaucratic working processes

review_title: Various Management Roles
pros: IBM is a large company with teams working in all industries. Through IBM I got the chance to work in a variety of roles and industry. This experience has been invaluable.
cons: IBM is a very very big company and in my believe too big. Based on decision that are often made thousand of miles away by management that are not even aware you exist key aspects of you employment are decided. Everything from weather you get a pay increase in a given year to who holds the key to the stationary cupboard is influenced by the business performance in countries. That amount of times I heard " sorry but the UK didn't perform last year" would be laughable if it didn't have such a big impact on my ability to do my job.

review_title: Networking is key
pros: Being exposed to one of the oldest technological companies allows you to gain important connections in the business world. This means that within a year you can easily progress to more substantial roles. You are also exposed to multiple environments which gives you additional skills that will help bolster your knowledge.
cons:
Unless you become closely connected to your management do not expect to get money handed to you. You absolutely need to communicate via phone/ text any accomplishments. This does mean that you may pay for certificates out of pocket. This is what sets you apart from others in the company, and allows you to negotiate a higher salary.

*Work/ life can be subjective to the project you are on.

review_title: Big, Slow and Wasting Talent
pros:
> Some exciting projects.
> Surrounded by very competent people.
> Balance between work and life is pretty good.
cons:
> Despite the company having very capable employees, IBM neglects, underpays and stops them from being creative and doing great work. It is probably why they have such a hard time retaining their talented employees. I've noticed the majority of them go towards or are looking at Accenture/Deloitte after a few years in the company.
> Very slow procedures, takes ages to get anything done.
> Education and Training is seen as an expensive.
> Strange politics within the company, which stops you from being innovative and creative. Makes it very hard to get . recognized for your work.
> Internal software known as 'Lotus Notes' and 'Connections' is absolutely terrible. Makes working more difficult.

review_title: Trying to cling on to positive memories..........but.............
pros: Some residual prestige associated with the name. I honestly thought I could find more to say than this, but I can't.
cons:
*Poor executive management, largely there to maximise personal gain before leaving. Most do not believe 'the strategy' will work and don't care.
*Cowardly managment chain, not prepared to challenge obvious stupidity or without the stomache/dedication for a fight. Many are just trying to get in as many paydays as they can and have also lost belief.
*Hard-nosed, naval gazing HR who churn out unpopular and irrelevant -initiatives, hence consuming even more of the precious time which employees no longer have..
*Pervasive self preservation rather than team co-operation to serve the customer.
*Tick sheet/ call centre/low cost centre mentality, even where totally inappropriate, leading to 'hidden' extra costs to solve problems
*Broken and massively discredited performance appraisal system, now almost completely hijacked for other purposes..
Professional judgement, constructive challenge and considered 'risk taking'  suppressed.

review_title: Huge opportunities, large company with lots of room to grow.
job_title: Senior Support Technician in Edmonton, AB
pros: Good management.  Reasonable pay, and room for advancement.  Great benefits.  I would recommend working here if you want the chance to find your IT specialty and have the opportunity to move.
cons: You can get stuck in one position and find it very hard to move out, you need to do a lot of work outside of work to advance your career, off time learning and taking courses to branch into a new field.  You need to play office politics, the better you schmooze the faster you move up.

review_title: I was the first college hire on my logic design team in 10 years.
job_title: Logic Designer for Power Systems Servers in Austin, TX
pros: Friendly people, interesting work, good benefits, networking opportunities. Morale improving. So is culture and experience with training new hires.
cons: Organization restructuring and poor business performance leading to layoffs and poor morale, causing people to quit, made people around me too overwhelmed to help me get me onboarded. It had been so long since they'd last had a fresh college hire that they didn't know how to train me, which made some things tedious and some things stressful. Talking to my manager didn't help, though the same business problems that created the problem in the first place might have tied his hands on several of the issues I tried to address with him.

review_title: Constant employee layoffs hurt the company
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Somers, NY
pros: There are many smart people and most are wonderful co-workers.  There can be a wide variety of opportunity, but it is harder to move around than it was in the past.  Benefits are decent. Working from home is open to many and it is great for balancing work and life.
cons: Constant layoffs, called "resource actions" hurt the company performance and kill morale.  There is no opportunity for mature employees to move to another assignment, once they have been tagged in a resource action.  Older workers are not wanted.  The performance review system is a total lying farce.  Employees do not get an honest evaluation of their performance. Workloads can be very heavy requiring  much overtime  for extended time periods.  Pay raises, at least for older workers, are almost non existent.  US workers are being replaced by foreigners working here on H1B visas.

review_title: Great if you have the right attitude
pros:
The people are IBMs biggest asset. I have worked with some great people in a lot of different teams over the last few years. There is always a focus on networking and we are pushed to expend our netwrks inside and outside IBM. This has opened up career opportunities to me that wouldn't be there if I hadn't made the effort. 
There is always plenty of room to grow your career and due to IBMs size, there is a huge range of roles you can work towards.
cons: Constant pressure on offshoring and redundancies is threatening to ruin the companies staff morale. Once we get on with the work the job can be fun, but what was once a huge IT company is now seeming run by accountants.

review_title: SWG/Cloud
job_title: Solutions Architect in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Given the breadth of offerings and activities. I was able to jump to interesting new projects & roles every 3-4 years.  Stayed 15 years past my distaste for the character of the company because of some of the things I got to do and try.

Saw the world, met some lifetime friends.
cons:
"They are who we thought they were"
Mega-corporate.  Process for everything.  (Way too many) Good, smart people building smart roadblocks to getting things done, in the name of auditing, control, project management "expertise".
Desperate need for SW solutions (&everything else) to satisfy every industry & perspective, which made solutions (&everything else) bloated, unfocused
At macro level, so much marketing vapor, but too little useful reality behind the fog.
Flexibility for job-hopping has decreased over time. 
Strong anti-employee moves from HR last 2 years, including vesting changes for 401k, reduction of severance.  Financial engineering bleeding through at every level.

review_title: They just don't care anymore....
job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Dallas, TX
pros:
Huge company, so a ton of positions and various jobs/responsibilities
Lots of training material, but it's all Web-based (they cut actual classroom, onsite education years ago.)
Lot's of good, smart people to work around and learn from.
Name still carries some clout, but not like it did in the past.
cons:
They no longer care about their most valuable assets - people.
Leadership only concerned with stock price.
When I was laid off (2016), I had 20 yrs with them and got ONE MONTH severance.
They are shooting for 75% support staff to come from overseas.
Slow to move and keep up with more agile competitors.
Benefits keep getting cut and are worse now than 5 or 10 yrs ago.

review_title: Good place to start your career
pros:
* Informal hierarchy. You can talk easily with your manager or other senior staff and be transparent and honest.
* Good technical support from the team and the manager.
* Supportive and friendly atmosphere.
* Good integration and socialising events.
* Possibility of working from home on single days on request.
cons:
* To much procedures, which makes work time consuming even when you want to implement a simple change.
* Too tight specialisations, where you are not exposed for the wider technology areas. This makes it harder to see a bigger picture and understand IT infrastructure as a complete system, especially when you just start your career.
* Sometimes overloaded with tasks, as for example the day before your holiday when you need too handover your tickets to other people. Moreover the same tickets get back to you after the holiday.
* Not competitive salaries and no pay raises.

review_title: IBM has its goods and bads.
pros: Excellent opportunities to work with highly skilled proffesionals.
cons: Bureaucracy of moving up the ladder is very challenging unless you have the right contacts or you devote many extra hours of your already expected overtime hours on an engagement.  Too many hours have to be put into the company to make yearly goals and this does not equate to work life balance.

review_title: IBM is a good place to work as a co-op.
pros: I am currently at IBM STG co-op.  IBM has given me the opportunities to explore the possibilities available to me at IBM.  I work with very knowledge people and the work environment is very dynamic and supportive.  I am comfortable, and I learn a lot about subjects that one cannot learn in school--which is the most valuable type of experience needed.  I am given responsibilities that affect the company going forward, and IBM empowers me to do my best by giving me all the tools I need to succeed.
cons: The only downside is that if IBM does offer me a position it will not be outside my co-op area.  I wish I would apply for other positions else where in the company internally.  The only downside so far.

review_title: Cut Management salaries and bonuses & keep jobs in the America
pros: Career Opportunities Globally. Communication is everywhere. The W3 website, IBM's intranet, it loaded with tons of information. They have sources to educate and provide you with information on work/life balance. There are many employees with 15, 20, 25 or more years of service with IBM.
cons: The management at the top has no clue who get's the work done. They talk of globalization, its just another word for "send the US jobs off-shore". Your treated as hired meat with meager benefits. They put tools in place to track every little thing you, You spend time each week tracking your work hours, over-time, down to the actual tasks you do. Staring in January 2009, they will have tools in place to compare the time on tasks with the time spent by IBMer's in India and Brazil as a way to justify moving the jobs to those countries. Morale in America sucks right now.

review_title: I was laid off after being reviewed as a top performer and told 'we need more people like you at IBM'
pros: flexible working conditions, ability to work from a home office, opportunity for advancement if you network internally and are persistent.
cons: IBM'ers must keep an updated resume in your top drawer at all times; there is no job security even for top performers.  You have to constantly promote yourself to management and remind them of your achievements or they will go unnoticed and unrewarded.   If your job requires you to be on Call 24x7, you will have no personal life and will experience burnout, as you are expected to be available at any time, even while on vacation, with no additional compensation.  Expect new college hires to be making more than you do even after 10 or 20 years with the company, at the same job position.

review_title: Benefits, good.  Job security, bad.
pros:
+ Benefits are very comprehensive.
+ Salary isn't great, but reasonable for the industry.
+ The employees work together as a team, even across organizations.
cons:
- Totally random layoffs - it's like thinning the herd - you never know who is going to be next.  
- Getting the top appraisal means you've worked the most billable hours, not that your work was the best.
- I'm seeing a recent trend where offshore employees are hired based on who is cheapest at the current moment.  With the fluctuation of the dollar we're looking at Brazil one week, Phillipines the next, Cairo the week after.  The offshore employees miss out on a lot of the benefits of working on a team.

review_title: GBS: Great place for exposure and very strong team members
pros: Exposure to many areas, people, and various types of work; Travel to various locations around the US; Ability to become a strong team contributor; Stellar co-workers with great know how and/or determination; Huge network to find support and help; Great benefits; Very stable and secure feeling;
cons: Extremely large company - hard to not just be a number; Lack of personal touch/feel; 100% travel; Difficult to obtain promotions and raises; Bonuses are very minimal; No true feeling of team/family/belonging; Constantly being put in situations where you are the "expert" but know very little;

review_title: Leadership needs a reboot
pros: Flexible work schedules. Opportunity to change positions every 2-3 years if you speak up. Interesting products. Going through a transformation, which can be interesting to be a part of.
cons: Very siloed with product lines not working well together on joint development; senior leadership is too in-bred (to lead the cloud initiative, Ginni passed over the CEO of Softlayer, who actually knew about cloud, and put a long-time IBMer in charge who had no experience with cloud); way too process oriented, not nimble like most younger tech companies; don't use some of their own best tools very widely, and conversely use too many of their own worst tools, so the business cannot be managed effectively;

review_title: Good for learning. Horrible for being recognized
job_title: Project Manager in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
- Amazing Team Work
- Excellent libraries of processes, methods, procedures, etc.
- Chance to change job inside the same company
- Good benefits
- Very high flexibility
cons:
- HORRIBLE salaries, unless you are in sales or came from the market with a good proposal
- Managers in Brazil take preference on employees who work close with them and promote them based on friendship other than achievements
- You need to be a hero to achieve the best level of performance - yearly goals are subjective and comparison between employees is not fair
- LOTS of processes, policies you need to follow, blocking you from doing project in an agile manner

review_title: Look around , the world is changing so fast
job_title: Senior Soft in San Jose, CA
pros:
Lot of big empty offices.
Getting to work with great people who revolutionised computer science 
Many people end up getting paid for noting.
cons: Its like hug aircraft carrier almost out of supplies , sailing to somewhere it thinks is land. Captain is making decisions based on the gauges and dials which are broken and only really smart engineers know what needs to be fixed. But they are never being asked so they are taking out the lifeboats and leaving the ship.

review_title: Rolling monthly redundancies are a danger to clients
pros: Colleagues. IBM attracted many people who are keen to work together and build effective products, real solutions. Great idea sharing and good execution before the rafts of redundancies began about three years ago.
cons:
These days the company is eliminating people who know how products work, who bridge legacy to new solutions. That's why the ABS Census failed - the knowledgeable and experienced people were gone. Four reorganisations in my last year ... company says it's re-adjusting its workforce, but it doesn't seem to be in any particular direction.
Sane senior managers complained to HQ, saying the cuts were deeper than necessary, would hurt the business. Those comments fell on deaf ears. ABS Census failure was predictable and avoidable. 
Neither a stimulating nor fun place to work - the only challenge is keeping your own chair warm.

review_title: Not a place to work
pros: With in IBM - GBS is a good place to work as you don't really interact much with IBM or Management as you work for a Client.
cons:
A lot of them on a high level
- Poor Benefits esp. 401k worst I have seen
- Politics in Management 
   I'm a victim of racism , I had been rated 2+(over achiever)  every year and successfully delivered projects on time but still put me on RA. And reason for RA is cost cut but my Peer who has not performed well and hasn't delivered project was not effected at all as she was White. I was asked to pass on my successful projects to her. 

I took the package which they offered as part of RA as I have seen enough. And the Best part they haven't settled my RA amount yet it's been over 2 months and HR keeps saying check is on the way...lol. I guess they ran out of money..lol

review_title: Network Support Specialist, Cisco
job_title: Network Support Specialist in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros:
Worked for 3 years in the Cisco department.

Good remuneration package considering the countries standards. Perfect job for students who are willing to work full time after their daily university classes. Separate teams for each technology which one could change and get most out of the knowledge base and gain hands-on experience with the Cisco networking equipment. Access to loads of learning materials and sources. Colleagues were willing to assist whenever and wherever they could and we had fun working together. I think it is the ideal place to kick off your journey in the networking world.
cons:
The current shifts covered in the Cisco department are mostly during the night hours (up to 4 in the morning for the late one). 
After a while, if you prefer staying in the same team, the job can get repetitive. 
It can get quite noisy at times as its an open space office. 
You will have to work on most of the official Bulgarian holidays.

review_title: He embodies the characteristics I want in a CEO: strong ethics, integrity, and focus to win.
job_title: Certified I/T Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: work life balance is excellent.  I can take time off whenever I need and get good recognition.  It has very entrepreneurial spirit so I can make solutions and am very free to pursue activities I think will help generate the most revenue.  Management in my case is very hands off and allows me to do what I want.
cons: lack of support from senior management to do my job.  No access to hardware resources.  I'm always scrounging to get resources to do my job.  There is no good direction, but this can be a good thing because I'm free to make my own decisions.

review_title: He embodies the characteristics I want in a CEO: strong ethics, integrity, and focus to win.
job_title: Certified I/T Specialist in Portland, OR

It has very entrepreneurial spirit so I can make solutions and am very free to pursue activities I think will help generate the most revenue.  Management in my case is very hands off and allows me to do what I want.
