review_title: Big, slow and complex. A place to hide or a place to gain experience for your resume
pros:
A recognizable name and fair to decent benefits are a plus for IBM. There are good, intelligent people to find as mentors at a company of this size.

Nevetheless, It's very easy to fall through the cracks here and coast along with little notice from management.

A good first job for those fresh out of school looking for a big name to boost their resume.
cons:
Constant threat of layoffs. IBM is moving many of their jobs offshore with little regard to their US based workforce. 

Red tape, complicated internal processes and little focus on the welfare of the employee make IBM a living example of a Dilbert cartoon. Often times, the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.

review_title: Good turn the crank company
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros:
Excellent compensation. Very predictable environment. Very standardized ways of doing things. Good company to go on cruise control while dealing with life.

If you do not want a challenging job, this is a good place. I find it very easy to get my assignments done, but very difficult to get new opportunities that have not been fully planned out by management. 

On the upside, the company is very predictable. No wildly annoying personalities. They won't last. A fair number of very serious, do it by the numbers people. IBM invented the box, so there is no sense thinking outside of it.
cons: Very little room for creativity. Every idea has to go through 10-15 meetings and 20+ people for approval. Very difficult to stay passionate about a job/idea when there are so many 'processes' to go through. It probably makes for more stable products, but completely kills innovation.

review_title: It is OK but not the great place it used to be.
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Working in IBM development you have access to the latest technical advancements.  It is not difficult to find an area of interest within the product development and the current environment of "do more with less and more quickly" does allow engineers to expand their horizons by taking on responsibilities in areas they have not previously had an opportunity to explore.
cons: Schedules and product requirements are constantly changing and by the time they figure out what they want, the engineers are forced to scramble in order to make extremely aggressive deadlines.  Layoffs and reorgs have left most teams with less resource than they need to do their jobs.  The rating system is demotivating since people who work very hard are likely to get the same rating as those doing little work.

review_title: A Grind
pros: Low stress environment if you are willing to go with the flow, average pay and compensation, good mobility options. Not a bad choice for moms.
cons: Slow, glacial growth within the company unless you work in sales. If you work in sales, cutthroat environment. IBM is now an overpriced giant, prepare for the crash.

review_title: Not your father's IBM
pros:
Employees with a passion for IT technology.
Processes and procedures for all aspects of the business keep operations running fairly smoothly.
cons:
Bully culture in executive ranks (at least in the US).
The company has been driving up the stock price by cutting expenses, especially salaries and benefits - hence the many rounds of cuts and early retirements which have decimated the ranks of experienced professionals in IBM.  The brain drain has accelerated with the voluntary departure of top talent.
Extremely risk adverse management forcing a unhealthy and unsustainable reliance on innovation through acquisitions.  (IBM Research still excels at invention, but their output typically must go outside of IBM to be nurtured to the innovation stage (by engineers and entrepreneurs) before being brought into the IBM product portfolio through company acquisition.

review_title: IBM should get of the GDF model!
pros: The benefits are amazing with 4-5 weeks of vacation time, 6 weeks of full paid sick leave and endless discounts from cell phone to car companies.
cons:
The amount of favoritism at Dubuque IBM is uncalled for. I see this daily as a team lead and management does not care for any employee besides themselves. All managers get a PBC rating of 1 no matter how poorly they do and get to downgrade each employee on the team to get a big bonus. I saw this the past few years and management looks the other way. It is sad to see this center has the worst turnover rate than any others.

The average salary amount is $32,000. We advertise our jobs at $45,000 to $50,000 and rarely offer that rate.

IBM used to be the place to work 10 years ago but with all the cuts in the past few years, I would advise not to work here.

review_title: So much history, so much potential, but so much drag
pros: If you ever do a quick review of IBM's history, you will find an organization that invented or improved a multitude of industries and aspects of modern life.  The original founder, and his son, seemed invested in creating a business that was a positive force in society and which took pride in advancing the lives of employees and their families.
cons: Today's IBM manages and incents plenty of unintentional and bad behaviors.  Managers are driven to protect and champion their own employees regardless of relative value.  Top line revenue numbers and short term profitability have overtaken innovation, customer loyalty, and employee growth as prime motivators in the company.  Employment at IBM can feel very frustrating from both a personal and technical perspective.

review_title: Sometimes who you know more important than what you know
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Jackson, MS
pros: Plenty of continuing education opportunities available direct from company.    Real good opportunity from someone starting out their career fresh out of college.   Work/Life balance entirely dependent on job role and group within company, but especially in client-facing roles, very generous.
cons: Fortunes of whole teams and groups impacted by the ups/downs of executive management politics.    Senior level non-executive professionals at constant risk of cost cutting and offshoring without strong executive patron.    Quality of health care related benefits have continuously declined although employee portion of premium has stayed reasonable.

review_title: IBM Summer Internship
job_title: Software Engineer Internship in Austin, TX
pros: The employees at IBM are very passionate about the projects they are working on. The projects are often on the front-line of innovation and exciting. With great people, good benefits, exciting projects, and a dedication to learn more and more each day, the internships here are remarkable.
cons: There is a huge learning curve when you first start, where you'll have to be able to quickly adapt and learn new languages, platforms, extensions, tools, etc. in order to continuously be efficient with your time. Although the above wasn't really much of a con, just a good challenge/motivator, the floors here in Austin need to be renovated a little bit... Its kind of like being in the twilight zone with all the hallways and enclosed rooms.

review_title: Good name to work for... but that's it.
job_title: Software Support Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Growth potential.  I say potential because it is difficult to get your manager to approve of you looking at other positions.  Work from home office, no travel, and no need to commute every day.
cons: Work/life balance is hit or miss.  Sometimes its okay to bring your kids to the doctor and sometimes its frowned upon.  Imbalance between employee/manager relations.  Absolutely no training opportunities.  Common phrase is "learn on your own".  Management is inconsistent and daily tasks that should remain constant are always changing.

review_title: Started out Great in 2010 and downhill from there....
pros: My manager was excellent. My department worked 8-5 M-F only. Benefits were above average and good time off. Dubuque is a small town so you won't have to drive in traffic jams and many of us walked to work. Yes it's Mayberry USA.
cons:
Very unfriendly people. Awkward silences in elevator every day. This center ran data like an assembly line of cars. Many employees left with not enough skills to get a job since IBM pigeon-holes employees into doing one job. Transfers were almost impossible. Raises were slim. Budgets were cut each year from 2010-2014. Layoffs left my dept. from 25 down to 10. Dubuque IA is a boring town. Iowa has 7 months of cold and many many months of grey skies only. This center is down to 200-300 I hear. IBM shafted Dubuque and Columbia MO. Most of these jobs have gone to India now.
IBM is out to protect its share holders. Doesn't care about it's employees.

review_title: Former Client Representative
pros:
-flexible start/end time
-great medical/dental benefits
cons:
-layoffs every quarter; morale is going down because of it
-stressful with high quarterly quotas

review_title: Great people, flawed strategy
job_title: Account Executive in New York, NY
pros: Really smart people you can be proud to work with, comprehensive solutions in many areas, high name recognition, global capabilities, decent health & 401k benefits. Company is pivoting to a sensible cloud/mobile/analytics/social strategy.
cons: Strategy is sensible but late, and IBM  is several years late to market with most offerings.  In the meantime, the older products that produce most revenue are being sold off or starved out.  16 down revenue quarters in a row, and billions have gone into stock buy-backs instead of R&D.  Whittling away benefits (e.g. as of 2014 the 401k contributions are paid at end of year instead of monthly).   Good people are distracted by constant reorgs, layoffs and comp plan changes.

review_title: Software Client Leader
pros: IBM (if in the right role) still is one of the most innovative technology companies.  IBM Research, Software Group, Watson, etc. have a lot of value to offer enterprise clients and the world.  If you are smart, have very good interpersonal skills and you are ambitious, IBM can offer you a very good career path.  The cumulative IQ and ethical culture are very high.
cons: Some parts of the company have become dinosaurs (hardware and Global Services) and it shows in their management style, workforce, perception with clients and focus (lack) within IBM's portfolio of priorities.  It is a big company....you have to trudge through a large number of unmotivated co-workers to find the good ones and the company is often mired in process.

review_title: Avoid internal roles if possible
job_title: Business Information Executive in London, England
pros:
Benefits were good. I found that having half a dozen different disinterested people to report top meant I had a high degree of freedom in what I did.
If you are in a client facing roles there are a lot of opportunities, if you are internal you are doomed as you will only be seen as a cost.
cons:
Completely numbers driven organisation which is reflected at every level. 
I found it impossible to move from an internal to a client facing role - internal non-fee earning roles have the lowest status. I never had any meaningful discussion about my future with any of my many managers. I had almost no training in 7 years there.
I found a general pervasive state of depression among IBMers - this of course may not be true everywhere but it was my experience. This was likely influenced by having an internal role and   by seeing many internal roles offshored to cheaper locations

review_title: Relatively poor choice for young professionals - Poughkeepsie
pros:
- The elder people you work with have a tremendous amount of knowledge and experience you can learn from
- Work hours are flexible as long as you do what is expected of you
cons:
- Poughkeepsie, NY is one of the least attractive places to work. The town offers nothing for young people. The consensus among new hires is to work for 2-3 years and then go work somewhere else, away from Poughkeepsie.
- Salary is sub-par, bonus' are poor, and raises are not definite. Sadly, there is no monetary incentive to stay; pay is much better elsewhere.
- Working from home has been banned. You must come into the office now, or you'll get the boot.
- Generally, cost-saving initiatives are at the expense of the employee reflected in their 401K's, benefits, compensation, and flexibility.

review_title: Parental Leave Program Changes!
pros:
I'm a new father and took advantage of the existing Parental Leave program that was available to us in the US. With the old program, it was 6 weeks of paid leave. With the new program, IBM dads and moms are now entitled to 12 weeks of paid leave. This program doesn't utilize your vacation days. So if you have vacation days, those days are still entitled to you. This is the primary reason I'm spending some time on writing this review.

Employee discounts. I honestly didn't know this existed till I started navigated the maze of wiki sites we have (see Con below). It was pretty nice that we had access to discounts from electronics to things like Disney park.
cons:
* Bonuses and raises are slim to none.
* Team members are also concerned about losing the ability to work from home.
* A lot of systems to navigate and old systems that are still in use that need to be replaced
* 401k matching isn't done till the last paycheck of the year

review_title: My experience at IBM was one of constant change.
job_title: Senior Consultant in Lake Mary, FL
pros: Learning possibilities are endless, internal networking was phenomenal, and accessibility to anyone at any level was unlike any other organization I had worked for previously.
cons: A constant , nervous feeling that there was no ground beneath your feet due to the constant disruptions, transformations, and restructuring. The move from a being a largely telecommuting company back to bricks and mortar is one such painful example where lives were disrupted. I wasn't around for it, but I lived through other disruptions.  The move back to offices must have been horrific for many. While at IBM, many were prepping for the eventual day that they that they are told you are being 'resourced' - that's IBMese for you're laid off. How does one stay productive and focused in such an environment?

review_title: Good amount of responsibility; difficult to move around projects
pros: I was based entirely in Washington, DC, so never traveled. This review is not for public sector consulting, which seems pretty different from private sector. I was given a good amount of responsibility pretty early in my career. Managers were always very supportive of me and were reasonable about deadlines. Since it's a large company, there were regular discussions about my career trajectory and options for growth within the company. Benefits were excellent, with many low fee index funds offered in the 401k. There were lots of happy hours and networking opportunities. I never worked more than 40-45 hours per week.
cons: I was in the Public Sector Consulting division, and it was basically impossible to move form one project to another. It didn't really feel like "consulting", more like you were IT support for government agencies for certain types of business software. Most of the projects were very long term.

review_title: IBM Global Services is the worst part of IBM to work for.
pros: When you first join IGS, usually through an 'outsourcing deal', expectations of career advancement run very high. However, as time goes on, these hopes are slowly and methodically squashed. One day you wake up and realize you work for "little blue" and thus considered an unwanted stepchild of the real "Big Blue" IBM, which I hear is a nice place to work.
cons:
Raises, most often below the rate of inflation, are few and far between. Benefits, like most everywhere else, are dwindiling. The company can no longer afford a decent benefit package because of the poor management decisions made in the past.

Starting out as a person that very much enjoyed technical activities, I now create superflouous paperwork and engage in meaningless tasks that appear to be adding value in the eyes of my customer. CYA is the name of the game. If IBM looks good, then all is well, right?

review_title: Corporate Executive greed is only looking for aquisitions to improve shareholders portfolios.
pros: IBM is a good place to get your foot in the door and once you realize they are trying to stick you where the sun doesn't shine then come to terms and leave the joint.
cons:
In the division that I worked in downtown Tulsa, Business Consulting Services, management was extremely unoraganized, training was unheard of, and anyone you needed to contact for help was located in India and didn't know how to speak good English. 
Everything is micro-managed right down to the time you sit at your desk to the time you go on break.  The yearly bonus was a joke and so was the pen & pencil set I received during the Christmas holiday.  All of my overtime and extra effort put forth in many projects went unrecognized.

review_title: Lack of recognition and promotion for the employees that keep the stock price up
pros: Work at home options and job flexibility
cons: Not all organizations within IBM are required to treat employees the same.  There are standard HR policies and guidelines in place, none of which are used by my organization.  If you're not working 60 hours a week, you're not working enough.  People leaving the company don't get replaced, the work gets dumped onto someone else and the pay doesn't increase.  Raises for the workers making it happen are non existent, but good ol' CEO and VP's get multi-million dollar bonuses.  Morale is non existent, and if you go to your manager about job dissatisifaction or needing more compensation, you are told you should feel happy and 'priveledged' to be working for IBM.  Then, you'll get laid off anyway as all work is shifting to the global workforce.

review_title: Great place to be from.
job_title: Research Staff Member in San Jose, CA
pros: Frequently a leader in technology development, though one's exposure and participation in that effort depends upon which part of the company you work for.  Most of the management is "sane", the real wackos are filtered out (usually).  The company has been around so long that they've seen everything and don't often panic when situations (of all kinds) occur.
cons: So large that the goals of different parts of the company often conflict.  Benefits, vacation, pension, stock purchase plan, medical, etc. have all been squeezed in recent years so the fringe benefits of working for IBM are not so great.  They're also working hard to transfer jobs out of the USA to China and India, this makes one's future with the company in the USA less stable.  The level of expertise of the technical talent can vary widely, many parts of the company are not attractive to really talented people who can get jobs elsewhere.

review_title: Great place to grow professionally, but not financially
pros: There is practically an unlimited amount of trianing opportunity here.  The ability to switch groups / careers is also a definite plus.  The IBM name carries with it quite a bit of prestige.  Ability to innovate and be creative is superb here.
cons: Getting a promotion beyond a certain point requires an extreme amount of documentation and can take much longer than needed if you hapeen to accomplish goals outside of their career framework timeframe.  This is a profit center, and management is not timid about expressing this.  They lay off folks pretty much every quarter, but also do quite a bit of hiring.  Stock price is the largest driver in this company.  Innovation is a distant second.

review_title: Great place to learn about cost cutting. Bad place to grow a career.
pros:
Work from home if legacy employee
Good healthcare
cons:
Your salary today will be your salary 5 years from now. Raises are about 1% a year. Bonus about 3%.
Management has no interest in growing or advancing your career. They believe  any off-shore or Dubuque person can do your job. Doesn't matter if it takes 3 of them to do it, as long as it is for less money.
Management's priority is cutting costs at the lower and midlevel and maximizing profit for those at the top levels. As an employee you are only a means to their end.

review_title: Cares more about profit than truly engaging employees
pros: Lots of different opportunities within IBM.  Great place to start a career with so many options and opportunities to get involved in various aspects of selling or delivering new business.
cons: Huge company and easy to get lost within the Bureaucracy  Often work work for managers with poor people skills.  IBM pays at best in the middle of the road.  Don't expect annual raises nor any significant profit sharing (1-2.5% of annual salary) typically. Hardly a motivation to work extra hours to get the job done.  Depending on which brand you work for, utilization targets are mid-high 80's to high 90's percentage...this includes vacation, statutory holidays and training days, so extra hours are a requirement to meet the annual utilization targets set by the company.

review_title: Too many middle managers
pros: Good products and strong professionals.  IBM culture drives pride in being an IBMer.  Easy to find help in meeting tasks.
cons: Matrix management has too many managers which leads to micromanagement of every decision.  IBM is a 100 year old company and many processes are slow and involve too many people.  Admin folks follow age old processes explicitly and not empowered to make exceptions to changing needs.  This bogs the organization down in detail as managers take excessive time trying to approve simple decisons as they work their way through excessive matrixed managment.  In summary, there are too many people matrixed into normal decision processes so not even simple decision can be made in a timely manner.  Even worst, no one seems empowered to step up and stop rediculous over management of what should be simple decisions.

review_title: Loved this company, but am deemed irrelevant due to my salary band and years of service
pros: Salary that is comparable to entry-level contract work. Work from home and client site, instead of an actual building. "Flexible" work schedules. Practically doubled in size during the worst recession in most of our lifetimes...though growth was everywhere except the US.
cons: IBM's idea of "flexible"work schedule means 130% utilization (or else), evening and weekend work, having to work an extra week for every week of vacation you take (or else), frequent stealth layoffs when IBM is looking to purchase another company in distress, a dramatic shift from quality to quantity (utilization is all that matters to them, now), abandoned core beliefs.

review_title: Strong brand with great working environment, but cost cutting cause very limited resource and training opportunities
pros: Strong brand, flexible working hours, great working environment, people are excellent, good medical benefits for people with family, flexible time-off policies, challenging projects in big customers, abundant online resources for self learning purpose
cons: Limited training/development opportunities due to cost cutting (IBM is trying to compensate this by providing abundant online technical resources for self learning purpose however most of the time the depth of the material is lacking if used in real life project), lack of transparency in criteria for promotion to higher band and position, a lots of approval sometimes can affect flexibility, most of the time career aspiration is difficult to accommodate due to business situation, many talented people leave this company, resources are very limited thus affect availability to work on customer projects.

review_title: Once was great but now struggles
pros:
Had a fantastic run in IBM because career choices were there. Can always move around within the company.

People mostly were of high calibre but deadwoods were there too.

Fantastic process. While can be overbearing at times, it made sure everything were done properly
cons:
Too slow to react to market change. CAMSS had been in the market for several years before IBM decided to enter it.  

IBM was a market leader, innovator. Now it contends to be a follower (the late move into CAMSS is a prime example). It completely lost its innovation leadership and I fear the end is close ala Nokia.

Career opportunities are now limited to presales and sales roles.  Not a lot of other roles left.

review_title: Smart People in a to big Company
pros: This company changed the way the world works. Very smart people, especially in R&D and the Consulting business. Once your in, you can stay for the rest of your life and change job role every second year or so. As long as you do your job, no one cares, how, when or where you are doing your job. If you are in consulting, you can work with the world most famous brands. All of them work with IBM. The management made the right shifts to turn around business with cloud and cognitive computing.
cons: Depending on your business unit (Sales, Marketing,etc.) you might be working 30% of your time with admin stuff. In Consulting, pressure is extremely high but compensations are low. As in every other Corp. strategies are shifting on a quarterly basis.

review_title: Great company, good work life balance,
pros:
1. Good and challenging job opportunities if you are willing to search and go get it
2. Great work life balance. You can define to what extent you want to stretch. There are opportunities where you can work 9-5 and there are also opportunities where you can take on fact paced business needs
3. Extremely supportive colleagues and managers who stand by you during tough personal situations
4. Talented, warm, friendly and helpful colleagues
5. No/very less politics
6. All in all a very progressive work culture
cons:
1. Average and sometimes low compensation. Hikes are below average
2. Growth is slow
3. PBC system which caused a lot of friction and low morale especially in a team where all team members are above average. Hence, rating any of them as average is not reasonable. This, I heard is changing for good

review_title: Worst Experience, Mental Harassment (ISL/ISDL India Systems Development Lab)
pros:
There is nothing good from people point of view, infrastructure wise it is good.
Work From Home facility is good.
cons:
Job is not safe here, so Team Leads doesn't share the product knowledge and even required Design documents. Keeps his team in dark. So that their job remains safe.

They will put shoe-polishing work on your plate.

Team Leads for everything shouts on others on the floor, other much experienced people are there on the floor, they don't even react to this situation. Nobody helps, literally no-body.

When you report these issues to Manager, zero actions.

Manager plays full politics, threatens people working under him, saying "let's see how your career goes here".
Biased environment. They don't care at all. Other people can't even help you.
Working here feels like committing suicide.

Manager is "impotent" in his role. Doesn't take any single good action, rebellious attitude.
Senior Managers are neutral on this front.

Do not join ISDL / ISL, if you want to live with peace and hoping respect at workplace.

From Work point of view, there is no good work, just shoe-polish work.

review_title: Living the dream!
pros:
When I landed a contract with IBM, it was a dream come true. I would be learning from the "Best" & the acknowledged Market Leader. People also were massively impressed by it on my CV. 
The individuals I worked alongside were top quality too.
cons:
The whole ethos of current IBM is saving $$$$. They are constantly looking for ways to manage people out & replace them with cheaper offshore candidates,  This is great for the budgets & the stock price but not so great for the customer. Top professionals are being performance reviewed out, leading to an overstretched & demoralised workforce, unable to supply the agreed contracts to the customer.
Sad to be part of but sadder again to see.

review_title: Best employer for LGBT+ employees
job_title: Manager, Enterprise Learning Design in Montclair, NJ
pros: Being out at work as lesbian enabled me to experience helping launch an internal startup -- a business development team dedicated to the LGBT+ B2B market. My management also supported my 6-month assignment in India with my wife, accompanying me, even though homosexual activity is illegal in India; it said that it couldn't get me out of jail if I were jailed due to the country's laws, but that Pat & I could be fully out as a couple within IBM's four walls; we were and local management and colleagues all were lovely to and inclusive of us. My U.S. management also sponsored my Master's at Columbia while I worked full-time. All this while being able to mentor and be mentored by amazing LGBT+ colleagues and allies!
cons: Join an investment bank, rather than IBM, if you want to be wildly wealthy, but you can earn a healthy living here.

review_title: Good Work Life Balance, But less pay hikes.
pros:
-> Undoubtedly one of the best in the world. 
-> They have many programs to support employees and since it is a huge organization, there are many opportunities within.
-> Nevertheless, once an IBMer.. Always an IBMer. 
-> An amazing company to start career with. Awesome work environment.
-> Many new things coming into place, enormous growth capabilities into Data Science, Security, Analytics, Watson, Cloud technologies and many other platforms.
cons:
-> Everything relies on manager opinion. However, this trend is slowly getting reformed by IBM executives with multiple programs.
-> Growth cannot be expected with your experience / skill. 
This was a situation probably a year ago or atleast what I felt working here.
->

review_title: Meh..
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: It's slow paced and a lot of managers aren't really involved. They just do their own thing.
cons: Most people here have been here a while and most without engineering degrees since they didn't exist back then. They do things here their own way and these life time employees are the team leads and management.This makes it really hard for new grads in engineering to come in and learn. It's also incredibly difficult to bring in new tools, get acceptance for new tools and to get the team to automate things. It's also difficult to do object oriented on legacy systems and one has to follow the teams coding  style right down to the comments so you end up being a depressed underpaid code monkey.

review_title: Managers, do you hear us?
job_title: Associate IT Architect in Southbury, CT
pros: flexibility, Open culture and work/life balance
cons: It is hard to find good first line and second line managers. Though i do not have much experience dealing with executives, I dont think too highly of them

review_title: IBM, where "Respect for the individual" really did mean something 15+ years ago.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Usually great co-workers and technically, some of the best in the industry IMO. Often interesting projects that allow you to greatly expand your knowledge in many, many fields.
cons:
Incompetent senior management that has restricted first line managers to the extent they are glorified team leads. Everything, every decision, every raise, every bonus, every schedule is micro-managed by senior managers. The first lines are just talking heads touting the company line when you know very few believe any of it.

That and that fact that every year, senior managers figure out a way to take something from the employees, vacation, raises, promotions, retirement, you name it.

Fire Randy McDonald (HR VP) first, he seems to take particular joy in sticking it to the employees every year.

review_title: The MDC is pretty much a joke
job_title: Applications Developer in East Lansing, MI
pros:
There is a lot of down time when you aren't on a project to do other things.
Some projects offer good travel opportunities.
IBM is now on your resume.
cons:
There is a lack of communication between managers and it makes it frustrating to get on a project.
Deployment managers are clueless to who you are and what skills you have.
You get thrown into projects where you don't have the skills or you are sold as a professional.
They say 10% travel, but many projects are every week to client location for months.
Salary is a joke to other jobs in the field, even in other IBM departments you get paid nearly 2X.

review_title: Not Good
pros:
- People in non-voice jobs have a little peace in their lives
 - the food court offers average-rated food
 - You get your final settlement on time after quitting
cons:
- U r lucky if u live close-by to the office coz there are perpetual cab-driver strikes
- Everyday is fire-fighting as soon as you reach work. Chaos is IBM's signature style
- The HR is very deceptive about your salary break-up
- Peers will do anything to deprive you of help and put you down
- There's not much time you can afford to spend with your team coz of loads of redundant paper-work
- Their technology, systems, applications & procedures are all complex (like working around your head just to touch your nose)
- No decision-making powers or feeling of ownership
- Unrealistic expectations and deadlines. No exceptions will be made unless you boot-lick

review_title: Good Place to Learn.  Easy to Get Lost in the Back Office.
job_title: Financial Analyst Co-Op in Rochester, MN
pros:
-decent ability to work from home when needed (flip side is you're expected to be "online" at ridiculous hours.  As a co-op I had to work until midnight once a month!)
-good compensation for the MN area
-tons of free education online, but it only applies to areas within IBM
-work only with other finance people at the Center of Excellence, lots of face to face knowledge sharing and ability to move around within finance
cons:
-TONS of employee turnover, it's rare if someone stays over 4 years
-not a lot of respect for the individual, most teams you support are not local, so there's only ST or phone conversations
-very easy to get into finance in Rochester and get stuck, I'm lucky I got out while I could

review_title: IBM is the best place to work if you're a geek
pros:
Lots of autonomy
Bring your own device
Amazing culture and opportunities to learn
Supportive management and fair treatment
Competitive pay and decent benefits
cons:
Only 3 weeks of vacation to start
Benefits could be better, they are average
A decent amount of big company bureaucracy
You have to use Lotus Notes

review_title: It is a good place to work
job_title: Business Support Operations Specialist in Budapest
pros: It is a nice company with many possibilities to develop yourself. If you are already in the company in any of the position, and you are doing your job good, than you have a lot of chance to get promoted, or if you are geting bored at your position, you can easily change to an other team. The managers are nice, and as far as the job is done, everything is flexible
cons:
The infrastructure is surprisingly bad. Despite the fact, that IBM is a leading IT company, the computers we were using are old and slow, and it makes a bit hard to work with them. And also the processes within the company are also slow (everything needs to be approved), for example: to hire someone (even to the lowest position) takes more months
But I guess it is the same with all of the multinational companies.

review_title: The Michgan Recovery Center (IBM) is a good place to learn.
job_title: Entry Level Java Developer in East Lansing, MI
pros: While I can't recommend IBM as a place to end a career, it is a good place to be able to make enough to pay the bills while learning Java and all of its associated technologies.  One thing about IBM is that they won't fire you on your first, or even second outings working with their clients, as long as you are trying.
cons: The old adage about IBM's "culture" is true, and is a hard thing to put up with, but I tolerate it well enough by telling myself that I am traveling in disguise.  Other than that, and the ~standard corporate tricks they attempt to pull on us, it is an ok place to work.  And East Lansing, if you like Michigan at all, is very nice.

review_title: Good company brand to have on your CV, perfect for Grads seeking experience.
job_title: Senior Incentive Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Plenty of opportunities to change roles gaining valuable experience if you have the right strategy.  However if you're stuck in 1or 2 roles and stay there for too long, don't expect much as your transferable skills will be IBM specific. Not many companies use IBM tools, defo not Lotus Notes.

Good redundancy packages!!!!!
cons: PBC process is to make sure you work hard, but it deprives you from your bonus, salary increases, promotions and so on. If you disagree with your rating (and most ppl do) and you have a strong case to prove that you're right - open HR case. They might give you 2+ instead of 2, but no salary increase to complement it. Nobody will know about it, as you're not suppose to discuss PBC ratings with anyone. It is extremely biased, promotes cronyism and low morale etc. Don't complain, just be happy to have a job!!!!!

review_title: Delivery Center Brno (IDC)
pros: IBM brand may boost your CV and you can learn a lot if you want. due to lack of people, they will never fire you so it is also quite stable for lazy and useless people - because of this, you can switch to any team and learn literally anything you want.
cons: below average salary, no benefits, poor mentality, endless cost cutting. IDC Brno is not "real" IBM but just cheap delivery center (other delivery centers are in Poland, India, Romania, Argentina..). first line "managers" (usually promoted by unsuccessful technicians) are simple puppets without any power or right to change anything, shifting teams every year (I had 5 managers in 4 years - really). very limited pay raise even with good personal results. just avoid if you skilled technician and come, if you will or want to become a "manager"

review_title: Engineer
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Once a great global tech company, but external rapid changes in tech landscape, the company no longer retain that position.  But I give them credit for just surviving as most of its peers have folded or bought out.  Any tech companies over 50 years old is a rare species.   This I believe has to do with its hiring, training, and management philosophy that was put in place in earlier years.  I have switched industry since then, but some of the best and most capable people I met were from IBM.
cons: Did not take Personal Computing (low margin and low ASP) seriously enough, or understood the consumer market well enough.   It should have spinoff that division in the 80's or not have outsourced key parts to the like of Microsoft and Intel.

review_title: IBM Explained
pros:
- Strong importance on give back to the community
- Inspires you to continue education
- Inspires you to start your own company
- Vacation benefits and sick leave are good if you are a legacy employee or longer than 2 years now
- Good resume builder and brilliant people to mentor (Avoid the bad, negative employees)
cons:
- Lack of concern for the individuals development even though that is the sales pitch
- Internally competition amongst divisions and regions
- Lack of focus on your background
- Like most consulting firms, the metrics used to rate employees does not incentivize efficiency, just billing hours for short-term revenue kudos to push stock price while compromising the delivery it owes to its clients.
- It is making poor globalization choices just like most outsourcing firms because the government incentivizes it to occur.  This is not IBM's fault but rather the government.
