review_title: Exhausting if Consulting is Not Your Thing
pros: Great compensation, health benefits, employee discounts on a variety of things. Easy for relocation as there are offices just about everywhere in the world. It's been around forever so it's stable in that aspect of job security. Nice 401k match and various financial options, tuition reimbursements, spousal and family perks, etc.
cons: 80%+ travel for consultants, which can be very draining if it's not your thing. Very poor work-life balance. The sheer size of the company makes it extremely easy to get lost in the shuffle. Lots of unnecessary bureaucracy and hoop-jumping for things like promotions and performance reviews, although there are signs of an attempt to improve this. Employee site very difficult to navigate.I still don't really know how to answer people who ask me "so what do you actually do?".

review_title: Find better company
pros:
Home-office and work-life balance. 
Good atmosphere in global work centers with young and friendly populations. 
Great starting point if you have no experience/are out of school - IBM loves cheap labor and you get in the two or three years of experience to seek better job opportunities.
cons: Non-competitive salaries, non-existent bonuses. Miserable, chaotic implementation of initiatives... Generally a mess, at least in its global centers. I'd recommend only if you have a family and need more time for yourself; outside of high-impact periods like closings for finance/accounting, etc.

review_title: IBM Global Business Solution
pros: With IBM you get to know people from different parts of the country. You get an opportunity to work with them and get an exposure that is all of a different kind. In IBM you are bound to make a new friend every now and then which is a blend of funand experience.
cons: Its very hard to find out the faults in IBM.The work policy of IBM is very different from other companies. It gives equal work opportunities to its employees. Also it is the first company to believe in and implement such kind of a work policy. Every individual’s work is recognized and appreciated.

review_title: Great work life balance
pros: As a human being we always strive for something new. Either new challenge, new opportunity, new relationship etc. Majority of this new revolve around money and family. At IBM you got both. Some strive for more money at the cost of family and some looking for family pleasure at the cost of more money.
cons: I do not find any such. I am regular on social media sometimes laughing at the issues mentioned. Not because it is not valid or incorrect but because it is not justified. They usually asking for both without slight compromise on any one.

review_title: A good place overall, but too much beuracracy and politics
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Columbus, OH
pros:
* I worked with some fantastic people
* Some of the products and services really were "best in class"
* There was a clear path to promotion while remaining in an engineering role rather than being forced to transition to management
* I was pleasantly surprised several times with raises and bonuses. It's literally the only place I've ever worked where I received a raise without asking for it, and it happened to me twice in 3 years at IBM.
* IBM's marketing and name recognition is awesome
cons:
* Some of the products were not "best in class"
* Bureaucracy and politics got in the way of quality and cost us good people
* A strategy shouldn't drastically change every year or two
* IBM's complete flip-flop on remote workers was the primary reason I left
* I had 6 managers in 3 years

review_title: A once great company that treats its employees with very little respect and appreciation
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Armonk, NY
pros: The best part of working for IBM is some employees have the option to work at home.
cons: There is absolutely no respect for the individual.  Sr. management could not care less about the employees.  They are on a mission to move work offshore to India and China, and get rid of as many U.S. employees as they can.  They are even forcing the U.S. employees to train their replacements.  Then, employees with 20+ years and excellent reviews are thrown out like yesterday's trash.  These are not low level employees -- we are talking about senior professionals in IT, finance, etc., who are highly educated and high performing employees.

review_title: great!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Quezon City, Quezon City
pros: they provide the best learning program... they dont just kick you out of the company very quickly.... they listen... and they let you explain your side.. the supports are as supportive as they should... and they are wonderful people you will ever deal with.... they will always help you with any difficulties you may encounter on the account you will work with... they will make it as easy as a blink of an eye..... getting hired as IBM employee is definitely a great advantage too... cause once you resign and look for another job,  it will be like a sugar coating on your resume.... :)
cons: agent's disputes are never processed.. that is actually the reason why is resigned

review_title: Never in the history of the world has a company been doing so well yet MORAL and Culture is so BAD
pros: Great work from home and ability to move around.
cons: Terrible moral, working employees to death to meet their Roadkill 2015 target.  The truth is they will meet it by selling off all the properties they aquired when times where good how ever in the process their SW/HW and Services group will crumble due to the lack of people, over worked and under paid.   Clients are jumping ship and it can be seen as their revenue remains flat how ever profit is booming.   That means SQUEEEEEZE.     Enjoy IBM while you can, work it, get experience then jump ship ad go some where that will respect and pay you accordingly.

review_title: A company of companies
job_title: Software Engineer (Band 6) in Campinas, São Paulo
pros:
A lot of brands, units, and an infinite amount of projects with great flexibility to move among them. This enables employees to change roles and move into new projects. Sometimes this even happens when the employee has no previous knowledge or experience on the new area.
Stable company, very focused on earnings and always with a vision for more growth.
cons:
We all work for the company stockholders. This seems much more like a financial company than anything else (service, it, etc): everything is calculated and there is always a cost/risk pair to it.
Companies nowadays call their employees "resources", IBM calls them "cost".
Too deep hierarchy. It's hard to know what is going on up there. 
Managers are moved from projects/areas/units/brands every 2 years, so you get a new manager who might or might not know about your project and how your team works... this is usually really bad. As always, there are some exceptions.

review_title: If you can work for kudos and ataboys instead of money then the sky's the limit.
job_title: Security Sales Executive in Denver, CO
pros:
Most employees are given the opportunity to work at home.
Work hours are generally flexible which helps with life interruptions.
The company name looks good on your resume.
cons:
Salary stays flat regardless of performance, promotions, or responsibilities.
Almost impossible to get paid training.
Benefits cost more each year so with no raises you actually take home less money.
The company has one goal only and that is earnings per share target.

review_title: Company in transition
pros:
You will be surrounded by really talented people who have high standards and expect the same.
In the division I worked, people were always willing to take the time to help a coworker work through a problem or to discuss new ideas. Lots of opportunity to take on different roles and career paths if you are proactive in managing your career.
cons:
Like any big company, you have to learn how to work the system to get things done. You also need to stay on top of technology trends and  position yourself to be part of the forward movement, as with any company..
Difficult to move between divisions if trying to change jobs/career paths.
As corporate VPs work to the 2015 EPS goal, cost savings by cutting back on employee compensation has been obvious.

review_title: Many opportunities, but you can get lost in the ocean
pros: There are many many opportunities whatever your interest may be, but one needs to pursue with aggressiveness and do a lot of homework to understand them.
cons: The policies are making it more and more difficult for genuine above average contributors to fall through the gaps and get lost in the complicated processes losing out on seniority for promotion and deserved salary hikes. The organization is saturated at the mid-management level and the management is using the bell-curve in exactly the manner it should not be - to avoid rewarding to the deserving.

review_title: Deep internal renewal required
pros: Apart from it's well know brand, IBM is getting into many business developing areas focusing on modifying many working procedures for its clients.
cons:
Although it's making lots of developmentes, it's not applying any to itself, therefore workers tend to implement new solutions for clients but it happens that internally things don't work out that well.
All main business developments happen mainly within the US area, and although the rest of the world forms part of the same company, it's generally not possible or very difficult to take part in any innovative project until years later...
Business values tend to be more client focused as time goes by, reducing each year workers benefits and asking people to work more hours each time without giving anything in return.
I personally like being an IBMer, but disagree with many of the actual managers view in an era where workers personal values cannot be forgotten, something which had always been a company's differentiator.

review_title: No Longer a Great Place to Work
job_title: Software Sales Executive in New York, NY
pros:
- Still a great name on your resume (for now)
- Ability to easily move to new roles based on career aspirations
- Great, smart people to work with
- Good work/life balance depending on the business unit you work in (NOT GBS)
cons:
There are many - here are a few:
- Moral is low because employees don't feel they are valued
- Promotions / raises very scarce unless you are at the lowest or highest levels
- Continual reorganizations - chasing changes in the market
- Continual territory changes for sales teams
- Revenue has not increased in years - profit is obtained and EPS is increased by cutting costs and buying back stock 
- Costs are cut via selling off parts of the business, constant layoffs (called RAs for Resource Action) and outsourcing jobs to growth market areas
- CEO and SVP team given raises, bonuses, & stock options even though they failed to achieve all stated objectives

review_title: Incapacitated managers
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Vitória Brasil
pros: Flexibility, benefits, health insurance, discounts at Hertz. There's not much to say about the Pros of working at IBM.
cons:
Managers often take decisions without looking at the whole scenario, causing big damage to the company and looking to improve their careers. Your future lies in the hands of your manager and I saw a lot of people stuck in their careers because their manager won't let them grow. The company is always in freeze and spend money dumbly (like they can rent computers but not buy new ones, for long periods, buying computers would be far cheaper).

I had a good time there but due to the manager's will to hold me back, I couldn't get projects in other competencies. Overall, I don't recommend a job at IBM.

review_title: Turning the tide
pros: IBM is a technology company, and it has a dazzling range of technology and services to offer. This makes IBM a place for people who like technology.  Its also a place to find like minded individuals committed, engaged and who want to make a difference.
cons: Transformation has been tough and is not over yet.  Now days, technical skill is not  rewarded without linking it to earnings.   Pay rises and bonuses will be hard to come by unless your talent includes competing, marketing and distinguishing yourself.

review_title: Once great; now scrambling to keep up
job_title: IT Project Manager in Kirkland, WA
pros: Co-workers; well-known brand; good benefits; large company so potential to experience many different kinds of business units.
cons:
Company leaders are wholly focused on shareholder price and looking good on the outside to the exclusion of everything else. Lots of spinning of image to look relevant, but on the inside staff are struggling to complete work with antiquated hardware and inadequate software tools. Many layers of process to complete a request. 

Frequent lay-off programs and stacked ranking evaluation systems either frighten employees into working themselves to death or pit them against each other to get a better ranking. Staff are constantly told to 'get exposure' to upper management so when ranking time comes around they will not be just a faceless headcount to cut. 

Raises, bonuses are infrequent; pay low to average.

review_title: Like a challenge? Like to show growth?
job_title: Leadership Development Associate in Armonk, NY
pros:
Visionary leaders across the organization, and across levels of experience.
Intense focus on how managers can create signature experiences for employees.
Many IBMers look up to leaders who have values-based behaviors, qualities.
Many tools available to share ideas, collaborate, communicate (Box, Mural, Slack, Connections).
Opportunities to use cognitive in the way we work.
Much improvement in video conferencing capabilities.
Extremely helpful culture; many, many smart people.
Senior leaders are listening to all levels of leadership and management to improve the company.
If you want to grow your leadership skills, I highly recommend working for this company due to their investment in leadership, and the role models that have worked there, and currently work there.
Tremendous opportunity to grow and improve, if you are willing to, and be recognized for that growth.
cons:
Highly implied expectation to constantly work.
Many concurrent initiatives, there could be more collaboration and simplification on how we work internally.

review_title: IBM OffCampus Placement Review
pros:
First of all i want to thank whole IBM Family for its Wonderful support, co-operation,management and everything and finally for giving me an opportunity to work for IBM which was my dream job( soon it will be done) .
The Team ( All Hr, Tr people  ) were doing there job in so professional way that i was not expecting, but the result was out of my imagination. I am very happy to become the part of this 
IBM( Intelligent Brilliant Minds ) family.
For me IBM is that lives at the intersection of technology and business. Which enables us to change the way the world works, and in so doing, to be essential to our clients and to the
society. A new world is taking shape before our eyes, remade by data, rewritten in
code and growing smarter every day. The work of transforming IBM continues, and
much remains to be done.

Needs blessing,
Thanks and Regards
cons: No Cons so far i have noticed, or come in touch.

review_title: Great work environment and people, but ISC is no place for SW Engineers
job_title: Test Engineer in El Salto, Jalisco
pros:
-Great environment 
-Amazing and talented people
-Cool benefits, salary and insurance 
-You are free to learn everything you want
-Easy to create and implement projects
-Easy to connect and make networking
cons:
-If you are a SW Engineer in the ISC you have to do operations or manufacturing activities, otherwise management thinks your are doing nothing 
-The location is far from the metropolitan zone
-You don’t get promoted unless telling management you’re leaving 
-Many people doing “especial projects” (doing nothing) while others getting a lot of work
-Sometimes the school you come from determines how fast you get hired directly (not as contractor)
-The saying “The shoemaker's son always goes barefoot" applies here.

review_title: IBM Client Innovation Centre - Project Analyst
job_title: Project Analyst in Preston, North West England, England
pros:
- Great team of people
- Good exposure to client facing roles
- Remote working (at task managers discretion)
- Good place to start your career
cons:
- Not a career for the long term future.
- Must be flexible and willing to travel to take on other roles (you may not even want) to have any chance of progression.
- Targets solely based on utilisation. 
- Lack of benefits despite introducing pension, child care vouchers and cycle to work scheme.
- Increased quantity of promotion bands limit pay rises.
- Unbelievable levels of bureaucracy. 
- Lack of promoting any form of networking within the wider company to get on a project or role you want - due to CIC politics.
- Top level management only interested in progressing themselves and achieving KPIs to get annual bonus.
- Business based on ‘Cost’ model, meaning the cheaper, the better.

review_title: Graduate Scheme at IBM
job_title: Business Technology Consultant in London, England
pros:
Within IBM there is a huge possibility for growth depending on your networking skills and how eager you are to grow and own your career. The Graduate Program, which I am a part of, has a huge platform for training and the higher-ups are also very involved with the growth of the early professionals (graduates and apprentices). There is a lot of exposure to various projects and opportunities to build good client relationships. 

The work culture is overall a good one where the people you interact with are there to support you and in essence build relationships with.
cons: As IBM is a very huge company, once you get past the Graduate Scheme, there is a high chance career growth stagnates and you become lost in the company as there might not be as much focus on how you progress.

review_title: A once great company being unnecessarily diminished ..
pros: Strong teamwork with knowledgable experienced professional peers and colleagues, good diversity, flexible working combined with a reasonable compensation package. A diverse portfolio of products and solutions with global reach.
cons: Regular rounds of “redundancy / resourcing actions” (even in area’s of strategic growth) damage morale, creating unhealthy internal politics that diverts resources from productive client facing engagements and activity. Too many layers of management focussed on short term 90 day targets and hype, creating unproductive inward facing workload, politics and bureaucracy.

review_title: All depends on project
pros: Atmosphere was relaxed, colleagues helpful. Pluralsight access and also Safari books and other training opportunities. In the team there were initiatives to inspire people to develop better coding practices or prepare some training. Also if someone would like to get access to some extra RPA tool it was sometimes possible to have it arrange so they could learn extra tool
cons: In my case communication was the reason why I left this job. I had a feeling I got stuck in a rut and there is no possibility of change for any better. I think a lot of people leaves due to this factor. There is no clear vision of the future in terms of what projects will be available etc.

review_title: Many opportunities and diverse jobs available
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros:
IBM is a really large company and there are many opportunities to do some interesting jobs.  There are many chances
for training ... as long as it's free and it's on your own time.  IBM has some really good benefits, although they recently
froze their pension plan, they do have a good 401K plan.  If you don't have to be on a customer site, then IBM is a big
believer in work@home.
cons:
In many parts of IBM, one has to constantly be worried about their job being off shored.  Many jobs in IBM require onsite
presence and/or weekly travel to customer sites. Many of the jobs are tied to customer contracts, so when contract ends
or isn't renewed you have to find another job.

review_title: I am proud to have been an IBM'er.
pros: Overall, IBM was a great company to work for.  The expect a lot from their employees, yet they still follow the motto from years past of "Respect for the Individual".
cons: IBM has become a 'sweat shop'.   They are so focused on the return to the stock holder (which I understand is a primary responsibility of the CEO), however their strategy to move more jobs to other countries is begginning to take a toll on the US employees.   I was impacted by the 3/2010 resource action, but was fortunate to have 34 years, so technically I retired.  When looking at internal job postings after being notified, I estimate that only 10% of the PM jobs were in the US and of those 90% was 100% travel.

review_title: At one time it was a great company to work for but not anymore.
pros: IBM allows most employees the benefit of Telecommuting and has great work/life balance allowing employees to take care of personal business when needed.
cons: IBM has lost its concern for their employees they are just another commodity/expense used by management. Even their pay is not as good as it once was. The side benefits like parties for the children and other events for employees are no longer in existence and this has hurt the moral. In a few years the number of US employees will be at their lowest point since all the work keeps going to the country that has the lowest cost.

review_title: Sadly Disappointing
job_title: Technical Team Lead in Hopewell, NY
pros: Brand name to work for..Benefits are okay..pay is average.
cons: Before I left, we had a meeting to come up with ideas with teams?? On how to re-invent ourselves?? Sadly in this business you should be overseeing your advancements on a weekly if anything monthly. To use to same routines no innovation or new ideas on how to press forward. Each IBM'er was to Independent to do his or her own thing..Our process engineers all wanted patents on processes..etc..No willingness to grow together. To bring new and open ideas to the table. Sadly IBM is behind the 8 Ball trying to play catch. I was very surprised how we still were in business.

review_title: Straight from college to IBM..worked for 6 years there ..started from Operations and left as a Project Manager.
pros: great place to choose the domain u want to be in and work towards it..internal movement options are immense..upskill..for freshers nothing like getting into IBM till u learn state of art technology and be ready for IT world outside.
cons: pay package should definitely be revised for senior employees ..great place to learn basics and start career but u need to dig in your self to improvise your knowledge..scope of work quite limited to get end to end knowledge  ..more power to HR, its a manager centric company.

review_title: A good place to use and learn analytics
pros:
You can access and use IBM's best analytics tools, through Blue Opportunities you can get involved in other interesting projects - as your daily job is usually boring it is really up to you how much you use the benefits of above options. 
Home office is quite common - which is s very good benefit too.
cons:
- jobs controlled by processes and due to the size of the company, you get a small part of the whole process - like a manufacturing plant, so you really need to make extra efforts to find what you would like
- compensation packages are below market averages
- personal evaluation is based on relative measures - so if there is anyone in your global team who found better in your area, you will not get the annual raise even if you are the best expert in your country or local site, no matter how hard you try

review_title: Demanding, high performance sales environment
pros: Possibility to be exposed to a tremendous amount of varied sales situations in which one can learn a lot. Opportunities for career advancement if you can cope with working in a complex matrix organization and company politics. Friendly environment for women with ambition.  Lots of possibilities to work with international teams and customers.
cons: Very high expectations that sellers will achieve sales targets which often times have no connection with the realities of the market or the products.  Working around the clock is expected and if you are a sales manager the administrative demands are brutal and will keep you from actually seeing customers.  Very convoluted compensation plans. The line of site to commissions and bonuses is nearly impossible for any seller to calculate themselves. No support in navigating your career.  You have to be very self motivated and have a string network to move ahead.

review_title: Been working for a couple of months. So far so good.
job_title: Senior Frontend Developer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: They have very good benefits and salaries, delivery center in guadalajara is nice. They have free transportation by bus to many places arround guadalajara. Its a big company with many projects so there is room for you to grow your career. Lots of learning tools.
cons: Delivery center is too far from the city, the food at the cafeteria is terrible. Some projects use very outdated technologies. If you are a frontend developer like me you probably wont be coding and they would ask you to upload videos, product, images etc on the cms which in my case is drupal and helios and we al hate it because it takes too long to refresh the data on the frontend.

review_title: It's not your father's IBM
pros: Amazing people that I call friends. Flexibility to work from home (for the past three years, that ends in 2017 for most biz units).  Great training programs.  You can get in the door with the IBM name.
cons: Morale is at an all time low.  The constant, every 6 month change to account coverage and strategy makes success very difficult.  The lay offs, also known as "skills re-balancing" or Resource Actions have taken a toll.  Often very good people have been let go because they have been in the wrong organization at the wrong time.

review_title: Program Director
pros:
Benefits were good.
Work in some areas was interesting.
cons:
Leadership is only interested in their career, moving quickly before the glass breaks.
I spend much of my management career trying to convince employees that taking away benefits was a good thing for them.
No executive is held accountable, only lower level management and employees - just look at who getting laid off and how many VPs a small organization has.
They have no clue on how to grow revenue.

review_title: Still a good company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Generally speaking IBM offers an interesting, challenging and expansive work environment with good career opportunities. If you deliver your quality work on time and are a good team player, then you'll get rewarded. There's equal opportunity.  There's lots of chances to further your knowledge through a vast offering of education opportunities. IBM rewards people who take charge and shows interest in the business.
cons: Mediocre salaries and declining benefits.  Poor long term employment stability prospects. Generally old and uninspiring work environments. Mediocre cafeterias. Work weeks of 40 hours is not so. It's easily 50+ hours in any of the full time development jobs. People are frequently, though politely, asked to do whatever's needed to get the job done.

review_title: IBM Research - Great benefits, flexible working environment.
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: Up to 20 weeks paid maternity leave and 12 weeks paid paternity leave is amazing. Competitive salary, flexible work environment, one of the few industry research labs out there. Supportive of publishing and attending conferences. Lots of room for growth if you take the initiative.
cons: Paid parental leave does not apply to post-docs, even though they are otherwise treated as full-time employees and this is not well-advertised. I found out when I was pregnant with my second child. A lot of bureaucracy when it comes to purchasing and safety. It is a major hindrance on innovation in research. A lot of tolerance for dead weight.

review_title: SAP Technical SME - Have been working in IBM for around 13 years.
pros: Innovation, Watson, Client Success. IBM gives lot of importance to appreciate right people who does the right work at right time, which would give lot of confidence and satisfaction to the people who always committed to give 100% effort for the organization and the project.
cons: Processes need to be adjusted as per the way or in situations while dealing with different clients as satisfying the client is utmost priority  for any organization, I feel sometimes bringing our complex process if any, may not be better always as some clients wouldn't be interested to follow process, meeting deadlines is only priority for those clients, so dealing with those clients, our process need to be altered bit to ensure client and organization are on the same page.

review_title: Think Before Joining
pros:
Good learning opportunity.
Better tools and technology.
cons:
Lots of politics.

One of Barclays account manager is rustic one who assumes their employees as maid and servants. He is the gatekeeper of that account who will make sure people will not get released.

This is women friendly company and mgrs are in favors of womens as they have which men do not have.
All credit, salary hike,promotion will be given to womens employee though one work hard and deserves it.

They will get the work done from you like machines (International Bussines machine) till machine hangs.
(Till blood get sucked out of you). They are puppet show of client and you will have to dance 
as per the steps given by client.

You will feel like you have come on streets after you work for few years as there is no descent 
career growth.

Very less (7%) or no variable pay.

review_title: Great Place to Work as a person but not the best products
job_title: Cloud Technical Sales in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: At IBM the managers and people really take car of their employees. IBM has great benefits and it is a great place to learn how a Big company works. As a Technical Sales Person they will always give you training and they will make sure you have everything you need to do your job. The Payment is good.
cons:
The Management from IBM (oldest people) believe IBM is the Best at everything and does not realize that their products are not the best, So when you do not make the target sales they will put the fault on you and not on the "old" product you are selling.
Now IBM is changing and innovating but they are not doing it as fast as AWS, Microsoft or Google, so the Cloud business is pretty tough, you will have to provide really innovative and new ideas on how to position IBM's products to be able to make them look better than the competition.

review_title: Okay if you are in the right division
pros: As an employee, you have vast resource of learning tools at your disposal. If there is a certification you want to work on, there are learning avenues for you to achieve it. IBM also has some very powerful applications - WATSON, Red Hat, cloud - that competitors cannot beat.
cons:
I have been with IBM for 5+ years now. In this time I have not received a single raise despite the fact that the contract I worked on meet or exceed our annual numbers. The issue is that raises & bonuses are tied to the WHOLE division you work in. Sine the division as a whole did not make the annual numbers, no raises or bonuses. 
Also, health insurance is very expensive if you want to cover your family. Instead of offering a family play, IBM makes you pay for each person covered. Pushes the cost of selecting the better plans out of reach.

review_title: Good place to work if you like large companies
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Job flexibility, ability to work at home, set my own hours.  Management cares about the work being done, not the when and where.  We enjoy a lot of flexibility, which really helps with work life balance.  It is okay to spend time during the day doing something at the kid's school as long as the work is made up in the evenings or weekends.
cons: Too large, hard to make a difference, hard to change things.  The structure and size is at times overwhelming...it can take days to find the right contact for a simple question, and one hand rarely know what the other is doing, leading to a lot of duplication of effort, and conflict.

review_title: IBM STG - where technology leads
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Systems and Technology group has some of the best and the brightest working on leading edge technologies.  It is a pleasure to work with these people and keep up on the bleeding edge of what is going on in the computer industry.  I have certainly learned a lot in my time in STG, and continue to learn on a daily basis.
cons: producing more powerful computers means that you sell less to replace existing ones.  Unfortunately, the cost of the new machines generally isn't 2x the cost of the replacements - hence lowering revenue.  In order to meet corporate expectations, cutting costs by reducing headcount has an impact on what can be developed and what can be sold.  It becomes a vicious cycle, low sales due to diminished products, which in turn leads to lower head counts.

review_title: IBM Spain
pros: Some of its people are extremelly capable and when the offer is right, the resources are aquired for the market needs. When a team is formed, really formed by the actions of the members, the loyalty and capacity to deliver are increased exponentially.
cons: Due to the only focus on profitability the company has lost the sight on the people that make it profitable so the clients are finding some issues when contracting services from IBM. The team is not as motivated as it used to be 10 years ago when there was a proper focuse on careers and skill building within the company.

review_title: Great Place to Start Career, spend few years and move on
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in West Chester, PA
pros: Great place to start a career right out of college.  Diverse projects provide an opportunity to observe how business is done in different industries.  You also get to travel and see the country (and possibly the world).  People who work here are great, they're some of the smartest people I've worked with.
cons:
Travel schedule can be exhausting. You are a profit center, so focus on maintaining billable status is paramount, and management assures you don't forget it!

The biggest negative I see about IBM now is, that the management is moving large amount of work off-shore to lower cost locales, this is great when the objective is to reduce cost, but quality is compromised. In my opinion, IBM will do well for the near future, but once the quality issue catch up.. watch out.

review_title: Serious workplace for those that want to make an impact to the world.
job_title: Senior Marketing Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity abound for those who want it. Conservative workplace, highly virtual where teams are global almost every meeting, extremely high matrixed organization provides challenges for those who want to navigate the system. The workplace is reflective of any megacap company except IBM sets the standard for those companies in business process, use of technology for employees, and work/life balance. Don't get me wrong, get ready to work 50 hours normal week and up to 70 a few weeks in the year when busy. But the work is terribly rewarding. It's great to be an IBMer.
cons: Large, really large company. Systems galore. Meetings are on the phone almost all the time except when meeting with clients or being assigned to client sites. When you have 420,000 employees, you need that. But, if you don't like having a serial number and being part of the machinery, you may want to rethink IBM.

review_title: MDC is just plain sad
job_title: Applications Developer in East Lansing, MI
pros: IBM on resume and experience
cons:
Salary Salary Salary is a joke 20K below national averages for people with no experience
Ability to transfer within IBM even after transitioning to regular status you have to wait another year
No OT anymore to make up for the horrible salary anymore by transitioning us to regular status
Inconsistent attendance policy as to who has to adhere to the three days work from Lansing and who can work from home whenever they wish even though they live in Lansing.
Being put on projects that are not part of our skill set just to make the center hit it's utilization numbers and required to work OT when we are not paid for it to help the center hit utilization targets
very few new benefits for being made a regular employee which the management tried to use to soften the salary situation

review_title: Unstable long-term US employment, but, otherwise a great opportunity.
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: IBM provides employment flexibility, independence and a sharing of knowledge with professional co-workers.  As an Enterprise Architect and Trusted Advisor, I was able to provide strategic influence over customer technologies and business operations.  It was a great opportunity to help many different organizations.
cons: I had little influence on IBM's direction and management seemed to have been trying to figure out what the next leadership direction might be, at least regarding US employment.  Employee concerns over employment may be summed up in a remark I heard...  There are 2 types of IBM'ers, those that were laid off, and those that fear they will soon be laid off.

review_title: Heading downwards and this getting faster
pros: Flexible working (wihin the long hours), co-workers mostly good, some benefits are not bad. Can be a variety of roles if you push to take them.
cons: Leadership,  direction, and even local management is generally appalling.  Process and admin way way over tthe top. Treated like naughty children. No prospects without tons of paperword. Impossibld targets and hours for zero recognition especially  pay. No pay rise of any meaningful nature for over a decade. Steer clear unless you need a job and its local to you!

review_title: IBM Software Group
job_title: Software Sales Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: IBM is a very empowering company even down to the Sales rep level.  They allow you a lot of freedom and opportunity for career advancement and training for a big company.  There are an incredible amount of very smart collaborative professionals.
cons: IBM is a political company that is very complicated internally and is overly thick in management layers.  I have been at the company for several years and many inept employees seem to avoid layoffs and continue to drag the quality of the company down.

review_title: Associate Partner
pros:
* Exciting to be part of 105 old company that is once again transforming to "Be Essential" to our clients and delivering new innovations (e.g. Watson, Blockchain) to the market.  Our challenges remaining at the top of a fast-paced industry ensure there are multiple opportunities to contribute and grow. 
* IBM invests heavily in professional development 
* IBM is a 'top 5' management company (as recognized by the Drucker Institute) and is a place for leaders 
* IBM has some of the best talent I have worked with in my 20+ year career 
* IBM's breadth and global reach provide unique career opportunities across Consulting, Offering Management, internal Operations- whatever passion you want to pursue
* IBM has a commitment to service and giving back to its communities in a meaningful way
* IBM values diversity 
* One of the best 401(k) programs and good benefits package
cons: * Like any organization of IBM's scope and size, you will run into fiefdoms and/or people that are slower to change

review_title: IT Services Manager
pros: Large IT company with many resources and business lines.
cons: IBM is in CONSTANT flux trying to adapt to a world where the need/demand for large Mainframes has dwindled tremendously.  IBM has been forced to cut down product lines, and unfortunately, has let go huge numbers of US workers with great experience and knowledge, for much cheaper but less experienced workers from India, China, Russia, Philippines, South America, etc.  The net result is that I was terrified to sell IT Technical Services since I knew that the quality of services provided was mediocre at best, yet I was charging customers the highest prices just because they were from IBM.

review_title: Review of 6 years with IBM
job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1) Work time\location flexibility
2) High quality on the job training
3) Availabilty of training\trial environments for employees to learn and transition to new roles\business domains\tehnology disruptions.
4) Structuring of the salary in order to optimize tax savings in a legal way.
5) Women friendly organization: Probably the best place for ladies to work.
6) Availability of SMEs and training resources if somebody wants to publish a paper, go for a patent etc.
cons:
1) significant salary increments need a lot of wait.
2) overseas opportunities are very limited. 
3) No overseas rotation policy as of now which results in a lot of deserving resources never getting an opportunity to work overseas. On the other hand, Many Indian MNCs have such a policy.

review_title: A big universe in itself.
pros:
Opportunity for almost every technology there is.
Great exposure in terms of large projects and clients.
Mostly good atmosphere among projects & courses to learn & grow for entry level employees.
( As there are loads of projects, individual experiences may vary )
cons:
Easy to get lost between all the technologies and projects in the Big Blue.
No proper framework to monitor working hours and claim utilization.
No proper pantry , cafeteria & canteen for lunch and snacks.
Employees usually have to extend as management does not possess the proper skill to negotiate with the client and often resorts to agreeing for every request and deadline.

review_title: mixed bag
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Ottawa, ON
pros:
-- always pushing into new technologies
-- many opportunities to learn the latest tech
-- some brilliant people from which to learn
-- opportunities to patent
-- opportunities to lead
-- no more stack ranking (but what took its place?)
-- you get a nice laptop
cons:
-- a strong tendency to chase shiny new concepts (e.g. the recent shift to moving people back into open concept offices because Spotify)
-- a strong tendency to prune the work force regularly (e.g. the recent spate of jobs moving from city to city to force attrition)
-- shofts products into maintenance mode before it is any good (because shiny new tech needs people)
-- too many weak teams, but since company is siloed it is never fixed
-- no detectable loyalty to  long term employees
-- few opportunities to mix with peers (opposite of the early aughts)
-- almost impossible to get funding for attending a conference
-- aggressively moves jobs to countries with low labour costs

review_title: Best and worst of big business.
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: IBM is a large company with many opportunities to have and hold many different positions through a long career. Opportunities from manufacturing to sales and everything in between exist. Services, technical, admin, staff, teaching, HR, sales, graphic design, TV and Video production, food service, etc. There are few companies where you can have this kind of exposure to many different positions. Large companies offer more stability, excellent benefits, and a diverse work environment.
cons: It's a big company. It's easy to get lost. Salary growth can be stagnant. Without establishing a network at the company, you will get lost. Many IBM workers are mobile workers and a sense of community can be lost if you aren't active in establishing it for yourself. This isn't the IBM of 25 years ago where Respect for the Individual was paramount and employee loyalty fueled its success. Lifelong employment at IBM is no longer guaranteed no matter how hard you work.

review_title: IBM: Great opportunities but bureaucratic
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: IBM provides a diverse set of opportunities across a wide spectrum of information technology, with considerable resources available when properly aligned.  There is the ability to work on significant projects and have a global impact.  The company has a long history and many creative and experienced professionals.
cons: After being wined and dined touring China and Russia, CEO Palmisano came back to US to talk about how "messy" Western democracies are and immediately began shifting jobs overseas at increasing rates including selling PC company to Lenovo.  There is a large bureaucracy with lots of internal fiefdoms.  Company has gone from respecting employees and striving for excellence to shooting for the middle ground across compensation and benefits.  Work can be all-consuming and the wrong immediate management can make life miserable.

review_title: I am just coasting, which is too bad.  I am very talented, energetic and I deliver.  I can be very helpful!
pros: I can telecommute, that's the only reason I am staying
cons: Completely lost with objectives, no clarity, a lot of noise

review_title: Overall, IBM is a very good place to work
pros: Interesting people, respect, trust, can be very flexible when requested, good benefits, if you don't like what you're working on - just move on to another project. Some learning - but not in ways you might have expected. Helps build a good reputation. I like it. Best company I've ever worked for (and I've worked for MANY).
cons: Politics. Many long meetings. Meetings about meetings. At times a lot of pressure/stress (but hey, what company doesn't have this).

review_title: Big Blue doesn't know how to develop & retain young talent.
pros:
great benefits - health care, 401K
good starting salary, hard to get laid off unless there is a recession or the company is doing poorly.
cons:
senior management does not care about your career.  They only care if you are billable.
Promotions are hard to comeby.  If you don't get the right project and role, you have no chance of moving up.  Raises are only 2-3% per year unless they determine you're being underpaid compared to the market.  When I left IBM, I was getting paid as much as a new college hire even though I had 2+ years under my belt.

Performance ratings based too much upon utilization.  It's not our fault if you can't find a project for us.

Annual Bonuses are lousy, barely 2%

review_title: People are just another line on the balance sheet
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Durham, NC
pros: My resume looks better now, with four years experience at IBM. It helped me get my current job. I was actually introduced to the executive vice president of marketing by my manager with the words... She comes to us from IBM. He seemed impressed.
cons: There are way too many layers of management at IBM, and they are too far removed geographically from where the vast number of employees are located. I worked in the largest single location where IBM employees are situated... at its heyday, there were upwards of 15,000 employees working there. But many managers aren't located there. My first line of management was several states and at least 1000 miles away. And he managed people in several states. IBM wouldn't even let him travel to meet his people in person.

review_title: Great people, very good benefits, flexible hours, growth opportunity, stress.
job_title: Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The people are great - some of the best people in the industry in terms of work ethic, can-do attitude, helpfulness and competency.  The work environment is pretty good -- cubes, decent equipment, comfortable, on-site cafeteria with decent food.  Vacation: I've worked with IBM for 25 years and get 5 weeks paid vacation, plus sick leave.
cons: The corporate focus is to make money for the shareholders and executives.  Employees are simply expendable resources, and are squeezed to do way too much with way too little.  If you're not a top performer, your life can be miserable until you quit or are forced out.

review_title: IBM is like the best spouse to be with, but he or she may divorce you at any point!
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Essex, VT
pros: Great talented and friendly people!  Lots of flexibility in organizing one's work, choosing projects, deciding how much  one want to get involved, etc... .  Lots of resource at your disposal!  Within IBM I always felt very protected and respected.  Great benefits.
cons: Frequent layoffs lead to constant  rumors true or false,  which lead to a state of fear.  Employees tend to forget what they have; instead focus on what they could lose and often become paralyzed.

review_title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
job_title: ERP Training Consultant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Great benefits (health, dental, special needs support, etc.)
Great co-workers (for the most part - - there have been a few bad apples)
Flexible work schedule (project dependent)
cons:
A lot of overhead administrivia (both weekly and yearly)
Disappointing bonus structure
Yearly merit increases are a joke
Management/organizational structure fluctuates too frequently

review_title: So so !
pros:
Very social, nice co workers, loads of projects to choose from, working hours are variable and they offer home working possibilities. 
Good place to start when in a new country, the HR department is very helpful with new comers.
Nice as a startersjob, not to stay for a longer period!
Co-financed trainings and studies by company. 
L&D and IT departments are very good and helpful.
cons:
Stress and backlogs, mismanagement to it's core and friends politics.
People are in leading positions who clearly do not belong. 
Growth within company is almost non existent if you do NOT speak their native language.
Overtime is not paid out but always Time4Time.
Salary is very low in comparison to the rest of the bpo's.

review_title: I loved the opportunity to drive my work and career in almost any direction I desired.
job_title: Client Technical Specialist in Glendale, CA
pros: From a technical point of view, your learning opportunities are unbounded.  Through training and job experience, even an "off" day can provide a chance to learn.  With solutions focus, working on one product area will almost certainly lead to learning about some other area.  People are great!  People are helpful and have a willingness to mentor, or be mentored.
cons: With mobile offices, you may be separated physically from a team, so be ready to use tools to feel connected.  Still a huge bureaucracy, so getting through or following processes can be frustrating.  The elephant is still learning how to dance.  No longer is being good at your job a guarantee you will be able to keep that job.

review_title: Nice muticultural company
pros: IBM is a multicultural company, it offers good career opportunities in a wide range of jobs and several benefits. If you are multi-lingual, you will be able to speak all the languages you know! You can learn a job from zero and move to different departments. Great team-buildings, company parties, great people in general. You can work on bank holidays and/or week-ends and get extra holiday or money on your next salary. Decent medical insurance.
cons: The salaries are not the highest, but that might be because of the country I am currently working in. At the time I didn't negotiate my salary, which is not high but covers all my expenses and allows me to save some money. Currently over-loaded with work, not enough people as the company is not going through its best moment.

review_title: Financial Analyst (Expense)
pros: Great job to gain valuable experience and the agile principles that corporate has implemented show promise for better management in the future. Also, great place for young professionals as there are many recent college graduates at the office. One of the best work-life balances I've seen for an entry level position as there are ample opportunities to work from home/remotely and paid time off is good for entry level.
cons: High turnover for employees (leaving for better opportunities, not fired) and even small changes can take months to become implemented. Even in Rochester, cost of living is essentially the same as MSP but employees are not compensated as such. Not the only option but the best option to make a salary that is comparable to an FA in the MSP area is to move to New York where cost of living is much higher as well.

review_title: One of the best company to work with
pros:
1. I am working in a company that has set the direction for the entire industry in the last 100 plus years.
2. Most of the upcoming technologies and related learning available for you to try and learn.
3. IBM stress on innovation and the transformation of the company working well and the results are visible.
4. IBM technologies are going to touch billions of people and your job is safe at IBM if you are ready to develop your skills and adapt to changes in the industries.
5. I enjoy the work life balance and flexibility in my role.
6. There is no micro management and enjoy the freedom to take responsible decisions.
7. A good environment and learn and progress.
cons: 1. A few of those who supports mission critical clients don't get the proper work life balance because they are supposed to connect to client environment whenever there is a critical issue.

review_title: Time to run away from IBM
job_title: Global Marketing Program Manager in Boston, MA
pros: There are no longer any 'Pros' to working at IBM. The company continues to loose customers and market share, the endless cycle of budget cuts, layoffs and increased expectations as eroded the last shreds of decency from the company. People are looking to either get out or protect themselves from the next layoff and seasoned professionals are being let go and replaced with young inexperienced people at 1/2 the salary.
cons: To many to list. The pressure is unrelenting, no one in marketing does any actual marketing they simply take numbers and information, drop them into powerpoint decks or incredibly myopic 'funnel charts' and 'spin the numbers'. Good, decent, seasoned professionals that have spend years trying to right the ship are being let go and replaced by inexperienced college grads and yet management wants to know why the numbers are off, why the pipeline isn't healthier. Marketing is told to sell and promote solutions that do not actually exist and if they do, don't work. The company is all about 'cloud solutions' but the cloud solutions suffer from poor architecture and constant outages.

pros:

2. Most of the upcoming technologies and related learning available for you to try and learn.

review_title: Transformation to the Cloud world is never easy
pros: The amount of business acumen across industries, languages and cultures is invigorating. There is no problem that cannot be solved - or so it seems. According to IBM's founder's view that "...every problem mankind is confronted with, can be solved, if people only THINK..." is embodied in how this large organism works every day. You get to contribute to solving problems like cancer, water shortages, production impasses, irrigation systems and many more with the solutions you help build. It is very rewarding to play a small - and sometimes not so small - part in solving bib problems.
cons: It is a big company and not for the faint-of-heart. You need to show persistence, conviction - and, yes, success - to get others to see the world your way. If you are looking for instant gratification, this one is not for you. Chances are, that the people around you are way smarter than you.

review_title: A new IBM
pros:
There are so many reasons to work at IBM. IBM has been there for 106 years for now, and all these years IBM has done something transformational. I am a re-hire and proud to work with IBM. Other than your BAU activities, you can do many more things which you are interested at. Your background doesn't matter here, if you have the right attitude towards something. You can work on Watson, Blockchain, Cloud computing, Data Science, Design Thinking, anything which you would like to learn.

IBM is also launching global events internally which is putting all IBMers on a single platform to collaborate and create something new. Our team participated in a Space Renovation event and won a grant of $5,000 for renovating our workplace. That is just awesome.
cons: Some cost cutting in terms of facilities, but I believe cost cutting is better than layoffs. If savings can save some jobs, I  am ready for it.

review_title: Not bad but not many people are able to understand the strategy and vision of company
pros:
Flexible working place
Nice colleague, supportive and friendly
Great HR team, helpful, competent
Easy to reach agreements with management, ready to negotiate and support
cons:
Low level of skills and business acumen in many employees. 
Company is changing drastically. Few years ago even a hairdresser could become an IT specialist if they spoke an extra language except English. But nowadays if you want a good job, well paid you need to be very skilled. Low-skilled jobs are declining. If you get to higher band the compensation is beyond competitive. See the upline managers, no one or very few have left the company which there is an indication that higher role are well paid.

review_title: No longer a good employer for technical career.  A husk hollowed out by corporate.
pros: Good reputation, and plenty of scope for taking different roles and moving around.   Generally very good quality colleagues to work with - there is very little 'dead wood' here apart from the internal IBM bureaucracy.
cons:
Poor morale due to promised bonuses and payrises not being delivered to high performers, despite record profits.  Constant pressure to book all hours of the week, but no overtime and scant recognition either financial or otherwise.  In particular the management are driving the environment and morale to the bottom to encourage higher levels of voluntary attrition.
Mobility requirement in services business puts a lot of pressure on family life and there's no understanding or appreciation from any level of management.  That's OK if compensation and morale is good - but it isn't.

review_title: Fear of job loss is everywhere - why would we expect to be exempt?
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
IBM has long ago lost the concept of commitment  being bi-directional. It expects more commitment from workers than it gives in return. That said, I think it is better than most companies. IBM does not shy away from dumping valuable employees but it probably does not pick that course as fast as many companies.

I can only speak for one small part of the software side but I think IBM does try to encourage people to try new things and give them some time to come up to speed.
cons: A very secretive place regarding job actions.  People simply vanish and when someone does vanish the people who work nearby seldom ask questions.

review_title: A 2009 Update...
job_title: Graduate IT Consultant in London, England
pros:
- Big projects with big clients
- Not hit by the credit crunch as badly as rivals in the marketplace
- Still investing in training budgets and not laying of lots of staff in the UK
cons:
- Payrises and promotions frozen for a year in the UK. A limited promotions cycle is apparently happening but with no payrises
- Salaries at the lower levels are not increasing as much as they should, and new graduates now start on more than many current employees (despite the aforementioned pay freeze)
- Removal of the final salary for older employees demonstrates the changes to the atmosphere at IBM where things are more individually focused.

review_title: Raises hard to come by
pros: Great technology and leading edge stuff in the hardware area.  Working with IBM Research can give you a good feeling about how you fit within the company.
cons: Promotions/raises few and far between.  Most advances seem to be saved for acquisitions in order not to loose key members of the new company.  Internal promotions are almost non-existent, and even though the company is making record revenues/profits, very little of that is being seen at the grunt level.  Hurts morale to see the company making massive profits and to be told either a) cut backs need to occur, or b) no raises again this year.

review_title: Good place to start but that's it
job_title: Inside Software Sales in Smyrna, GA
pros:
- Never ending training available as long as you seek it. 
- No matter what, IBM has a great reputation with large companies and some SMB. 
- Great benefit package (medical, vacation, personal days, flexibility)
cons:
- Company is huge therefore the visibility of your business unit is limited to the ivory tower in NY. 
- If you are talented and make your numbers, your manager will most likely not let you move however if you do not perform the same scenario applies. It's very hard to move. 
- IBM lacks a CRM software and the entire business runs on an excel sheet. 
- The administrative tasks take up too much of your time. 
- Highly layered management. Sometimes makes you wonder what certain roles are for.

review_title: Innovation no more
pros: Brand and company are great to have on your resume, everyone knows big blue.
cons:
Innovation in the company is less and less the focus is shifting more and more to cater to wall street.  The days of ibm being a company of thinkers and great innovators is long gone.
For employees especially American based, every day is lived in fear that today will be your last.
Raises and bonuses even for top performers are below standards if even given at all.  Negotiate up front only newer employees from outside have remotely competitive base salaries, once in be prepared to live with that salary regardless of duties position or band prerequisites.  If cost of living and above average performance combined  is worth 1 or 2% a year then this is the place for you.

review_title: IBM rewards results not efforts!   Really ?

review_title: Good work experience!
job_title: Client Technical Professional in League City, TX

cons: Working remote with such a huge company does vastly limit the ability to develop strong networks throughout the company. review_title: Good company with long history, but some concerns for future direction
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Given the size and breadth of the company, there are many opportunities for career growth. Generally well-respected company at least gets you a foot in the door with clients. Constantly re-inventing itself to stay relevant and ahead of the curve. Flexible work options (e.g., work from home) although this is changing and shifting to greater emphasis on physically being in the same office with your team.
cons: Constantly re-inventing itself means frequent churn, in some area more than others. Quick to cut funding (marketing, projects, etc.) in order to make quarterly targets. Along the same lines, there are many jobs pushed offshore which can cause unease -- and goes against the push to have teams co-located.

review_title: A great company that has gone down the tubes
pros:
Company Reputation
Excellent medical benefits
Moving between divisions used to be easy (right now it is hard because IBM is laying people off (Called Resource Action (RA) in IBM parlance)
cons:
Pay raises and promotions are slower than others
Work from home, which had been one of the mainstays, is being cancelled
Very tightly defined roles -- you are pre-sales only, and penalized for giving after sales support. This hurts both your and the company's reputation
Tech team is under the thumb of sales, so it can't produce on its own. If you have a bad seller (e.g., can't close, won't hunt), you will be penalized and held accountable for their performance
In my last group, management was always hunting for someone to throw under the bus if a deal didn't close. Twice, I was asked to say who was responsible for the loss of sale. At other companies I have worked, it was viewed as a team effort and we trained tech people to improve.

review_title: Career and Growth at IBM
pros:
1. You get an opportunity to work on your corner of interest, even though you are working on some thing else. How? You can opt for some stretch assignment and explore new skills or work on your choice/interest of skill set.

3. Growth in career is easy at IBM. How ? Lot of Certifications and online courses are available within IBM. Also adapting to new skills and opportunities to implement the same are easy in IBM
4. Employee friendly environment. How? Flexible timings, work from home/remote location options
cons: 1. Technical events do happen but the entry to other IBMers is limited due to number constraint. So only a few get a chance to attend these events. We need more such events and should be open to more IBMers.

review_title: Flexible & Good Remuneration
job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Dublin, Dublin

Competitive salary
Nice people

review_title: Good impressions of a well established international corporate business
pros: IBM has impressed me with their commitment to diversity.  The company has so many interesting projects in development and combine viewpoints from international employees as well as those within the US.  The resources available on site are quite sufficient for research and personal development and the location of the site is ideal for anyone interested in live music, making for a good work/life balance opportunity.
cons: Apparently there are some divisions that do work longer hours, but I have not experienced this personally.  I find that those who work longer weeks are a bit too committed to their work.  I have found that the managers are quite flexible when it comes to their employees' schedules.

review_title: IBM is innovating but employees don't always benefit from its success
pros: Real innovation, global company that takes new opportunities very seriously. The research work going on at IBM is perhaps the most cutting-edge in IT and even in other industries. IBM has a tremendous cash-cow in zSeries machines and can continue to capitalize on it for years to come. This will finance other projects .
cons: If you have not gone above grade 10, your salary will not match your abilities or qualifications. Moreover, cost cutting has become a culture so pervasive that even after a great quarterly result, senior managers are asked to freeze hiring, travel budgets and call off international meetings. Hardly anyone can travel in business any longer, even senior execs. I've seen Sr VPs sitting in open space offices -- these are people with 100s of reports. Something is severely screwed up when seniority no longer has any rewards.

review_title: Great place to start.  If you're a white man, get out with your 10 year anniversary gift.
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member (Band 10) in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: IBM is a great place to work, if you are a minority or a woman.  If you're a woman and show the slightest spark of competence, you will fly past your male counterparts, whether or not you deserve it.  Because of this, there are so many horrendous first and second level managers, as well as Senior and STSM level technical leaders.
cons: The only way to get into the top ranks is to be the toady of a mid-level manager.  If you are really unfortunate, you will work for an EO candidate who will surely take credit for your accomplishments.  If you are really lucky, you'll work for one of the dwindling number of career managers (30+ years with the company) who will be straight with you.

review_title: IBM Needs to recognize their employees, something they are failing miserably at presently.
pros: Other than the benefits, there is very little to say positive about IBM as an employer.
cons: Most of the employees are treated very unfairly. Management treats the employees like they are a commodity for them to make advancement in their careers. I have worked for IBM for 12 years, and have never been thanked for my years of service. After making 29 Billion dollars this past quarter, it would be nice to get some compensation comparable to other companies. In this regard, IBM is very bad, where less than 1% wage increases are the norm. IBM is also paying their employees the industry average as a maximum, with the only way to get above average is being a top performer. A top performer is something that maybe 2% of employees receive. As a result the other 98% will remain at average compensation with almost no chance of ever seeing another increase.

review_title: IBM stimulating work environment, needs better management.
pros: The pay at IBM Canada seems to be about at par with current market salaries. You also have many opportunities to develop and work with cool and ground breaking products. If you enjoy a challenge and want to work in a stimulating environment, IBM is the place to be.
cons: People tend to be hired into management generally due to their seniority and not necessarily due to their skills. This does create an ideal meritocracy, which I believe would be the better platform for promotion. This creates managers that are not suited for their position; they may have been great coders but may not necessarily be suited for a management role.

review_title: IBM research is a good place to be... but...
job_title: Research Staff Member in Hawthorne, NY
pros: IBM Research has a lot of smart people, working on a variety of projects. Its easy to find a project thats deep and interesting enough fairly quickly. There is a strong focus on getting your research to make a financial impact - this can of course be a pro or a con depending on your POV. High level of independence to select approaches to selecting problems/projects and also in choosing approaches to solve them.
cons: Although the project you're working on may be making a large impact (within and outside the organization), apart from a couple of your peers and your immediate manager nobody really cares or seems to notice your contributions. Its very very easy to just get lost here - this is similar to a complaint I had while in academia.

review_title: IT Specialist @ IBM Global Technology Services

cons: performance evaluation is very subjective, career path will be most likely be determined by business condition and opportunity - it is possible for some people to do the same things over the years due to this rule, hardcore technology company - not fit for those who would like to pursue IT management career track, it is really vague about the criterion to advance our career

review_title: Very challenging job, requiring more work to be performed many evenings and into the weekends
pros: Enjoy working with people who have a passion for the jobs they perform. Most IBMers are very knowledgeable in their areas of expertise and will help you wherever possible.
cons: As in most companies, I believe we are working far longer hours then ever before. If you are an exempt employee, your hourly rate drops significantly due to the excessive nights and weekends worked. As much as you earn, when you look at an hourly rate, it's not always that impressive.

review_title: Worlds worst company by far
pros: Really can’t think of any
cons:

Sad really, but just an awful place

review_title: Watson Health Sales

review_title: Any monkey can do this and they are the only ones promoted

review_title: Very unstable company

review_title: Where is Robin Hood when you need him?
job_title: Project Manager in East Fishkill, NY

I took advantages of educational programs (offered in the past) and IBM paid for and helped me earn a degree.  The old IBM was very good to work for, the new IBM will not give you one morsel more than they think they need to.

Basically promotions and meaningful raises, at least at the worker bee level, are as rare and far between. review_title: Never take a job at IBM unless you are in desperate need of a job.

review_title: IBM India WAS a good place four years back
