Bureaucracy! Too many layers of management. This tends to create a bubble up effect, when an issue arises at the staff level, by time  the executives are engage they are told everything is under control. Meanwhile the fire rages out of control.  Because of this, most executives seem out of touch with the teams on the front lines. The executives always tend to get low ratings on the employee surveys. 

Also, work / life balance doesn't really exist. Most people that want to advance in their career are working 65+ hours per week.

review_title: Great opportunities.  Sub-optimal processes
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in London, England
pros:
Include:
- choose (for the most part) what you want to do
- feels like being self-employed but with a regular salary
- constant reinvention
- market leader; in almost every field in which IBM chooses to do business
- intellectually stimulating.

You will be working with lots of very bright, motivated people.
cons:
Some of the internal processes are cumbersome to say the least.
An obsession with quarterly reporting, billable hours and too little focus on building the sales pipeline.
It's probably easier to get promoted by moving outside of IBM, especially at senior level.
If you are on a long term project far from home, travel can be debilitating.

review_title: Performance Assessments and Contributions Issues
pros: Originally? training, education, paid certification, bonuses, profit sharing, effective team meetings, clear communication through the management chains.
cons: Now? absolutely none of the above. Everyone is burned out, hiring freezes, no education budgets, no certification budgets, minimal growth profit sharing, no band promotions, cross team collaboration is dismal, etc.

review_title: Company needs some serious fixing and fast
pros: I can work from home AND they give me a Lenovo(R) laptop to use for completing my work
cons: Technology, processes, administrative overhead, large corporate politics, lack of quality reimbursement of actual business expenses.

review_title: Valuable experience
pros:
Unique opportunity for research within a semi-cooperate environment, where projects range from fundamental research to product prototype/proof of concept.

Colleagues are world class researchers with very diverse background and always happy to chime in with their expertise.

I was grateful for the choice of using gnu/linux on the company laptop. The facility was top-notch, especially the cafeteria --- if it wasn't for the early closing time (16:00), then again one could argue that this is done in order to promote healthy work-life balance. ;)
cons:
IBM is truely a venerable company. Unfortunatly this implies that there is a lot of regulation for various things. While I felt that in Resarch a lot of effort is being made to circumvent this, the sheer size of the company can be felt in the amount of rules and regulations.

However, once I was accustomed to said regulation did not bother me as much as in the beginning.

review_title: Technical Support.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Great place to build a career, a lot of opportunities to switch jobs.     Global presence, you can switch work locations.    Opportunity to work from home office.
cons: Yearly review process was brutal, management would get together and fight it out on which employee was eligible for what.  (I heard that this has changed starting this year, 2015, it was a source of many sleepless nights)      Meet a lot of managers that had no idea what was going on, did not understand technology and seemed to be a lot more interested in their own careers then moving the company forward.

review_title: Poor CEO + Low Morale = Avoid!
pros:
- Decent benefits package
- Competitive base salary
- Name Recognition on your Resume when you inevitably decide to leave
cons:
- Low morale that keeps getting lower
- Lack of employee support from leadership, leading to widespread disapproval of C-suite
- Corporate Policies which indicate mistrust of practitioners (guilty until proven innocent)
- Archaic evaluation and promotion practices
- No interest in your personal career or retaining top talent
- Shrinking talent pool due to lack of innovative work and unwillingness to promote top talent without meeting preset "years served" guidelines
- Year-end bonuses are virtually non-existent and "raises" barely match inflation
- No corporate culture or identity

review_title: Manager
pros: you can work remote but you work more hours and by the time you are finished you make 10/h they do have excellent vendor training
cons: IBM abuses and lies to customers - they promised jobs in Dubuque Iowa and they brought in people with no experience from Africa India and you name it. Management was composed of husband and wives teams, some even divorced found girlfriends that were promoted fast. Buddy system is so unfair that if you have a degree and are experienced you get killed by these survivors and humiliated. The HR system is composed of the same teams and they support these managers. It is so corrupt that you will waste your career. All jobs are offshored and there is no communication as some even have us e-mails very very very very bad! and your good people get fired for no reason. The executives and managers need to be fired money needs to go into a fund for the bonuses they have stolen by firing employees and HR needs to go. HR needs to all be fired they discriminate and abuse employees that are afraid to speak up!

review_title: So many chiefs, so far from the customer...
pros:
A great place to get 2-3 years of experience. 
Some very good people who care and work hard to do the right thing.  
If you're just out of college or have experience in a related solution or industry, there's a good chance to get hired.  
If you're upper management, you're apparently safe from the age, experience and skills mandates driving much of the current workforce churn.
cons:
Very demanding work environment, very cost obsessed culture
CFO's and accounting run the show down to who, where and when of the the work force and the compensation.
Almost all of the executives are life-long IBM'ers - like 30+ years  - confusing when you see excellent employees let go because they want people with less experience?
Front-end solutions do not mesh well with back end processes

review_title: Great environment, but company is struggling
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer (Band 8) in Dublin, Dublin
pros: People are great, bright and nice, there is a good work life balance, top technologies and interesting projects. Facilities are very good. There is this great culture in a +100 year old company, teams are solid, everyone covers each other backs, from engineers to managers.
cons: Cons are all about money. Company is having a hard time, trying to adapt to the markets. There isn't a lot of money around. Pay is below market average, bonuses are a joke, salary increases are very hard to get, and there not enough perks (almost none).

review_title: Mixed feelings
pros:
+ Exciting place for a grad to start their career, but they over-recruit and most had minimal work to do (hence able to have 5 or more 15 min coffee breaks a day!)
+ Big company, looks good on your CV
+ Made many friends 
+ Pay was good
+ Work life balance was awesome, never overtime
cons:
- Waves of restructuring and low morale let all the good people go
- People abuse working from home and are unreachable 
- Your team is generally all around Aus and abroad so expect many phone meetings but never meeting anyone in person (Can be isolating if your team is such as mine was)
- Management lies about restructuring and stability of teams 
- Difficult to change roles or progress to different departments. Was stopped by my manager
- No coffee/tea - bare minimum facilities and equipment

review_title: A look inside after 10 years...
job_title: Software Development Manager/Software Architect in Hortolândia
pros: Very nice pack of perks and in some areas, flexibility for Home Office. However, this flexibility changed a lot starting mid 2016, where thousands of employees were pulled back into the offices. Depending on your network, you can explore various career paths within the company.
cons: Huge bureaucracy, inefficient processes and it's very hard to get a promotion (specially being a GBS/GTS employee) in the short/medium term.

review_title: IBMs Unique Programs
pros: In addition to being a part of a global technology company that actually creates products and gets patents, IBM has many programs for employees to help families, working parents, and those that want to grow themselves.  One that I recently participated in was the IBM Corporate Service Corps which is IBMs Corporate Service Responsibility initiative.  After being accepted into the program, my team was deployed to India for one month to work with a non-profit to help farmers get their corps to market and get a fair price.  This program sends IBMers all over the world to assist with global business problems.  It's a  perk for employees and another way in which IBM is helping the world.
cons: All corporate jobs have bureaucracy, and IBM is no different.  You learn to accept re-orgs every year (seems like) and things are always changing.  Lot's of new products and services to keep track of, but it keeps you learning.

review_title: Overall Good Company, Some Cleanup Needed
pros: Very good employer. Good Work-Life Balance. Immense scope of learning new technologies. Pretty open door culture. People respect each other. Clients behave good because of the brand value.
cons: Very average package. Manager's company, redundant non-functioning management layer doing PMO level jobs without any relevant contribution. While training give a large insight to newer emerging technologies, there isn't enough projects to utilize those skills. Once you change projects all your contributions are drained down, you start from scratch in new project. No credibility is carried over. Rating system has no sync with increments / promotions. Promotions are largely document based, not performance based. Innovative initiatives are spreadsheet fillers for Managers, real idea generators are not valued.

review_title: Low pay is High Attrition
pros: Flexible Hours, decent "Off the books" benefits like unlimited sick days (As long as you get your work done) and the option to work from home. The area can be a pro if you like living in the middle of nowhere.
cons: Pay is quite low, especially considering the mandatory 44 hours a week. Any time you talk to someone about their project, people will respond with "Dumpster Fire". Every is overworked and feels like their project isn't going well. Attrition is extremely high, you can see cubes empty almost every week.  The area can certainly be a con, if you aren't used to living in the middle of nowhere. Most things are an hour or so away. Cost of living isn't very low, especially not as low as a recruiter may try to make you think.

review_title: Old
pros:
The salary it’s ok but you might not get a raise when you want it, for me it was delayed by a year.
People are great but you can find great people in other companies also.
cons:
Very bureaucratic 
You need a business reason for everything, even a laptop if it is not the standard one, free courses are wothless and paid courses are almost never approved, on the other side money are wasted by management in some stupid ways. 
Ussualy you will be stuck woth old technologies bad clients which the management entertains in the bad practices.

review_title: Lots of opportunities but very big.
pros: Big company presents lots of opportunities.  Most of the people I worked with were bright and good to work with.  It's such a big company that there are lots of different areas to work in, and I believe moving around is not too hard if you're qualified.
cons: Being a small cog in a big machine - ocassional bureaucratic headaches.  The pay was adequate, but perhaps felt a bit on the low end vs. competitors.  Benefits felt a little stingy.  It was a bit disapointing when I was there that a big portion of bonuses were tied to the division's performance and the overall firm's performance, so in a time when parts of the business I had nothing to do with were under performing, my compensation was was lower.

review_title: My name's Sam.  I'm a multi-millionaire, and you're not.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Employee discounts with many of the business partners, including auto companies, financial institutions, insurers, cellular phone providers, large retailers, and many others.  It's especially nice at Christmas time.  There are also discounts on IBM items, but they are rarely used because IBM doesn't exactly focus on consumer items.
cons: Many, many of their engineering jobs have been offshored.  The older workers mostly feel they're doomed to being laid off after the next quarterly report that disappoints the analysts.  The company is more than happy to replace these workers with younger ones or foreigners who cost less.  The stock price RIGHT NOW is the most important thing, always.

review_title: Life at IBM today
job_title: Sales Specialist in New York, NY
pros: A company motivated by innovation and research-the crimeajewel in the crown of any high tech company in the information age.As we move to NGN fibre networks all over the US and Europe,and download speeds of 100mbs become the norm for everyone,and all tech devices become ip enabled,(with the ability to communicate with each other-even though manafactured differently by different companies with different designs),the pace of the information age and the demands on people in both their work and home life will increase dramaticly.In this world of instant information and feedback, innovation and speed to market in a compeditive enviroment will be key to corporations and SME's winning out.
cons: Long hours.Too many meetings.Not enough promotion prospects.

review_title: IBM Jobs In Transition
job_title: Advisory Program Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I worked for IBM to obtain training and opportunity. Even though there have been significant cutbacks in funding for education, IBM is still a good place if you need to further your education, (e.g.BA, Phd). The work at IBM is challenging and looks good on a resume.
cons: No matter what career path you take, expect to get the feeling that you will be laid off any moment. Layoffs are the norm as work transitions outside the US.  Pay and benefits also change constantly so expect to spend a lot of your time with financial planning and understanding health insurance terms.  Pay is OK for employees hired with upper level degrees.  Don't expect recognition if you earn an upper level degree once hired.

review_title: IBM
pros:
competitive salary and benefits
flexible work arrangements
global opportunities
comprehensive work locations if located near a primary office (cafeterias, lounges, kitchens, etc)
solid results even in poor economy
stable company with good reputation
Volunteer opportunities and company support of them
cons:
high emphasis on outsourcing US jobs and training of your replacements
poor management execution of IBM values and processes
failure to reward technically skilled professionals (more advancement based on politics or popularity)
sneaky layoffs (resource actions) that are designed to avoid regulations and reporting requirements
technical work often focused on proprietary products that are not standards based, thus some knowledge is not highly valuable outside of company
management does not understand technical issues or complexity
too much management churn/movement
very limited accountability for managerial mistakes
too much finger pointing from management towards engineering
high emphasis on rewarding management and sales but low emphasis on rewarding engineering

review_title: If you are looking at First 5 to 6 Years of your Career Start  - BooM (you at the right place)
pros:
- Awesome Flexibility (Work from any where, nobody cares as long as work is done)
 - Great Learning Opportunities
 - Flexibility to choose the domain / technology after you have spent some time in your current role.
cons:
- If you are growing internally / Moving Laterally - No Band Change.
 - Basic Benefits to the Minimum
 - All though this is stupid  - No Tea / Coffee, No Subsidized Food, Bad Canteen Areas, at many sites it is usually in parking lot or  basement.
 - BAD COMPENSATION

review_title: In US, pays just enough that you won't leave until you are fired
pros:
Work with some very smart and wonderful people.  The people "in the trenches" are the best around.  I have really enjoyed the teams I have worked with inside the company.  Very smart and hard working people.
Mentoring is available depending on "who you know"
Some online training can still be had for free.  Paid training is extremely limited and you need to take classes on your own time
Depending on the job, project & manager decent work/life balance and time off can be had
cons:
Lots of jobs in US being eliminated
Work/Life balance can be an issue.  Especially when working the global clock (needing to be available to meet with teams in all time zones).
Enormous pressure to meet deadlines/cut costs, often not realistic.

review_title: Learning opportunities
pros:
- breadth and depth of the industries you can work on
- opportunity to travel if desired
- many clever people you can learn from
- great to build foundations
- graduate salary is very competitive to market rate
- many learning opportunities
cons:
- salary is not at the higher end of the market rate (it's at the average end)
- performance rating can be subjective depending on manager you get
- depending on demand, may not get a role you like
- lots of red tape to do in your own time
- work life balance sometimes hard to find if project is behind schedule

review_title: Technology leader reinvents market over and over again
job_title: Software Renewals Sales Team Leader in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Working for IBM is working for one of the most innovative and successful technology leaders, who is around for over 100 years by now. The brand name is established well and their smarter planet initiative reached beyond the technology savvy audience. Inventions such as IBM Watson excites not just geeks and science nerds, but society. All in all IBMers are proud to work for the "Big Blue".
cons: IBM is to big to even know what the company is doing all over the world, as a "regular" employee at least. Many internal processes and tools are used to run - to many for some. Products and services sold could be easily used inside IBM, but I guess to implement things at a worldwide level and such a diverse scale of employees and management takes time.

review_title: 2-Year New College Hire, Disillusioned.
pros: Big company, Ok health benefits, the illusion of job security.
cons:
Really frugal (cheap) company, no snacks, employees are required to work on old/outdated computer equipment (lots of developers still forced to work on Windows XP), and managers don't seem to appreciate your input or innovations. I actually applied the Joel Test to the area I worked at within IBM, and found that they failed miserably.

If you're a Software Engineer, you'll most likely find yourself working with outdated technologies and programming frameworks mandated by non-technical executives. And if you haven't heard, IBM is laying off people left and right at this time, with the possibility of more layoffs coming towards the end of this year. Definitely not the best company to be at right now.

review_title: Not your father's IBM
pros: I worked for IBM for 26 years, now retired.  Over the years I was well compensated and had many opportunties to advance.  Had several job changes over the years, last being a software engineer for the Information Management of the Software Group.  This was the best job I had.  Worked from home 100%, had very competent co-workers and mostly good managers.
cons: Over the years, benefits were slowly taken away, to the point where they seemed to be squeezing ever last thing they could take from the employees.  Just one example, workers at home were compensated for internet access when I stated, but the last year I worked, they stopped.  Their reasoning was everyone would have their own internet anyway so why should IBM compensate, they gave us the option to go to a work site, but since that was 90 miles away, that really wasn't an option.

review_title: Excellent skills development, fantastic global experience
pros: 1) Challenging work 2)Excellent global experience 3) You can gain a variety of assignments in very different business units without changing companies
cons: 1) Finance runs the company so it's impossible to get reasonable resources -- people or pencils-- 2) Bureaucracy is rampant, so it takes a long time to get anything done and a sense of urgency is squashed 3) Leaders (even mid level executives) are generally not trusted to do the right thing and every decision is scrutinized. This leads to the disenfranchisement of the leadership team and the feeling that they don't own their decisions. You can surmise what the downstream effect of that is.

review_title: A solid company, but impersonal
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Boulder, CO
pros:
Very well respected in the industry
Solid financial results allows freedom to do new things
Almost universal work from home policy which allows employees to spend time with family
cons:
Work from home policy means that most teams are geographically dispersed and in some cases you may never even meet your boss or coworkers in person.
Policy decisions are often made by the institution - i.e. no one stands behind them so they cannot be challenged or discussed.
The power is all in management - the workers are just resources.
Yearly layoff policy trims thousands off the payroll silently on a regular basis Q)  "Where's Joe?"  A) "Didn't you hear?  He left the company in the last Resource Action"

review_title: Big Blue is having its blue fading but it is still Big Blue,
pros: IBM still is a company with an amazing story of success and still have amazing people. If you are in the beginning, it has a lot to offer given it's culture and worldwide organisation.
cons: Given the pressure in costs and competition, IBM no longer offers what made it so special in the past. Your performance counts but your salary should not be in the upper side of sigma. People is not as valuable as it used to be. It's values changed significantly and it is not what we used to know about it years back.

review_title: Center of Incompetence
pros:
Possibilities to work from home (depends heavily on your manager though... but the corporate policy favors it!)

Work pressure is not too high
cons:
* I should say this job is in the Center of Incompetence, not in the main IBM Madrid office
Horrible office: looks depressing, bad and noisy airco, no decent lunch spaces, not enough microwaves, no free coffee (people bring their own coffee machines which looks amateuristic and often leads to unsafe situations like machines that stay on all night), no relax spaces, no free parking spaces, ...
* very bad salary (1333€/month) given the requirements they set (Bachelor/master, experience, speak 2+ languages fluently)
* quite long office hours (9.00-18.00). 9.00-17.00 seems more reasonable.
* constant cost cutting, even on the most ridiculous things (like a 5 internet usb sticks for 800 employees... too much lets cut on that...)
* no room for growth
* absolutely no room for salary raises
* constant pressure of lay-offs
* when IBM lays you off they dont pay you what they owe you!! If they owe you 100, they'll offer 25. Not happy? Hire a lawyer and fight 10 years in court. Since most people here are relatively poor they just take whatever IBM proposes.

review_title: Pressure cooker environment
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Armonk, NY
pros:
Big company, lots of opportunities to learn new things and career choices.
Working from Home positions!!!
cons:
IBM keeps cutting workforce in the US every year moving the work to APAC... customers do not want to deal with people who are not local to the US so they cling onto the few US resources left overloading them with work... fewer and fewer people make for very long work weeks.
The added aggravation of all the overhead activities to be performed to align with Management initiatives turns this company into the only relationship you will entertain as you won't have time for anything else

review_title: IBM
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in New Manila
pros:
Work at home, High salary range, Positive reputation, Profit sharing, Globally competitive, Advancement in research and patents. 

Outperform, get noticed and you will definitely be rewarded.
cons:
Some projects and teams lacks coordination, poor process management, poor operational management and service delivery especially with global teams. Although I  have work with excellent people from different teams, there are global teams from the asian community that are lazy, unprofessional and with poor technical knowledge. Don't get me wrong or think that I am quick to judge, but if you certainly experience group of people that commits the same mistakes or either clueless in the middle of a scheduled change, you'll understand what I mean.

Change management is not so effective. Changes are poorly documented and audited. Execution, back out and test plans in the system are mostly generic statements and not actual execution steps. 

Crossing from one BU to another is nearly impossible. This is because part of everyone's PBC is utilization.

review_title: Research Scientist Intern
job_title: Research Scientist Intern in San Jose, CA
pros: The working environment is very friendly. Each intern has his or her own space. I prefer a relatively private space compared to the open-spaced design in many IT companies in the bay area. Each Tuesday afternoon the team will get together in a tea hour to talk about everyone's ideas, progress or anything you like. The interns will have opportunity to present the work during intern as posters. In the end there will be a formal presentation summarizing what you have done in the summer, which is a good start for a paper outline. No traffic jam in the rush hours because we are in the very south.
cons: The location is the very very south of silicon valley (I think it is the most south). So if you want to stay near to your friends who work in mountain view, it is a little bit far.

review_title: Good company for it's customers but not so good for employees.
pros:
An OK place to work for sometime and learn but don't get sucked into the processes and work culture.

The brand looks good on your resume.

If you have a good manager, you can have the opportunities to explore and look for opportunities outside your current role if you are looking for a change.
cons:
With a very strong focus on meeting numbers, employee welfare takes a backseat.

Most managers are just numbers focused and don't really care about the development of people.

Salary and hikes are bad and don't meet industry standards.

Work culture is quite political and unprofessional.

Managers are encouraged and trained to only manage numbers

Too any processes and legacy systems - don't get fooled by the focus on cutting edge technologies. None of it is implemented in the organization.

review_title: All About the Money
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Use to be a great company which supported and invested in their employees and clients.  Work balance and autonomy was fantastic if you achieved.
cons: Ageism is rife.  Retrenching majority of “older” people for many years who are on six figures.  Replacing with young cheap labour.  All about the bottom line for CEO and shareholders.

review_title: Lots of opportunities if you are willing to network
pros:
- Was able to gain lots of experience very fast 
- Many opportunities to learn and gain industry experience
- Opportunities for new roles
- the company is always reinventing itself and it can be exciting to be part of that!
cons:
- Not a lot of yearly raises or bonuses
- To get a new role you need to network internally just like getting a job
- Sometimes work long hours and weekends depending on your project and role

review_title: IBM - Still The Best Company To Work For Year After Year!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
IBM is a large company with a lot of great people to work with.  The IBM community is diverse, with locations around the world with people of all races, creeds, religions and beliefs.  With all of this diversity, I think IBM has the ability to do anything it wants.  The talent pool seems endless and the opportunities that arise for its employees are there if you are motivated to go after them.  

Often when you come out of college, you think you know what you want to do, but once you start doing that job, you find that it just doesn't suit you.  IBM has many many disciplines that allow you to morph your career should you desire a change.
cons: It is a large company, and this isn't for everyone.  Still, I believe if you are motivated, the large size shouldn't be a problem.

review_title: Great benefits, if you don't mind signing over your intellectual soul...
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Durham, NC
pros: Benefits are great, work-life balance can be good if you're an efficient worker with a good manager and you leverage that.
cons: IP Agreements are extremely restrictive given the size of the company.  Since IBM is into so many different areas of development, much of what you may be interested in working on externally they could reasonably claim ownership of.  Your group may not work on anything remotely close to what you want to work on in your personal time, but IBM can still claim ownership of it because it falls under the wide open umbrella of the entire company's "actual or anticipated" business interests.

review_title: IBM Offers Long-Term Job Security But At What Cost?
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: IBM is an extremely stable company.  There is a lot of opportunity for advancement across the various towers which can help to make one's career at IBM a very long one.  I feel strongly that I could remain at IBM for the remaining 25 years of my career and retire from there, if I choose to.  Not many companies offer this level of job security.
cons: It takes a lot of effort to make any significant impacts in a company with nearly 400,000 employees.  Advancement is based almost entirely on one's influence within one's business unit and IBM in general.  It takes a great deal of effort, experience, and ability to make an impact within a company this size.  Additionally, the salaries at IBM tend to be lower than at similar companies.  The benefits help to offset this somewhat but not completely.

review_title: IBM is a tough company to grow in not for the lack of opportunities but for the abundance of talent.
job_title: Engineering Manager in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: A huge company.  Diversified options.  Something for everyone.
cons: Huge Company.  No shortage of talent.  Lets say 1% is considered the cream of the crop.  1% of 370K employees is 3.7K ppl competing for top positions.  Easy to be really good and still not make it at all.

review_title: A respectable company that needs to do some damage control before its too late.
pros: It always looks good to have IBM on your resume since it is such a respected company.  There are good, intelligent people to learn from.  IBM pushes innovation so most of their employees hold multiple patents.
cons: No one seems satisfied at IBM Tucson.  Many people have left or are looking for work outside the company.  The main reasons are compensation and career advancement.

review_title: IBM GBS Consulting: 100% utilization + poorly scoped/managed projects = NO work/life balance and LOW morale.
job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros: PERCEIVED IBM brand. Great opportunities for different types of consulting assignments, though not so much anymore due to the infighting for bill rates between organizations. Good job security but poor opportunities to grow, so if security's your only criteria in measuring a 'GREAT' company, then it's an OK place. 90% of your IBM colleagues are truly GREAT and you will learn far more from each other than the company.
cons: Consultants have NO work/life balance; just utilization targets. Period. Anyone who tells you otherwise isn't a full time consultant at IBM. Negotiate your salary VERY carefully before you sign off. Virtually NO raises once you get in, and you'll quickly find that new hires (many MUCH less experienced), make MUCH more than you do because they knew how to research and negotiate better. Also, bonuses are a joke so focus on your BASE pay.

review_title: Not a great place to advance one's career
pros:
* Timing Flexibility
* Casual Atmosphere
* Opportunity to work on any tier of technology
cons:
* Very poor compensation
* No facilities whatsoever
* Work done is often monotonous and provides no pride at all
* Endless bureaucracy
* Be prepared to be sucked up in a  frustrating and back-breaking loop of formalities if you have to travel for work... at the end of which you are made to travel in the cheapest mode possible ( each and every step required has to be researched and performed by you ) It is a clear indication that the company does not care at all about the employees.

review_title: Good People - Oppressive Management/Bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros: Smart technical people with great work ethic.  Good facilities and compensation.  Generally good work/life balance (save crunch times).  Some flexibility in working from home.  Great opportunities for learning and exposure to wide range of technologies.
cons: Acquisitions make life hell for developers.  Very limited opportunity to create and innovate  (vs acquire and integrate). Entrenched products and management make change very difficult to achieve.  Low respect for technical people (seen as replaceable resources).  Very poor project planning with unrealistic schedules and staffing.  Outsourcing trends suggest a short career shelf-life for most employees.

review_title: Different roles at IBM for over 13 years
pros: Was great early in my career, had excellent benefits, excellent talent...etc
cons:
* Gets worse every year for the non-executive workers
* Benefits have been getting worse to the point where smaller companies have better benefits now
* Most workers are either, young in their 20's (first job) or have been in the company over 30 years (there for old retirement plans). Everyone in between has left the company 
* Bonuses (profit sharing) is a joke even for highest performers (not even 5%). Promotions are even a bigger joke (4-5%). If you're not a top performer, you can go 3-4 years or more without a raise, even though your responsibilities keep increasing due to "resource actions" aka layoffs.

review_title: I work with good people, but unfortunately the company is mostly driven by meeting EPS goals.
pros: Very Smart employees, Good for gaining leadership experience, Company still has a lot of prestige (looks good on resume), Competitive Starting Salary & Benefits
cons: Slow & Tedious Promotion Process (You essentially have to write 16 essays on why you deserve a promotion and this is with the new "less cumbersome" Go Organic process).  Executive pay is tied to EPS Goals and any failure to meet those goals rolls down on employees and effects compensation.  Company changed 401(k) matching so that match is paid in lump sum to 401(k) at the end of the year.  You miss out on investment growth throughout the year and if you leave before 15 December, you don't receive any match for the entire year.

review_title: Senior Recruiter
pros: When you think of IBM, you will think of innovations, and this is what attracted me to join IBM in the first place. This organization serve as a big school for new entry and at the same time you can have a long term career where you can grow internationally within the organization. You will learn a lot working here whatever job you do and opportunities is unlimited, even if you want to explore a totally new area within the company.
cons: Large organization, every process takes time for approval. Highly competitive as the company is full of talented people. Managers/Management plays big role on your career progression.

review_title: Great people, somewhat misguided motives
pros: At IBM Research, you have the opportunity to work with some of the best research brains in the industry, and some of the most ambitious problems. The company has great global collaboration practices, so you have access to all Nobel award winners, Turing award winners, fellows and whoever you wish to reach out to. Also access to resources, and the might of a big company behind you opens up a lot of problems that smaller companies just wouldn't have the wherewithal to attempt. There's a lot to learn.
cons: Like any large organization, IBM suffers from a fair amount of bureaucracy and politics. Research is fairly insulated, yet there is an epidemic where people try to do work that makes them look smart, aligns with buzzwords instead of things that are fundamentally meaningful. The appraisal system is non-ideal and not always meritocratic. If you can shield yourself all of these and keep your focus on good work, you will be fine.

review_title: Good for work life balance, but very profit minded just like any US corporate
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Flexible working time
- Good reimbursement system
- Low bureaucratic tendencies in country
- Consider employee as an asset
- Good e-learning modules
- There is a sets of career paths, but you can also change role easily by internal hiring

If you are proactive person, and have self learning attitude, IBM is really match for you.
cons:
- Very US corporate -> capitalism
- Profit oriented
- Budget cutting for 2015 goals
- Conservative
- Very huge company (longer chain of command)
- Lotus Notes
- Passive HR
- Depends on synthetic growth (like MA, IBM kept selling their unprofitable LOB and acquire new companies)

Sometimes you feel like you don't have a say, even though IBM Indonesia is very open to your suggestions, but the chain of command is really long, so the status quo is often maintained.

review_title: Go elsewhere for marketing
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Armonk, NY
pros: Working from home, prestigious degree of technical talent, flexible schedule, brand recognition
cons: Field marketing aka demand programs a.k.a. performance marketing at this company is antiquated. Tools are dramatically out of date and slow. IBM will never be able to keep up with its more nimble competitors for this reason.

review_title: Project Manager
pros: Ability to work from home in certain positions.
cons: You are no more than an insignificant cog and a commodity at IBM. IBM is totally focused on shareholders' value and invests very little in employees. Compensation is below average, however IBM goes to great lengths to produce "industry salary reports" to show how fairly employees are supposedly compensated. IBM Global Services goes after outsourcing contracts without having resources to fulfill the contract and without consideration of the actual effort that it takes. Sales team appears to be completely disconnected from the realities of providing a service under a contract. Salaried consultants are forced to bill 50-60 hours per week (if not billing at least that much, then performance reviews suffer and your job is on the line.)

review_title: Good enough
job_title: Senior Web Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
If you get the right project will be challenging, you will be able to learn lots because there is people working there that are really smart. 
The tools of the company such as learning tools, career paths are well defined if you are into growing within the company.
cons:
The salary at the beginning could be competitive but you will not increase the income for years. 
The visibility its really narrowed to your position so growing takes lots of time. 
The yearly reviews some times are made not taking in account all the work you did or you are compared with people with other skill-set and other positions that makes sometimes a disadvantage.

review_title: Changing and transforming but many challenges remain
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
+ Name/Brand/History of success and ability to adapt to changing markets
+ Many different roles in different business units - interesting and different work in many places (just not in consulting)
+ Starting to wake up and realize cost reduction is not the way to create long-term value/growth, seeing more investment in infrastructure and people
cons:
-  Pure comedy to see other consulting firms brought in to do work with healthy expense budgets, better hardware (computers, SW) while we are supposedly an industry leading tech company
- Despite being revenue producing there are almost no raises unless you are promoted and minimal bonus pool
- Not much quality consulting work unless you work on internal projects

review_title: Great company to work for // only few minor issues
pros:
- High, competitive salary. Could not believe I was making X amount out of college.
- Access to the best training whether that be online on in person (free!)
- Great health insurance
- Good reputation . . . Everyone always looks very impressed when they find out that I work for IBM
cons:
- Ambiguity within the first year of job. Had no idea what I was doing for about 10 months
- Front line manager isn't helpful or open for questions (please note, this was with MY manager. There are about 10 others that I hear are really helpful and great leaders... I just got unlucky)

review_title: Be cautious
pros:
- Large company trying to become successful again
- Salaries are competitive
- Might be a good place for new graduates
cons:
My opinion based on conversations with a lot of friends at IBM:
- Cannot be counted on for long term stability with multiple layoffs per year.
- Layoffs appeared to be mainly talented lifers and hiring appears to be young inexperienced resources. Only time will tell how this change will work.
- A few weeks before the layoffs, IBM changed the severance policy from 2 weeks pay for every year of service to 4 weeks severance no matter how long you were there. 35 years and you still get 4 weeks of pay. To me, that should be of great concern for those interested in IBM.
- Unless the new IBM changes go very well, the stock is artificially inflated due to recent layoffs of 10's of thousands (most likely from the US) and this might be a concern as well.

review_title: This is where you study to be
pros:
IBM is one of the biggest companies there are, the opportunities are endless. 
Training, benefits.... You're 1:1 meeting with management will probably be over a coffee which gives you the intimacy necessary to tell you manager your needs vice-versa.
IBM was my first job when I had no idea what I wanted in life, all I conquered afterwards was thanks to the faith they put in me. 
If you get bored or feel like changing careers, IBM will give all the support to do so, the company had endless departments, and relocation is more than a possibility, is a reality.
cons:
Sometimes you wonder how a technology company can have 3 different tools to input extra office hours if they all do the same.
Also you have to do crazy hours sometimes, but there are pro and cons for that, because extra hours are really well payed.

review_title: "IBM Way"
pros:
Higher pay compared to some.  About on par for other large companies though.
PTO/Health is VERY standard.
cons:
Long working hours (based on team).  But it seems fairly consistent that most are asked to regularly work 50+ hours.  Salaried employees especially.

The "IBM way" phrase that gets thrown around is their way of saying "work longer, for no extra pay, because you work for IBM" (which clearly means you're superior to the competition and should be proud).

They have no real structure, or company goals, other than money.  

In my orientation class, they ACTUALLY said "What does IBM do?  We don't know, but help us define it."..... They actually do not have any core.

Others: 
 You wont be able to move within the company.  If you do well, your boss will not allow you to move, which they must sign off on.  
Consistent fear of RAs for many.
They are very sneaky in their hiring process, in terms of their expectations of you.

review_title: Great Place to Learn
pros: Knowledge Repository. If anyone is interested in learning about Information Technology IBM is the place for them. Senior advisors,architects,  senior delivery managers etc have such in depth understanding of the field that is a pleasure to be around them. Learning opportunity is immense.
cons: Below par industry standard package.  I mean way below par. This is in India I am talking about. Lack of adequate infrastructure at workplace.

review_title: Hopeless Business Unit
pros:
Flexible working hours
Proximity to incredible researchers
Plenty of practitioner-level talent
cons:
It's a hopeless, confused situation for some Business Units. Middle and upper management should be replaced entirely. No strategy, no sense of direction or purpose, and our competition is eating us alive. A lot of management promotions will leave you scratching your head, too. Like, are your products are stagnant? Do you hire ridiculously bad managers? Is your staff morale in the toilet? Have you experienced more attrition than anyone before you? Promoted.

On top of it all, good luck trying to get a promotion, access to new software, or even a steady supply of napkins or cups in the kitchen. IBM can't afford it.

review_title: It's what you make it
job_title: Data Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
- Access to infinite resources to learn, grow, and innovate
- Excellent retention and work life balance for a Big corp/tech company
- Excellent parental leave benefits
- Relatively easy to change teams and move to areas of emerging technologies
cons: - As it's the case for most big companies, if your group or team projects are less exciting and less revenue generating outside of R&D, you won't have a pleasant ride.

review_title: Interview them as deeply as they interview you!
pros:
Great staff at the technical levels.
IBM's reputation seems to earn it some solid Government contracts.
cons:
Should have taken the obvious hint the universe was trying to send, when the interviewer for the first interview arrived 30 minutes after the appointment time, and didn't seem to know what was going on.
Accepted a senior management role, but within a month or two it became obvious the role was surplus to requirements. Let go after five months with little support or direction, and wondering why I was hired.
IBM Ballarat has a close relationship with Federation University, so be prepared to work with students in "Earn and Learn" programs - this is both a pro and a con.
Workplace is distant from the Ballarat CBD, with not many facilities close by.

review_title: Not so good or challenging
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: Some opportunities to work with Cloud technologies and/or Open Stack
cons: No team environment in my dept. (In Bucharest, GDSC) - no improvement,  no real Project Management. The organisational scheme was made in such a way that we had  multiple projects and less people, so we ended up doing countless week-end  work and/or  overtime hours.  What made me leave was lack of understanding (including team leader - but  I found out  much later, that is why I write this review now)  from management  - understanding in building  a high performance developing team, based on professionalism and delivering high quality.. There was no interest ... Moreover , having one of my kids ill from a degenerative disease , and finding the medical analysis results during my work in IBM ... I was  recommended  by my manager  to try to find another job ...

review_title: IBM not bad but could be better
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: There are lots of opportunities for advacement and to do different and challenging things. The benefits package is pretty good. The vacation package is reasonable and IBM is very good about extra time off for getting married and having children. There is also a lot of opportunity to work from home.
cons: IBM is very beauruacratic,, and it is getting worse. It becomes more difficult every day to get things done.  The education opportunities used to be much better. They are very restrictive now about the cost of attending classes. When I began 8 years ago there was much focus on promoting educaction and having people develop new skills.

review_title: Great Manager, Very Poor Leader
job_title: Program Director in New York, NY
pros: IBM has a very respectful working environment.  Employees have tremendous freedom to complete their work.  There is a campaign environment to much of the work that divides the year into distinct cycles and phases.  The opportunities to interact with Research, Services, Software, Hardware, and Industries provides a lot of areas for professional development.
cons: Very slow career progression.  Many executives bully employees.  IBM constantly revisits old ideas instead of searching for new ones.  Some of the best leaders have recently retired.  The yearly PBC review process is arbitrary and the goals are often abstract.  IBM has one of the most convoluted compensation programs in the world.  Complaints from sales reps about unpaid commissions and constantly changing bonus metrics are so common.

review_title: Just a job.  it pays the bills
job_title: Customer Fulfillment Representative in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: IBM still does have a decent benefits package - Insurance, sick leave.  Even though the cost is much higher that we have paid in the past, it is still much lower and coverage is better than what you can get on the outside.
cons: Hours - management thinks that we should be living, dying breathing IBM.    We are penalized for things that are out of our control.  Lack of respect from management.  Many feel that we do not have the intelligence to do our jobs.

review_title: Not the place to be if you want to pursue a career in semiconductor manufacturing....
job_title: Senior Engineer in Essex Junction, VT
pros: There are some top notch technical people at IBM and in general, my coworkers are competent and pleasant to work with.
cons:
IBM Microelectronics' glory days are in the past.  It lost its technological leadership years ago and it has long been a second class semiconductor manufacturer.  As IBM continues to be less and less a hardware company and more and more a services/software company, its days as a semiconductor manufacturer seem numbered.

Working for IBM in general is a cold, dehumanizing experience.  As an employee, you are a piece of office equipment to be surplussed when business needs change or when there is a business downturn.

review_title: short term only
pros: It is a good place to start your career if you are fresh out of school and have no experience. The company offers slightly above average salary for start, which gets increased twice in the first year and every 12 months afterward. Ability to get experience with some interesting technologies such as mainframes etc.
cons: After 2 or so years in the job you are getting underpaid and the management chooses to hire graduates  who are cheaper than to give enough money to the senior employees. Because of this the fluctuation is quite high. People management roles are given higher relevance than technical roles, even first line managers have much higher benefits (mobile phone for personal use, car, ..) even though their skills and value they bring for the company are questionable.

review_title: Good place to work in good times.
pros: IBM has a reasonable wage.  And it still has a family like culture.  IBM values Diversity so thoes who are diverse will be more Secure.
cons: IBM is a good place to work as long as your manager believes you are in the in-crowd.  Once Management changes and you are no longer in the in-crowd and things get bad in the economy then they will get rid of you.  I was just laid off after many years of great performace.  I was left scratching my head as to why they chose me.  There were plenty of others that did not have the skill or pashion for the job as I did.

review_title: IBM is changing, but still a solid place to work
pros: IBM has always been very respectful of work-life balance and time off for life events, etc. Leaders are generally very accessible and willing to engage all employee levels. The work can be very rewarding.
cons: The spreadsheet mentality means that they may not always completely understand how to value a good employee whose benefit to the company rises above their bottom line or utilization tallies (particularly in the area of User Experience and other creative/design roles). It was NOT always like this here. It seems back in the earlier part of the decade, we were encouraged to "Do the Right Thing" and were rewarded for our efforts and risk in a more organic way.

review_title: IBM is good to lead a relaxed life - not for fast paced career or professional growth
pros:
Flexibility in work life is biggest plus in IBM. 
Work From Home facilities, no hard & strict work timings just you need to ensure work is done without any delays, a relaxed work culture, open management (approach your managers any time) are some of the biggest advantages working with IBM. 
Wide array of domains to chose and move across. Excellent exposure to business and leadership skills.
cons:
Compensation packages & benefits below par. Very less technical growth, if your career is not properly planned and adhered might get lost working in projects not useful to your professional & technical advancement. Year end feedbacks provided are not correct and useful. 
No challenging projects as such apart from a host of AM work.

review_title: Frustrating
pros:
Ability to work from home
Large number of opportunities if willing to relocate
Diverse group of intelligent people
cons:
Poor Worklife Balancing
First level managers have little to no power to impact anything
Glass Ceiling for non executives
Poor Bonus Structure

review_title: Way too much internal processes, procedures, business controls, audits, private interests ...
job_title: Technical Support Manager in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros: + Great team and internal cooperation
cons:
- Management did not keep their promises
- Management betrays trust
- Zero attention of how the staff feels, if there are problems HR dept. can only record it - but not react to it
- Almost no salary increase and promotion in the last 3 years
- No recognition from management side
- HUGE amount of internal processes, procedures, regulations, business controls reviews, audits. In the same time country & above country management expects the numbers to be delivered regardless of the excessive administrative overhead
- HUGE above country structure with a lot of people overlapping their roles and responsibilities
- Interests of the company are not defended - all possible transactions are pushed through "Business Partners", direct business is deeply unwanted and all local management is avoiding it
- And many more ... but those were the most important topics that irritated me.

review_title: Monster company with frustrating bureaucracy
job_title: Client Technical Professional in London, England
pros:
Lots of training available
Still looks good on CV
Opportunity to get lots of experience
Good Ts&Cs
Decent benefits package
cons:
Reducing job security
Self promotion is the largest contributor to your career progress
Lack of recognition
Too many people tell you what to do with little value to your day job
Salaries better elsewhere
Values process over client satisfaction and job effectiveness
Little to no help from Management to do your job
Too many jobsworths
Lack

review_title: IBM is a huge company, sometimes the little people get mistreated.
job_title: Applications Programming Specialist in East Lansing, MI
pros: Lots of experience around, lots of internal resources, good insight into the corporate world, great experience for college graduates just breaking into the industry.
cons: Hired in for one thing but end up doing something completely different, pay is low compared to other companies, management is lackluster.

review_title: The cogs turn, but very slowly.
pros:
IBM is big enough to weather the storms in the economy and also a good place to work.  There are many enthusiastic employees who thrive on challenges and there is a good sense of team within the organisation.
There appears to be a wealth of job opportunities within IBM, but it is often difficult to move across teams if your skills are in demand.
cons:
Policy, policy, policy and too many of them which handcuffs the lower management into being messengers rather than managers.
During my time at IBM I saw different CEOs brought in to do specific tasks, such as close the final salary pension, reduce employee benefits, cut the majority of travel expenses, and seek a share price high over everything else.  Some of this is good for the company, and mostly to the detriment of the employee.

review_title: It Depends on Where You Are And What You Do...
pros:
Great benefits package and comparable salaries
Ability to work from home is widely accepted
Can really grow your career and expertise if you so desire
Most colleagues are nice, professional and in the same boat as you.
cons:
Yearly layoffs drastically impact moral and ability to get work accomplished.
Internally-facing organizations move very slowly and it's frustrating.
Externally-facing organizations often move too quickly and rush to failure.
As much as they cut the dead weight, there are still middle-managers who are apathetic and just filling a seat.

review_title: Flexible work, opportunities, but slow growth
job_title: Research Staff Member in New Delhi
pros:
Relaxed work culture, flexible timings, work from home is possible

You can get to work on many different projects/problems depending on your group/manager, so you can move to a different project if you get bored with one. You can move between different research groups, or even to different IBM organizations (although people rarely do the latter as Research supposedly pays higher salaries that other organizations and has a more relaxed work culture).
cons: Bureaucracy! You need a ton of approvals for anything and everything. This eventually impacts your growth at IBM ==> extremely slow growth as it takes a lot of time for your research to get into IBM product/services. Publishing papers in conferences and journals may help you get timely bonuses/increments (if the company is also doing well), but does not advance your career at IBM.

review_title: Has degraded extensively over the years, as a company to work for
job_title: Engineering Technician in East Fishkill, NY
pros: Good technical environment (semiconductor business) to expand knowledge base.  Empowered to do experiments as needed, to find answers to ongoing problems.
cons: Penny pinching.  CEO and executives are focused ONLY on "EPS" (Earnings Per Share), and the price of common stock.  After all, this how they grow their personal wealth...through stock options.  Living in constant fear of being sold off or outsourced.  No conferences allowed.  Very little new equipment purchased for our lab.  Seem to be "cooking the books", for years now, to make the division more attractive to potential suitors. Forget about meaningful salary increases.  Many, many years since I saw one of those.

review_title: Values eroded and lacks a visionary.
pros: Awesome people to work with, some of the best minds anywhere. Processes and procedures in place for everything. Fantastic potential in a company to ride the cloud generation and pull out the guns it has and the incredible reputation. Watson technology can take it over the top once again if they let the Ginny out of the box.
cons: No visionary at the helm that would inspire the masses. Good candidate for a show like CBS's Undercover Boss to see the reality of the field. Massive brain drain occurring due to lack of leadership. Too much emphasis on dividends and rate of return, stock buybacks. Selling of key parts of company continues (hardware, chip development) creating a shell with a volatile inside.

review_title: unfair performance reviews, underpaid
pros: Great resume builder to work for a company as big and well known as IBM.  Great healthcare benefits for full time employees.  As an employee you get a lot of discounts from various companies.
cons: Because of the size of the company it's extremely hard to get recognized for good work.  Pay raises ate based on a ranking system that is unfair.  I say this because senior management tells your direct manager how many people they can select for each ranking. 1 is the best 4 is the worst, only 10% of staff can be a 1, 10% can be a 2, the 80% left need to be 2's and 3's.  Only people with 1's get a raise.

review_title: Running with donkeys
pros: You may have some decent people to work with, and you probably won't have to talk with the ones you don't want to. The benefits are ok. They have an online library membership that has a few useful books.
cons: I could list off the cons and air ibm's dirty laundry and it would be a very big and long review. But to keep it brief, there are a lot of things that will keep you shaking your head and wondering why you're still here. The absolute worst thing is it feels like the management doesn't trust the employees.

review_title: Project Manager
pros: Great company history, work hard get paid well, great people to work with and around.
cons:
Changed a lot in last 10 years.  If you like to live to work then this is the place for you. 
Can go years without a pay raise. 
Lots of offshoring, jobs are not secure, regardless of what division you are in.

review_title: IBM
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: There used to be many of these but they have slowly disappeared over the years. Some of the few left are the ability to telecommute when needed in most cases. It depends on your manager.
cons:
This list gets larger every year but the biggest con is that there are constant layoffs. IBM values its stock price over its customers and employees now. Layoffs have nothing to do with your performance and everything to do with your being a senior employee making a higher salary. Last I heard for people getting laid off this year you only get 1 month salary no matter how long you have been with the company. 
Benefits are dwindling slowly but surely.

review_title: A review on IBM
pros: Unlike any other IT giants, IBM is providing a humanitarian face to the field. The working conditions as I heard is better at IBM and provide the option for the employees to switch to their field of interest without changing the company which is great.
cons: Salary is little bit low for freshers as comparing it with other biggies like Google and Microsoft. IBM has offices at only few of the Indian states so the employee mostly need to travel away from his/her home for employment, for ladies this may be a drawback.

review_title: Good for a frehsres
pros: I was a full time employee with IBM R&D and did enjoy the work there. Though timings were stiff, but the work from home feature helped a lot to control the fatigue. Compensation for freshers is fine but over the period it doesn't seem to move as HR policies are bad and increment is less. I appreciate the work and the smart people you find around you. Good learning curve. But, move on when you feel stuck
cons: Managers can be rigid. Also, too many hierarchy for you to move up. IBM is an elephant and it takes years to reach a good managerial position. But, once you are there, it even more tough. But, managers were shifted across divisions too frequently that was an issue in my case as it lead to trust issues. Overall as company IBM still is a name everywhere wants to link themselves with, and is a name you wish to have on your resume.

review_title: Good Company for freshers to work
pros:
I joined IBM as a fresher and it is great start as a fresher. Here are few Pros
1) Friendly management
2) Great Culture
3) Work life Balance (Work from home)
4) Unlimited casual leaves
5) Team members will help you a lot to grow in your career.
6) You will grow technically strong when you are in good project.
7) Great atmosphere and Big Brand Name.
8) Big clients to work with
9) Unlimited free training and you can train in any domain;no one will stop you
10) Now IBM is in Cloud and Big data era, if you have good knowledge in any of this technology you will grow here like anything.
cons:
1) Everything depends upon the manager - Manager depend company.
2) Rotational shifts - Shift rotates for every week which will be a great problem to your health.
3) Very less salary and perks.
4) Lot of politics in management.
5) Sometimes you will get bored to do the same work again and again.

review_title: Get out what you put in, good company values, out dated management
pros:
Genuine people - one of the best parts of IBM is the people, rarely meet someone with a bad moral compass.
Variety of opportunities - I've worked in client facing roles in outsourcing  delivery for huge organisations accross almost all industries from day 1 as a graduate giving huge experience. Then moved into bus. dev., and finally consultancy during a 4 year period.
cons:
Beurocratic - One of the most process driven organisations (largely due to size and cost restraints) reduces ability to deliver to clients effectively, and demoralises workforce
Siloed - Technology and Business divisions often compete and do not collaborate enough
Diluted quality of talent - lots of acquisitions and outsourcing (IT takeover) brings in poor quality talent

review_title: Abundant opportunities if you fight for them
pros:
Diversity of challenges to solve
amazing colleagues - some of the smartest people I’ve ever met are IBMers. I love the people I work with
Geographic reach
cons: Upper level management out of touch with customer and employee needs and too entrenched in legacy, cumbersome business processes. Incentive systems based on previous org siloes that can make it feel impossible to collaborate across business units for the benefit of customers. Mixed messages on purpose: shareholders vs customers vs employees vs society. Despite a female CEO still limited women at the top and no visible effort to nurture the next gen of female execs.

review_title: It's a good place where you can learn
job_title: Back End Developer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
- IBM has a lot of tools that you can use to solve your work problems without 3rd parties, for example: they have their own sql database, noSql database, IBM Cloud,  etc 

- You get to work with a lot of people from whom you can always learn something

- The IBM Campus in Guadalajara feels like a University because it's not just a big building with elevators and stuff, there are open spaces where you can sit and relax

- They give you free transportation from a number of places if there's a bus route near you, to IBM and back to your house
cons:
- Growth is not much of their interest

- As long as you can do the job, you're more than enough, even if it should be 2+ people working with that
- Outsourcing

- You could leave today and they're just going to find someone to replace you without even trying to change your mind

review_title: Employees make IBM great.
job_title: Business Development Executive in Austin, TX
pros: Sharp, sometimes brilliant, colleagues; opportunities to talk with colleagues in different jobs/divisions within the company and learn from them about latest trends in developing technology and what customers and business partners are doing. At IBM the employees are first-rate -- really creative and smart.
cons: The workload is overwhelming. I have worked 70-hour weeks for years, and still can't accomplish everything I want to do to feel satisfied with my job. I am at the highest level of non-executive employee, and everyone at my level feels that we have targets on our backs -- IBM is trying to remove highly paid people in Western countries and hire less competent people in developing countries.

review_title: Make 95K sitting home, eating chips, and checking your email every 2 hours!
pros: Working at home.  Make 95K sitting home, eating chips, and checking your email every 2 hours.  Another good reason is that IBM looks good on your resume.  Finally, you get really good at dealing with politics and difficult angry people (who are this way because they are stressed from being overworked and forced to achieve unrealistic goals.)
cons: Hard to advance career (even when you really try hard)  and  LOTS of red tape to go through to get anything done.  I always tell people working at IBM is 90% filling out forms / 10% doing actual technical work.  IBM needs to start caring about employees again and we will care about the company.  Until then, we will be unproductive.

review_title: Senior Execs overpaid, hard workers taken advantage of.
pros: A lot of different opportunities with one employeer.  In many instances, given the ability to work from home or a remote location.  IBM tries to give a good work-life balance which often works in some peoples favor but can also hurt others.
cons: Easy to get "lost" in such a large corporation.  Something always seems to be changing which requires learning a new system or process that is not always an improvement.  The ability to work from anywhere is also one of the downfalls.  I have found that employees (regardless of their position or standing) are expected to be available at all times regardless of what is going on in their life.

review_title: Senior Execs overpaid, hard workers taken advantage of.

The ability to work from anywhere is also one of the downfalls.
