review_title: IBM, no reward, frisk or no risk, your choice
pros: You now have no motivation to do anything 2 years on the trot, no wage rises for best performers, you could get a PBC1 or a PBC3 and still get the same recognition. So kick back and wait for the market to pick up now.
cons: None really, it will die in 2009/2010 and shareholders may make your life a little difficult after this, therefore you have to hope the market picks up. Your also expected to offshore everything to some of the most useless people on the face of this earth, mind you with the UK/USA not investing now in tech careers, and employers refusing to hire anyone then your stuck with it.

review_title: Sentenced to 20+ years hard labor
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Armonk, NY
pros:
There haven't been any good reasons to work on the ibm finance team for over 10 years now.  The ibm finance leadership team has become increasingly small minded, lacking in any BACKBONE, and is purely self centered.

The only reason to work at ibm is for a paycheck until you can find another better job elsewhere which many former employees have already done and continue to do so.
cons: ibm is a great place to work if you enjoy working 60+ hours a week, being harranged by do nothing 1st & 2nd line managers, and if you like working for people who you do not respect.

review_title: Software Developer for maintainance in Argentina
pros: Very quiet environment, at least at maintainance support. You have very good  home working policies. There is no better place to work than your own house/appartment. The managers are also very good-
cons:
Regarding the conditions, the payment is very low here in Argentina as in most companies, but a bit lower than the average. It's not enough to get to the end of the month and save to buy whatever you want, a car , a house, or do your own business.
  The hiring conditions are very bad, because you pass the IBM interviews and examinations and after they tell you were successfull, they say oh.. we forgot, the hiring is thru a consultancy company we work with..  Most employees at IBM argentina are hired by third party companies,.

review_title: Disappointing, especially when compared to its reputation and pretention
pros: 1. Because of its reputation and standing, it gets interesting assignments and you get to do interesting work. 2. It has a large, organized reservoir of templates, models, tools and instruments -- and training to back their use -- and you can learn and grow in your profession. 3. It has many competent professionals and encourages 'communities of practice,' which aids professional growth. 4. IBM is huge and involved in many different lines of exploration, which in turn broadens your professional view and, if you choose, helps you develop your knowledge and skill in a new or different direction -- a major career advantage in a time of radical flux.
cons: 1. Despite its claim, it is a very mechanistic organization, which has an engineering approach to its employees, who are viewed as cogs in a machine and left to feel used and dispensable. 2. Despite an elaborate on-boarding program, its treatment of new employees is casual and thoughtless, and the initial period for newcomers is hard. 3. It is particularly bad for younger employees, who haven't had long working experience and are not principally self-directed; they often rudderless and lost in a giant maze. 4. Most employees are now 'virtual' and get scant team or organizational support, leaving them isolated, unsupported and painfully on their own.

review_title: Exhausting, low paid, no room for advancement
pros:
Healthcare, 401K, good location, its a job and a good name for your resume. 
Good education to take with you to your next job.
cons:
Low paid, limited if any raises, no room for growth, too much work, too few people due to constant turn over.  I have seen at least 100 people on my floor leave in the past year then you have to pick up their work even though you have no time.  The if you can't fit it in you get a poor rating. 
Managers are like robots, running around like crazy, always in a frenzy, no time for their people. Two or 3 years without a raise or bonus.

review_title: Mediocre work experience, with a few individual staff member exceptions, overall poor morale and internal culture.
job_title: Marketing Program Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Company offers wide variety of opportunities for different roles, career paths - IF you can get support of your manager.
cons: Very few opportunities to build interpersonal and team relationship(s) with colleagues and coworkers as most are work from home. Spend lots of time on conference calls with cast of dozens or more. Very slow movement on projects due to "too many cooks," political wrangling and landscape. Difficult to build trust, as many are individual contributors focus on impressing management and rather than focusing on projects that help move the organization forward.

review_title: Great place to learn, not a great place for a career
pros: Good training & development opportunities for both early and mid-career people. Good for the resume, because IBM is well known and respected. Opportunity to develop or expand a professional network, as lots of folks move into and out of IBM.
cons: More recent globalization of the company means very limited career path for non-emerging market employees.  Leadership "talks" about career, work-life balance and opportunity, but that's all it is - "talk".  If you want to be recognized you've got to forget the work-life balance and be a complete politician and workaholic.  Horrible culture resulting from weak middle management, continuous "workforce rebalancing" - layoffs and pressue to train and re-train and re-train staff brought on in growth markets where turnover is huge.

review_title: Twenty plus years
pros:
The people - Most IBMers rank as the "best of the best." Very exciting to encounter and work with the most extraordinary people in the business. 
Depending on division and management chain, projects can be challenging, exciting, with a great deal of relevance to current and future technological impact on business and society.
A wealth of available online education.
cons:
Unfortunately, in recent years an alarming number of what I believe to be the most dedicated workforce in the world are quite literally dropping dead from causes related to overwork and excessive stress.  (My statement is based on personal knowledge - not hearsay.)
In many areas, work/life balance is nonexistent. 
Personnel review system is a numbers game with no relationship to actual performance. Final decisions are often made by managers who have no personal knowledge of the person under review.
Raises are all but nonexistent.
Benefits erode every year.

review_title: Came for a job, stayed for career over 25 years
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Markham, ON
pros: IBM has some of the top sales and technical professionals in the industry, that work practically in a boundaryless way at a global scale, whom you may work and/or learn from.  The basic beliefs from Thomas Watson -- respect for the individual, service to the customer, excellence as a way of life -- are deeply embedded in the management system and culture.
cons: Encouraging autonomy in the company means that managers can learn from their failures, but some first-line managers are challenged in their learning.  Difficulties can be resolved with the second line manager as an employee's career manager, but if both the first-line and second-line managers are bad, the "open door" process to executives had better be open.

review_title: With IBM, you don't sign for just a job, you build your Career...
pros: IBM is a unique organization , the only company that has continuously reinvented itself.. era after era, continuously, for 105 years. And has built careers..in all these eras...with focus and commitment. An organization that transforms itself continuously and also supports and encourages its employees to do so.  I realized this when I joined IBM..I did not sign up for a job..  I landed myself an amazing opportunity to enhance my expertise and skills in the field  I was very keen to work in. And it has been possible due to IBM' s "Underlying commitment to Enhancing Skills", "Promoting a  Culture that is Committed to driving Great Employee Experience",  a "Strong Focus on Nurturing Talent" and "Encouraging Feedback" . That's what  you get...when you get an opportunity to work in IBM.  You get build your Career...
cons: None that I have experienced .

review_title: Starting days at IBM
pros: The environment is very good. All the colleagues and especially my supervisors are very cooperative. When I joined the company I was expecting tough times for me where I will be required to follow some predefined rules and schedules all the time. But here the best thing was, I was given freedom to choose and work on the project I like. I could give my own input to change the perspective of the ongoing project. Above all the behaviour of my supervisor was very encouraging for me and gave me much confidence during my starting days. I hope I am going to have some really exciting moments ahead.
cons: Language barrier is the only negative I can think of right now. One must understand and speak German if he wants a good career here but naturally it is always difficult to learn a new language. Without German language it is almost impossible to find a permanent job here.

review_title: Financial Analyst
pros: Some of the managers and employees are truly amazing and make the experience worth it all. Plus working for a fortune 500 company comes with the perk of endless knowledge and daily challenges that really push your limits and help you grow rapidly.
cons: Most of the employees and managers are at the end of their careers or are spouses of Mayo Clinic employees and don't have a passion for what they do. They are truly there to collect a pay check and will gladly let you know that. This causes a somewhat hostile and dull work environment with feeds into the high attrition of millennials.

review_title: Regulatory Delivery
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lupton, CO
pros: In the past IBM has used a very effective work from home program. However, even that is changing to low cost "Agile" work centers were everyone knows a little bit about a lot but there are no real subject matter experts.
cons:
Toxic work environment.
"Global Resources" does not include the United States.
Upper management is totally disconnect from the day to day workings of the business
Movement of work to low skilled resources in India, China, Mexico, Costa Rica etc is killing customer satisfaction and quality

review_title: Slow-motion train wreck
pros: Bright, passionate (but beleagured) workforce. Good, though continually reduced benefits. Flexiblity and W/L balance *if* you work within a good org.
cons: Continued layoffs, disrespectful and/or oblivious leadership, unrealistic and unattainable goals underpinned with the overt threat of job security, disempowerment of rank-and-file and first-line mgmt, continued hiring freezes (for everyone except executives who seem to be hired by the truckload), reactive coupled with stagnant thinking, "agile" workspaces (where *no* thinking actually happens), competing divisions who are supposedly focused on the same goal, too focused on lowering costs instead of focusing on improving products and services, focus on "minimally viable products" that are never enhanced beyond "minimally viable"

review_title: data entry/management
pros:
Focus,  eyes for details, enthusiasm to work hard to achieve success, Specialist data management, Database management, effective communication skills, requirement gathering and analyst. Use Case Modelling, SQL/ Normalizing Data, 1st, 2nd, 3rd, & ( BCNF) normal form. 
 BSc & MSc Computer Science
cons: Work on a particular  project over and over again, and sharing with people not measuring to task, Absenteeism, with team member may delay project deadlines. any way, there is always a way around it. Slow down project and not able to deliver, not encouraging.

review_title: 31 Years at this Progressive Company
pros:
Despite being in business for more than 100 years, IBM is a surprisingly innovative and progressive company.  Like any big company there are times when it's hard to move things forward; however, working for a company this size you have the tremendous resources and an opportunity to work at a truly large scale. 

Additionally, I've been with this company for 31 years as an "out of the closet" bisexual woman.   Over the years IBM has been cutting edge regarding it's social and anti discrimination policies.  I'm truly proud of this.  Ethically, this company is superb.
cons: I personally don't like the "back to the office" policy that has been instituted.  For those of us who where asked to work at how 10 years ago and may have moved to other locations, it's not easy.  However, my leadership has worked with me on this issue, so there is some flexibility.

review_title: Volatile Environment
job_title: Senior Cloud Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Good salary,  great benefits, work from home and opportunities to travel.  Great people to work with and very smart ones at that!
cons: Have to worry every quarter if you are next to be RA'ed (resource action, another acronym for "laid off"). Poor performance quarter after quarter.  Too many silos and nothing gets done in a timely manner.  Very "old" school company and stuck on "old" processes and procedures.  Too many politics and upper management.  Very little or no advancement for pursuing other career opportunities.  If you want job security, doesn't exist at IBM.

review_title: Awful place to work
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Washington, DC
pros:
I receive a paycheck.  
I have a job that offers mediocre benefits.
cons:
No room for advancement.  Management at all levels have no idea what it actually takes to achieve the desired results and will not pay attention to those who do.  
Experience means nothing, the "process" is everything.  Square pegs must fit in round holes with no thought given to trying to help the client, being proactive or what it takes to achieve the desired results.  Managers have one agenda and that is making themselves look good at the expense of their employees who have no say in how things might be run better.  The CEO sends out several emails gushing about her great achievements and accomplishments that appear to have little to do with the actual operation of the company and more about making herself look good.  The bottom line is more important than employees.  Benefits are adequate to poor with everything done to benefit the company at the expense of the employee.

review_title: Consulting as a new grad
pros: I started IBM Global Business Services as a new grad as part of consulting by degrees program which is a new grad program for top students in universities. Had hands on experience on projects, supportive environment in terms of learning new things, international training opportunities, dynamic, challenging and great place to improve your skills while adapting yourself for new technologies, methodologies in various industries
cons: Low salaries, even it is a new grad program no clear career path for employees, everything is self service and complex internal processes takes too much time.

review_title: A great stepping stone for career advancement into next company or stay 20 and become partner
pros: Legacy Brand Name that still has impact on Resumes, The closest leadership has the most impact and thus if they're amazing your career will be as well. After 100 years the policies have panned out to be stabilized and easily understood.
cons: A cog in a 300,000 part machine can feel like an unimportant piece in a really big puzzle. Although I listed it as a pro a con is that the policies are also in some parts outdated. Utilization target for GBS Federal was higher than compensation although this might differ annually.

review_title: Great name, currently transforming itself, internal struggles
pros:
-  IBM is a company that rewards individual initiatives and gives you the space and freedom to do so. It will not take you by the hand, but expects you to lead.
- Has a great established wealth of tech knowledge and expertise to learn from.
cons:
- Large corporate where individual efforts are not always recognized as much. Easy to get lost in internal processes before getting approvals or other things done.
- Reputation in the Netherlands is rather negative or neutral; young Dutch people often do not know what IBM currently does. 
- Currently struggles with selling large scale innovation projects, hence a constant supply of interesting client engagements for young people is lacking.
- Aging workforce.

review_title: Nice place to visit, but I wouldn't want to make a career there.
pros: Employee competance, in my experience, is outstanding.  Engineers and most management personnel are very intelligent.
cons: Workload is extremelly overwhelming most of the time.  It is uncomfortable to address this issue because all employees, including management, are in the same boat.  Many times management is not on-site, which makes confronting workplace issues difficult.

review_title: IBM could be very good investment but not a good employer
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: IBM has excellent executive management and they know very well how to run business. I would say IBM is a good investment but not a good employer. You can learn well about business if you are in management chain at some senior level.
cons: IBM is not very well paying employer. IBM has excellent executive mgmt but they are quite conservative in passing profits down the line. IBM is always striving to increase margins and they try that from both the ends. Increase product/service rates and pay less to employees. IMO, this is short term view instead of developing satisfied work force with high moral.

review_title: Stepping Stone
pros:
Good place to learn technical basics.
Good access to technical tools.
Unfortunately there just aren't very good reasons to work for IGS.
cons:
To many management layers.
Promotion and raises heavily dependent on how good you are playing office politics.
To many under performers that drag down the good workers.
To many first line and second line managers that simply go through the motions.
Very little personal responsibility and accountability. Promotions go to those who avoid responsibility. Common game, is for "senior" technologists to avoid direct work assignments but "assist" lower band workers. Often the senior technologist provides no value, but implicitly is given credit if the project succeeds, and completely avoids accountability if the project fails.

review_title: I've grown an enormous amount working with such smart hard working people, but I'm frustrated by the lack of mobility.
pros: IBM has an exceptional level of professionalism at all levels. The management is top notch, and there are essentially unlimited resources if you know how to access them. It is reasonably easy to move around within the company. That in addition to a 1 job year commitment policy provide opportunities to try new careers without leaving.
cons: The processes put in place to make such a large company viable, also serve as frustrating obsticles to create change. IBM has become a very top heavy company. Due to new policies put in place to address this, it is slow and difficult for new graduates to move up. This is especially frustrating when collegues at other companies get promoted multiple times while you wait.

review_title: A once great employer that now only cares for earnings per share.
pros:
Scope of opportunities - you could end up anywhere doing anything.
Brand reputation - IBM is the premier name in IT.
Training and education - there will be a course for it in IBM
cons:
Poor compensation. Salaries have not kept pace with the market.
Don't expect a pay rise as your career progresses. Once your an IBM employee there are lots of career opportunities. But as your responsibilities increase and your value to the company improves, you don't get better compensation.
Work/life balance van be poor - you will be expected to travel on a Sunday night and spend the week living in hotels.

review_title: Good company with bad management
pros: Excellent benfits for employees paired with a generally relaxed environment and very good work/life balance.
cons: All levels of management like to spout corporate BS about people being assets and looking forward while entire focus is on how much money they can post to Wall St this quarter. This causes many internal tools to fail to work properly as resources are pulled of projects to work on others or just laid off resulting in less efficient working conditions. They are now asking how to keep contractors furloughed to below 40/hrs per week without paying any extra. Raises are still on hold for at least this year, maybe next for contratcors and employees.

review_title: Work a million hours, make a million dollars!
pros: Great people! Leading technology. Plenty of on line resources  and training. Enough job specialization that you can find a niche where you do what you love and someone else will do the other stuff. You can make lots of money.
cons: 1st line managers are often geographically remote. For upper management, its all about the numbers; do not expect any personal consideration for unique circumstances.  Money follows effort, but it takes lots of effort.

review_title: It's Bland Man and Culture Challenged.
job_title: Mainframe Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: Free parking and being in low traffic location.
cons: Besides the low pay, this offshore "answer" ends up being the mojo contributing to a culture that exemplifies the many absurdities that might be found in a Dilbert cartoon (i.e - on demand seating policy at this facility for instance).  It's Beige Man, in not only the physical surroundings, but in the energy, the vibe, the leadership/management of people.  Creative, Innovative, and status-quo challengers will find it stifling and consistent with the same ole' lumbering bureaucracy where people are just numbers to be manipulated.

review_title: It's Bland Man and Culture Challenged.
job_title: Mainframe Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: Free parking and being in low traffic location.
cons: Besides the low pay, this offshore "answer" ends up being the mojo contributing to a culture that exemplifies the many absurdities that might be found in a Dilbert cartoon (i.e - on demand seating policy at this facility for instance).  It's Beige Man, in not only the physical surroundings, but in the energy, the vibe, the leadership/management of people.  Creative, Innovative, and status-quo challengers will find it stifling and consistent with the same ole' lumbering bureaucracy where people are just numbers to be manipulated.

review_title: Great people, great experience, very bad work environment, 60 to 70 hours is norm, zero concern for the human.
job_title: Executive Program Manager in Armonk, NY
pros: Opportunity to gain true global experience and to meet IT people from many other companies who have been outsourced by IBM.  Opportunity to work with many other large companies and gain the insight of how they run.
cons: "Resource Actions"/layoffs all the time, never know when your number is up, exempt employees are often expected to work 60 to 80 hours a week and often form months at a time.  Often the job requires travel, still need to do all the work with what hours remain in the week.  Compensation is not that of the competition unless you are a new hire and negotiate real well.  This year the lady running IBM canceled variable pay.

review_title: Sadly just a shell of its former greatness
pros: After 15 years living and breathing IBM, I learned A LOT about enterprise IT.  I had a chance to do big things, work with great customers, tread new territory in the outsourcing market.  I met some brilliant people, made some life long friends.
cons: They are asset stripping themselves on purpose.  Managers who have been with the company over 20 years will tell you they also hate what it has become.  Cold hard steel.  I left before I made it to the RA stack for an excellent job 2 levels up at 30% more pay.  What this should tell you is a lack of fair compensation or promotions for many years along with ridiculous policies and overhead has made this company a dying behemouth

review_title: Challenges shifted from being innovative to trying to stay employed.
job_title: Senior Engineering Lab Specialist in East Fishkill, NY
pros:
One of the most enjoyable work environments if you consider fellow employees and cultural diversity. Some of the best engineers and other performers worked their way through
the big machine and mostly moved on if they were able to. Solid "B" performers can make a decent, somewhat remunerative career. There are still opportunities and challenges every day.
cons: Hierarchical, paternalistic, minimal financial incentives. Asinine predetermined evaluation process, which is designed to minimize payroll expense, rather than improve performance.  A mixture of game-players and very hard workers managed to maintain course, innovating for a company that only seeks shareholder value at any cost. They've long ago lost the "carrot-and-stick" approach; taken away all the carrots; it's all stick.

review_title: Software Engineer
pros: A wealth of intelligent and helpful people.  Benefits are competitive.  Salary is competitive.  Huge company so you can go just about anywhere and there are endless opportunities to learn new things.
cons: Old school company.  It is trying to act/react like a cutting edge, small company and it's just not feasible.  There are too many high level management personnel who just want to keep doing the same thing over and over.  The review process is all politics.  If you're not constantly "contributing by delivering services for use by the client" then you are at risk of being laid off.  This makes it a bit difficult to tell where you stand as you could be working on a huge project that gets scrapped.  Then you have nothing to show for it and that creates an issue when the time for more layoffs come.

review_title: Ibm india nab review
job_title: Senior Technical Support Executive in Bangalore
pros: Just a place to get good salary ..but plz see ur quality scores are good else ur will be thrown out. Whatever reasons may be.
cons: Frustrating place to work in one word. Dont even attempt to go for interview. People have no professionalism  . More u try to be close with manager u ll be best. Very few ppl are their who are understand professionalism nd work on truly without any demands. Once u go u ll be irritated by stupidity.. feels like college students who just have completed their college have just come. Damn frustrating enviroment. Ppl have no rules and regulations to follow ..ppl will squeeze ir blood for their targets to be completed but  when u get csats no one cares but dsats they will treat u as if u have committed crime.

review_title: Over the years......
pros: Great overall employee value proposition - multiple careers within one organization, flexible work arrangement, continuous learning environment, exciting innovation which impacts the world, a very progressive company and always reinventing to be essential to the world. In my >20+ years in IBM, I have seen the high and low in the company and each time we come out stronger and relevant. It is a different company from the time I joined, but still very exciting place to have a career today
cons: Compensation package is not the most attractive - annual increase % is behind market, benefits has been removed, variable pay (GDP) has been eroding and is now less then half months salary. If compensation is the only main focus, IBM is not the company for you.

review_title: Great place if you are not in it for the money...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
1) Flexible work - reality means having to occasionally work from remote locations or work odd hours to meet your personal AND professional goals...no one bats an eyelash as long as your work gets done.
2) Really smart colleagues who are changing the world for the better.  Truth.
3) Business strategy is on track and diversity of thought ensures we continue to succeed..
cons:
1) Really cheap.  Few/low salary increases, yearly bonus 1/10th what it was (which was poor to begin with but has REALLY been decimated for experienced professionals).  If you want to work like the best but be paid like the middle of the pack, this is the place for you.
2) Over-reliance on low-cost and entry-level workers to meet revenue/profit/innovation targets.

review_title: Best tech company i worked for
pros: IBM is the best tech company I worked for and believe me I worked at many companies :) The people are smart, procedures are well established, employees' responsibilities are clear, management is very experienced and talented, tools and resources are enormous.
cons: Company car policy was one of the worst in the country but heard that it is developed. Some people are in the company for so long time, nobody can criticize them. YoY salary increase is very poor, so some people had to get another outside offer and fight for an increase afterwards. Some of the managers or employees are kind of snob about being IBM. Yes, well deserved reputation and success for around 110 years but, hey! wake up, competition is catched up and even going ahead in some areas.

review_title: Wasn't what I signed up for when I interviewed, worst job experience ever
pros:
-Good pay, decent mentorship
-That's it
cons:
-Truly stands for I've Been Moved (Moved me to a role I wasn't passionate in or I didn't have a job before I got onboard)
-Which led to I've Been Miserable...
-Location matters with this company (Better 3 month internship in experience in one location than 8 month "Full Time" in another).
-Honestly don't care about you

review_title: It was a great place for me
job_title: IT Senior Specialist in Herndon, VA
pros: It proved me opportunities to grow and develop my career.  I had some fantastic managers (and some not so great) who supported me and were truly my advisors.  The corporate culture and values were aligned with mine. You are in control of your career but the downside is that you have to take control.
cons: In the 7 years I was at IBM, I had 9 different managers  which meant that I needed to establish the relationship over and over.   It is easy to be stove-piped into a role and can be difficult to move into a new career path. However, if you are persistent and willing to do the work to make it happen, you can make it happen,

review_title: You are just a number
pros: Good for an early career person to get experience if they are willing to work long hours.
cons: No loyalty or personal development for employees. So many experienced (aka older) employees were let go in the last few years, the people left (mostly early career) do not understand what is needed to plan and execute on marketing programs.  There is no work from home, work/life balance (expected to answer your phone at ALL hours), retirement (minimal and only if you are employed on the last day of the year) or mentors (they were laid off) anymore.  Open space seating makes it difficult to concentrate or talk on the phone.  Bring your own phone for company calls,  IBM doesn't supply you (or reimburse you) with an office phone. No privacy.  Morale is very low.

review_title: Flexibility at the cost of sacrificing your interest
pros:
1. Flexible.
2. Work from home.
3. Appropriate number of leaves.
4. Understanding colleagues though some of them are just dependent on you.
5. Understanding manager though he makes you sacrifice your work interest for the product delivery.
6. Average pay.
cons:
1. No free lunch, tea, freebies, snacks.
2. No fun environment/activities. Only work unlike the new age companies.
3. Very conservative in spending money on employees. There is a long approval process for any spending on the employees.
4. You have to work on something in which you are not interested in for years. The manager will make you do that in the name of growth.

review_title: Have worked hard, but hard work doesn't seem to be appreciated...  at least not monetarily!
pros: Work / Life balance.  Work from home.  Auto contribution to 401k
cons: Too big, a lot of slackers.  Very difficult to "work your way up" as all future raises will be based upon your incoming salary with a 5% promotional cap.   5% of nothing is nothing, even though the nothing is backed by an MBA (3.9 GPA).  Will be moving on......

review_title: If you want to work with great clients and talent people for LOW pay, this jobs for you
pros: Great technical team, very dedicated people, access to international resources
cons:
There is very low morale across the country across all sectors. the two factors are poor management and extremely low salaries brought on by 5 year salary freeze. The low salary means the dedicated are disgruntled and new hires are from the lower end of the talent pool.
Senior executives are at the same time acting like robber barons with HUGE compensation rewards while the rest of the company is a sweat shop. 
There is a culture of lack of accountability and reliance on hiding behind 50 layers of policy to avoid doing the right thing by staff and clients.

review_title: pro and cons at IBM
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Work hours are flexible as long as you can get your work done. The managment understands life and work balance. There are oppurtunities for advancement and that needs you to intiate the process with upper managment. You're encourged to take on site course whenever it's available.  If you're lucky you might get your own office but sometimes you might need to share an office with another collegue.   There are no cubicle at the SVL location.
cons: IBM might not work for young professional because there is not a real energetic culture there and no free food there. I thought there would be finanial aid with tuiation help for training course at an educational instituation but I thought the process was diffifcult becuase it needed to a few level up management for approval. Sometimes you're expected to work long hours to get your work done.

review_title: Lost & Found Department:     Looking for "Respect for the Individual" at IBM
pros:
The IBM US corporate culture used to be a culture of cooperation and working together for the benefit of all, and some of the old-timers still have 
that attitude lingering around. Try to work with them if you can find them, but their numbers are dwindling because . . .
cons: FEAR is commonplace. It is every man/woman for themselves and nobody really knows what 'doing a good job' means anymore. Some of the best and brightest are laid off so what exactly what does 'doing a great job' mean?

review_title: If there were another job in the area with equivalent compensation, I'd be there in a shot
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Littleton, MA
pros:
It's a paycheck.
Some first line managers are good and will save your hide.
Compensation is decent.
cons:
The company is focused completely on the bottom line.  Experience isn't valued.  Layoffs have no rhyme or reason, and often seem to be veiled attempts to offshore job functions, and are alarmingly frequent, even if a good year has happened.  The bottom line has priority over product quality and customer satisfaction unless you're a premium customer or employee satisfaction.

If you have a decent first and second-line management, life can be tolerable.

Benefits and compensation are often spun as "in line with industry averages", implying that we're only average.

review_title: Good place to start
pros: Good company to start a career at. Average benefits.
cons:
Like any other multinational. Employees are fodder for the international business machine. A$$ kissers advance easily. Real talent often overlooked. 1st and 2nd line management usually not qualified. Stodgy, "Think" moving an elephant.
Take the job knowing you will leave in a few years. It's a good training ground but be ready to move on to move up. Sales rules. You'll do good there as long as you make the club but watch out for bum territory assignments if you are too successful. That's how they dump you. It is unspoken but you are not allowed to make too much in sales. Engineering is dead end, no different from other multinationals. Learn something and move on.

review_title: Not got the Shareholder, Customer, Employee balance right
pros:
Plenty of internal opportunity to develop a career and try new things
Opportunity to move abroad if you have the right skills
cons:
Process bound - e.g. three levels of approval required to travel to a meeting
Doesn't value it's employees

Remuneration package constantly being eroded
You are encouraged to work from home but dis-incentivised to do so

review_title: Full of learning and being a big organisation its a land of opportunity.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: If you are in a good project there is no stopping in kind of learning you get. If after working for say 2 years you feel you are not having much learning and want to explore something new you can look for some projects with IBM which can be with in India or outside India. So its a good company if you know how to get those extra benefits.
cons: HR interaction with employees is less. The company needs to check those employees you are involved in frauds. Some employees do submit fake claims. Because of huge number of employees IBM is not auditing them much.

review_title: Sr. Product Manager
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Global market presence, Well structured process, Matrix Organization, Amazing reach into enterprise customers; great sales coverage; general camaraderie of being an IBMer, Work-from-home option
cons: Not competitive salary; Manically focused on Wall-street and is missing the big picture; Not able to map to new market trends and probably missing out; current business models not aligned with changing market landscape;  hard to grow and get promoted; Have not seen any new blood in the recent past;  Top-heavy management that feels that they can grow by cutting lower ranks

review_title: Good range of technologies to work on and excellent work life balance
pros: The range of technologies being used is vast, depending on the project. There is great opportunity to move internally also and find projects of interest The work life balance is great, and working from home is supported by the company. I work from home 2 to 3 days a week
cons:
In my particular role, I am dealing with a lot of new or emerging technologies so it can be hard to keep up all the time.
The canteens on premises are pretty bad with a poor level of food.
There can be a LOT of politics in IBM due to it's size (approx 450,000 employees worldwide) and this can be quite frustrating at times.
Very little company entertainment, i.e. crap Christmas party, no social occasions with a few pints.

review_title: So glad I left before the RA
pros: my teammates who are typically smart and hardworking and frequently considered to be industry experts.  Option to work out of home office was nice.
cons: Miserable morale and loss of respect for employees.  Shifting people out of the business when their skills and knowledge of how to get things done will be lost forever.  Recent restructuring created many new senior exec jobs just before the Resource Action which eliminated many lower level employees.  Employee's were given low performance ratings to ensure they do not get their bonus on the way out the door, however, senior execs will all get bonuses this year.

review_title: Squeeze the company for what you need, because that's when you're most highly valued
job_title: Senior Human Resources Professional in Chicago, IL
pros: Vast, raw, untapped opportunities abound for your needs for exposure, self-satisfaction, personal validation, professional breadth and depth of expertise and experiences, and conditioning to not only boring-old direct reporting relationships, but REAL and top-quality matrix reporting relationships. You can be happy here in 3 ways: personally, professionally and organizationally, and you can do this if you approach IBM as a place where you best contribution is made by figuring out how to squeeze the most of it.
cons: Do not come here if you think you're going to be led in to everything you need. Do not come here if you have no idea what you need. Seriously, I'm not kidding, GO TO THERAPY before or shortly after coming to IBM to understand what are your personal needs--like REALLY your personal needs: are you an introvert, an extrovert, a go-getter, a centrist, a self-deceiver, a self-validator, needy, self-aggrandizing, narcissistic, unsure of yourself, oversure of yourself, etc. etc...only come here if you know what you need. If you don't know, don't come here. Second, don't come here if you don't understand what you could possibly build on your resume in the 1st 100 days. I firmly believe that 1 year at IBM is worth 2-4 years anywhere else. If you can't put 2-3 things on your resume in 100 days or less working for IBM, then go back to therapy and see my first point. Lastly, there is no organization to be FOUND at IBM...none. It's flat, with no more than 11%-14% of its employees as people managers. IBM's organization lives IN YOUR HEAD--so get it all up in your head and figure it out. If you are the type of person who needs a very clear organization structure and you freak out without clarity, then please don't come here.

review_title: Endless opportunities but no work-life balance
job_title: IT Project Manager in Boonton, NJ
pros: IBM is a great place to work if you are willing to work very long hours and be assigned anywhere in the world and in client sites. This is the place for the young and looking for a very dynamic environment.
cons: Always on the move. You are only a headcount. Not an environment if you have a family to attend to. If you are assigned in client site, you are forgotten. You also forget that you work for IBM except for the emails that you get for endless administrative requirements and trainings that you have to attend online which for the most part have no impact on what you're doing in client site.

review_title: It's a trap
pros: Work from home, working hour flexibility, GLBT friendly, learn a lot.
cons: After 5 years of full dedication, being evaluated as an employee above the avarage for all the years.... I was told the company was going through a transfortmation and I was no longer needed. I joined IBM planning a careeer and they definetely dont know to keep employees motivated and help them creating the paths of a career. They just fire people for no reason and no respect at all. It´s all about the stakeholders, they dont give a damn or respect for the people working there.

review_title: IBM is just another job
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: IBM has a great (but fading) legacy of hiring only the most competent, ethical, and motivated employees. It is uncommon to work with an IBM employee who is not exceptional. There are still a lost of great people at IBM.
cons: For the past 10+ yrs, IBM Management has firmly placed their allegiance with the IBM Stockholders  to the neglect of IBM customers (and more especially, IBM employees). The once vaunted IBM policies of "respect for the individual" and "full employment" were finally dispensed with by Lou Gerstner. Ever since, IBM has never missed an opportunity to take more and more away from employees: pensions, reimbursement for office expenses, funding for education, 401K contributions, etc. Now, its just another job.

review_title: Too many accountants and lawyers
pros: Great benefits!  Although benefits have eroded over time, they are still highly competitive.  There is room to build your own business unit over time (I did!)
cons: IBM used to be an outstanding company to work for...  And, it could still be.  But management believes labor to be a variable cost of doing consulting.  When in fact, it is a fixed cost of doing business.  You just can't lay off wave after wave of people and expect revenues to rise.  Get rid of half of your accountants and lawyers and life will be much better.

review_title: Amazing Career Opportunities as You Progress in Life
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Chicago, IL
pros: As I progressed through life and my 30 years at IBM, my job interests changed. IBM has so many career opportunities and remains so current, that I was able to move from engineering to project management to consulting to sales and to human resources, each job building on the skills I developed from the previous role. And, I was able to do this within the same IBM family. Leadership development is also a great advantage, allowing me to take on exciting and challenging assignments to prepare for the next phase of my career. I made the right choice.
cons: There is too little time in life to be able to experience all the career opportunities that IBM has to offer.

review_title: Innovative and Inclusive
pros: IBM is an amazing company-- a place where people are encouraged to bring their whole selves to work and empowered through rich learning opportunities to deliver their very best in service of innovation that matters to the world. The people are brilliant, the culture is inclusive and the opportunity to make a difference is great.
cons: I've thoroughly enjoyed becoming part of IBM. I work with brilliant, agile leaders who are motivated to make a difference in the world. It's a huge company, so it takes skill and commitment to get things done.  If you like that, you'll make a difference at IBM.

review_title: Closed for business
pros: Work from home, employer pension contribution 6% of salary, partial health  insurance subsidy, opportunity to file patents. The process and management has had over 100 years to be refined, so everything is by the book, and they have a book for every situation.
cons: Low salaries, long commute, salary reviewed annually (max), annual performance evaluation requires someone to be assigned a score of zero (even in small departments),  no overtime compensation, large layoffs, no bonus

review_title: Technical Support Analyst
job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Hartland, WI
pros: Great benefits. Good Personnel on team. Can work remote. Pay is decent for the area. Can make extra money doing extra work here. (can be a pain to get paid for this though)
cons: No HR on site or that are relevant to talk with.  Training non existent.  L2's rarely assist.  Have to provide own hardware in office and at home.  Was literally given a ball mouse on my first day. Took 3 months to get the headset on my phone to work properly, would have been longer had I not ordered the piece I needed to get it going.

review_title: Working at IBM
pros:
Good company to learn and get exposure to technologies

Good Brand Name 

If you work under a good manager , your life will be best in IBM .
cons:
No proper hike 

No work life balance (again it depends on project)

Its very difficult to contact HR , we don't even know who is our HR . And when we contact HR they say everything depends on manager . HR is not supportive , and employees suffer a lot due to this in many cases

If you dont get a supportive and a good understanding manager your life will be hell in IBM

review_title: IBM services division is not a great place to be noticed
pros:
- Travel (if you like that)
- If you are skilled and well known in certain circles, there are many interesting projects to choose from
- Good benefits
cons:
- Travel (if you don't like that)
- If you're new or tend to keep to yourself, you may end up on projects that are uninteresting or failing
- You are a cog and with the matrix management system you don't always get noticed outside of your immediate project. 
- You are not always rewarded by how good your performance is on a particular project.  For instance, on a well run project with a good team, you may not require a lot of overtime.  Since billable hours are what gets noticed, a poor performer on a bad project might bill 70 hours per week and therefore get rewarded over you at the end of the year.
- Difficult and time consuming to get promotions

review_title: Great company sinking due to inept management
pros:
Great trainings and certifications sponsored by the company.
Good Work lifebalance, flexible on timings and work from home options (depends on the project and manager though).
Good for diversity
Lots of opprtunities to explore new technologies.
If you are proactive and manage to have good network, you can mould your career as you want and do whatever you want and in any stream you want.
cons:
Very low compensation.
Hopeless  management.
Bureaucratic and very slow no clarity about what to do. Employee feels left out without any clue.
 Its I By Myself.
No transparency in appraisal process.

review_title: Welcoming, tolerant, professional culture with big company red tape and politics
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Littleton, MA
pros:
Welcoming, tolerant, inclusive, all genuinely so. No bullying, shouting, sour grapes etc. Those attributes at IBM are not manufactured or beat into your head all day like they are at places like Google, rather, it is just how it is. Very professional. At the same time, casual dress, flexible work hours depending on manager.

Complex, relevant technologies. Opportunity for promotions and growth for those who take initiative, ask questions, push for progress, take a stand.

Upcoming CEO Arvind is a huge step above Ginni. Things are looking up for IBM from the inside. Positive things are happening.
cons: Boring culture, global teams can leave people feeling isolated, big company politics in executive management, executive management is fair to poor. Yearly cash bonuses are pathetic, no stock comp.

review_title: IBM is a great place to work for self directed people
pros: IBM provides great opportunities for learning and advancement. It is also a very family oriented company and they do provide you a lot of tools and resources for work life balance but they do expect you to be responsible for your self and your own work life balance, you must be responsible for yourself.  Some people might not like that.
cons: IBM is a global corporation that knows no time zones, working for IBM can disrupt your life outside of work. It is an always on company that requires you to be able to manage your own time and not rely on others to do so. IBM provides the platform for work life balance but you must be responsible for yourself.

review_title: Unfortunately,  it's only a good job now, not a career.
pros: Brand and company recognition and pride from those who never worked here.  They do offer some nice perks, such as work life balance, but be assured, it works in the company's favor.
cons: Bottom line driven at the expense of resources (humans).  I have been strung along with ok appraisals for 7 years, but no pay increases.  Great place for those with poor memory, as you hear the same excuse year after year.

review_title: IBM is a fast-paced company that has highly-skilled employees that work on challenging tasks at a decent salary.
job_title: Intern Software Developer in Ottawa, ON
pros:
* Motivating job: IBM gives interesting challenges that you won't find in some companies
* Flexibility: can work from home, or even from another country. 
* Collaboration tools: Working at IBM gives you the chance to use many collaboration tools such as Sametime, Rational Team Concert and e-Meetings.
* Salary and benefits: decent salary and benefits.
cons:
* Lack of structure. Our team didn't apply most of the techniques proposed by agile and other processes. We didn't even had iterations.
* Management is mostly composed of non-technical employees. 
* Lack of communication between management, marketing, development, user experience and testing. Every department is isolated from the other.
* Microsoft offers a better salary.

review_title: STG - Valuable or not?
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: The work is very interesting.  There is a lot of variety in what one can work on and can learn.
cons: There is a lot of churn in the products supported.  It is unclear what our direction is.  It is unclear where we will be in a few years.  Is this a sustainable area?  There is a long rich history for many of the product lines, but it sure seems like odd management decisions will prevent future growth.  The people are smart and talented.  We just need more 'vision' and commitment from upper management.  This is still a profitable area, and yet we don't really get treated as an area of value.

review_title: Yes to IBM but don't unpack your bags!
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Fair Pay, Work life Balance, Annual Bonus, Benefits, Corporate Credit Card.  IBM does have a wonderful attitude towards it's employees.  You are rewarded well for good work.  When they let you go they offer you great packages plus training and allow access to professional counselors to help you get back in the work force.  They started a alumni network so that employees can network and keep in touch as well as share information about jobs.  This alumni network is sort of like a linked-in for former IBMers.  The corporate card does help you with the travel issues.  They made it comfortable to be on the road again.
cons: Travel, Competitive Employees, Downsizing, Two many chiefs not enough Indians, Inferior Management, They favor non-heterosexual employees probably due to the travel situation.

review_title: Engineering Middle Management
job_title: Senior Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: When I joined IBM was in the mist of designing, manufacturing, shipping and support the System 360 line of computers. The S/360 catapulted IBM to the fortune 500. Innovation in technology  was the driving force that set IBM ahead of it's competitors until the late 1980's.
cons: In the late 80's IBM abandoned it's technology roots. Started buying other companies technology putting it in a Blue Box with IBM logo and marking it up 40%. IBM sold off the DISK file business to Hatatci and cut way back on developing advanced technologies in favor of growing the SERVICE functions. IBM now has NO Competitive Advantage. EDS and many other companies are good at SERVICE. IBM has outsourced much of it's workforce to India and Japan. The health plan is but a shadow of the great plan offered in the 1970's.

review_title: Great Name, terrible place to work if you don't like stress!
pros: Great benefits, and a great name on the resume.
cons: Managment will tell you what you want to hear, but the truth will be completely different. When getting an offer, they tell you it will be reg full time, and most times you become a long-term suppelmental (basically contract) you get less benefits compared the regulars.  They tell you that you will be converted soon and it takes years no matter how hard you work.  Over worked, under paid.  pay is 40K in rochester, no matter what, no negotiations, and unless you want to live in Rochester, MN, stay away.  Not worth the stress.

review_title: Micromanaged to death

Managers refuse to tell upper line management anything that they do not want to hear . . . will actually remove truthful statements from RCAs if they dont want upper line management to see it.  Way too many layers of management and they are completely out of touch.

review_title: Good starting job.

cons: If you aren't revenue generating you are considered back office and if you are in the US there is a good chance your job over time will be moved offshore.  Best opportunities for me are oversees. If you get out of mgt its hard to find your way back in. No longer reimburse for professional certifications but I'm glad I obtained tthem.

review_title: Functional consultant in Global Business Services in Italy and in the UK
pros: People attitude is one of the best ever met. Everyone is keen on teaching and helping. I have had great managers who demonstrated to care about you as an individual. Secure job: difficult to get fired .
cons:
Lack of mobility within different company functions. So that if you want to have a career within IBM, you need to enter and remain in HQ. 
Consultants rarely have a salient role in company strategy.
Salaries and salaries increase are very low and few.

review_title: Not a place to start your career
pros: IBM employs very smart software engineers.
cons:
I started my job right out of college at IBM, with high hopes unfortunately..

- Pay was far below average with raises only going to the 'top performers'.
- My manager was non-technical, had 20-30 people under her and honestly had no clue what most of her employees job's were. When review time came, she skimmed through what we wrote about ourselves and rated everyone as 'average' aka no bonus + no layoff.
- Lots of layoffs which caused a very negative attitude around the office.
- The work was boring. Being right out of college it's fun to work with new technologies, at IBM you're forced to use old technologies like Java and Dojo for web.
- It's very hard to get into a leadership role unless you've worked at IBM for a long time.
- No free coffee or anything for that matter. Honestly how hard is it to offer your employees free coffee?
- IBM's "agile" is a joke, it's really just waterfall.

By working at IBM I learned what type of company to avoid.

review_title: Wasted potential
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: IBM does a little nvite if everything, so you can  get to work on pretty much any problem, with some of the brightest people in the field. They were an early adopter of remote work, and manage distributed teams much better than most other large companies. There is a non management track for technical careers. Very good diversity initiatives. Enlightened time off policies. Lots of open source opportunities.
cons: The company is still pretty hierarchical. Senior management is not interested in quality products or services, till recently just financial engineering to drive up share price short term. There is too much middle management for employees to be empowered to make decisions quickly. Even one bad line manager can completely derail your career — HR's only there to minimize liability. Although there is a technical career track, the pace of promotions is glacial, the product of another decade. Hiring processes are mediocre, and there are layoffs every year.

review_title: Slow, dated, stagnant & boring

- You can get paid to basically do nothing, if that's your thing
cons:

- Clueless non-technical management chain

- Horrible proprietary workflow/"productivity" software
- Getting anything accomplished requires wading through miles of red tape
- Rabid focus on churning out patents

- Management does not listen to or care about your concerns

review_title: Be Warned: This company majors in the minors and produces loads of DISSATISFIED IBMers
pros:
