cons:
* Constant threat of layoffs hanging over your head (there's no real rhyme or reason for the management team's decisions)
* Employees are not treated respectfully by management (of course this varies with your manager, some are humane but First Line Management team does not have any real authority, they are just handing down the directives form upper management)
* MASSIVE amounts of overtime EXPECTED in most areas of IBM.  And don't expect anything extra for it... you are basically told "be happy you have a job"
* No or minimal raises, there were no bonuses in 2014 for the vast majority of IBMers

review_title: IBM used to be a great company to work for, now it's just a job.
pros: I have worked with some great people, unfortunately they have pretty much all been RA or retired.  Pros: my pay check has never bounded.   lol
cons:
Management used to understand the stress and challenges of the job but most have been promoted from other areas and hence don't understand.   They want to make a sales force out of all the technical employees.   Don't they understand that we are all wired different. 

HW support used to be top notch, however they have fallen out of sorts by RA the good employees and off-shoring of jobs.    Haven't had a raise in years.   Local IBM let a good tech walk because they didn't want to spend 1/2 of what they have spent training his replacement.

review_title: very good company
pros:
good salary ,good environment,This article is about the technology company sometimes referred to as "Big Blue". For other uses of these terms, see IBM (disambiguation) and Big Blue (disambiguation).
International Business Machines Corporation


International Business Machines Corporation (commonly referred to as IBM) is an American multinational technology and consulting corporation, with headquarters in Armonk, New York. IBM manufactures and markets computer hardware, middleware and software, and offers infrastructure, hosting and consulting services in areas ranging from mainframe computers to nanotechnology.[3]

The company originated in 1911 as the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR) through a merger of the Tabulating Machine Company, the International Time Recording Company, and the Computing Scale Company.[4][5] CTR was changed to "International Business Machines" in 1924, using a name which had originated with CTR's Canadian subsidiary. The initialism IBM followed. Securities analysts nicknamed the company Big Blue for its size and common use of the color in products, packaging, and logo.[6]
cons: no cons no cons no cons

review_title: Junior IT Specialist
pros: Good people to work with, great working atmosphere, nice starting job for experience.
cons:
Company lies  regarding career development and salary growth. Let me warn you, once you enter with your base salary it will NEVER EVER change. They will tell you any excuse (freeze, low profit, etc) and in the meantime they will suck all your experience and skills.

My advise, if you are an average joe, fresher. Join to learn some minor experience and leave after 1 year.
If instead you are a senior, ask for high expectations as they will never change that later, if they refuse it is because they were already lying at you and are trying to scam seniors for low budget for low position works.

review_title: Good for building experience on CV
pros: Good place to gain experience in positions that are hard to come by where experience is necessary. A lot of smart and good people (those that are left onshore)
cons: Pay rises or band increases are a very rare thing in GTS ANZ right now. If you get an opportunity to gain experience in a higher up position, be aware that its most likely that youre seen as a cheap resource and the position has probably come up due to a redundancy to cut costs... so dont expect more pay for working a higher position for a while. Too much red tape/beauracracy. Not a lot of support.

review_title: Good place to start if all else fails
pros:
Work life balance is good, short hours in comparison to the likes of Accenture
Good variety of projects and clients
Some (although limited) opportunities to travel
Good self promotion process (when freezes aren't in place)
Graduate induction was fun
cons: Poor culture, a huge focus on 'being 100% billable' at the moment which results in a very negative feel. Due to 13+ declining quarters of revenues there has been continuous promotion freezes, statutory redundancies, holiday bans  and training bans. There is never a 'Thank you' at the end, the bonus scheme is abysmal and although the starting salary is good it doesn't remain competitive. The technology we use internally is so outdated as well which is extremely ironic.

review_title: IBM Public Sector Consulting is a good place to work
pros:
- Public sector consultants mostly stay in the DC area, so there isn't as much travel as commercial consultants.
- Pay starts off very competitive when you're first hired on.
- IBM's software suite and knowledge base is unmatched.
- Good coworkers, good clients, good work/life balance.
cons:
- IBM is very stingy about bonuses, and annual raises do not keep up with the market. After you've been at IBM for a while you're better off leaving for a year or two, then coming back, in order to stay at a competitive salary.
- There's a lot of bureaucracy and pointless busywork that affects your annual performance review. But that's probably unavoidable at a company the size of IBM.

review_title: Mixed Feelings
pros: I've been with IBM for a number of years.  I've always been proud of the longevity of IBM's commitment to diversity, specifically the LGBT community.  I've found great support from most managers, directors and leaders. However... (continue to Cons)
cons:
Our current CEO currently has a very close relationship with the current US Trump administration--an administration does not value diversity or trust.  Makes me doubt how genuine IBM's commitment to diversity is.
Separately, there is currently little job security at IBM currently and the severance/layoff package is only 1 month's pay no matter how long an employee has worked at IBM.  So when working at IBM, even if you are a  long-term full-time employee it is better to think of yourself as a contractor.

review_title: Great People to work with but the company struggles to transform  itself without outdated systems and processes
pros:
Great people willing to help and support you.
Remote working has been part of their DNA for years. 
Shifted to open plan touchdown working in the offices to help with collaboration.
Great flexibility to do a lot of different roles in IBM to grow your career
cons:
Outdated internal systems that require a lot of manual intervention as well as complex business processes that negatively impact the way in which you transact with the customer. 

A lot of great leaders have left the business as the operating model has become very frustrating.

Duplication of cadence and reviews which waste time and seldom add value and impacts the ability to meet clients.

review_title: Working at IBM has its advantages.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Fairfax, VA
pros: IBM issues laptops to all of their employees and depending on your manager this makes working remotely fairly easy to do. When it comes to HR related tasks IBM seems to trust their employees and their managers as vacation/sick time is not centrally tracked.
cons: IBM is an extremely large company and as such sometimes suffers from its size. Because of its large size the company has implemented many process/requirements that cause inefficiencies in day to day work.  Compensation and pay are awarded based on a pool system that is sub-divided as you move down the organization which results in limited flexibility for managers to reward top performing employees. Additionally as the company is spread across the globe you may be working with people who you've never met face to face for years.

review_title: Great company to work and develop your skills in
pros:
Great opportunity to learn and pursue skill development(incl. well established educational and e-learning oportunities); Global company(with many locations all over); Good awareness of virtual teams, cross-division and cross-culture collaboration. 

As a global company that sells all over and is not only focuses on a single market/region, great potential to do fine over time and not be dependent on the economy ups and downs in a single region.

There are various innovative venues for employees to show their ideas and collaborate with others- incl. Blue Opportunity and BizTeck projects which enable you to take some of your weekly time and work on a cool project with a team other than your regular job' team.
cons: Too big of a company to get noticed or to find who works on what and who to talk to.

review_title: Strong company, great opportunity but low morale.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: If you are good at networking there are several opportunities as this is a huge company with operations in most countries / areas. The company is very diverse and there is increased flexibility with the regards to working remotely , from home, etc. Many employees only need a laptop and power cord to conduct their day to day. This company has been around the good and bad times and has survived as the true elephant it has been called. The benefits package is good.
cons: The pay is not considered the highest. The current morale is not good.There is a big push to move US jobs to Asia so you should always look to stay competitive and look at jobs that require a close presence. Many coworkers are working 60+ hours. Because of cuts, many are overworked.

review_title: Getting rid of retirement Eligible Employees
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Decent  salary and benefits compared to other available jobs in the area are the only reasons I can think of that might justify working at IBM nowadays.
cons: IBM has lost all respect for it's employees.  After working there for almost 36 years and always getting reviews ranging from "always  far exceeds requirements"  to "always exceeds requirements"  I was suddenly told I was underperforming and was let go!  It just so happens that there were 3 of us doing the job and I was the one with the most years (translation "highest paid").   It's just all about the bottom line now- no more concern for the employees at all!

review_title: Work Life Balance does not exist!
job_title: IT Specialist in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Great people to work with.
Great flexibility for work at home.
Competitive salary and benefits
cons:
If you are on call, you can expect no work-life balance.  You can expect to be called at odd hours, and while on vacation.
Way to focused on outsourcing to China and India.
Although the flexibility to work at home is great, it leaves you disconnected with your team.
If you enjoy 60+ hour work weeks, then it is a great place to work.
A LOT of information provided, VERY difficult to find it.
Vacation - use it or loose it, but management makes it hard to use it.
Quoted form another poster:  "...you won't have any opportunity to improve your skill set (since you will be in the same role for a few years...it's IBM's way of doing things)"

review_title: Good corporate culture and work/life balance, poor pay and advancement opportunities
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros:
Good corporate culture: Not expected to work weekends/holidays/etc.  Managers and other employees are respectful and courteous, even when there are disagreements.  
Excellent work life balance.  I can work from home any time I want to, work fairly flexible hours, and take time off when I need to for personal reasons.
cons: Huge company bureaucracy makes it difficult sometimes to get things done, or even find out what decision was made about a key issue.  Interfacing with development partners can be challenging.  Pay is poor -- my salary has not even kept up with inflation since I started working here -- and advancement opportunity is limited.  There is no reward for working hard or going "above and beyond"; everyone gets pretty much the same (small) profit sharing every year.

review_title: It's a big company!
pros: The work can be stimulating and challenging, but it depends on the organization. The pay is decent (they claim they're competitive). Many areas encourage employees to work from home. Good benefits.
cons: Due to its size, different areas can be run very differently. If you're in a bad area, it can be hard to get out. Many areas micromanage expenses to the point where it's really rather ridiculous. Employees are just another commodity and the easiest way to reduce expenses fast is to let them go. If you get anointed, you stay anointed whether you deserve it or not. If you don't get anointed, it seems like nothing you can ever do will get you anointed. ("If he/she were good, he/she would have been promoted and rewarded before this...")

review_title: Wasted 5 years of my life
pros:
get to see how disorganized a big company really is.
There is a lot of chances to innovate/improve because there are so many gaps
They have more processes then even they are aware of.
cons:
HR is the worst Dept - not involved in hiring, hid from employees, bias to senior management
Executives have terrible personalities and it manifests in their organization design and decisions
GDF - Killing Mindset and behaviour.
IBM CEO till 2011 - Disrespectful to the employees

review_title: Enriching from knowledge point of view but pathetic for the people angle.
pros: IBM Research and global teams are excellent.We primarily have a grid system in which all the industries, sectors, service line and team merge to bring out a unique value proposition for the organisation and client all around the world. Also given that we have expertise and next generation solutions for each sphere of business, one tends to grow deep skills and expertise specific to their job or roles.
cons: Nobody cares about creativity, people management or even allowing flexibility. Its just based on who your boss is and he/she can either ruin or help you move up the career path regardless of how  much or how effectively one works

review_title: Lots of smart people, less opportunity in the US
job_title: Program Director in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Lots of great, smart people. A good place to start or change career paths and work as part of an experienced community. Mentoring and common career communities are top-notch (technical and non-technical), but on you to participate and make the time to contribute.
cons: There definitely an effort to reduce headcount in the US. Visible shifts with less opportunity and job security for US and Western Europe employees. Shifts in compensation and HR policies make staying long term less attractive. Expense control is insultingly tight and is a near daily hinderance to getting work done.  A common joke is wondering when we'll all have to bring our own chairs to work.

review_title: An unpleasant place to work
job_title: IT Consultant in Rio de Janeiro
pros:
- Good work environment
- Team co-workers are always willing to help you when something big arises
cons:
- IBM likes to use a bunch of white lies when you are under interviews (such as career plan). I was promoted after 4 years working in the company and my salary still the same (always having good/excellent PBC 2/2+ rate). The only thing which was increased was my work load and my inbox :-)
- Each IBM department is a completely new world in terms of effort recognition, opportunity, etc (so you end up being in a lottery game where you never know what the result will be).
- A negative work/life balance rate (team leaders bringing you work for weekend all the time).

review_title: Not the future you are looking for if you want to grow.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Flexibility with work location and schedule. Reasonable management chain. The vast majority of employees are pleasant to work with.
cons: People who tend to stay at IBM are interested in optimizing their work/life balance, not pushing the envelope. This is a place for folks who like meetings, process, talking and power point. Unfortunately this cultural reinforcement has resulted in chasing off true development and technical talent which is not tolerant of these activities. Given the focus on cost cutting there is not much money to pay talent and due to the widespread exodus of engineering ability it is nearly impossible for management to recognize the truly skilled contributors from the pretenders.

review_title: Great people and technology held back by process
pros:
Work with some of the smartest people
Access to pretty much any fortune 1000 company that you want during product lifecycle
They will pay tuition for recognized programs on a you pass we pay basis
cons:
The organization is so stuck in the processes that it sometimes feels like you can not make move forward.  
Moral can sometimes be challenging.   In some cases it feels like an emotional roller coaster.
I so want to rate this company a 5 to work for as it has so much potential.  However the current state with regards, to compensation, moral and work/life balance dragged it down.

review_title: Fantastic Company
pros: IBM was a fantastic company to work for and provided plenty of opportunity for skills development, learning, and career growth. It also seemed to me that employees got out of IBM exactly what they put into it. Some just coasted along and got "average" performance reviews for average performance. But for those who really want to feel like they are making a difference and want to expand their career, IBM will support them full stop. NOTE: This review is based on my work with Software Group within IBM, which tends to be much more progressive and faster paced than other groups.
cons: The growth of my career and opportunities for development were directly proportionate to how progressive and open minded my direct manager was.

review_title: Good Old Boy Network with Discriminatory Pay and Delusional Perspective
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Hopewell, NY
pros: Excellent training ground if you are willing to work hard and learn.  Multitude of opportunities to contribute, across many different skill sets. I was able to voluntarily leave, take my skill sets, and leverage them for more than twice the salary at another large company.  You will never hear me complain about what I learned there, and some of the unsung heroes that I worked with and learned from.
cons: Do not expect to receive recognition for your contributions.  Managing up, including misrepresentation of contributions and facts, are the best way to advance.  This contributes not only to unfairness, but to the downfall of the enterprise.  Discrimination was outrageous in the chip division.

review_title: Good company
pros: Good culture, supportive managers, flexible work (home office), possibility to develop in the aria you want, a lot of training material available online, you can constantly learn, traveling and working on global projects, find out about the jobs you didn't know they existed
cons: Difficult to get promoted despite doing jobs that are above you current band and salary, it can take years,  bad compensation comparing to other similar companies, a lot of process restrictions, some middle management is really old school management type

review_title: Marketing
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Global business exposure and a good place to start a career.  Lots of good people and managers, and there was once an ethos in the company.
cons: No job security ever. The intent of the company is to treat full-time people like contractors. Politics growing as the same senior people get the opportunities, so you are in or you are out. Benefits decreasing. No longer good for families. Constant layoffs that never seem to effect the top layer. Stopping employees from taking vacation by giving them so much work that its impossible. Forget any opportunity if you stay too long. Silicon Valley hours and expectations without the shared equity.

review_title: We need to improve a lot
pros:
So many tools and checks in place, its good to track team activities.
IBM values are excellent.
cons: One side we are promoting to be agile but practically there are so many things which we are doing as per ancient age people used to it. Can't we change those set patterns and start innovative ideas to improve our daily activities, this will improve our productivity.

review_title: Typical big company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Wide range of jobs to work in during your career. Recognized brand opens doors.
cons:
Fairly political old boy culture. Institutional ego: they've been doing things their way for so long they don't realize the rest of the world works differently. People who start their careers at IBM think it's normal until they move on and realize there's a whole spectrum of color in the world, not just drab blue. Management tries to compensate with lots of cheerleading and arm waving, but it's all words with no substance. After a 3 day "Jam", where all 400K employees were supposed to collaborate on values and purpose, the big epiphany was that customers come first.

In the absence of real revenue growth, management keeps cutting costs. It's the only place I've worked where you don't even get free coffee at the workplace.

review_title: Consulting by Degree - Waste of time
pros:
Chance to interact with senior executives 
Being part of a big technological movement e.i Blockchain 
Great work and life balance 
Big company, thus it's possible (but hard) to find your own space/voice 
Compensation jump from a consultant to senior consultant is great
cons:
Often you get assigned to a projects before SOWs are signed and they can take up months to get signed, thus might end up on bench for several weeks or even months
CbD program needs massive improvement, as CbDers we get three managers and all of them are useless 
It's hard to find people to vouch for you
Managers expect you to do work without a code
Some projects are waste of time, chances of it moving from POC or MVP to Pilot can be low 
Not a lot of project on the pipeline

review_title: Being an IBMer
pros: IBM would bring you a robust learning and experiences that would surely fit to your career path, if you really put focus and interest to your short and long term goal as an efficient employee.
cons: IBM can offer you lots of opportunities and allows to handle multiple role so long as you can, that requires also lots of efforts, extended hours but still it all pays off.

review_title: IBM CIC (Baton Rouge)
job_title: Applications Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
Educational Resources (maybe)
I am finally out!!!!!!!!!!!!
cons:
- Below the minimum industry compensation
- Weak benefits
- Long hours 
- 100% travel (Contract specifies only 50%)
- Terrible management (care only about numbers and will tell you whatever you want to hear) Never share anything and never trust them. I've seen people get burned because they were naive and trustworthy
- Baton Rouge, LA (No offence to this city, but NO thank you, never again. This city is the kingdom of boredom and depression) I bet if the center was located in New Orleans it would have been less depressing.
- Almost no chance to transfer (Beware, the unspoken policy to transfer is that you have to spend at least 2 years in CIC. Never specified in your contract. So was caught totally by surprise)
- No career path. You will be hired as a developer and will perform analyst work instead or/and vice versa. 
The list of Cons can go on even further, but I just wanted to highlight the major issues with this specific location.

review_title: Work-life balance can't be beat, but don't expect to be working on "cool" projects.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Lexington, KY
pros: Stability, work-life balance, prestige, breadth of opportunities.  IBM is a well-respected company and offers excellent understanding and support of a healthy work-life balance.  Working from home is rarely a problem and is popular among myself and my coworkers.  As long as the work gets done, management seems to care little whether you are in the office or working from home.
cons: Easy to get pigeon-holed and thus dissatisfied with job and unable to move on to something else.  Incompetence and seeming obliviousness of upper management.  "Cutting edge" Web-2.0ish projects are few and far between and are generally lacking in features and sophistication.

review_title: Travel to distant clients while talking to India every morning an night.
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: There is still some feeling of teamwork among certain practice groups.   It is possible to get good experience because you are working so closely on solving client's problems.     This experience comes on the back of the client and has your mgmt may have very little to add.
cons: Lots of travel to client site to stay in horrible IBM selected hotels.      Once you are on-site on the client you may have two spend your days working with the client and your evenings talking to IBM India.    Lots of staffing challenges trying to find competent technology folks in India.    Overall, a very difficult place to work.

review_title: Employees are just a cost at IBM!!
job_title: Senior Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Very innovative company within techonlogy sector
cons: Employees are not treated well.  Employees have gotten pay cuts even when IBM has record profits.  Employees are not getting rises even with good preformance.  I did not get a rise in 2008 even through I had over $350,000 of billable hours and helped win two mult-million dollar sales of IBM software.  I received no real financially reward for this only the sales team got a financial benefit.  The sales team gave me $25.00 Thanks reward for this work.  I found this total unjust and insulting.  To conclude employees at IBM are seen as a cost to upper mangemet and not as an asset.  All companyies say that employees are assets to they companies but only a few truly mean it and IBM is not a company that means it.

review_title: Saccharine
pros: Work life balance is second to none. One can juggle a home life, study requirements and the job and still have some down time without feeling as if it is begrudged by the employer. It is practically encouraged. The team spirit is there which is positive for obvious reasons but there is also the "peer pressure" to be available and so on. This is however a soft bit of pressure rather than old style "face time" pressure.
cons: So much time has to be spent trying to figure out who is in charge of what or doing what that there is much less time doing actual work and making decisions.

review_title: IBM Good for 1-3 years MAXIMUM!
pros: Great learning experiences to work with talented teams, large fortune 500 companies and excellent training.
cons: No career growth. I know many project managers who have worked for 10 years and still not even making 100k where as the PMs who leave to go elsewhere such as biotech companies, financial industry, health care or technology companies with only 5 years of PM experience out of college are making 100k salaries.

review_title: Just one of the herd, not unlike any other IT consulting company.
pros: Potential to be exposed to many different technologies.  Good internal training and decent benefits. Very respectable company that is working hard to provide better consulting services.  Good outlook for security services with the acquisition of a lot of smaller specialized security firms.  Pay is adequate and time off is respected.
cons: Just feel like you are one of the pack.  No personal attention given my managers to consultants.  Managers make the individual responsible for finding the next project to work on.  Opportunities to attend training events and conferences only seem to go to only the most senior consultants.  Can get stuck on projects that don't fit your background if the proper personnel aren't available.

review_title: IBM, A Good Place To Work
job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Access to the latest IT productivity tools.  Good training/professional development resources.  The opportunity to lead teams comprised of full-time, part-time, and contract employees.  The compensation, medical benefits, 401K plan are 'on par' with other companies in the Global Business Services industry.
cons: You'll need to understand that there's an 'IBM way' of doing things, this can be an adjustment for recent graduates that haven't been previously employed in a corporate environment.  There was a time when first and second level management worked together to lead employees; that has changed dramatically.  During the last 4 years i was employed, there was a lot of reassignments of first level and second level managers.

review_title: Not very good.
pros:
If you want to come at any time and want to go at any time then this company is good for you. Nobody is recording your in/out time. you can have work life balance. 
Infinite sick leave is the best thing here. People have gone for 9 months of sick leave without any problem. 
Work from home facility.
If you get a chance to go to onsite (USA only) then it is gr8.
cons: Not very talented or challenging people here. Most of them are lazy. They are ready to point finger to someone else. No increment for new joinees for 2 years. After 2 years you will get maximum 6-7% hike after all hard work and great rating. Variable is just to show on ur offer letter. You get only 10% of that.

review_title: Over worked and under paid - but good place to start a career.  Get some skills then get out!
pros: Workplace flexability is the best reason to work at IBM...  Also it looks good on a resume.  Lots of product areas means lots to learn.
cons: Way too many lofty expectations and lack of compensation when you actually pull of what they want.  The management politics and process slows everything.  They make 80% of their revenue on 20% of their clients - a huge portion of which is mainframe hardware sales which are declining severely.  IBM is a sinking ship that can't innovate.

review_title: Fantastic people, but changing mentality
pros:
I worked at the Almaden research center and in the Yorktown research center
Great research with state-of-the-art equipment.
Very knowledgeable people, who are also friendly and reliable
Still good core values of the IBM company, with people doing their whole 40-year career at IBM
Personnel encouraged to patent, publish and go to conferences
Internal recognition through awards
cons:
Compensation below microelectronics industry average 
Hard to obtain information on the technology orientation for future processor generations
Company starts to rely too heavily on process improvement rather than disruptive innovation
Excessive bureaucracy
Recurrent budget restrictions even though IBM Research is highly profitable

review_title: IBM is a good company. Brand + normal package + flexibility + freedom + RESPECT
pros:
1. Work from home - flexibility
2. Freedom - gives abundant time to complete certain unit of work.
3. package - Normal one as other companies do - not much to expect
4. Onsite chances - if you are lucky.
5. Brand value 
6. Respect - which you get with the clients
cons:
1. Low package - which is normal across similar companies. - But this is not the company where you can expect more than normal
2. There are only limited leaves per year - 22 I think which can't be even used fully since utilization % may go down.
3. Getting relieved from a project would be a headache, sometime this may lead to put down your papers .

review_title: Very good 14 years then forced into downward spiral
job_title: Technical Team Lead in Durham, NC
pros: Good benefits, good time off and work life balancing.  Decent salaries but they will plateau.  Non management personnel have some exceptional people to work with.
cons: Hit a glass ceiling, difficult management for technical people to work with.  Work continually increasing and fewer people to handle it.  Constant push to do more than be excellent at the job you are assigned.  Enough is never enough.  Lack of education and new opportunities.

review_title: Not a company you'd love working for
pros:
Flexibility as long as you perform, many people work from home
'Some' very competent people
Working at large companies whom outsource to IBM makes it interesting
Opportunity to move to other accounts
Let you take on responsibility if you so wish
cons:
Enforcement of global processes which make little sense locally - such as mandate to send work to Softlayer cloud, GDF program, order process for new hardware
Lack of training for technical staff (but improving)
Pay freeze, travel freeze - really tight on perks. 
Recognition award from management is bottle of wine and a certificate! Its an in house joke and high performers don't even want to be nominated

review_title: Nothing special anymore --Sr. PM, northeast US
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Northeast, NY
pros: Like many other reviews, the work-at-home option is a great perk.  I spend a lot of phone time (and some face time) with a great group of coworkers
cons:
Once IBM was a special place to work.  I don't doubt that things had to change, but IBM has changed so much that now it is just a run of the mill employer  - actually worse than that, since they so aggressively try to cut back on the workforce and everything they provide the workforce.

I don't know why it took the markets so long to realize how deficient and how self-interested the senior management really is.  But now the cat is out of the bag.

review_title: Hard work at a company that cannot sustain itself.
job_title: Market Segment Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The company has a storied history. It also has a set of values it tries to adhere to. It's not always successful at that but it is better than many other companies in the industry and the values don't change based on the whims of management.
cons: IBM saddled itself with a pledge of a $20 per share of earnings target target that it cannot reach in face of changes in the market. That target caused them to make cuts and jettison businesses that had a strong future because they we weighing on the earnings target. IBM  became increasingly desparate as the deadline for the earnings target came closer and it was not a fun place to be.

review_title: IBM on the decline
pros: Flexible enough to trust work from home employees, works well with minor changes to work schedule as long as it fits the client / account needs, most mid-level managers have heart and do care how changes in the company policies effect their employees
cons:
Constantly watching over your shoulder for the RA (IBM's term for layoff). 
No pay increases.  and pay ranges are actually lower than business averages in many job titles.
Higher management levels care more about the bottom line then the people.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked for!
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work from home, which is typical of most consulting jobs
cons:
There is a long list.. where shall i start. 
Lacks leadership and direction. 
Too much bureaucracy and an insane unreasonable obsession with outdated processes - some of which are xls based (can't believe I work in a major IT company). 
Extremely political. 
It doesn't matter whether you generate a higher billing rate for your work as long as you hit 150% utilization even if your rate is at the bottom.
The company finds every possible way to snatch away the tiny perks of traveling despite the sacrifice consultants do.
While consultants and those working on ground, who bring real money to the company keep getting ignored, senior management, which is mostly overhead keeps getting paid millions in bonuses and incentives.
If you don't have a godfather or a godmother in the company then god help you. Of course your godfather or godmother needs to be a strong politician within the company..
I can just go on and on..

review_title: Good culture, but not disruptive enough
pros: In the Software Group, good technical culture. Technical skills are valued, and good technical leads can influence the company. Also lots of great people to work with and learn from.
cons: Not disruptive enough, has become an industry follower rather than a leader. Company is also very distributed, a lot of work is with remote people through the phone or through conferencing; not enough face-to-face. Finally, though there is a good technical ladder, it is infinitely more competitive than the managerial ladder, resulting in less competent managers at equal levels with technical leaders.

review_title: Senior Software Sales
job_title: Senior Brand Client Representative in Zürich
pros: What really is valuable is the flexibility and the high acceptance for home office work. Sales do get high commission potential. And there are a lot of very nice people working at IBM Switzerland.
cons: Very high amount of working hours. There is a lot of  fluidity in how commissions are valued and paid. That this is solely under IBMs control can be demotivating. Also commissions are paid 1-3 months afterwards, the delay also is not helpful. There is way to much, unneccessary complexitiy in the sales operations processes.

review_title: The Good the Bad and the Ugly
job_title: Executive Program Manager in Sorrento, FL
pros: Great people from all over the world and from many different companies creating a great opportunity to learn.  Opportunities to work almost anywhere in the world. Still not bad healthcare and a fair 401k
cons:
The Bad....The pay is higher at other IT companies.
The Ugly....They think nothing of expecting you to work 70 hours a week month after month and of course there is no compensation for it.   Then when you do get a vacation there is no backup so when you get back you need to step it up to 80 hours a week for a while to get caught up.

review_title: First software job out of college
pros:
Great experience, good pay for a graduate, good for resume

This is my first job out of college and a great one at that.  I joined my team towards the end of last year during some restructuring within my small department.  The people are fantastic to work with, though most of them are much older than me.
cons: If I could change anything, it would be  to work with people closer to my age.  This is not to say there isn't anyone my age, just few.  Also, I'm not a big fan of the town I'm in.  It would be perfect for families though.

review_title: At IBM I have a career
job_title: Strategic and Executive Communications in New York, NY
pros: IBM makes a difference in people's lives by applying innovation and technology to create the future. IBM is unique in that it is the only technology company to reinvent itself through multiple technology eras and economic cycles. In 20+ years at the company I have continually found new career opportunities. I have stayed most of all because of the smart, ambitious and talented IBMers I have worked with over the years.
cons: Given its size and reach IBM can be slow moving. It can be difficult to see one's individual mission as essential to the whole. In a time of industry disruption, the pressure to keep skills relevant is relentless. As IBM moves our clients to the future, we as IBMers must constantly move ourselves to the future as well.

review_title: At IBM I have a career
job_title: Strategic and Executive Communications in New York, NY
pros: IBM makes a difference in people's lives by applying innovation and technology to create the future. IBM is unique in that it is the only technology company to reinvent itself through multiple technology eras and economic cycles. In 20+ years at the company I have continually found new career opportunities. I have stayed most of all because of the smart, ambitious and talented IBMers I have worked with over the years.
cons: Given its size and reach IBM can be slow moving. It can be difficult to see one's individual mission as essential to the whole. In a time of industry disruption, the pressure to keep skills relevant is relentless. As IBM moves our clients to the future, we as IBMers must constantly move ourselves to the future as well.

review_title: as an IBMer
pros:
A very special IT, Consulting, Services and Product company.
Hugh and flexible to learn lot many things subject to individuals networking ability within the organization.
Kick-off to change and transformation are highly commendable.
cons:
Hugh / giant organization that takes heavy time to see transition and any moves.
Complex internal process and systems.
A bad pay-master but takes enough of utilization irrespective of banding and salary.
Though the strategies are well thought and aligned to markets; the delivery wing shall be far away from the competitive realties.

review_title: From GREAT to Good
pros: IBM has survived many dramatic changes in the technology landscape. It is great place to balance your work life and pursue other interests. This is a great company for the senior & mature staff. There is a promise of big transformation.
cons:
Today's young generation techies would find it a lot more slow & un-trendy than they expect. Salary has been extremely poor lately...almost negligible increments year on year. Silly that people are duped into long term career prospect but there is no notable recognition of loyalty. In fact the employee recognition has become  a lip service.

In past IBM's focus had moved from selling machines(mainframe, servers) to selling people (skill), but recently the focus is back on machines(watson, cloud).

review_title: Some notes from a former contractor
pros: Good variety of projects and locations. Personnel are friendly and professional. Excellent opportunity to work with technical experts. Flexible schedule and remote opportunities are a big plus.
cons: For a supposed leader in tech, far too many inefficient processes. Receiving a badge and a login for key systems took way too long after completing a background check and coming on site. Processes for protocols were not transparent and required asking multiple people. The need to call tech support to change a password is incomprehensible and inexcusable.

review_title: Working in IBM: a Millennial Take on the Corporate World
pros: Loads of knowledge out there. You can meet some of the smartest minds - the extended team is across the globe. Great exposure to various cultures & beliefs and more importantly you never have to worry about doing the same job for the rest of your life.
cons: Corporate culture can be intimidating at times. You have to spend time networking with the right people. It doesn't matter what you do in the workplace, what matters is what others think you're doing in the workplace - Sad Truth

review_title: Contract CSR - IBM Global Services
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Saint John, NB
pros:
- Work from home
- Continuous Training
- Good opportunities to develop skills.
cons:
- No advancement (even if willing to move to contact center location)
- Low pay
- No benefits
- Contract work (1 year, 2 years, 3 years), after 5 years with the company, you need to take a year off.
- Employee mus pay for Internet (Business Speed, or FibreOp), and homephone.
- Will find ways to cut pay "by the minute".  (Basically, you end-up paying for your bio-breaks, whether 2 minutes or 5 minutes.)  If it's slow on the phones they tell people to log-off but don't pay for time off the phone.  Eventually, your 40 hrs/week could come to less than 40 hrs/week.

review_title: Below average employer
pros:
-Working hours flexibility.
-Working from home option.
-Nice & friendly overall atmosphere. 
-Good for beginning a career in IT.
cons:
-Process obsessed. 
-Too many politics.
-Frugality is taken to the extreme, cost cutting has impressive aspects: no screen monitors (a real pain in the butt during working days), no supplies of any kind in the kitchens (no sugar, tea, coffee.. etc.)..
-Low pays compared to market. 
-Slow paced environment. IBM is mainly like an huge elephant..
-Continues to lose competitiveness in the market with the rise of AWS & the momentum going quite well for Microsoft, especially in Cloud & Xaas market.
-Not for highly skilled, aggressive, competitive professionals who would like to see their career growth boosted & their market value enhanced considerably in few years.

review_title: Sinking ship.
pros: Good co-workers, decent pay, good schedule.
cons:
TERRIBLE upper management, AWFUL corporate vision, constant lay off, furloughs, and pay cuts.
IBM's corporate vision to make a profit has been to abandon what it was good at and jump on the trendy Cloud Computing   model (5years after Amazon, Google, and Microsoft). IBM is failing so the answer to turn a profit over the last 5 years has been to slash qualified personnel stateside and hire droves of unskilled unqualified workers overseas. Layoffs, pay cuts, and terminating employees close to retirement.

review_title: Work Hard and Invest
pros: IBM helps tech people build and prove their resumes, facing the tough global labor market. IBM motivates employees to constantly re-invent themselves to bring value to each customer. Well-defined corporate ethical policies enable employees to stand on high moral ground in technology projects.
cons: IBM's stock buybacks amid sagging revenues may be feel like disinvestment. Technology careerists like IBMers benefit from investment, which helps them research & develop, train, innovate, produce revenues, and thrive.

review_title: Best Work-Life Balance
pros:
Global culture
Rich values around Giving Back to Community
Best work-life balance
Best place for diversity
cons:
Top-down culture
Local governance
Location wise opportunities are little less

review_title: IBM's future is not certain
pros: It is a very stable environment to work, and if you don't like doing what you like odds are pretty good that you can switch to another division in IBM fairly easily. There are a large number of interesting projects going on at any given time, and it's nice to be able to say you work at IBM.
cons: Management is completely unaware of what is required to produce quality products, at least in my division of IBM. There is a general lack of respect and concern for the products, and it is obvious that many of the managers are only concerned with their careers without any regard to anything or anyone else.

review_title: Good company - while it lasts.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: An extraordinary level of flexibility in where/how you work in software development. Many IBMers work at home. This is great for allowing time to deal with the demands of life.
cons: The pressure to perform and deliver is intense and consistent while the reward is 'having a job'. The flexibility (ability to work at home at any hour) also has the ability to morph into a strong negative depending on your managements expectations and people skills. You will be expected to work from home during the evenings/late night. You will be expected to work weekends when management deems it necessary. Management will send you email on the weekend and expect a response. Management will call you on the weekend to instruct you to work on a hot problem/defect.

review_title: Great working environment in Research division.
job_title: Research Graduate Co-Op in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: IBM had a very relaxed environment.  Although I was a co-oping for them while finishing my masters degree, the atmosphere was very laid back.
cons: If you work for IBM for a long time and try to move to another industry, you're in for a little culture shock, most places aren't that laid back compared to IBM.  I know several people who left IBM to work for one of the big finance companies and they went back to IBM to beg for their job back because they couldn't handle the workload and amount of off-hour commitments.  Try to keep yourself up to date on technologies and hardware that's going on outside of IBM to avoid becoming a dinosaur.

review_title: IBM-START YOUR CAREERHERE
pros:
Excellent place to launch acareer.Difficult to move up but benefits and expereince make up for that.I say one should go for it.At IBM, we make some of the industry's most advanced information technologies, including computer systems, software, networking systems, storage devices and microelectronics. Equally impressive is our worldwide network of IBM solutions and services' professionals that translate these advanced technologies into business value for our customers. 
  
Our range of products and services has given IBM a unique role in the networked world; we are at the center of the global e-business revolution. It's fuelling our growth and inspiring our people. If you spend some time with our people in an R&D lab, in a brainstorming session or even in the cafeteria over lunch, you'll feel it. A strong sense of purpose. A new determination.
cons: Moving up and benefits aren't as great.

review_title: IBM Bangalore Software Engineer
pros:
Flexibility to work, work from home, reduced working time options available
Documentation of work is considered very important and so there is a lot of scope to learn the environment or about the project for the new joiners.
cons:
Salary or pay package is very much less when compared to peers at any other IT companies, the joining salary may be higher than other companies like Wipro, Infosys but the hikes are very small and sometimes zero percent and very ambiguous that we sometimes see ourselves paid lesser than the person who enters the team with lesser experience and qualification/skills. 
Communication to HR is only through Managers, so Managers' decision is final.
No much onsite opportunities and performance recognition is very rare.

review_title: Rated as one of the top 100 Canadian employers until 2006.  Off the list since 2007.  Coincidence?  I think not.
job_title: Staff Software Developer in Toronto, ON
pros:
Very competitive salary in the Toronto / Ontario region
Flexible work arrangements - flex hours, working at home
IBM still viewed highly in the industry - looks good on the resume
cons:
Layers of management and bureaucracy to wade through, wasting your time from doing your actual work
Little to no organic innovation
Rewards those who play the political game and position themselves well, rather than those who consistently output quality work
50-55 hour weeks are the norm, with 60-65 crunch weeks often enforced, for weeks and months at a time

review_title: Awful place to work
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Essex Junction, VT
pros: Very good co-workers, nice facility. Good place to learn about semiconductor manufacturing and test. Beautiful area of the country in Vermont. Management was good at giving people time off when needed.
cons: The extremely negative atmosphere made it a very hard place to work. Everybody was stressed out about coming to work and wondering when, not if, the next layoff would occur and who was next on the chopping block. There is and was little to no upper progression for most. The supposed mentoring program was a joke. IBM Burlington is just about the only game in town with decent wages and they know it. Little to no acknowledgement of a job well done. Lack of communication. The type of business is very cyclical with many ups and downs. When the business is down, the first thing they do is get rid of people and equipment.

review_title: Great Place to Work If you Can Find a Hiring Opportunity
job_title: Project Manager in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros:
Competitive salary
EXCELLENT Benefits
Vast knowledge base & learning resources
Great place to build your skill base
Global teams
cons:
VERY High Stress
Executive Management that is only interested in their next position
Managers that often have little actual management experience
Limited respect for the individual employee
Very high attrition through layoffs within the US workforce

review_title: Once was great - not so much anymore.
pros: Technically challenging projects for large customers.  Definitely a great opportunity to learn on the job.  Enjoyed working at IBM for the first 10 years but the last few were unpleasant.
cons: Forced work on weekends (no pay).  Utilization targets that mean you have to work overtime (no pay) before you can take vacation.  All training is on your own time.  Moral is very low. Low compensation and bonus is a joke.  Very disappointed in what IBM has become and now that I left, I see just how bad I was being treated.  Wish I had left a few years ago.

review_title: Good place to work, if you can avoid Global Services
pros: Many great, smart people.  Flexible and interesting work.  Good pay.
cons: Moved to Global Services after 20 years in Development.  What a difference!!  Global Services is a soulless organization.  The first three things in their mind are 1. utilization, 2. utilization, 3. utilization.  And the fourth thing is reporting utilization on time (or even better, report it early). Only place I've ever worked where their attitude is that if you have been around long enough to earn more vacation (or happen to get sick), you need to work more overtime in order to hit your utilization target (based on total hrs, not available hrs).  I understand that Global Services is a labor-based organization and utilization is a key metric.  But it's an obsession with management.  First time I have ever felt completely devalued as a person.

review_title: Stressful beyond any normal work conditions, overworked, excessive hours, mandatory travel weekly, management bullying.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: In the beginning it is a great opportunity to grow within the company.  Also, in the beginning wonderful benefits for health and pension, 401k, etc.
cons: Many benefits reduced, pensions taken away.  Advancement diminished, layoffs every year, only to hire new, inexperienced employees or worse move jobs to other countries and layoff US employees after 20-30 years of experience.  Excessive work hours mandatory, averaging 60 or more hours per week with no compensation for salaried employees.  Mandatory travel, even when you live with in 10 minutes of a site location!!  Mandatory travel, meant on a plane weekly, home on weekends only.  Management bullied employees, forced early retirement, health risks due to excessive stress.

review_title: Good work life balance
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros:
Been here 14 years, learned a lot about various programming languages and technology.  

Able to spend half or more time working from home which is very nice.  Certainly this may vary for others depending on your manager and job role.

Stock options were very nice (while they lasted.)
cons:
Like most big companies like this, you are a resource that could be let go at any time.  

Any programming you may do outside of IBM still belongs to IBM legally because of the agreement you sign when hired..  

Can get competitive and stressful at times.  

There are legal rules/guidelines that are ridiculous and in conflict with each other:  things like MySQL, Wine and Citrix Receiver being banned for internal use by some internal areas within IBM but used freely by others.

review_title: Learning on the fly
pros:
You had good team support and training, the vacation and sick policy is very generous, along with some work hour flexibility at times, though getting true product and tools education was mostly a do it yourself project.  But if you worked at it and kept it in front of the manager, you would get it eventually.

One thing I did love was the working environment - very little sniping or backstabbing.  Rather amazing for a large corporate environment.
cons: Hard to promote up, there often seemed to be a real churn in leaders 1 and 2 levels above you.  Discovered after I left that were was a HUGE variance in pay for people in the same tasks.

review_title: Systems Group Brand Expense Analyst
pros: IBM provides great OTJ training, access to relevant systems and builds skills quickly in the field of finance. The workplace is highly flexible and there are frequent departmental activities and outings to build morale. Working at the finance Center of Excellence allows for a great deal of networking, team building, and skill sharing.
cons: There is a lot of turnover with a very young workforce. Individual roles vary widely in both responsibility and workload, with some having very little work while others require overtime. All finance employees enter under "long-term supplemental" status, which includes slightly less pay and less benefits.

review_title: Once upon a time, a great company.
job_title: Service Delivery Planner in Miami, FL
pros: IBM employs  some of the smartest people on the planet. The rank and file, every day non managers are some of the brightest and smartest people you can ever meet.  Very supportive, and highly efficient.
cons: Once upon a time, IBM was a great company.  Lou Gerstner saved IBM, but at the cost of its corporate soul.  Now IBM, while still a good place to work, but it's only average... Management is no different then any other tech company.... Id go as far as saying it's probably below average hen it comes to management and leadership.

review_title: Is your career progressing too quickly? IBM has the solution.
pros: The people are pretty cool, workload is minimal, performance reviews are basically an exercise in copying and pasting, and you will probably be able to work remotely or have flexible hours.
cons:
Caveat: median salaries for everything are higher where I live.
Wages are completely uncompetitive -- other employers are paying 20-50% more for the same work. You need to be "compliant" with whatever meaningless metric the executives are freaking out about this month. Career opportunities are slim to none. You get micromanaged by someone in another country who has no clue what your particular customers want or need. Everything from the aforementioned executive gets filtered through 5 layers of middle-management (think telephone game).

review_title: Horrible Company - an industry follower at best
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: There are none. 30 years ago it was a great company to work for. Senior management cared about the most valuable asset within the company, their employees. Today you are just a number no matter how well you perform. Salary and benefits lag behind the industry and management lacks vision.
cons:
Benefits are average at best, most  lag behind the industry. 
Salary lags industry and annual increases are hit or miss. Increase percentages are a joke. 
No clear direction from upper management. There truly is no vision, just great "buzz" words. 
The worst HR people in the industry. Most HR people are flunky's who flushed out of real jobs.

review_title: Burnout culture
pros: The salary was ok, however it's not worth it
cons: Many cons - burnout culture shows that IBM does not care about the long-term health and well-being of employees. Project timelines have gotten shorter and shorter, with expectations that employees will work 12+ hours per day to meet deadlines. It's impossible to meet the deadlines and to do any kind of quality work at an incessant manic pace. IBM has been in a financial downward spiral for many years, there is no end in sight and it seems that management doesn't know what to do about it at this point.

review_title: IBM Review
pros: IBM is a fine company to work for. There are plenty of avenues open to employees to further educate themselves and IBM will help.  For the 22 years I worked for them, I was able to further my education and open a couple of new chapters in my life. I was able to better myself quite a bit.
cons: IBM is a large company and sometimes it is difficult to find who you need to go to in order to go farther with things you are trying to do for customers.  But, once you do find the correct avenue, there is usually plenty lf information.

review_title: Current global redundancies
pros:
Name looks good on CV, but based on historical viewpoint.
Some wonderful people working there but these are leaving or being made redundant in droves - NB 5 rounds of redundancies in the last 2 years (at minimum pay)
cons:
16+ Quarters of losses
Poor salary increases/bonus
No overtime pay / pressure to work all hours
Awful work/life balance, unless you are fortunate to have a project close to home
Internal processes / systems are antiquated, clunky and more red tape than necessary
PBC system is awful, paying staff off against each other
Projects woefully undersold to get the client biting so cost cutting and quality cutting from the start and things only get worse thereon in.
You will be force to foist IBM products/tools on clients at every opportunity even though these are seen as out of date, unworkable and poor replications of market leaders (and very expensive to implement too).
You are a number in an accounting sheet not a person

review_title: Veteran friendly, encourages community service
pros:
As a veteran of the US military, I've always appreciated that IBM recognizes the unique value, skills, and experience each individual brings to the company. Our leadership supports hiring veterans and encourages  veterans working for the company to share their thoughts and help others with military career transitions.

Additionally, I appreciate the company focus on corporate citizenship. As an individual IBM, I've found volunteer opportunities in my community and logged time I committed to nonprofit organizations I've served. I received an IBM community grant for one organization for the time I volunteered. Also, I was accepted into the Corporate Service Corps and spent a month as a corporate volunteer, consulting with an organization in Vietnam.
cons: IBM is a large, global company. If you're considering employment and have worked for a small company or organization, it may take time to understand the many divisions and organizations within IBM.

review_title: Great place to live a career....just keep learning and self-manage it
job_title: Senior Cloud Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Ability to switch to different roles and completely different jobs while inside the same company.  Access to leading thinkers and do-ers across a very VERY broad range of technical and business topics.  Availability of training programs.  Support for volunteer activities in the local community, as well as key programs like Corporate Services Corp where I spend a month with a team of 10 IBMers addressing IT challenges in central Africa.  Respect that comes from association with the IBM brand and history.  Relentless re-invention toward emerging and strategic areas of technology.
cons: Not as much flexibility for mid/low level managers as their would be in a small organization.  Be aware that skills atrophy will result in minimal compensation increases and eventually needing to locate alternative roles or even company -- but this is reality of working in a tech business.

review_title: IBM is a place you can grow
job_title: First Line Manager in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: There has been 15 years for me on IBM, I joined even before I finished my college degree so basically is all the work experience I have, I had the opportunity to be on different roles and learned different processes in the company. I like that is big and you have the opportunity to move across organizations
cons: IBM has some programs to recognize employees, but I constantly heard from seniors employees " we used to have this /that but not anymore " , I think there have been good things that employees has lost during time and have not been replaced.

review_title: Love the company and its culture
pros: Excellent place to work if you like a work life balance. Company thinks for its employees and the policies reflect the same. No swipe in and out, the culture in this company is that if you have work you just need to do it, time in office is not relevant.
cons: Its a giant and any changes (positive) are slow to implement. The middle layer of management is not something I would expect from a tier 1 IT company maybe because a lot of them have evolved from entry level technical streams. If you are in India and you hope of onsite opportunities then this is not the company for you.

review_title: Great place for who are self learner & motivated
pros:
-Flexible work timing, no login logout timing.
- lot of training offerings ( mostly self paced learning)
- big place for various kinds of tools, technologies. But depends on your effort and luck. It's an ocean, someone should know how to swim.
- great place for researchers/innovators. Few IBMers have got nobel prize.  Highest number of patents registered by company for consecutive 15+ years.
- You can bring your family members to visit office.
cons:
- Less salary/Appraisal for dedicated (who are in company fir longer period of time) resources.
- Getting good opportunity is difficult. You have to put your own effort. But this is good. You become dependant and responsible for yourself. 
- No exit interview.

review_title: IBM - big, wonderful, scary place
job_title: Distinguished Engineer in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: IBM is huge with 10K's of products, 340K employees, and unlimited potential. When you figure out how to work with and use IBM's size, you can delight your clients, make a good living, work with people who become your friends, and on rare occasions get an amazing reward like going to Hawaii with friend for Best of IBM (only 1K go).
cons: IBM is huge with 10K's of products, 340K employees, and unlimited ways to get lost or feel unwanted, plus some areas just don't succeed. It takes brains, heart, guts and a little bit of luck, but that is true anywhere.

review_title: Let this be your last job option
pros:
1) No work pressure
2) Can relax
cons:
1) Risk of affecting your career track record in the long term.
2) Too much focus in the organization around perception building, marketing yourself, impressing the boss. If you are hard working and focussing on 'delivering/implementation' you are told you should 'work smart' which I still do not understand what that means.
3) Senior people busy making presentations and impressing Directors/VP's for their next promotion. No accountability towards actual execution or delivering on a commitment.
4) Rapid promotion among senior levels only.

review_title: Senior Software Engineer
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: IBM provides many resources available to you regardless what job you may have. IBM has global locations, wherever you travel to, you can find colleagues there who can lend a helping hand. IBM has good managers who normally are eager to help to make you successful. IBM has increasingly become Open Source software driving development company, its services and technical skills have been up to date in every area. IBM provides relatively flexible working hours so that employees can have their own working habbit to be very productive.
cons: Since the company is very big, in some cases the communications between leaders and workers may not be as good as it can be.

review_title: Good place for a job but...
pros:
- Good place if you are starting out and looking to get some great experience.
- Good security product but lagging behind competition.
- Great benefits.
cons:
- Specially in Engineering if you are not part of the white boy's club then your growth is stymied even if you are well deserving. This is easy to prove based on who is getting promoted and who is leaving the company because they do not see a future in staying.
- Drinking at work is a big problem even though it is against company policy. Lot of "architects" and managers always have a buzz on.
- Your exposure to conferences and customers (which is held in high regard at IBM) is dependant on your popularity with the select few. They are running a high school popularity contest :/.

review_title: Working at IBM
job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Decent pay and benefits.  Good remote work policy.
cons: LOTs of bureaucracy.  The company is turning into EMC...lots of hacks and disjointed groups.  IBM is struggling has been laying off 3 times a year, for the past 6 years.  Leaders are very focused on their own gain and are not focused on the customer.  For some reason, they are not replacing executive leaders like Microsoft and Google have.  Their products don't work well, and there are layers and layers and layers of management and policies and blah.  Moral is low and people fearing for their jobs.  Lastly, IBM hands out jobs to relatives/friends of former executives.  There are young people in management roles that have no business there.  This company has not yet turned around.  The consolidate divisions and say the new unit is profitable.  Silly finance tricks like that.

review_title: I loved IBM but I was blindsided by redundancy!
job_title: Business Transformation Consultant in Manila, Manila
pros: Great learning opportunities, amazing scope - particularly for a non tech focal, good benefits
cons: You are on your own, you need to find a mentor who understands how to navigate IBM.  If your in sales you need a sponsor

review_title: Average pay, but the environment and work/life balance depends on management and team
pros: Decent salary, Large and long-established company
cons:
Experience will largely depend on co-workers and your team's management, but more often than not, they'll promise the customer too much too soon, and then development is left with the difficulty and stress of making it happen.

Since I've worked at IBM, I always had the feeling that they sort of fell behind after the tech boom. IBM used to be a company that was known for innovation, and these days it just seems like IBM is looking at the competition and asking, "How can we do something like that but offer it to the customer for a cheaper price?!"

review_title: Good company to work for provided you are in the right group.
pros: Work Like balance is probably one of the best things IBM has going for it provided that you take advantage of what they are offering.  Otherwise you can get sucked in and commit way too much time to work.
cons: The promotion system to rating have recently been disconnected allowing them to give praise but hold off on promoting and paying more.  It really boils down to a "trick" to keeping you working for them for less money.  On a different topic IBM is a big company and they say you can move around when you first start.  I would say that this is not always the case.  Depending how the business is doing and your area they will often hold you back.

review_title: Wear the Blue Suit
pros: IBM really provides it all. If you want to work in a certain area of IT, the company does provide support tools to achieve those goals.  Also, if you are an experienced project manager, you will have the opportunity to manage very large, complex installations within a few short years.  The culture of IBM differs from Deloitte and Accenture in that it has a much more rigid hierarchy and is truly a corporate environment.  The blue suit rule still stands.
cons: IBM is really a mature organization, therefore, newly hired college graduates are expected to act within their roles and not make waves.  Innovation that matters is true, but only if there has been a thorough business case brought to bear.

review_title: Innovative company with much potential that likes to drive away the true talent due to bureaucracy and poor management.
job_title: Test Lead in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Very innovative company with incredible potential. Fairly quick on moving into emerging technologies. Decent education opportunities available to employees even if initial training is terrible.
cons: The majority of managers are too worried about covering their own butts and only focus on the numbers, so the actual quality of work is terrible. Countless employees with amazing talent are practically forced out of the company due to management not showing recognition for their hard work. New employees are many times left to fend for themselves due to inadequate initial training. Management is so worried about losing back fill spots that they keep incompetent contractors around wasting space instead of working to replace them.

review_title: good pay but high stress if you will have a job tomorrow.
pros: The pay. Good pay and easy work. I have simple projects with lots of detail. The deadlines are flexible as long as I am making progress. The pay is great but since I am with a contractor, no benefits.
cons: The lack of job security. One week im secure for years, the next week I am on the chopping block. Very nerve racking. There seems to be always a budget issue. Apparently it is possible to go from contractor status to full time regular status....but we shall see. Also there is no teaching. You need to learn the job yourself or you sink.

review_title: IBM Global Business Services -- Great place to work - need better comp plan
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Houston, TX
pros:
People - One of the most enjoyable aspects of working at IBM is the people.  Very talented, smart, motivated, and friendly people.
Challenging Environment - With clients all over the Fortune 500, you can rest assured tat you will be engaged solving business problems and devising solutions on every engagement.
Knowledge Sharing Tools - IBM has made a huge effort in implementing internal knowledge sharing tools that are top-notch and allow you to find the information you need and learn from what other have done in the organization.  The latest web 2.0 emphasis is remarkable!
Available information
Benefits
cons: Compensation is below industry although it is said that we are competitive.

review_title: Big Blue - great place to cut your teeth; leave before it makes you bitter.
pros:
Stable - fits the "just do my job" kind of person. 
Great access to self-study resources, if you find  the time.
I miss my ThinkPad.
I miss Sametime. It's a great tool to connect with any subject matter expert in the organisation. And they're usually  quite friendly.
cons:
Stable - don't rock the boat culture.
IBM brags of innovation and all but the culture doesn't reflect it. Many good ideas never saw the light-of-day. 
Malaysia was (is??) seen as a low-cost and hence, unfairly, low-skilled location. Great developers never got the recognition they deserved and have since left. 
I myself have been passed over for a Bravo award just because of the numbers game. 
Some managers need to get past their obsession with the hierarchical organisation.

review_title: Overall a great company culture, depending where you land.
pros:
The pay is competitive and the number of vacation days is also good.  The flexibility of working from home can be very nice depending on your personal needs.  I enjoyed the ability to work later in the day.  The company culture is relaxed.

I personally like the attitude of Sam P. and I agree with his direction/strategy.
cons:
It is difficult to move within the company from one position to another.  I felt locked in my current role for the past several years.  It seems like this is only particular to my department.  Working from home can also kill your work life balance since you are always checking your email when you're at home.

I do not like the middle management because they make very important decisions and it looks like they have no idea how things work in the "front lines".

review_title: Regret having worked for IBM
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Durham, NC
pros:
-Overworking means that you're able to learn a lot of new things: I'd think 1 year at IBM is equivalent to ~2 years at another company: experience-wise
-Exposure to Customers and designing customer solutions
-Flex time, Can work any time you want.
cons:
-Complete Lack of Respect for Employees by Management, No loyalty to employees
-Unrealistic exceptions for EPS/Profit that when failed to meet, is then used as excuse to mistreat employees.
-Long work hours for no benefit.
-Unedible cafeteria food.
-Less Pay:  I actually didn't feel like I 'wanted' more money, but the job I took after IBM paid >30% more than IBM.
-Currently very low morale: In the last 3 years or so all the 'water cooler' talk and been negative and depressing.
-Lack of long term friendships:  Because of all the turnover and layoffs and moving around people, 100% of my friends had since come and gone.
-Embarrassing to say work at IBM.  Because of all the Cons, it got to a point where it was embarrassing to say I worked for IBM when speaking with neighbors.

review_title: One of the worst jobs I've had
job_title: Account Executive in San Francisco, CA
pros:
1) IBM has name recognition
2) IBM has a long history
cons:
Too many cons.  
1) Dog eat dog environment.  No team work or comradery.  Everyone is out for themselves only
2) Given accounts that have had little to any software sales in the past 5 years!  Quota of $1750K and the history of the sales in these accounts for the past 5 years was under a million dollars!
3) Mgmt will never, ever support you.  Dog eat dog.  
4) the processes they have in place are so mind numbing, frustrating.  Laptop problems arise on a weekly basis.  Have to send it in to someplace across the country to have it fixed!  Frustrating and not productive
5) First line managers are basically baby sitters.  Have zero power and are hired to be micro managers. They are on top of you every second.
6) No work/life balance.  They expect you to work 12+ hours a day.  They monitor you on SameTime.

THE WORST ENVIRONMENT TO WORK IN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

review_title: Go In with your eyes open - IBM
pros:
looks good on CV - IBM does have a good brand image
Possible choice of roles (if you actually get a response)
cons:
You have to find yourself a role in IBM or sit on the bench
Lack of communication with managers and senior execs when you have the skills needed to deliver projects to clients
Its not what you know its who you know.
Large unresponsive organization 
Resource managers do not help with  role allocation
there is no work life balance - its a IBM only Balance
No support for new starters - sink or swim mentality

review_title: Politics and propaganda, not hard work will get you to places
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Home office, flexible work hours, access to lots of information and products.
If you are efficient with your work/time you can learn new stuff.
Computers tend to not have the performance you need to perform the job, refreshes every 3-5 years.
cons:
IBM will not prepare you for the job, it does not want you to move fast. It is a sales corporation, more than IT.
You do not get points for doing technical work, you get points for brown nosing and letting everybody know you are the "something" guy (even when you don't know it).
Management is bad, catastrophic bad with very few exceptions.

review_title: EPS and profits above everything else... rapidly becoming a giant mumbling rathole
