pros: Global company with huge portfolio of advanced software and hardware products, competitive cloud platform (SoftLayer) and good (but not great) service capabilities.  Vast sales and distribution network across all industries, strong ties to government institutions (in most countries), access to the largest companies across the globe.  Solid (but rapidly deteriorating) technical and consulting know-how.  Attempts to "move decisions closer to the clients" are laudable, but drown in the sea of incompetence.
cons: Mid-level management structure and their lack of skills (both technical and people-management) are absolutely atrocious.  There are layers upon layers of "pointy-hair managers" - every other Dilbert cartoon seems to be inspired by IBM. 2015 EPS target drives all decision making, cost-cutting replaces innovation, and there is shortage of ideas where the new growth should come from.

review_title: Fear & Loathing in IBM
job_title: SWG Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: They are RARE, but, if you are lucky, you can find one, MAYBE two IBM managers in a 20+ year career that actually care about the people and are professional.
cons: What was once a stellar example of reciprocal fidelity and mutual respect and professionality in the 70s/80s is now a maze of backstabbing, obfuscation, double-talk, and outright lies. No, I wasn't even cut in the "Project Chrome" resource action, but I may end my tenure shortly and by choice. Piece of advice, don't work here, this isn't knee-jerk, it's honest. Look elsewhere because I haven't inflated my comments, they are accurate, I am not angry, I am disappointed, and that is far far worse. Find a company that will value and nurture you to give them your absolute best, but don't look here.

review_title: Big data, data analytics and Business Intelligence
pros: you get to work with the latest technology and meet and work with different professionals from across the globe. Traveling and working with different cultures is also a plus. IBM focuses on keeping employees skills current hence you undergo alot of training. I love the culture and people
cons: A lot of processes. For any activity you do there must be a process and relevant approvals. Though this is a good thing, sometimes can be seen as bad when working for a client and there is a simple solution but process and approvals have to be followed which in the end can take weeks to achieve when the actual work was a 10min activity

review_title: Appalling treatment during redundancies
pros:
For 10+ years IBM was a great place to work.  My blood was blue, and I lived and breathed IBM.
Great people, awful managers (although there are a few exceptions - typically those who made it to upper management from rank and file positions).
cons:
Despite profits in the 10's of billions, IBM can now only afford a "statutory minimum" minimum packages, despite offering significantly better separation packages less than a year ago.

Ginni .. 17 consecutive quarters of declining revenue on the trott.  How much longer do we continue this trend ?  Either the trend must stop, or the leaders must go!

review_title: Restructuring, for better or worse
pros: IBM is such a huge company that there are many opportunities available. Chances are, if you end up in a position you don't like, you can transfer to a different position although it's much easier if you transfer within a division. Of course there are many opportunities here to work on stuff that really matters in society. The company's restructuring efforts may finally be paying off this year.
cons: Since the company is so large, sometimes it's difficult to turn the ship around. Change is happening, but slowly. Some of the tools we have to use only make the job more difficult. It's easy to be lured in to a job or physical geography with no growth, as some locations are only downsizing.

review_title: 28 Years and counting
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros:
IBM is a great place to work, to grow, to learn and even to reinvent yourself.
IBM has many resources to help employees achieve their goals.
IBM is a company built on values
IBM employees are very talented
IBM values corporate citizenship in areas of education, environment, health, community, development of less privileged communities and countries
cons: With 28 years with IBM I have seen changes to IBM and to the industry. When I was looking for a job out of college there were many companies that talked about "Full Employment" - this is a concept from the past where no one ever got laid off. You could get fired based on performance, but not laid off because your job went away or it went to another part of the world.

review_title: Amazing Company to work with!
pros: IBM is amazing company to work with. They are always at forefront of the technology. You name any IT technology, say Oracle, SAP, in-memory, they all have started as a small project at IBM! Now with Watson, Cognitive- IBM is setting next phase of revolution in technology of human kind!
cons: IBM is not sales oriented company. Many Directors, Partners, VP level people who are incharge of revenues and sales are not sales oriented- many of this root cause traces to the fact that IBM is heavy matrix'd. You have S&D, GBS, GTS, Software, Cloud - and within each brand you have industry sector sales team and horizontal team - all carry quota, but they are not paid by their achievements propotionally!

review_title: Security Sales Manager
job_title: Security Sales Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros: IBM Reputation with existing customers, technology
cons: Management that is cross pollinated into different divisions where they have no technical expertise to run a business unit. Questions around ethics of management

review_title: Getting paid for sales is like The Hunger Games
job_title: Software Sales in San Francisco, CA
pros: Still some good people are there. Decent pay and benefits. The company does care about diversity (except for the layoffs of older employees dubiously called "skills transformation.") The company has a few good senior leaders.
cons:
In software sales for large accounts, you get paid based on a subjective judgement rather than how much you sold. You have to prove that you worked on a deal. Many people who helped on large deals get nothing, and then those people get PIPs for lack of performance.
The company is still driven by EPS rather than by making customers successful and employees feel valued.

review_title: Avoid if you are ambitious and keen to learn
job_title: Head Office Worker in London, England
pros: Brand name, salary, benefits, some big clients
cons: The words that summarise IBM are: cliquey,  not inspiring,  not open minded,  very mediocre middle management,  not ahead of the curve although desperately trying. The company culture doesn't promote out of box thinking  and it's not inclusive. You either like everyone else or you are out! Doesn't embrace change and value feedback.

review_title: Overall, working for IBM as a Business Transformation Consultant is a good entry-level job.
job_title: Business Transformation Consultant in New York, NY
pros: They have state-of-the-art technology in areas such as blockchain, cloud, AI and robotic process automation. They offer great resources to learn about the different technologies and how they apply to certain industries. The hours usually aren’t bad (8-10 hours/day) and the people I’ve worked with are nice and helpful.
cons: It’s easy to get lost in the crowd. IBM has recently hired a lot of entry-level consultants, so it can be difficult to get on a project, especially within the technology area and/or industry you’re interested in.

review_title: Amazing co-workers, great learning experience, compensation not so good.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I've had the pleasure of working with the smartest people ever in my professional career.  The experiences are fantastic - super interesting projects for wonderful clients.
cons: While health benefits are still pretty good, pay increases and bonus pay, in particular, have suffered due to lagging financial performance.  Bonus pay has been close to non-existent many years.   This is unfortunate as most large US employers are performing very strongly and rewarding their employees with at least a 20% bonus.  Ours is closer to 2%.

review_title: IBM Mumbai Airoli avoid
pros:
1) If you are in good projects and not in airoli then you might learn new skills.
2) Work from home used to be there now almost gone.
cons:
1) Too much corruption and favouritsm. Some projects will promote only old employees even though they hardly contribute. New comers are just temporary and old employees will try their best to eliminate them from the company.
2) No hikes mostly. Lot of partiality for promotion.
3) Doesn't matter if client is impressed with you. If IBM managers are not then you are doomed.
4) Juniors might end up become lead of super seniors if they are managers favorite.
5) People end up leaving in 3-4 months after they join company.

review_title: Terrible opportunity if you care about being valued/appreciated/not being lied to (IBM Baton Rouge CIC)
job_title: Applications Specialist in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Good resume filler (that’s it)
cons:
Management so disconnected from the actual work, truly unbelievable. All they care about is hiring enough people. Placing people in rolls they are prepared for? Nope. Paying people what they are worth? Nope. Overall interest in the employees and their lives outside of work? Nope.

When leaving, my manager told me I was making a “big mistake”. What kind of manager does that? All they would push is the hiring number they had to reach. That’s it, you don’t matter to them at all.

The leader of the office once said “I sometimes forget you guys have families” to us employees at the company picnic. Awesome! Way to reassure me that this place is a terrible work environment. 

Terrible training plan, huge disconnect from “core” IBM. Embarrassing to even say I contributed to that office.

review_title: Too many managers.
job_title: Advisory IT Architect in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Good reputation and the chance to work on bleeding edge technology.
cons: IBM hates their employees.  They want to replace all of their American employees with offshore resources.  Overtime is unpaid, yet expected.  If you do not work overtime then you get a bad rating.

review_title: I care, shouldn't you ?
pros: The people and their feelings about going all-out to help the customer. I know folks (myself included) that have worked issues non-stop for 24+hrs to get systems back up and operational.
cons: Albeit not only within the STG organization, executives typically stay in a position for two years and leave. This makes them less accountable for decisions they make for the long term. Many decisions are made for the short term particularly to meet schedules, then move on leaving the person that replaces them to deal with things.

review_title: IBM, A good learning ground, but not a place to stay for an entire career
pros: Excellent place to start your career and understand how to work in a large organization. Alot of opportunity to try different areas on the business
cons: It's a very political organization, every year it seems the company takes a little bit away from employees. The compensation is below the industry average. IBM has a way of institutionalizing you to the IBM way, this can be dishearting for those the question the norm, eventually you have to make a decision on whether you can live without anything changing and becoming an IBMer or quit drinking the koolaid and find a new opportunity outside the company.

review_title: IBM, A good learning ground, but not a place to stay for an entire career
pros: Excellent place to start your career and understand how to work in a large organization. Alot of opportunity to try different areas on the business
cons: It's a very political organization, every year it seems the company takes a little bit away from employees. The compensation is below the industry average. IBM has a way of institutionalizing you to the IBM way, this can be dishearting for those the question the norm, eventually you have to make a decision on whether you can live without anything changing and becoming an IBMer or quit drinking the koolaid and find a new opportunity outside the company.

review_title: IBM is a good place to start a career but it's hard to end one there
pros: Training programs were very good.   IBM puts alot of money into training for their consultants.  It was a good place to work in the begin of my career because they had lots big clients and projects.  The system implementation methodologies that they employed was very good and delivery and customer service was key.  This served as a point of pride for me because I felt that I could tell people I worked for IBM and it gave me instant credibility.   IBM also had a very good mentoring program while I was there.   You were assigned to one senior mentor and it was this person's responsibility to make sure you were on the right track.
cons: There was 100% travel and it was very political

review_title: Not bad for new employees, but a tough place to work for those with experience.
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros: There is good opportunity, experience, and exposure for new employees.  It's a great place to start to get some experience before moving on to another opportunity.
cons: Continuous layoffs and work demand - I am often required to work long hours and must give up vacation time in order to meet the schedules.  The company seems obsessed with micro-managing the employees doing the work and having TONS of people to track the progress with charts.  The company is huge and well-established, but the last 10 years or so has been a real whirlwind.  There are continual layoffs every couple years....the departments get disbanded, the employees get laid off, but yet the managers get promoted or moved on to other opportunities.

review_title: whatever
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Sarasota, FL
pros: Pay and very little more.
cons: No care about employee welfare and/or growth.  All about cost and profit.  Treated like a piece of meet.  Currently demanding more for less.  65 hour weeks are common. No opportunity to learn about other career paths or open jobs

review_title: Good place to start a career but don't expect to stay.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros: Good place to start a career and gain experience.  Be prepared to work lots of hours and don't be afraid of accepting new challenges.  Flexible hours are great.
cons: IBM has become a company that only cares about stock price and dividends.  They no longer have respect for the individual.  You have a lot of flexibility, but don't be fooled you will always put in more than they are willing to give back.  If your can do your job from home it can be done from ANYWHERE in the world, including "low cost country".

review_title: Project Manager-SAP
pros:
1. Great Processes  and learnings /opportunities to lead BIG Teams -100 /150 consultants . 
2. Trust and Personal Responsibility values - Work from home 
3. Great atmosphere and camaraderie at work
cons:
1. Too much bureaucracy - Exec Mgmt seem to have forgotten that processes are for servicing customers and employees and not vice versa. Politics starting at senior level is too bad  with everyone looking for CYA and not thinking on innovative ideas.
2. Giving phony raises of 2% . Variable pay is a joke ..don't expect more than 25% of the amount listed in offer letter
3. Bad-Bad HR in IBM India ...Enjoying all the time ..bunch of buffoons as HRBPs

review_title: IBM is a solid corporation, and thus be prepared for very demanding multicultural politics.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: No matter what your position is, you will learn a lot about many independent software suites and applications you likely have not been exposed to. Also, you will have many chances to network with many new people (internationally) for other possibilities if you leave IBM, or would like a transfer within the company.
cons: Corporate politics can get dicey too quickly, usually fueled by a select few. Some managers have been known to “rush-to-judgment” without consulting the engineer in question, and this enthusiasm can easily lead to a valuable departure of a very good engineer from the company too easily.

review_title: Downhill Slide And Getting Worse
job_title: Sales Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Used to be a great company to work for but now it is not.  Eventually, some day, they will turn things around and become a reasonably good company to work for again.  But that won't be anytime soon as their downhill slide shows no signs of slowing down.
cons: Systematically destroyed employee satisfaction over the course of time, all in lieu of their stupid 2015 roadmap earnings plan.   Everything has been cut to the bone.  Product quality is low, employees are completely expendable, employee satisfaction is at an all time low, customers are leaving in droves because they have grown tired of IBM delivering lower and lower quality while simultaneously raising prices.

review_title: Not great, to put it short
pros: Ermm,  this is is hard. It's seriously hard to find something above "very bad" level here. We have 14 inch laptops for all tech employees, as an example.
cons:
1. I met multiple Infrastructure Architects who never heard of Jenkins. Guess what they are building.
2.Everything is VERY budget. Old laptops, lotus notes, very short list of approved software. gVim is banned. Seriously.
3.My knowledge transfer from previous team was 10 minutes of cursing.
4.Local management is horrible. You are not expected to talk with anyone.
5.Medieval technology. 90% employees really believe someone apart from IBM uses AIX. That leads to very strange technology.
6.99% of people I met never heard of Git.
7.No one hides the fact there are no raises.
8.Security checks. You are officially not allowed to use internet apart from .IBM.com domain. 
9.A lot of senior people work 25 years here. Go convince that guy ksh is not a good programming language for all automation.

review_title: Proven big consulting Firm driven by sales goals
job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
Once you settle down you can flexibly manage your time.
Virtual relationship with your manager
Work independently.
You work for top class clients in major cities across the world
Promotion process is straight forward; you get promoted once you meet and document the predefined requirements.
It does everything you can imagine.
A lot of smart hard working consultants who always delivers what is promised.
cons:
Top heavy.
Too much overheads for non profitable internal works.
GBS and few other divisions feed other non-sense divisions.
Slow to market and new technology demand due to its size and decision making hierarchy
Inversley undiverse
One lump sum 401K match at the end of the year; if you leave before year end you lose year worth 401K (I am not making this up).
You have no control over your raise. you get what they decide.
Bonus is a joke.
Too many org changes and moving corporate goals

review_title: Java Developer
pros: Sharing and receiving tips and helpful advice from any IBMer in the world is priceless. Being able to work on high level solutions with high level professionals is a very intense experience for any professional.
cons:
In Chile IBM is really affected by the economy and it's very difficult to compete against smaller companies because of their prices. That being said, projects tend to be underestimated in terms of hours and deadlines become impossible to meet.

All this situation is well known by the management tier, but no actions are taken beside burning out technical human resources to try to get some results which are, of course, unsatisfactory to the client.

This has become a reality for almost every project I've worked on IBM Chile.

review_title: Contractors don't get raises
pros: Prestigious company with innovative solutions... great to be able to say you work at IBM.  All really depends on department, manager, colleagues, etc.  A lot of smart and talented employees both full-time and contractors.
cons: Company is made up of over 50% contractors.  (Could be as high as 80% according to WSJ article.)  Lay offs of both contractors (despite renewed contracts for years) and full-time employees are abrupt and often handled very poorly.  People are viewed as a number.  As a contractor, don't expect a rate increase no matter how long you are there.  Not even a cost-of-living increase.   A lot depends on managers.  The department is only as good as the manager... the morale is only as good as the manager.  Your work can be inspiring, satisfying, and growth oriented depending on the manager.

review_title: Security Software Sales
job_title: Security Software Sales in Houston, TX
pros:
IBM is making a deep investment in the data security portfolio. Lots of solid acquisitions (QRadar, Big Fix, Resilient Systems) Compensation for sales position is competitive. Deep penetration into the fortune 500 with relationships at the very top make large enterprise sales possible.
It is possible to reinvent your career at IBM. IBM enables and encourages this.
cons:
Channel sales are a mess. The programs are difficult to understand and even more difficult for business partners to get paid on. Most VAR's in the security space don't work with IBM. This is a huge opportunity missed.

The culture is dated. Too many people who have been at IBM for way too long with dated, unproductive practices. Meetings that result in meetings so they can schedule more meetings.

Healthcare is very expensive for such a large company

review_title: No respect
pros: I worked in the systems business in field sales.  The work life balance was good.  The pay was mediocre.  Since revenue was dropping each quarter the axe was always falling.
cons: Eventually after all the cuts the only one left where the 20+ year IBMers who where married to IBM.  Anybody who had talent and was not afraid to leave left.  Their are still a few good folks left.  I wish them well.  My advice is if you decide to leave be prepared to be terminated the same day.  Do not tell them where you are going.  They have no right to know.

review_title: Lipstick on IBM
pros:
- Many good people
- Good work/life balance on the right team
- Free coffee and snacks
- Remote work allowed
cons:
- Hiring standards quite low. Definitely not the best of the best
- Low pay. Non existent bonuses
- On call with no pay
- Very low morale
- Constant reorgs and layoffs
- Endless bureaucracy
- Very poor product vision and not communicated clearly. Nobody knows why they're working on what they're working on or where we'll be at in three months.

Don't buy into the Watson hype. It's not any better than traditional IBM.

If you want to punch the clock or this is your first job out of school, it's an OK choice. If you want to do something meaningful or have pride in your work, look elsewhere. If the team requires on call, run away fast.

review_title: Why IBM is more preferable for engineers
pros: IBM manufactures hardware software middle-ware and offers hosting and consulting services in areas raging from mainframe computers to nanotechnology. It is also a major research organization holding the records for most patents generated by a business for 23 consecutive years and emerges as  new cognitive solutions and cloud platform company. Inventions by IBM includes automated teller machine, the hard disk drive, the floppy disk, DRAM, the SQL programming language, and many more.
cons: As i am a fresher and recently placed in this company i did not have the privilege to experience the work environment in this organization. But i do not think there will be any downsides as it is one of the respected and well biased company till date.

review_title: Bait and Switch
pros: Good benefits. Professional atmosphere, flexible with family
cons: Poor working hours, badly disorganized. Very little training. I was hired for a new team, it was implied that there were multiple shifts to choose from however about 2 months into the job we found out that the only shifts were second and third. Took a long time to get access to everything we needed for the job. Once complete, there was only one person to train 4 other people, and that person was assigned to other projects. We were then sent out to struggle on our own.

review_title: IT ARCHITECT
job_title: IT Solutions Architect in Victoria, BC
pros: Lots of opportunity for learning and growth if you are willing to travel and take on challenges. Canadian market opportunities are definitely centred in the east and career growth is focused in those areas (unless you are an executive).
cons: Undergoing a major transformation towards a technology suite and putting a lot of emphasis on the Watson and C(Cloud), A (Analytics), M (Mobile), S (Social) and S (Security) space.    Some traction in the marketplace but usually with large clients.   IBM rates are pricing them out of most public sector opportunities.

review_title: Sales - Cloud @ IBM
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
- as IBM is a huge conglomerate, you can have many different career experiences in one place.
- despite all the negative press, the company has a strong balance sheet and strong product margins, i.e. good stability and a cautious view on taking risk
- good benefits, though like most companies they pare back - 401k match (up to $16k annually), deferred comp for high income earners, low-cost medical.
- if you are good at your work, work/life balance is at least possible
cons:
- need to negotiate starting salary strongly - raises/promotions are very, very rare
- bonuses even on sales plans seem totally subjective and random
- 60% of your colleagues suck, and somehow the resource actions never seem to get those people
- near constant organizational and territory change disrupts client and partner relationships, a competitive disadvantage and leads to a lot of internal "self-promotion"

review_title: Waste of time with unacceptable policies!
pros:
- Job security (But one needs to follow IBM policies blindly even when it is not possible)
- Leave policy
cons:
- No work ( All you'll get to hear is projects are in pipeline)
- No transportation facility ( difficult for anyone commuting from far area)
- No decent hike ( Don't except a good hike forever)
-  Lots of employees on bench not getting a project for more than a year.
- They'll ask you to relocate to another city if situation demands without any hike in your salary.
- Notice period rules and regulations - Only HR and Management gets to decide. Employee becomes a fool as he has no idea when to put down the papers since management can ask you to leave within few days instead of serving 3 months notice period which leaves the employee with no work for another few months until he/she joins another company.
- I have seen other companies taking their employees outside for team bonding and fun but IBM doesn't believes in this policy.

review_title: Salesforce Consultant
pros:
- Up to 6% 401K matching
- 3 month paid maternity & paternity leave
- Great internal education opportunities (tons of resources) although this isn't relevant to Salesforce
cons:
- Make the company money or you're laid off
- Massive company with slow, outdated processes and systems
- Terrible culture
- Offshore devs
- Slow promotions
- Unclear career path
- Poor Salesforce education and no encouragement to seek certifications
- Low salary with poor bonus structure

review_title: Good on boarding experience
job_title: Advisory Systems Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
They have a good system of onboarding a candidate like
1. First you will get get emails to fill some online forms. 
2. You will get an email with a link with your offer letter.
3. If you accept the offer then you will get other emails for filling out some more forms and upload some documents, of you find something not wrote in offer letter then can call their hr to make it write and they will again send you the offer letter with the corrections
4. You will get a link for a slack channel specifically for the the new joiners to help them in joining process. 

So everything systematic
cons: Although Whole joining process seems systematic but could have been better, there are too many you need to do and they  don't easily reply on emails.

review_title: Great place to work if you can handle bureaucracy
pros:
Endless career options throughout the company, different locations, lots of opportunity to work from home, Work life balance is promoted and you can usually have management support to adjust schedule when necessary. Great education possibilities, IBM payed for my MBA. 
Some benefits are industry leading and the company attempts to keep up with the market.
cons:
Cheap vacation allowances - 10 years to get 4 weeks is absolutely ridiculous
Your manager can make or break your job satisfaction, they have too much control over what you can and can't do human resources policy wise.  
Managers don't adhere to policies or don't support them and you don't get to take advantage of the great programs IBM has.
Poor first line managers

review_title: Not really into software products.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Stable position once you are inside.  The networking can be very useful. There is a culture of mentoring and networking that takes a certain amount of effort to get into, but does yield decent information.
cons: Bureacratic. Poor attention to quality. Overall software product strategy is lacking. Lots of vague, insincere, old-style rah-rah.  Management tends to bring in their friends rather than hire for competency. Project schedules are set without understanding the details of what the commitments entail.  The product designs tend to be overelaborated and inelegant and user-hostile. They have a rigid, waterfall product management template AND they are attempting to ram agile development into it.

review_title: Large company that is hard to navigate
pros: IBM is a large company with a long, established history. Generally speaking, people know who IBM is--across the globe. The global reach is an additional benefit: provides more stability in the crazy global economy and makes it veyr interesting in terms of working with colleagues in different parts of the world and getting their view of things.
cons: The company is so large that it's very difficult to navigate. More importantly, the size becomes a greater issue as more of the workforce is remote. I've worked with people for years whom I have never met. Additionally, there is very little consideration of the issues associated with working with global counterparts: ie: the fact that the people with whom you're trying to meet/work are 12 or 14 hours apart.

review_title: Lack of Opportunity at IBM, Unless You're In Asia
pros: As a large company, there are many divisions, fields, and locations from which to choose.  This advantage gets lost, though, when opportunities come up in different locations--the company, which used to stand for "I've Been Moved," will not pay for your move--you pay out of your own pocket (except if you are an executive, of course).
cons: Outsourcing, layoffs, increasing workload for remaining employees, working weekends with no recognition or extra pay, no pay increases 2 of 4 years.  If you want a promotion--good luck.  If you want a job in a different location, you pay for the move yourself.  No travel, no Christmas parties, no retirement package, no stock options--just more and more work for the same amount of pay.

review_title: Create / Provide More JOBS OPPURTUNITES IN USA
pros: It is a Global Company, recognised and respected throughout United States of America and globally.  IBM has been in business for a very long time and has several Innovation and research on the pipeline. It is a one of the largest service and technology company. It also exposes to several different sector's, naming a few would be Finance, Automobile, Healthcare, Insurance, Pharma and Biotech.
cons:
It is very large and growth has been slow for the united states employees, cut back all the time and it is a survival game.

It would help to keep jobs on shore since the customer and business presence is in the United States.

review_title: Used to love my job!  Now I am not sure it will be here next month.
pros: Benefits, they are still great compared to other Large companies, but slowing losing ground.  Working with a great group of people, it really does feel like a family.  Flexibility to work from home a couple days a week.  I am actually more productive on these days.   Flexibility with work hours, ability to start a little later if needed, or take a long lunch for a doctors / dentist appointment.  Most first line managers are wonderful.  Recognition when a job is well done.  Continual effort in fostering of teamwork.
cons: The constant fear of 'the job' going over seas.  Upper management is too quick to say yes to every poor idea.

review_title: a regular job for a regular guy
job_title: Technical Service Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros: job security, big company insurance package, ability to move up - but limited.  I met a lot of great people at the job and still keep in touch with them.
cons: monotonous, "Office Space" movie-esque, typical office politics, you are definitely faceless and the management does not have a clean hold on what goes on.  I don't understand how management can make suggestions and implement action plans when they have never picked up the phone and dealt with the problems we had to.  the managers don't even know the equipment.  I made the mistake of ONCE asking for help on a call and the manager looked at me blankly and tried to come up with some kind of answer.  It was oh so very painful.

review_title: IBM's current leaders only care for themselves.
pros: Salary,  company resources, business reputation.
cons:
IBM does not value its employees.   Treats people like commodities.    Senior management view themselves at the chosen ones, and the rest of us as "resources".     In my view, they have no morals,  no character and no soul.     They are not creators of wealth and jobs, rather they are exploiters.    In the past, I have seen some great leaders at IBM.   No more.

I think the future of IBM as a company is not good.    The present culture is not sustainable.   They are throwing away too many good people.

I remain thankful for the years I have had at IBM and hope to remain employed there for a few more years.    I could not in good conscience recommend it to anyone else.

review_title: Good place for a young person, experienced developers should think twice
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Westford, MA
pros: Most of the engineers you work worth are over-qualified for the work asked of them.  Everyone is polite and professional.  Junior software developers will be technically challenged.  It looks good on your resume. Great career track for a FEW management-bound people.
cons: Salaries are being reduced thru raises which don't keep up with inflation.  Everyone worries about being fired -- everyone is ranked, and bottom 2.5% are whacked every 6 months.  Medical and dental benefits are expensive for families.  IBM's interpretation of Agile software development methology has turned the place into a sweatshop.  Every Band 9 ($120K+) faces a "move up or move out" dilemma.

review_title: great company to work at
pros: opportunities for growth. name of the company on your resume. The best reasons are of course excellent benefits package whcih included additional health insurance, company cars,  phones and so on. additionally the company does team building very frequently and helps employees develop a relationship. and last but not least, the people who actually wor at he company are the best - if get into the right group however. here and there you might come accross some interesting characters but overall the people are great.
cons: life/work balance is missing - very stressful. most of the people who were leaving left due to the stressful job

review_title: Just like any other Consulting company
pros: Good 401k match, good health benefits only for employee
cons: No work life balance, work nights weekends, a lot of travel, no salary increments unless you get a 2+ or 1 rating or get promoted

review_title: My experience has been satisfactory.
pros: The benefits, such as health benefits and 401K are very good.  Resources within IBM are great as well.  The intranet and all its contents are great resources for employees at IBM.
cons: I do not enjoy working for such a large company.  There is excessive regulation and rigid conformity to formal rules  working for such a large company where I have never had that working for other companies in the past.  By being a consultant that travels, we have to file taxes in each state we travel to.  The per diem rates we receive through IBM are considerably lower then that of the GSA federal rates and we as the employee lose out in the end.

review_title: Marketing Company - all talk, less stuff
pros:
1. Good As legacy product based company
2. Diversified professional global community
cons:
1. Less maturity in services industry. Self glorifying of achievements should be stopped
2. Remove People managers role and replace them with project managers as first line managers. PeM are waste of resource and unqualified in India. No hard feelings gs during annual review phase
3. Big Blue processes should be trimmed for operational efficiency 
4. Lethargic support departments (mobility team, it service team, travel desk, and HR) 
5. Not a good choice for starter, but the best choice for near retiring resources.

review_title: This opinion is about Network Solutions, which is an IBM acquired company..  A pure DESI & goal-less company
pros: Nature of Business is Good; But the people are too lazy to take interest in the Company's growth..  Especially Senior Management are kind of Escapists, taking the Business Rudder-less.. (Plz take this opinion as for NETWORK-SOLUTIONS..  But, NOT for IBM
cons: NOCi Product - too stupid product to buy; It is not even updated in their own web-site; Also, Application Development Team just enjoys while screaming & shouting..  No calmness & seriousness.  Ironically, Product Managers themselves talk NEGATIVE about their own Product; Make mockery of it..  And so is Engineering Manager / Engagement Manager - Just passing time..  What a rubbish company to work with !!!

review_title: Just enough pay to stagnate
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Markham, ON
pros:
* Decent job stability relative to the entire tech industry.
* Great place to start your career, get a good grasp on software development.
* Ability to work from home at your discretion, depending on team, flexible work hours.
* Friendly engineers and quiet work environment.
* Above average pay depending on performance.
cons:
* Performance evaluations and distribution of profit sharing archaic and detrimental to team work, innovation and morale.  
* Extremely low bus factor  as a result of people hoarding information
* A lot of talented people are being pushed to management and sales since technical jobs are getting shipped overseas to ISL.
* Meetings upon meetings upon meetings.

review_title: Good for about a decade.
job_title: Software License Analyst in Alpharetta, GA
pros: Nice environment for supporting outsourced accounts and often able to work at customer sites or remotely. IBM offers competitive salaries and educational opportunities for some positions.
cons: IBM is one of the leaders in off-shoring jobs and if you're in a role that's offshored, you have about a 90% chance of being cut in a resource action.  They target folks who have been around 10 to 15 years and maxed out on salaries. They start by lowering your performance rating without supporting evidence and once that happens, you're history. They supposedly give you an opportunity to find another position in the company but once your names on the cut list, that won't happen.  The folks who stay are chosen based on personality vs performance within the group.

review_title: Worst working environment I've ever experienced
pros: Entry Level job with a well known brand. Solution Sales training is good.
cons:
The job is basic. Lots of distributed system, huge amount of administration to get job done. 20 or so different databases with customer information.

One size fits all enterprise, no exceptions, management not capable of making decisions or influencing anything. Location in Ballycoolin is appallingly old-fashioned. Little natural lighting, canteen food is horrendous.
Bonus is paid on an exponential curve, and capped at the bottom. Unless you reach at least 80% of your number you don't get any bonus at all. It's also capped on top. Plan documents are only communicated after you sign the contract, so no visibility into to be expected salary. Bonus calculation takes very long 2-3 months and cannot be tracked or checked.

review_title: Not a place you'd want to work
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: The pros are pretty limited and so are the reasons to work here. It is a big company with many clients so that does present some opportunity to get experiences with different clients, although still the work may be repetitive or not at the upper tier of consulting work.
cons: The projects are boring and low level IT projects as opposed to those that are truly strategic. In my time with the company a majority of the projects in my practice area were a failure or added no real value to the client. Career growth is terrible as management does a terrible job managing resources and basically only see resources as bodies to bill utilization, without caring about whether a project aligns with career aspirations or current skills at all.

review_title: Not a place you'd want to work
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: The pros are pretty limited and so are the reasons to work here. It is a big company with many clients so that does present some opportunity to get experiences with different clients, although still the work may be repetitive or not at the upper tier of consulting work.
cons: The projects are boring and low level IT projects as opposed to those that are truly strategic. In my time with the company a majority of the projects in my practice area were a failure or added no real value to the client. Career growth is terrible as management does a terrible job managing resources and basically only see resources as bodies to bill utilization, without caring about whether a project aligns with career aspirations or current skills at all.

review_title: Good company overall
job_title: SAP Consultant in Caracas, Capital District
pros: Very good perks given the international character of the company, very large catalog of online courses allow you to continue to grow and improve your expertise on many subjects. You get to meet lots of people of many different countries. The support both from your coworkers and the managers, is remarkable.
cons: Tons of bureaucracy make almost every act or move inside the company, a very difficult and time consuming endeavor. The disgregation and dissemination of the company's own departments throughout each region make it rather cumbersome to communicate your needs. The salaries are far behind the market average for a company as big as this one, at least locally.

review_title: Not Your Father's Big Blue
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
- Name Recognition
- Ability to work in a large company with a massive scope
- Able to see a broad area of world technical progress
cons:
- Lack of connection between employees and managers. Managers change more than once per year and more often than not don't work in the same office as their employees. When year-end reviews happen the results are inconsistent. 

- Random layoffs and job stress
- Expectation of continuous long hours
- Poor track record on raises and promotions

review_title: Software engineer
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Medical dental 401k Benefits are excellent. Employees have the ability to reinvent themselves by switching teams. Take on international assignments, take on stretch assignments which is temporarily working in a new position. Giving the employee the chance to "try on" the job to see if it's a good fit, without fully committing to it.
cons: Extremely hard to break into management. I've been identified as having leadership qualities,taken the required leadership courses. Expressed my desire to manage. Taken on more responsibilities. Excellent performance reviews. But with the constant management shuffle above me, no one to champion for me.  Mentorship is basically non existent.

review_title: A matured MNC
pros:
IBM- World's most prestigious IT BRAND.
Opportunities to work on world's most admired clients in all verticals.
Opportunities to learn ( if you are on good project and lucky ) a lot.
Ideal for working ladies , specially the WFH , sabbatical leave, maternity leave  ..etc ( if you have good rapport with PM )
Good company to retire , once you are financially settled.
Onsite opportunity depends upon project requirement.
IJP, internal move facilities, BU change opportunities.
Master Blue program, is a veteran emp training arrangement to retain employees interest.
cons:
Variable pay is controversial.
Hike is very unlikely to be happen .
Like other Indian (desi) MNC, Brotherhood, buttering may indulge a good growth!
No complimentary pantry facilities and GYM as such.
Average standard cafeterias.
Mediclaim insurance which doesn't cover parents .
Shift allowance/OnCall benefis are too avg.

review_title: Hybrid Cloud Sales Specialist
pros: Great company history, great name and smart people
cons:
- Extreme pressure from the top down to produce and help Ginnie keep her job
- Culture of mistrust between managers, reps and business units
- Arrogance at the middle management level
- Their desperation to meet unrealistic targets make them lose any and all all sense of humanity
- Tense environment as reps and/or managers are on edge waiting for next round of layoffs
- Extremely stressful environment especially at quarter end when they're desperate
- Buddy buddy systems w/ managers favoring and protecting "Yes Sir" reps

review_title: Depends on the project
pros:
If you are 'lucky' to work in a challenging project than IBM is for you.
The people in Romania are mostly very young, out of the university.
The salary is ok but if you want a raise you have to convince a lot of people and to make a 'package'.
You have other benefits like healthcare insurance, 50% off of your sports monthly pass and other discounts on brands.
cons:
The managers are always trying too hard to please the client.
Some leads are very demanding and you have no chance to report them because it will come back at you.
Instead of making the 'package' for a raise it's easier to leave (because they don't fight to keep you) and come back after 6 months or a year with an 30% raise.
The 'benefits' are not really considerable.

review_title: Great colleagues, appalling management especially upper management.
pros: In truth for new joiners it would be for the CV, but there are still quite a few good people here to learn from but reducing fast. Some interesting stuff to do as well if you end upon the right place but difficult to find.
cons: Abysmal management, finances and direction. Zero direction or idea what they are doing. Good troops still try to help clients but constantly hampered by clueless management (who only care about their pay packet and culling troops) and increasingly poorly skilled recruits often offshore but now recruiting poorly skilled locals as well to cut cost but deliver very badly at the same time. Strategy such as it is is just wrong and badly done anyway. Many lies given to staff daily.

review_title: Operations Manager
pros: work from home, somewhat flexible hours
cons:
Poor salary, lots of stress and pressure, lots of overtime work, evening and weekends, and rude management putting down people to make them feel successful 
IBM Values are gone, at least in CEE ..

review_title: Has its ups and downs
job_title: People Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Tons of things going on, which means opportunities to focus on new interests. Plenty of resources (people, books, videos, courses) if you are someone who enjoys learning a little every day.
cons: Constant rumors of layoffs, now with a limited severance program - 1 month no matter how many years of service. Raises and bonuses below industry average due to (planned) sharp declines in revenue and stock buybacks to elevate stock price. This is not a place for those who are anxious about losing their job will thrive due to your being up all night worried about getting let go.

review_title: No longer a merit based advancement system
pros: Good work life balance. Chance to work on interesting projects and interact with bright people.
cons: IBM Research has gone to extremes in recent years to advance the careers of women. While there is no doubt that historically many talented women have been discriminated against, this is no longer the case and programs designed to give priority to women over men in technical leadership roles need to be critically questioned. The levels to which these programs are practiced has made it very difficult for qualified men to advance in the company and many top (male) AI researchers have left as a result. I realize that no place is a perfect meritocracy but IBM has swayed so far way from one that it has compromised its ability to attract top talent.

review_title: Digital Sales - Summit Program
pros:
First 6 months of training in Summit program are great. Learn a lot, challenging, flexible work schedule. 
Name recognition. 
Relatively good pay. Don't think it is above average though.
cons:
Horrible work culture in the Coppell Sales Center. 
Unsanitary work facilities. 
Inflexible management around remote work.
Required to come in office despite zero valid need to do so. 
Siloed view of the rest of IBM. 
Lots of workers look well past age of retirement/lots of shuffling around the office.
Poor attitudes in older workers - i.e. treats kitchen staff terribly. 
Kept at uncomfortably cold temperature. No covered parking for extreme heat or hail storms. 
No food or drinks left out for free at any point.

review_title: IBM is not perfect, but the best job I have worked in and I have worked in quite a few.
job_title: Executive IT Architect in Fairfax, VA
pros: Can work at home.  Casual dress unless at client and then its do in Rome as the Romans do.  Many possible jobs to change to.  Many different organizations to work in.  More smart people than perhaps any other company.  Great access to research.  Decent benefits.  Try to avoid layoffs.  Great projects to work on.  Always looking to work in the latest technology.
cons: You can end up with way too much travel.  Travel benefits suck.  Cost savings seem to be more important than revenue growth.  Such a big company makes it hard to find out who knows what.  Many managers are incompetent.

review_title: My condolences to you for working at IBM ... the grass is greener on the other side
pros: The only reason to work for IBM is to have it on your resume.  Software group is a respectable place to work, but you have to plan on moving to Reserach Triangle Park in North Carolina if you want to continue working in that group ... That is how I ended up in IBM Global Servicesm see the negative review for what I think of them.
cons: IBM Global Service forces its employees into mandatory overtime via a practice known as utilization ... if you do excellent work that your peers and colleagues appreciate but are under utilized ... there goes your bonus performance evaluations.  Matrix management does not well, especially if you move into a group where the manager already has his favorites.

review_title: Not willing to spend money for skilled workers.
pros: Work Life Balance.  You can easily schedule things during the work day that you need to take care of and make up the time after hours.
cons:
Getting any sort of raise is like pulling teeth.  IBM spends a lot of time pushing for you to enjoy life while working.  They offer most employee's the option to work from home.  The only problem with this is that you have so much work to do that you end up working more from home.  
The method they use to measure employee utilization is also very flawed.  They end up pushing people beyond limits with work which causes the quality of work to suffer.
Upper management is always looking for the quick fix to increase profits.  But not willing to spend money.

review_title: Good place to work if you want a stable environment
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Room for advancement, stable company with global opportunities.  Management has gone through alot of trouble to make sure the HR infrastructure is tailored to helping employees develop their careers.  IBM has alot of talented employees that are easy to reach out to and get help.
cons: Bureaucracy is almost engrained in IBM's corporate culture.  IBM is slow to react to changes in the industry.  There are so many parts of IBM that sometimes act independently, or even worse, to each other's detriment.  There is much confusion inside of IBM as to where the boundaries are between groups.

review_title: Stands for great things, but is an immovable object
pros: I work from home, and I greatly appreciate the time and money it saves me. I don't commute, I don't eat out, I don't incure huge clothing bills or dry cleaning expenses. I also love the flexibility - I can work from anywhere, so I get to travel a lot. I just work during the days and have my nights and weekends to visit with friends and family or sightsee in a new place.. Also, for those who have been around awhile, we get plenty of vacation (I have 4 weeks now and will get 5 weeks shortly).
cons: "Browbeating" is still the classic managerial style. There is a lack of leadership and creativity in management, even though the matrixed nature of the organization really calls for it.

review_title: IBM Microelectronics
pros: IBM Microelectronics works on some of the most bleeding edge technology projects in the industry.  You'll be working on industry leading projects.  IBM makes the processors in all the latest video game consoles and was a leader in developing multi-core processor designs.  Their foundry and manufacturing business
cons: In my opinion, IBM doesn't want to be in the processor business.  They're just trying to milk the division until it no longer helps serve Services and Software groups.  I don't believe they compensate the microelectronics group fairly in terms of performance bonuses.  Server group almost always gets the lowest bonuses at IBM even though the other groups revenues are based upon server group hardware.

review_title: I would like to stay at IBM
job_title: Software Sales Specialist in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: IBM has a strong SW portfolio with good positioning within services and hardware segments. Hi investments on research. Company with good values. It's good to work in a company with long term relationship with customers. IBM has in mind the future and is not likely to take controversial decisions that can damage your reputation in the market.
cons: Professional recognition is not clear. Been apart of the ERP, CRM and other business brings an unfair challenge to the SW Group sales team in General Business marketplace. The managers at IBM don't have any power to change or to propose big changes and are locked performing forecasting and taking care of burocratic workload. Too much talk and too low real action.

review_title: Good people, bad processes
pros: Technical and Sales colleagues are some of the best around, and generally make up for insufficiently skilled managers and laborious internal processes. IBM also has some really good technology, which it does make investment in.
cons: Obsession with internal processes that stifle the ability to get the job done and which means the service to client is reduced.  Too many middle managers who add little or no value and are only interested in how they appear up the chain, rather than helping to enable people and performance below them.

review_title: IBM
pros: Large company with opportunities in many fields.  You can change jobs from time to time.  You can move to other parts of the country or internationally and stil work for the same company.  Benefits are still as good as any other company.  The company is profitable and, overall, seems to be managed for the long haul.
cons: For a US based mechanical engineer - they appear to be getting out of the hardware business and are moving work to Asia.  So the future is limited.  There is little opportunity to advance engineering skills because they use the lowest cost manufacturers, so the technology is always the same.  New materials and processes are seldome encountered.

review_title: Frustrated with affirmative action
job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in Durham, NC
pros: The best reason to work for IBM is it's a company everyone has heard of and will look good on your resume when apply for a new job.
cons: In the area where I work IBM has pushed affirmative action too far. There are all kinds of support groups for women and minorities, and if you are a woman or a minority you can expect someone in upper management to mentor you and help you get promoted. If you are a white man, good luck. A minority doing the same level of work as a white man can expect to be at least one band higher if not more.

review_title: Other places are better
pros:
Flextime is available, but that is almost a standard in the technical world, so I'm not sure it's much of a pro.
Lot of smart people to work with, but I've found lots of smart people to work with in other places too.
Educational opportunities, but such cost controls that one can never participate in really valuable education.
cons:
No way for advancement without significant job change and likely a relocation.
Money is sub par compared to other companies
Poor moral due to severe cost controls that hit everything from "thanks" and other  awards to simple team pizza lunches. 
Long hours and good work go unrewarded
IT equipment is sub par compared to other companies. Lack of resources to do the work.
Constant feeling of impending doom as you wait for the outsourcing axe

review_title: Good place to do your PhD if you want to gain early experience in a technology company
pros: Good work environment, lots of out-of-work activities, such as hobby clubs and other events for employees.  Benefits across different stores and online shops as an IBM employee. A nice place to do your PhD, you barely find a place which offers a nice salary and lots of exposure to industry at the same time. Although it is not definite that you`ll get a permanent position after you graduate, there are many options for you to take once you finish (PostDoc + wait till a position opens for a Research Staff Member, or Engineer position)

review_title: Working hard may or may not get you ahead...

review_title: Long time career employee
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: The people I work with are smart, wonderful people. Good work life balance. Very flexible with personal time off if needed.
cons: Several years ago, IBM changed the 401K match for new employees to 3%. Prior employees receive a 6% match. Annual bonus' and merit salary increases ONLY go to the top performers in the work group (top 10-15% of employees). Annual performance reviews are stack ranked. That means there will ALWAYS be a bottom group regardless of how well you perform in your job. Several years ago, IBM reduced the maximum vacation for employees hired after that date. They will never receive more than 20 days per year. Prior employees can receive 25 days. New employees start with 15 vacation days and max to 20 after 10 years of service.

review_title: They don't care about moving people up, no salary increases.
job_title: Java Development Team Lead in Lansing, MI
pros: IBM has a good education program, allowing you to take online courses.  The projects expose you to differing technologies and experiences.  They are a challenge.
cons: IBM, at least where I am, does not give yearly increases, to my knowledge.  They expect you to bill your maximum hours, and do your online education on your own time. There is a lot of bureaucracy.  I just earned an MBA in Aug 2013 and applied for internal entry-level consulting positions: everyone I have contacted about those positions has virtually ignored me.  There is a large emphasis on the numbers, but little or no emphasis on rewarding a good job.

review_title: Wallmart of Tech Consulting
pros:
Federal Consulting only:
1. Large programs with national significance.
cons:
1. Pay is crap.
2. No annual raises - even inflation raises. COLA adjustments don't occur.
3. 12% bonus potential mentioned before getting the job is a fallacy. You will never even get 5%. If you get rated a 1 (best), good luck in getting 3%.
4. The way IBM GBS is setup in the public sector, it actually incentivizes one to become a 1099 and work with IBM. In fact - it is great as a subK.
5. Strong smart IBMers leave - unless they're paid well or are IBMers from the "Old Blue".
6. Most IBMers I know have almost never received a raise. In years!

review_title: Life at a heartless multinational corporation
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Detroit, MI
pros:
Enormous opportunities. A company this size is really many, many companies, and the pros and cons depend more on which part of the company you are working in, not the name on the check. 
I worked in SO, "Strategic Outsourcing". Here's a standard joke, "How do you know when you are out of transition?" "When you are in CritSit".
cons: Like most heartless multinational corporations, they don't care about individuals. They don't go out of their way to abuse people, but if the numbers don't make sense, the person is gone, and their work is probably off shored.

review_title: Client Executive

cons: Huge & complex company to work for; matrixed orgranization makes it difficult to be quick & responsive to client needs; constant management churn makes it difficult to have clear strategy in place to execute; change is constant which makes it difficult to produce consistent results; top management unable to show revenue growth, but is very focused on EPS metric to make Wall Street happy;

review_title: Project Executive
job_title: Project Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work life balance if you manage it yourself. There are still a few perks left, but they are deminishinf quickly.  The pto and sick time policy is still one of the best.  The health insurance is also still one of the best, though declining.
cons: Rapid layoffs, so continually changing work environment with high stress.  Cloud and Watson are safe areas to work in.  Very few pay increases and low variable pay.  Need comp plan to make real money.

review_title: Decent for short-term. Beware of layoffs
job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Diverse clientele. Good name to have on your resume. Leader in analytics which is obviously a hot field. Smart people, for the most part.

Company does very little to help you get staffed. HR is practically non-existent. National staffing model means you can be put anywhere on a project.

review_title: Back office/Operational employee's view

review_title: Rocket Center is mediocre at best

review_title: IBM is a toxic environment to work.

review_title: Great Flexibility and opportunities but lacking culture for younger engineers

review_title: I enjoy working for IBM Cloud

review_title: Good work life balance but poor salary structure

review_title: Big blue is a pretty good place to be
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's a market leader with lot of opportunities.  With over three hundred thousand employees around the globe and core business that spans hardware, software, and services, there are tons of opportunities to learn and grow in just about any area you field you care to pursue.  Also, IBM is good at listening to it's employees.  It is an organization that encourages autonomy and contribution by it's personnel.  This may be due to the proclivity towards hiring independent minded technical people.  In fact, you do not need be a sales or management star to excel at IBM.  There are many, many individual contributors on a technical plane that are akin to executives with their power and pay.
cons: It's a behemoth that encourages specialization and has an engineering dominated mindset

review_title: International Business Machines
job_title: Business Development Manager in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Opportunities to move jobs, change careers, get educated, travel.  Time available to take care of self or family in times of sickness or death - as well as birth.  Some of the smartest people in the world work here, most are accessible.  Great mentoring program.
cons: Top heavy organizations.  Too many executives.  Too many Fellows and Distinguished Engineers.  No local management.  Spending at the highest levels is out of control.  Limit corporate jet / helicopter passes to Sam and his direct reports with <10k people orgs.  Realize that not everyone fits in the same box.  Too much politics and too much 'friends and family'.

review_title: What you see is what you get.
pros:
The best reasons to work for IBM are one, name recognition, second, the opportunity to work anywhere in
the world and finally very good advancement opportunities. I met a lot of great people.
cons:
I found IBM slow moving....also there was this "one size that fits all mentality" that really hurt 
productivity. The biggest disappointment for me was I thought IBM was a place for growth, training and
long term employment. It really turned out to be a typical US company these days...ie no direction, no
training and the minute the stock falls there's an employee fire sale...many employees I meet said 
management cared more about stock price than their welfare...i tend to agree. Also....IBM seems to
shed a lot of really good talent at the entry level.

review_title: good company
pros: A stable, solid company, process-oriented, structured company who treats employees well. The benefit package and long PTO days are very attractive. Salary is above average, very reasonable for the type of software development work required. The work environment is very nice too. Nice campus, location, cafeteria, gym and various services on site.
cons: Dealing with globalization may not be easy. Teams that coordinates with offshore teams often work long, strange hours. You might be expected to attend meetings (online, at home ok) as early as 7am or as late as 10pm. More agile than a company of similar size is still big. Product cycle is slow and very process oriented. Things don't get done as simple and as fast as they should. Maybe folks there are pretty set in their own ways. Not the most innovative crowd. Don't be stuck in a group that is not performing. Bottom line counts a lot.

review_title: Consulting within IBM
pros: Remnants of old school corporate culture where everyone treats you with respect. Potentiall very friendly atmosphere. Travel opportunities for consultants although some of the places you go to will not be that exotic. Rapid promotion is possible if you are lucky and/or have been identified. Sounds cliche but it really is what you make of it.
cons: Very impersonal. I have never met my manager in person. Arbitrary promotion and resource deployment scheme within the consulting organization. Project deployments based purely on billable hours, no regard is paid to career growth. Pervasive bean counting. Management shakeups are frequent. Old PriceWaterhouseCooper organization is not well integrated. If you're not one of the lucky ones on the fast track you could be in for a very miserable time as no one is really watching out for you.

review_title: No respect over C-plan pensions.  IBM youngsters, I fear you're next to be attacked.
pros: Currently, the brand image is trading high.
cons:
Pensions have been attacked in a most vicious and calculating way in the UK.  If the senior exec managemtn team is allowed to get away with this attack on 50+ year olds then they can get away with a subsequent attack on the youngsters that are contributing to a different pension scheme.
Brendon Riley has shunned the very people that re-built this company in the 90's by telling them that the final salary pension scheme that formed a part of their compensation package is to close and the penalties for early retirement from april 2010 onwards will be punitive.  In my lifetime I would have to work an extra 6 years to make up for this cold calculated attack on my trust.

review_title: Global, Adrenaline rush, overloaded

review_title: Good to be here for a few years right after phd and then move on.

review_title: Big company & amazing IBM transformation
job_title: Client Solutions Executive in Cambridge, MA
pros:
The shift from a hardware-centric to service-centric and now to a cloud and cognitive service model. A transformation of this kind is not easy for any company with more than 75,000 employees let alone 400,000 that IBM has world-wide. Google reports at 57,000, Apple around than 80,000, Blackberry/RIM at 7000 (at its peak) to put into perspective.  Blackberry led the market was too comfortable and failed to transform to market demands. 

Many, many of the leaders and executives at IBM have Engineering, Computer Science backgrounds - they aren't your typical no-work experience MBAs.  They make decisions very analytically (as Engineers tend to do) with their clients in mind trying to help solve business and world problems. That problem was once mainframes, servers, storage and systems; evolved to implementing and building IT solutions around that hardware; now it's an hybrid cloud implement-yourself-slash-business-service.  Very few companies own the entire ecosystem (mainframe, business solutions and cloud availability) - IBM does. The cognitive guys can request improvements and features to the hardcore engineering server CPU team for maximum optimization- making the most advance system easily available to all businesses.  

No doubt, IBM is years ahead the competition with their Watson Services and it's built on an ecosystem that is in line with the CIOs and CTOs initiative going into the future.  The platform also lends well to startups and smaller companies being able to leverage and take advantage of IBM's top-notch enterprise and industry services at flexible, scalable and affordable rates.  This is new ground for IBM that was typically reserved for big firms and enterprise companies. Way to go, IBM!
cons: Old sellers not willing to adapt to what the industry is demanding will have a tough transition. Again, 400,000 employees makes it difficult for any company. People can get comfortable and changing becomes difficult.  Again, Blackberry/RIM is evidence of being the smart phone leader who failed to transform and was just barely saved from a bankruptcy by being acquired for pennies on the dollar. Again, Jim Balsillie, former CEO of Balckberry, had no engineering or computer science background, and tried to run the company solely with his Harvard MBA, which he ran into the ground.  IBM has a lot of work to transform a lot of people who are more comfortable doing things the old way.

review_title: GBS was not for me

cons: My manager did absolutely nothing to develop me. It was all about billable time. I didn't feel supported at all in my role by my direct manager or the administrator (who was in in Ottawa) who didn't do anything to make sure my laptop worked, etc. For projects I was never put on anything that was suitable. They would staff it with anyone who was available, even if I didn't have the skills for it or wasn't suited to it. I found this very stressful as the client was sold "expertise" I didn't have.

review_title: IBM does not value their employees, it's just not the company it used to be.

The CEO obviously doesn't care about us, she lays off thousands, and then doesn't see any problem with collecting a $4.5M bonus.
