review_title: Company losing direction and out of touch
job_title: Software Sales Representative in Bethesda, MD
pros: Flexibility to telecommute, good mentors if you seek them out, career progression possible. I met some fantastic people and the best part about the job are the coworkers I work with... outside of them honestly it's an old boys club with a bunch of old white men running the show.
cons: The company is trying to do too much and there is no clear vision. Layoffs are happening all the time because the company is not doing well - letting experienced people go in favor of cheaper younger people. You are (in sales) expected to have no outside life.. Culture is money and revenue over everything including client satisfaction. So much bureaucracy that you're going through at least 16 different people to get anything done. And honestly, there are some questionable business practices going on that in not comfortable with.

review_title: Technical Architect
job_title: Technical Architect in Englewood Cliffs, NJ
pros: There were a lot of opportunities at IBM.  There broad range of products and services create ample opportunity to move in almost any direction desired.  BTW, I originally worked for Informix Software where I was Principal Technical Architect .  Informix was then acquired by IBM.  I left IBM back in 2002 -- the system doesn't allow for older entries; so I note that here.
cons: I would say that aggressive people probably fit best at IBM.  I never felt that employees worked together and supported each other as I had experienced in other companies -- even though the model at that time was that of a matrix organization.  All-in-all, it seemed to me to be mostly  a very competitive environment.

review_title: Data Scientist and Watson Consultant
pros:
Generally speaking, the Work Pressure at IBM can be observed to be manageable. I work in the innovations field, hence the opportunity to work with state of the art technology like Watson and other data science solutions is very rewarding. 
The Flexibility one has when working at IBM is very attractive. 
The options of Home office and flexible work timings(dependent on project) are a boon.
cons: The salary compensations, salary revisions and other perks are a the downsides of working at IBM.

review_title: Storied history, great people, future uncertain
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Amazing people to work with, probably the most diverse workforce in tech (and they mean it when they say they embrace diversity). Doing lots of exciting projects in artificial intelligence and enterprise cloud. Storied history. Moving into newer urban facilities instead of being stuck in the exurbs.
cons: Shackled with systems and processes that struggle to keep up with the pace of change. Spent too much time destroying innovation and product capabilities with Roadmap to 2015's financial engineering shenanigans. Lost a lot of talent,  institutional knowledge, and a key employment differentiator in the tech industry, when switched away from encouraging remote work.

review_title: Not Good for GTS (Telecom) -- Below review is strictly for IBM GTS (Indian Telecomm client)
pros: Stability, security & Brand are the reasons to STAY in IBM (For GTS Telecomm accounts)
cons:
Client first in any case, If client hurts by words or action still fair.  
No growth. 
No personal life. 
Need to work on week offs.  
No variable pay
No salary hike

review_title: A company with solid values and a long history of transforming itself
pros: IBM is a company that stands by its values of dedication to client's success, trust and responsibility, and innovation that matters. It is also a company that truly celebrates diversity across the world. There is so much to learn, so many different opportunities, and many different jobs and roles one can play.
cons: It is a very large company which you need to know how to navigate. It has been around for more than a 100 years and may not seem as sexy, exciting or current as other younger companies (but it is!)

review_title: IBM Still an OK Place to Work
pros: Even if individual managers do not nescessarily understand the rights of their employees (some do, some don't, like in any large org) systemically the rights of the employees seem protected. A far sight from perfect, but better than any other place Ive worked.
cons:
IBM is, as it has always been, a place that it takes a long time for the average guy to make good money. Ive seen many young managers handed great responsibility while making far less then their run of the mill employees.
Also, the pension isn't any good, especially the one for new employees.

review_title: IBM needs to grow younger
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Burlington, VT
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for IBM are: IBM cares very much about work-life balance and allows for very flexible working hours; IBM provides plenty of learning opportunities through projects across different organizations; IBM has the resource to carry out pioneering projects that most of the smaller companies cannot afford to; IBM's scale makes the job relatively stable in the current market place.
cons: Some major downsides of working at IBM include: it is such a large organization that it is very difficult and may take a long time to advance in the career path; breaking barriers between organizations can be difficult and often result in low efficiency; there are too many old people that are too used to the established way of doing business

review_title: IBM Microelectronics - a great place to be from
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in East Fishkill, NY
pros: Being part of the state of the art of technology development. Being on the cutting edge. People work hard and produce in this division. It's great to work with such a talented and motivated group.
cons: Career advancement and recognition are almost non-existent relative to other divisions within IBM. Other IBM divisions are recognized for their accomplishments. RSUs, options and annual awards are the norm. These things are RARE in IBM Micro. This "other division" recognition is hard to swallow when you realize that it is your team's accomplishments that have SIGNIFICANTLY helped the other divisions succeed. An important but not immediately necessary IBM non-benefit is the lack of a retirement health plan for new employees. Plain and simple, there is none. This is a huge downside for IBM.

review_title: IBM has forgotten its  legacy and is dead set on re-inventing itself.....at the expense of the people that built it up.
pros: If you are focused on moving up the corporate ladder and playing politics you can go far in IBM, regardless of your talent level, but you will have to re-locate.
cons: You never know when your time is up, regardless of how well you do from a numbers standpoint.   There is never any feeling of comfort, always worry that you will be the next to go.   IBM has drastically changed as a company and it is all about EPS, period.

review_title: Management is not listening to the workers in the trenches
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Houston, TX
pros: Fellow practitioners make IBM a great place to work.  The talent is very good and can accomplish anything given the chance.
cons: The company is being run by accountants. Every year there is something else that is reduced which is affecting morale and productivity.  Basic software that my customer has that I can't get. I know many people who buy their own copies of software just to do their job we are asked to do. Education is a big complaint as well.  And every employee gets animated when we bring up the subject thanks awards.

review_title: No place for ambition.
pros: - Good network of information and access to professionals in variety of areas of expertise.
cons:
- Job growth is very slow, despite continued excellent performance. Learning and skill development are only talked about, and employees are not given enough opportunities to actually carry them out.
- Management does not always take responsibility.
- Process of assessing and rating management is very poor, and does not accurately convey their performance to their reviewers.
- Position classification system is not well designed, and employees' skill levels do not suit their position within the company.
- The interview processes are not well designed to properly assess candidates' skill levels.
- Lack of openness toward employees.

review_title: Not your father's or mother's IBM
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: IBM continues to seek out the best and brightest among computer professionals from around the world.  The culture of technical excellence and advancement is still solidly in place.
cons: With so many highly talented and skilled professionals, the culture at IBM is often cutthroat to the point that genuine talent is overshadowed by personalities and cliques.  Employees are often viewed as disposable and interchangeable, with more emphasis frequently placed on bringing in fresh college hires than retaining more experienced workers.

review_title: Opportunity to work with good technical people, but slow moving and lacking in proactive strategies
pros:
excellent flexibility in work hours
solid pay
Working on some IBM technology can be great experience for moving to career with IBM's customers
cons:
tech company completely run by accountants and sales
Virtually no technical backgrounds in senior leadership
No emphasis on creating truly world class technology
With massive job cuts in the US workforce in recent years, it's nearly impossibly to move around in the company, which was previously a big positive

review_title: Great Organization
pros: IBM offers incredible career development opportunities. As a global company I had the benefit of traveling to international locations for work and regularly work with global colleagues. In addition to career development the work life balance is fairly good given how competitive the technology marketplace is.
cons: Like many large organization there is a fair amount of bureaucracy that gets in the way of doing the actual work that I enjoy. I would say that this is necessary to manage and control such a large enterprise. The scale and resources, however, far outweigh the occasional headache from a tedious process.

review_title: Excellent company overall that has lost focus on the value of people
job_title: Business Development Executive in Toronto, ON
pros: Good people to work with who are focussed on their goals, great brand, good opportunities for variety of jobs.
cons: IBM has forgotten what they used to value most - their people.  Since accountants and lawyers now run the business, they have forgotten that people make results happen - so you need to reward them and make them feel valued.  IBM has come to the point where they make you feel like you are never good enough.  Overall I enjoyed my years at IBM, and left on my own for another opportunity simply because they lost the values they were built on.  Loved my years at IBM, but it was sad to see them lose their way.

review_title: Actively trying to outsource all engineering talent overseas
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros: The benefits are really nice and the people who do work locally are all very bright and dedicated.
cons: I worked for a company that was acquired by IBM.  While IBM has a lot of talented people working for it, it quickly became apparent that as a highly paid engineer at IBM you are considered a liability.  We were actively interviewing engineers in India and Singapore to replace us and we told to expect yearly layoffs.  They delivered on that promise. To say the mood was sour is an understatement.  The worst part is the quality of our products suffered greatly and eventually there will be no one in the U.S. who actually knows how the software works.

review_title: Bewildering, enlightening, frustrating, interesting
pros:
Collegial atmosphere
Looks good on your CV
Great systems and access to knowledge
Access to large, strategic projects
Easy to meet key decision makers
Opportunities to progress
"Work / life balance" (work remotely or in office as you choose)
Genuine commitment to equality and fairness
cons:
Old-school sales culture (think "selling is telling""death by powerpoint")
unmotivated and recalcitrant sales support staff ("I can't do a client meeting on Wednesdays, I'm picking my kids up...")
Inward looking culture (too many lifetime IBMers with stale ideas)
Unrealistic growth targets
Outdated hierarchical and macho management culture
Constant internal conflict where another part of IBM frequently costs you business
Process, forms, more forms, approvals, red tape
Pay below market rates

review_title: Short term job is ok
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros: Excellent people to work with.  Challenging job assignments.  You get to work with a lot of modern technology
cons: Management is brutal towards employees.  Yearly layoffs that are random cuts no matter how good you are ( e.g. really good developer was promoted one month, laid off two months later)   Very cheap company ( e.g. no budget for training / education,  laptop upgrade only every 5 years)  Very short term vision for management focus on expense reduction ( e.g. Hardware is not provided to test software because it is too expensive)   Pay and benefits are below average.

review_title: The increasing lack of employee appreciation has caused my enthusiasm to wane.
job_title: Executive Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: For the most part, IBM employees are exceptional; bright, driven, hard working, conscientious, productive.
cons: In the years that I have been with IBM, it has gone from a company that seemingly valued its employees to a company that only values its bottom line.  IBM no longer provides money for continued education, no longer provides work-from-home employees with necessities such as printers, monitors, keyboards, etc.  Raises are minimal and do not meet cost of living increases.  Bonuses have shrunk over the years to being nearly non-existent.  Employees work together for years and never meet their fellow department members or managers.  There are several resource actions every year and the employees who remain are expected to pick up the resulting unassigned work load.

review_title: Big shiny big blue has problems under the surface - employee engagement being the biggest one
pros: Lots of credibility built up in the marketplace (from when employees used to care and be proud of working for the company) and a large enough business to sustain itself through challenges for a while
cons: IBM is increasingly being run by the bean-counters, with a maniacal focus on financial metrics, at the expense of employee development and engagement. Hard to come by IBMers who are truly proud of the company and enjoy working there.

review_title: GBS Sr. Managing Consultant
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
Big 4 consulting org
6% match on 401k
generous vacation and holiday time off
Warm leads from SWG and other sales teams
Most funded R&D org in the industry; most patents in world each year
Respected Engineering firm
cons:
Salary is lower than industry average
No pay raises
No bonus in GBS
Not a marketing firm (lacks marketing expertise to bring new innovative products to market - speech failed, mobile failed, collaboration tools don't hold a match to google docs, will see how watson does)
Loads of processes that are costly but ineffective - DS&P, PMR, Delivery Excellence, etc. 
Ran by spreadsheets, lots of resource actions all around company to meet 2015 financial goals; lots of offshoring key roles for same reasons; 
high pressure for over 100% consultant utilization

review_title: My experience with IBM was short but quite interesting working for a large worldwide corporation.
job_title: Windows Systems Administrator in Portland, ME
pros: Company values are ethical.  Great salary, health and dental benefits and training. Ability to work from home was much appreciated.  Time off was sufficient.
cons: Lack of support and communication from their HR.  Overwhelming expectations initially with training and requirements. Need for career better opportunities.  Once contract expired, most jobs were only available for internal candidates.

review_title: My experience with IBM was short but quite interesting working for a large worldwide corporation.
job_title: Windows Systems Administrator in Portland, ME
pros: Company values are ethical.  Great salary, health and dental benefits and training. Ability to work from home was much appreciated.  Time off was sufficient.
cons: Lack of support and communication from their HR.  Overwhelming expectations initially with training and requirements. Need for career better opportunities.  Once contract expired, most jobs were only available for internal candidates.

review_title: Excellent place to start your career and build a resume
pros: IBM has some of the best talent out there. Many of the technology and technologists are second to none. IBM encourages patent generation and has many opportunities to grow skill base. Great work-life balance. New employees can take on a lot of real responsibility.
cons: Large bureaucracy (100 years in the making). Executve leadership team driven by short term financials and reactionary behavior, which consistently undermines the creation of great technology (takes many quarters and financial fortitude to carry through). Variable compensation rarely delivered due to poor strategic decisions from executive leadership team.

review_title: Good company, but no such thing as "security"
job_title: Manager, Corporate Citizenship & Corporate Affairs in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
IBM is flexible and rewards innovation (for those high enough or allowed to introduce it).  Great people work there that want to do good.

Fantastic volunteer programs through "On Demand Community," where one can earn cash rewards for the nonprofit or school they serve with 40 or more hours a year.

Good leadership development programs.
cons:
There is NO loyalty to you or job security.  You can have friends at IBM, but unless you are a very strong performer, NO ONE will stick their neck out for you.  No one.  

It's also never a good idea to have opinions contrary to the company line.

review_title: Tired Culture that requires change
pros: Generally smart workforce. Support remote work environment. Opportunities for training and development. Company still has many "tentacles" into clients and prospects in order to pursue potential business.
cons: Workforce is overwhelmingly apathetic and tired. Most employees are motivated primarily to do whatever is needed to cruise into retirement. No focus on employee satisfaction. No focus on enhancing loyalty. First and second layer management talent is generally weak and primarily focused on job protection and internal politics.

review_title: Good for career kick-off, not that much for seniors
pros: IBM offers variety of entry level jobs, and enables graduates to build solid professional background. Your career can grow rapidly horizontally and vertically, as rotations are promoted and available. High dynamics of self-transformation trains employees in flexibility and adaptation.
cons: The pace of transformation got crazy, resulted into ambiguity. Fast changing priorities and weak change management have been deteriorating morale and motivation of general staff. Touching motivation - the obvious low engagement of senior management is just another reason why highly performing senior employees prefer to seek further career growth elswhere.

review_title: Extremely interesting experience, are a very hands off, expects you to be self motivated.
pros: Large scale projects. Work that keeps you invested in what you are doing. Hands off non-micromanaging approach. Valuable experience. Encourage learning and increasing ones own value.
cons: Salary could be higher considering the importance of the work being done. Job security can be unstable based on cash flow from client, unless you can move to another area within IBM. Sometimes tough to move up latter for raises.

review_title: Life at IBM in Baton Rouge
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: The people at the Baton Rouge Center are great people to work with. Friendly and gives you help on your project even if they are on another.
cons: This is a Consultant position, not a developer position. If you are looking for in-house developer position this is not it. It is also a sink or die situation. There is no way to move vertical or horizontal. You are stuck in your position until you find another job. You work 44 hours or more per week which means you will burn out quickly on some project.

review_title: Designer at IBM
pros:
The community of designers is wonderful
Solving difficult problems through design
Being part of the whole process of design
Great place to learn about other design disciplines
The organization as a while has come a long way in a few years with regards to incorporating design and design thinking. (Still has a long way to go, but there is progress)
cons:
Suffers from the typical faults of a large corporation
As a visual designer, opportunities to be creative are somewhat limited
Overall happiness is VERY dependent on the team and org

review_title: Fun while it lasted but I know my market value...
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Flexible work schedule and location 
International travel opportunities
A lot of vacation time
Exciting technology
Most of the folks in the product side are gung-ho and engaged
cons:
Morale was terrible the last few years, with the constant cutting and underperformance of the company overall, which meant no real bonuses or raises.
Too many layers of "do nothing" management.  Between my FLM and the GM there were about four other people who created no demonstrable value.
No advancement for the technical track
FLMs are just cycled through the company.
Productivity software was anything but... seriously ditch Notes/Verse, Communities, etc, The market has rejected them so should IBM finally.

review_title: Good Good - I am from IBM India, GBS, so review are given in purview of GBS Vertical of IBM

1. Work from home facility.
2. No punch in and punch out Facility.
3. Big Brand Name.

review_title: Customer Service Representative
pros: The city of Wroclaw, is very welcoming, warm and great to live in. Job gives you a lot of experience in handling the customers in all situations possible. Some teams are really great with very good managers.  You have multisport card, and private healthcare. If you have good reason, you can make your own schedule like 70%. Opportunity to grow in the team and in the company to other departments. Canteen, lidl and bus stations nearby.
cons:
The queries are long, customers are most of the time in a hurry and everything is urgent. Of course depends of the team, but when you deal with trade and retail, 
 in supporting banks there is always a queue. There were few technical problems with the equipments, some app versions were old and we were lagging in the rush hours.

review_title: Proud to be an IBMer
pros: When you find yourself lost somewhere in the world of competition, if you are at IBM, with grace you can tell the world that I’m an IBMer. When an organization encourage its employees, to up-skill, learn and apply cognitive thinking approach on the things that matter to the world, you see the changes in the world that matters to you.
cons: I feel as an IBMer we need to find a way to showcase our talent and capabilities to rest of the world. Currently which is lacking and impacting the organization as a whole.

review_title: IBM India CIO organisation Sales and Incentives, FMS and other projects
pros: Working under non technical project managers.  Work from home. If you are close to managers you can work 3-4 days a week. Managers can come office and show face to employees and go home and do home works , evening come and show face to employees.
cons: Age old technologis. Project managers are worst in this organisation for especially FMS project.  I have worked under a lady project manager having lot of head weight. Manager don't respect peoples from same company if they are comptative to their position. Guys do not join this organisation for this project. A lot of micro management. They convince employees joining project telling we use cutting edge technologies but in real ground is nothing.  Funniest is that agile scrum is 30-40 min meeting for them and a lady scrum masters from the project ask manager to take action on senior employees by doing micro management.

review_title: Current management is killing IBM
pros: Work from home and flexible work hours we major pros
cons: Once the layoffs started it was dog eat dog and everyone began looking out for themselves. Management became indifferent to the employees under them, contracting out became the norm for project resources since employees were progressively laid off, internal departments were off-shored which may have saved money on paper but made trying to get anything done a slow and painful process.

review_title: IBM review
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Irvine, CA
pros: There are very bright people and the work is challenging. Good benefits.  Opportunity to completely change career directions (e.g go from technical to sales).  Management is taken very seriously.  You can learn a lot and there are some very good personnel practices.  Responsibility is given to people throughout the organization. The company cares about its customers and is succesful on the whole.  You do get exposed to global cultures and there is commitment to diversity
cons: Work life balance is weighted too much to work especially since we are a global economy and deal with other geos that are in different time zones.  There is too much beauracracy. There are challenges to move beyond a certain level unless you are located in a lab.  Too many meetings.

review_title: IBM is not the place for you if you value compensation and an appropriate evaluation of your job performance.
pros: Flex-time and work from home options. There are lots of e-learning opportunities that you can take of advantage of on the learning @ IBM site. Opportunities to consult on a variety of topics.
cons:
Salary is lower than industry standards.
Formal evaluation of work performed (PBC) does not truly reflect employee's performance. Evaluations are distributed  based on formula. So many individuals must receive a low number no matter if they actually performed at a higher level . There are lots of ways that you must document the work that you've performed/ There is a utilization requirement wherein you end up not really getting any paid time off (vacation / holiday) because you are working extra hours to make up for any "time off" you may be taking.

review_title: a large company but no invention, no place for creative people and consultants has to administer and not to consult
pros:
- IBM has importent history in IT development
- company has a lot of employees
- good advertisement in media
cons:
- unprofessional working and administration framework for consulting company
- no orientation for customer satifsfaction 
- consultants has no time for customers, they waste a lot of time for internal administration
- roughly project execution
- unprofessional continuing education
- low cost policy at all
- has a lot of low cost emploees that have no knowledge and is in projects not employable

review_title: IBM is no longer a great place to work...
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
There is some job flexibility - you can work at home in some jobs.   

The benefits are good:
- Several options for health insurance
- Dental/Vision coverage
- Long term disability
- Matching 401K (but no pension)

The pay is good when compared to other companies.
cons: The hours are very long.  People are expected to work overtime almost all of the time.  There is no such thing as a 40 hour work week.  There are limited opportunities for advancement.   It is difficult to transfer into another position - your manager will not want to let you go.  The wrong people are rewarded and promoted.  Most importantly - they outsource jobs overseas constantly.   There is no job security whatsoever.

review_title: IBMers truely work more than 40 hours a week but overally have a good ethics espeically delivering positive results.
job_title: Global Data Center Program Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: IBM is a stable, wealthy company that has many perks including the benefit package and health insurance avaiable.  IBM employment for the most part is relatively stable.
cons: IBMers are typically overworked providing services that exeed 40 hours a week including nights and weekends that are just expected.  Balancing personal and work life can be difficult especially since the many positions are work from home.  Additionally, collaboration becomes very difficult in this position since everyone must engage in conference calls.

review_title: IBM Then and Now
pros: IBM has a true grasp of business, plans well, and teaches its employees.  It is the perfect place to begin a career and learn all you can.  If you can manage to stay relevant, it can also be a great place to end your career, aka retire.
cons: IBM has lost some of what used to be what set it apart: Respect for the Individual.  It was too quick to try to mirror some of the behaviors of newer, fresher companies in the 80's and 90's.  Most of those companies are no longer around; IBM managed to outlast them, but at the cost of some great talent.

review_title: Once a great, formidable company, but not any more.
job_title: Client Technical Specialist in London, England
pros:
Have worked here for more than 27 years, so I know what I'm talking about. I've been very successful here. 
Company name opens doors. 
People rally round when the chips are down. 
Work at home or in the office, very flexible.
cons:
Lack of empowerment at junior management levels. 
Absolute belief that if a product is useless it can be made effective by saying it is so. 
Career advancement depends on playing the game, getting your face "known" & this is rated far, far higher than actual technical ability. 
Personal objectives meaningless and not set until around a third of the way through the year. 
The US corporation shafted an entire generation of IBMers over pensions.

review_title: IBM is not anything at all like it used to be.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: IBM has lots of very talented and hard working people. There is a wealth of technical knowledge within the company.
cons: IBM seems to be focused solely on the bottom line.  The company no longer seems interested in maintaining a competitive advantage through technical innovation or by attracting and retaining top technical talent.  IBM is bleeding away talented people through resource actions (aka layoffs) and people leaving on their own initiative. The remaining people are expected to carry the ever growing workload with fewer resources after losing strong experienced people.  Also, the periodic layoffs strip away any sense of job security.

review_title: A once great company caved in to Shareholders' greed
pros: Really good  people to work with, only if any of the nice and smart people still left after the multiple wave of  culling in Australia and offshoring the jobs. Good experience and the work load would have produced many long endurance  multi-tasking super employees that other companies might see as value added asset.
cons: Hardly any pay rise for last few years to keep up with inflation. Not paid enough for the high stress, long hours and week end work to satisfy the executive demands and "help " from the global team.

review_title: Software Sales Specialist
pros: IBM's direction of where they need to be seems right on.  Solid people work for the company and the expectations of all working hard for the best of the company are there
cons: The company is not the same as it used to be with customers first, employees second and that contributes to the best for IBM.   Think is is IBM business first, customers in there somewhere but the way it was making financials over the last few years was taking a good bit away from employees:  401K, insurance (always used to be top) and career goals.

review_title: Not the company it was
pros: Fantastic brand name and for many years IBM was a great place to work. Full of very bright people and great innovative technology.
cons: There is a process for a process and the company is downsizing so much that the quality of delivery and people is seriously compromised. Lots of fake forecasting and then reviewing made up opportunities. Bureaucratic and no more respect for the individual - something IBM used to pride itself on. Lots of dodgy hate dealings. Rich US directors get richer. The employees and customers suffer. Far too much focus on shareholder value and not customer.

review_title: It's not your father's IBM anymore (sometimes in a good way)
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Benefits are great.  If you're willing to travel and keep up with the demand to have your billing percentage up you'll gain a lot of valuable experience.  There's always room to learn new skills and apply them in a project.
cons: Long hours depending on the assignment.  Travel can wear you out, so look for opportunities within IBM to remain valuable and be billable.  Depending on your assignment, work-life balance may not equate.

review_title: Mixed feelings
IBM US
pros:
1. Web Based education available
2. Work from home availability
3. Opportunity to work in multiple IT fields
4. Large knowledge base
5. Global opportunity
cons:
1.  If you have been with IBM longer than 10 years and are in the US your days are numbered.
2.  Constant assault on benefits by finance
3.  Very low % raises if any, even for high performers
4.  Finance driven employee evaluation system forces low evaluations in an effort to justify layoffs.

review_title: Flexible but Not User Friendly
job_title: Senior Technical Director in Annapolis, MD
pros:
Telecommuting
Flexible 
Internal Recorded Training Resources 
Lots of mobile tools

review_title: IBM - Empire in Decline
job_title: Technical Solutions Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Working remote/home for many positions (just be aware that this is a prelude to EVENTUALLY outsourcing your job to a cheaper 3rd world locale). You have access to some strong co-workers for support and to learn from.  In general, there are also many opportunities to get involved with different technologies (although that comes with a caveat, see my comments in the "cons" section). And across the industry, for resume purposes, IBM still has a good name so take advantage of it while it lasts.

IBM is now a good company for any fresh-out-of-school newbie that wants to gain some standard 21st corporate world experience. Plus the pay is not bad for newbies. For more experienced workers however, IBM is very limited.  Executive management's not-so-secret agenda is to layoff as many "high priced" USA-based employees (and in other developed countries) and outsource everything possible to the 3rd world. Any gaps are theoretically back-filled with the "layoffees" as contractors, assuming they can't find work elsewhere.
cons:
At this point in IBM's history, it's a lot like life during the decline of the Roman Empire. There were worse places to live during the decline of the empire but the Visigoths were coming. When considering the eradication of IBM's developed-world workforce (and compensation packages) throughout a never-ending quest to transfer the payrolls to cheaper 3rd world countries, there is a lot of risk involved with working at IBM long term.  In the short term, it's a decent place to pay your dues for a few years and then leave for greener pastures with 'IBM' on your resume.

You'll have lots of exposure to different technologies at IBM. Unfortunately, a lot of what's forced on you is either proprietary, obscure, or rapidly vanishing outside the world of IBM (think Lotus Word Pro, Lotus Notes, Domino, etc). Many US-based jobs at IBM are "tenuous", so the workplace feels a lot like dining under the Sword of Damocles. Since your co-workers know that the end could come at any moment, and their survival depends upon how well they rank compared to you, the result is reduced information flow/share, cooperation, participation, and general workplace camaraderie among your co-workers.

On the subject of "how you rank", the PBC system (performance reviews) at IBM is a TOTAL FARCE.  It's basically a random system of ranking by the managers. Worse yet, you usually already have a performance number assigned before the evaluations ever begin -- based on who the manager's favorite employees are, how many people in the dept the execs said will need to be laid off in the next year, etc.  

Specific to a bonus/commission/performance-based role at IBM like the TSM position, another rub is that you don't pick your assignments - they're given to you. So, if a manager needs to get rid of someone, it's far easier to assign the "DOA" and "tire-kicking" deals (which are almost certain to go nowhere and therefore result in lower performance) to anyone targeted for layoff than it is to deal with concocting other reasons to get rid of them and thereby meet executive management's employee attrition goals.

review_title: IBM India Pvt Ltd, Kolkata
pros:
1. Opportunity to work on various technologies and domains
2. Access to a lot of products and tools (IBM owns them ...;-))
3. Access to a lot of intellectual property (learning materials)
3. Good company to start your career.
4. Onsite opportunities if you are lucky and patient.
5. Good rewards and recognition policy.
6. Work environment is fine.
7. Mature company with well established processes.
cons:
1. Pay package not competitive. 
2. Benefits are negligible and decreasing day by day as the headcount is increasing.
3. Annual raise in salary is minimum. 
4. Bonus is even hardly noticeable.
5. Career growth may get stagnated if get stucked in long term projects.
6. Work culture may become laidback with time.
6. Cafeteria food sucks!

review_title: Great company if you want to settle in the country.
pros:
Company values really drive you to be the best.
Good pay, usually better than market even among MNCs.
Good career programs that lets employees grow their careers.
All information you need to do your job (and excel at it) can be found online.
Opportunities to learn anything and everything outside of your project.
Opportunities to contribute to fields outside of your project.
Good awareness of environmental problems and pro-active in helping out.
Industry leader.
Office in Cebu.
cons:
Benefits are so-so.
Managers listen to employees but are oftentimes to busy to meet with employees.
If you are the type that find 1-on-1 mentoring with your managers important then you might have a difficult time with this company.
Offices are at Quezon City only (within NCR).

review_title: Great company to work for
pros: Working for the IBM brand has benefits. Excellent benefits, but pay can vary greatly depending on how high value your work is. Services is more low value, margins are low and so are pay scales. That said, there are also some computing areas that are high paying and high value, if you are lucky enough to have earned those skills.
cons: IBM is an ocean to work in. There is move to relocate work towards global delivery centers and tier 3 cities and away from the work from home model to reduce costs. This means layoffs for those high paying jobs unless you are willing to relocate to these centers. If you are a rock star and perform high value technical work or client facing work that involves intimate knowledge of client domain there is a good chance you will not get RA-ed.

review_title: Formerly a great company, has potential to be great again if they can grow revenue
pros:
Overall values and vision of the company; more highly functioning than most companies.
Cutting edge technology and business ventures (eg Watson).
Career growth opportunities within and across organizations can be vast, depending on your profession.  
Management at the lower levels generally is very supportive of its employees.
cons:
Penny pinching ways.  This includes forcing employees to use subcompact cars and travel in coach even for flights to AP, having employees use outdated laptops and applications, and scrutiny / controls on even incidental office expenses.  
Too many processes, approval layers, and fear of senior management.

review_title: Exhausting culture coupled with regular cutbacks and reductions
pros:
- Historic company -- felt a genuine surge of pride the first time I received a badge
- Very smart, very driven people throughout org
- Excellent online internal resources
cons:
- Layoffs, layoffs, layoffs -- feeling of "who's next?" is pervasive throughout organization
- Lack of trust in leadership
- Shortage of managerial courage. If something doesn't go as planned, enjoy the show as "leaders" scurry out of the way and try to assess blame
- They preach work-life balance, family first, the importance of self-development, etc. ... but these are given extremely low priority when it comes to day-to-day
- Performance appraisal and compensation programs are absolute embarrassments. Unless you're a 'superstar' or know someone, it is not unusual to go years (literally) without an increase

review_title: Great people hampered by stale culture and risk-aversion
job_title: Director, Business Development in Somers, NY
pros: Great people here, some great managers, opportunities for advancement if you are in the NY area (where the decision making takes place), commitment to diversity initiatives, flexibility and ability to work from home when needed (but this is largely manager dependent).  Base pay is pretty competitive.
cons: Bureaucratic, too process-driven, pervasive risk-aversion and managers are uncomfortable making decisions, slow to adopt change, innovation and new business models, bonuses are non-existent for non-executives, way too focused on pleasing Wall St.

review_title: Not bad, but could be better
pros:
- Good people to work with - very diverse giving you several possibilities to work with different people
- Promotions and raises are solely based on performance without taking much consideration in how long someone has been there; this can be a con to some, but I personally believe this is a entirely fair and seeds out to reward the best workers... hence, hard work pays off
- Work life balance is manageable and good when you have a lot more going on outside of work, but on the flip side, it may be too slow or 'not exciting' enough for a younger employee who is very focused on career growth
cons:
- Underpaid for being an FA
- Difficult to move up in the company
- Unless you're in higher management, I don't have a 'rewarding' job that makes a difference, or makes me feel good

review_title: Get to work with lots of good people
job_title: IT Project Manager in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: There are lots of opportunities at IBM to research and use the latest technologies. The people are also talented and hard working. I got to work with people all over the globe - Argentina, Brazil, Italy, Czech Republic, and India - and got to learn a bit about their cultures.
cons: While 40 hours of education are required each year most departments have no education budget so you're forced to take whatever free courses IBM offers. Even if a department did have an education budget it was usually only enough money to allow 1 person to go to class.

review_title: Not your father
pros: It's still an impressive company to have on your resume. Benefits are generous, but not as good as they used to be. People are still proud to be IBMers.
cons: Nobody gets raises any more. IBM is actively trying to move every job possible out of the US. Don't expect much financial appreciation. Expect to work long hours. There is an annual bonus plan but it only pays off to the very highest of performers, as rated by their manager. You have to practically get VP approval to buy a pencil, expenses are so tightly controlled. Bean counters galore!

review_title: Software Development Intern
job_title: Software Development Intern in Littleton, MA
pros: I was a software development summer intern at the Mass lab in Littleton, MA. The location is really nice during the summer, and the premises feel pretty new. This probably varies for each intern, but the team I was in was really nice and willing to help me with my problems, and we all got along pretty well. Pay depends on the number of credits towards your degree that you've finished, but the rate is relatively good.
cons: Even as an intern, you can feel the bureaucracy going on in the background. Also, this depends on the team, but be prepared to have a lot of meetings, most if not all of them including having to deal with the joy that is conference calls.

review_title: IBM _ Excellent Work Culture & Atmosphere
pros:
Recently IBM involved all its employees to decide how its most critical HR process should be. based on employees feedback IBM has done away with the forced bell curve and team based decision making and fully empowering managers to decide based on merit.
 It has been received very well. Provides excellent opportunities to work across business units. Best of the technical minds to interact & work with. Great executive leadership - Approachable & Helpful Above all, the workplace flexibility allows you to ensure that you are with your family when it needs you. Lots and lots of learning and career growth opportunities. Helps innovators and performers to do better. If you are a self-learner, you'd love to be here.
cons: A bit stingy when it comes to money.

review_title: Supportive Employer
job_title: Education Quality Assurance in Austin, TX
pros: Strong support for internal and external education. Flexible scheduling. Improved review processes. Support for volunteerism. Great benefits both medical and financial. Positive reinforcement from colleagues is encouraged through BlueThx program. Mentorship encouraged.
cons: The only downside that I can think of is that change has been slow because of the massive size of the organization. But as the company is turning to an Agile methodology it appears that changes are happening a little more quickly. Also, while IBM encourages employees to learn about new IBM applications, it could do a better job of ensuring that all departments have the means of incorporating appropriate software into their department processes.

review_title: Depends on what you're looking for
pros: Has may long-term projects that provide stability though they may not be that interesting. Can sometimes get on interesting projects from other more well-connected offices, that's the plus of a global company. Opportunity to try different roles. Pretty good recognition program for moving up/raises.
cons: Remote work makes you feel like an anonymous drone. When projects finish it's on to something else you may not be interested in or have the skills in because it's all about billable hours. This is good for learning new skills and bad for when you know the work you want to do. Confusing hierarchy and executive structure. Remote clients may require travel. Lots of new hiring with little work lined up for them. Many times on shorter-term projects there are 55+ hour weeks, weekends, etc.

review_title: Going down the hill
pros: worklife balance, teleworking, salary is just average. Not sure if this is really a pro, but lots of people get away with doing nothing at all. Obviuosly, this is not a pro if you're one of the silly ones who end up doing their job in addition to your own.
cons: IBM is aggressively laying off all around the world, even products which are very profitable. Their way of brining up the value of shares is just to cut off costs by reducing employees. In Italy, they're currently selling out the Workload Scheduler, a product which earns 170 million dollars while costing only 10. The whole of the Rome software lab, once a major development and innovation center is now at risk. Kind of makes you wonder why should bend over backwards to meet their demands when you're just a number to them...Depressing and disheartening...

review_title: sales
pros: I love working for CDK, this organization offers excellent pay/benefits and flexibility. I consider myself very lucky to work for such an awesome organization! I trust leadership and respect my manager. My colleagues are strong, very smart people who are committed to this organization.
cons: This business is going through transformation, reducing facility foot print and a lot of associates are upset and they are writing bad reviews on glassdoor. This is such a great company and I would be upset too if my facility was closing and I was losing my job at CDK. CDK has to move forward to the way companies are doing business in 2016.

review_title: Very happy with my decision
pros: I just recently on-boarded with IBM in Columbia, MO and I couldn't be happier with my experience thus far. The opportunities are endless, the energy is vibrant, and everyone is incredibly welcoming and helpful. IBM seems very "fluid" in their approach to different areas of business, and I find that refreshing because it allows for employee's to share their thoughts/suggestions. I  am very excited to see where things lead with IBM.
cons: I'd say the one drawback I have come across is the multiple apps/programs that are used. Not the end of the world -- just an improvement opportunity I have noticed.

review_title: Senior Consultant
pros:
1) Flexibility at workplace. Work Life Balance is excellent. WFH any time .
2) Work as a one man army in project because of it get more exposer to interact with client which need to wide angle of knowledge in domain technology.
cons:
1) Very slow Salary hike and Promotion. 
2) To get promotion eligible after 2 year of joining. Which usually take once in 3years. 
3) Annual salary hike average is 6% once in a 2years.
4) Get very less opportunity to meet team member because most of the time they do WFH.
5) No designated HR for employee everything is portal oriented.

review_title: Enterprise Sales multiple roles
job_title: Watson & Cloud Platform in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing company  with a culture of innovation, in continuous transformation, leader in AI, Blockchain, and strong position in the battle for the cloud. Salaries are competitive for the industry, there are endless opportunities to grow within the company, nice people, hands off leadership, many more benefits, overall great company to work for.
cons: continuous change can be challenging for many people to embrace and adapt and then change again (change of clients, territories, products on the portfolios, managers, leadership, go to market strategy, new products, new teams ETC) = change, change, change, be ready for it. If you can deal with it (I personally find it engaging), then you are in good hands

review_title: Client manager
pros:
Great, funny, clever sharp people around in this company with a strong community involvement from within the employees. Work life balance can be achieved with support - no problem!  

IBM has an enormous eco system of a brilliant pool of talented people and products that can really make a huge difference to business from  small to gigantic company size

Superb top notch,  training to be offered on an ongoing basis.....a lots of it too!
cons: IBM suffers  greatly in my opinion from not being a 'visible' value add to organization throughout the world  at larger. IBM was once one of the main go-to for clients - we do need to let the wider world know we are still here and make a stronger shake at marketing ourselves.

review_title: Good for Juniors, No way for Seniors
pros: -Good place to learn Finance &Accounting and start your career for beginners.
cons:
-Bad organization and low experience in management
-Poor international atmosphere
-Lack of appreciation for experience and effort
-Bad office equipment, old and traditional policies
-Different approach to foreigners than polish workers.

Overall, never expect anything for the years of labor and effort. They can easily waste you with a single escalation. Don't raise your voice if you don't want to be tagged. Eventually, you will be forced to resign, because you are nothing more than a high cost FTE in their eyes...

review_title: Great learning experience
pros: Awesome exposure to technology and talented people that want to change the world. Good projects if you are lucky to carve out your space. Good career progression in junior and mid-mgmt levels, especially if you work hard. The place where I learned the most in my late career.
cons: No guidance, you have to be ultra-entrepreneur. Politics play a huge role and many people have been promoted piggybacking on big projects without knowing what needs to be done - process over merit. You need to play the game to keep rising through the ranks and befriend the right leadership.

review_title: Run Away unless you wish to ruin your life
job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: There is only ONE “pro” and that is working from home.  That’s it!
cons:
This company cares NOTHING about the employee. They care about one thing.  Dollars!  

Clients hate us. The processes are insane and quash all ability to work with any creativity. 

IBM does not care about its customers. If they only knew what goes on behind the scenes. 

No bonuses, or when they come they are a complete and utter joke.  Less than 1% of salary. 

Raises non existent for anyone other than management. 

In short, unless you are a complete F-up, I’d run for the hills as this company will put you in the dirt. 

They expect you to give them your heart and soul, but when the bean counters or analysts decide they need to cut, you could be Mother Teresa and you’ll still get kicked to the curb with an immoral 1 mo severance.  No matter your tenure.

review_title: Great steady place to learn and meet geniuses
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros:
1. Meet research gurus and many famous geniuses
2. Steady, stable work environment; not terribly high pressure
3. Have lots of time to learn new things and experiment
4. Excellent support and incentives for patent development
5. Many tech talks, outside visitor talks of great interest
cons:
1. Can sometimes feel cloistered, esp. since said geniuses are usually not social wizards
2. Salary / Title growth very slow
3. Very miserly, essentially nonexistent bonus program
4. Highly bureaucratic -- almost like government

review_title: IBM Sales Job Review
pros: I enjoy working with really smart people and IBM is filled with them.  People typically have a very well-meaning, "how can I help" attitude.  The benefits are great with annual rebates for participating in a healthy living program.
cons: The cash portion of compensation is lacking.  For instance, I've been at the company for four years and have always received "top performer" or "above average contributer" ratings and have received a single 3.5% raise.  Another complaint is the beaurocracy and paperwork required to do anything.  We are significantly less nimble than our competitors because of this.  It can also be difficult for some to work in a matrixed organization where you have to please multiple people, both your direct management and others.

review_title: Good job flexibility helps offset stagnant salary/career growth.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, AR
pros: Tremendous work flexibilty in terms of when and where to work.  Depending on job may work with some of the best minds in the industry.  Salary and benefits are competitive, however the cost of living in the Poughkeepsie, NY location has gotten dramaticly more expensive over the past few years but salaries haven't nearly kept up to make it worthwhile to live/work here instead of for example a place like Austin, TX.
cons: Stagnant salary and career growth.  New hires fleeing due to uninpired leadership and work.  Very low morale.  High cost of living and not other opportunities in the area outside of IBM keeps salaries down.

review_title: IBM is not perfect, but I like my job here.
pros: Very interesting work, particularly in the more technical areas. Lots of smart people to work with. Lots of opportunity to move, and if you are lucky you can gradually move into a job that is a good fit for you. This might be harder is a smaller company.
cons: Very big company - not all parts of the company are equally well run. Some parts don't seem to be as good as others (in terms of being a good place to work).

review_title: IBM is not perfect, but I like my job here.
pros: Very interesting work, particularly in the more technical areas. Lots of smart people to work with. Lots of opportunity to move, and if you are lucky you can gradually move into a job that is a good fit for you. This might be harder is a smaller company.
cons: Very big company - not all parts of the company are equally well run. Some parts don't seem to be as good as others (in terms of being a good place to work).

review_title: It's the good, the bad, and the ugly
pros: IBM is very big on telecommuting.  When you decide to take your vacation days they are not heavily scrutinized.  There are tons of opportunities to move within IBM.  The company and its brand is recognized world wide.  The company has an excellent knowledgebase and intranet.
cons: IBM can be very impersonal.  The company is very process driven which can be a plus, but often people use it as an excuse to not do any work.  Raises and promotions seem to be non-existant unless you have a good manager or know how to work the system.  Not a great place to work if are looking to move quickly in your career.

review_title: IBM is old style management - manage by fear.  Employees are plug and play!
pros: The IBM name is impressive on a resume.  Some of the folks working there are very talented.  Some of the managers are very good and understanding of the pressures in the work place.
cons: Overall a cut-throat, finger-pointing environment.  Managers have no problem yelling at individuals in front of their peers.  When work load is heavy, management expects employees to work round the clock to meet THEIR ridiculous schedules.  Too many releases leaving exhausted employees with no time to regroup.

review_title: IBM: Great place to learn, bad place to work.
job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Great place to learn from others
cons: Focus is given to those who only exist to contribute to IBM, without regards for any personal life. In other words while IBM touts "work/life balance" as being important, it actually encourages an "all work / no personal llfe" atmosphere. The moment a person realizes that they need to slow down and re-claim their personal life, IBM loses interest in that person and labels them as "making too much money...", hoping that the person will eventually get frustrated from a lack of forward financial progress, and simply quit. Alternatively, if the person doesn't quit, they get laid off.

review_title: Good place to get experience, but very poor performance review system.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Great people. Lots of opportunities inside IBM. Good compensation.
cons: Performance review is done in a meaningless way. Everybody except one or two has the same performance review. Some managers are incompetent compared to others. Generally, performance reviews must be done strictly to managers as well as employees. Whatever standard will be like publication, patent, and product impact, it needs to be completely reviewed. Senior management is only running the company to maximize their own personal compensation. Work coordination between teams is not done well. Decision is made very slowly. Good work often is not recognized if you are under incompetent manager. If you want to work at IBM, try to find competent manager.

review_title: Nepotism Trumps Competence
pros: company with solid financials, established footprint in emerging markets, breadth of portfolio, well established and respected brand, as saying goes 'no one is fired for hiring IBM'
cons: large and disconnected organization, insular groups with no incentive to work with other groups or divisions, new hires left to their own devices to acclimate to firm and figure out how to be successful, career path unclear, nepotism rampant and trumps competence in career advancement, 20yr veterans has top slots so newcomers have a while to wait to reach senior level, matrix management of at least two managers for each employee is a waste of money and cons outweigh the pros

review_title: Great smart people, lots of knowledge to be gained, lacking direction and innovation
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Rochester, MN
pros: The people at IBM are second to none in intelligence and problem solving ability.  You learn more working here for 5 years than you will at any other company.  Lots of ability to know the whole computing industry and define what you want to work on
cons: Upper management is only concerned about EPS.  Thus squeezing most of the innovation out of the company.  Most innovation is now accomplished by working extra hours and struggling versus being encouraged and part of the job descriptions.  Lots of work as well making charts with pretty colors that executives and management can understand versus doing product cutting edge work.

review_title: Not as good as it used to be.
pros:
Flexibility to work at home for many people.
Great benefits.
Company name recognition.
cons:
Push by IBM to move many jobs from the US to other countries. IBM has made it clear that as a global company, they want a global workforce. While this makes sense in some ways, IBM is letting really good people, with experience and knowledge go, simply because they are based in the US. This move of resources to other countries means there are many people new to the company and job. 
Excessive workload leads to excessive work hours. It is expected that you will work nights/weekends to complete all the work that needs to be done.
Focus on negatives instead of positives.

review_title: Don't stay too long (<7y) - it's a short cycle to attain skills, contacts and move on to brighter career futures.
pros:
Great and reliable research sources, very intelligent workforce.
Excellent IT resources - no end to what you can have to enable a data deluge
A place to make a few great friends outside of the corp culture
Diverse enough so you're not always talking to "the man"
cons:
in an effort to bring operation costs down, down, down  (and show profits)- employment in the US is almost non-existent.
too much management  (un-actionable) 
too much cross functional decision-making, makes projects and success long and protracted
still too siloed , GBS vs, S&D, vs, SWG - no single face to the customer
groups work against each other, and there is no hesitance to throw folks under the bus with lots of blame-gaming.

review_title: I, like many others continue to remain optimistic and forge onward.
pros: Even in the economy of today, IBM has continued to provide pretty favorable benefit plan options. Comprehensive medical, dental and vision plans are all still offered which in today's economy is very much needed and welcomed.
cons: IBM continues to layoff employees practically monthly under the guise of the phrase Resource Action and the directive or reason most often given is "  re-engineer and move your work to an offshore location". If work were to remain in the US would not that help with the issue of unemployment in the United States?

review_title: Hardware business increasingly being marginalized by higher-margin services
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: IBM still has some of the world's best engineers, and we have access to cutting-edge technology.  Work-life balance is excellent.  Compensation is decent.
cons: Our new CEO, Virginia Rometty, seems to have no vision for the future of the company.  She's a manager, not a leader.  The semiconductor business, where I work, is increasingly being pushed aside in favor of IBM's higher-margin services business, which is itself increasingly moving to India.  Working in semiconductors has become mostly an exercise in cost-control rather than innovation.

review_title: Huge company, expect it to be run like one
job_title: Client Technical Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Good product offering and customers usually want to hear from you.  Working from home is becoming pretty standard for most jobs.
cons: This is a huge company and the disconnect between upper management and everyone else is impressive at times.  I think I'd have a better chance of seeing the Pope in person than our CEO.  Big changes (base pay reductions, org changes) can be pushed down in an arbitrary fashion with sometimes little rationale.  Even managers 3 or 4 levels up don't seem to know what is going on at times.   Politics is just as important as the quality of your work, so know that going in.

review_title: Going through a rough patch and difficult to recover
job_title: BI Solutions Architect in Des Moines, IA
pros: We'll established systems that work really well.  Expense reimbursements are pretty much clockwork.  Travel agency does a good job.
cons: Second straight year with 10,000+ layoffs or resource actions as they call it.  Layoffs seemed to be random since some people had 75%+utilization and already booked on projects for most of current year but they were still laid off.  They also had good performance ratings the past few years. Too much self service and hard to get a hold of competent people to help with questions.  Must rely on your own network to get some things done.

review_title: A once-great company in a long death spiral
pros: Smart, dedicated co-workers; Some vestiges of the old collegiality at the working level.
cons:
IBM's business model is totally out of date.  They are now being marginalized by new players like Google, Amazon, etc., and old competitors like HP-Compaq.   As sales are falling drastically, they can't fire people fast enough.  The executives are running the place like a third-world banana republic:  Massive bonuses for themselves, the working stiffs in the US are all being fired for low-cost third-world labor offshore.  

The only engineering innovation that matters any more is financial engineering of the Earnings per share.  However, EPS targets can only be achieved by layoffs and share buybacks, due to falling sales, and Wall Street isn't fooled.  Businesses and employees are being jettisoned at a rapid pace, a much smaller and weaker company will be the result.

review_title: Work with good people, but being continually asked to do more with less
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Ottawa, ON
pros: I can honestly say that many of the best people that I have ever worked with were from IBM.
cons: do not get comfortable doing what you are doing ... you will be asked to do less with more.  you will inherit other projects and not receive backfill for people moving onto newer projects.   It demonstrates that leadership generally is not able to balance the product portfolio or make decisions about what is important.

review_title: Good company to work with wrt to Work and personal life balance
pros: Not like any other indian MNC where you have to be in office for 9 hrs or so. Doesn't matter when you come to office ,the ultimate goal is to deliver to the client on time. Moreover, For Experienced professional I will say the best company to work with.As One can avail work from Home facility whenever they have some other task at the office time.Nominal onsite opportunity as well and Lots of learning opportunity .Even it is mandatory for every employee to do 40 hours of mandatory skills development training in a financial year and have to do atleast a certification in a year in the vertical path of their career growth.
cons: Less hike in Comparison to other US Based MNC.

review_title: Your manager can make or break your time here.
pros: The right manager will enable you to succeed and climb the ladder.  Salary met industry average-- the general opinion was that working for IBM outweighed higher salaries at other companies.  Training was sufficient.  Benefits were good.
cons: The wrong manager will end your career. Politics, politics, politics-- it's all about who you know, who you're aligned with.  While there is the exception, my time with this company proved the culture breeds management that supports only themselves and personal gain with no respect for the employees under them-- It's every person for themselves.  Very little work-life balance.

review_title: If you like unbriddled chaos, this is the place for you
job_title: Senior Business Delivery Analyst in East Orange, NJ
pros: Good benefits and time off, if you can get it.
cons: No matter what your level of experience is, if you do not brown nose, you will be stuck in the same position until you quit or they fire you. They promote inexperienced managers who are hated because they don't know enough to get out of a locked room. You will be worked to death, and you don't ever expect a thank you. When they decide they want you out, they concoct ridiculous reasons to push you out the door. They lie to clients, don't meet deadlines because their management staff is incompetent and knows zero about the industry. They are behind the times in their thought process, think 1968. Seriously, what other company remotely thinks mainframes are a technological advancement?

review_title: A good company undergoing transition -- making it a tough place to work
job_title: Presales Solutions Architect in Dallas, TX
pros:
Good benefits
Pay is OK but a little below local market average
Ability to move around in the company -- I've had 3 jobs in 8 years (by choice)
The company has a deep technical stack that is not matched by its competitors
cons:
The market is changing, so is IBM and those changes are painful (including lots of job cuts)
Management changes major focus every few years and abandons thing that were key before they have a chance to produce results
Growth by acquisition, not by native development
Many customers see the company as having old, outdated technology.

review_title: Decent company bad local management
pros: Liberal vacation, time off (ie. sick, funeral, etc) Great work from home policy if you work for the right manager/division. No ceiling on your growth potential. Training and learning opportunities abound if you look for them and have the right manger that supports doing that. IBM wants you always learning always growing and always contributing. If you don't like change this is not the place for you. You have to reinvent yourself every 5-7 years.
cons: Constant layoffs, horrible middle management. Huge disconnect of local management with corporate Armonk. Pay is different for each region. Find out about the pay for your region first.

review_title: IBM
job_title: Executive Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: I have 25 years at IBM and have loved the journey. The culture is based on a core set of IBM values, but each area has it's own personality. I have had the opportunity to challenge myself to grow my career and responsibilities with each new assignment. I had the opportunity to work from home for the last 15 years  - and that gave me the chance to have a bit of work/life balance while contributing at a very high level.
cons: Constant 'rebalancing' these days which is an ibm term for 'lay off'. It used to be an annual thing but it has turned to monthly. Morale is down in the areas where this is happening more frequently, as expected. And it very difficult to see talented folks let go.

review_title: A Dysfunctional Dinosaur
job_title: Campaign Manager in New York, NY
pros: The best reason to work at IBM is... I honestly can't come up with the best reason to work at IBM. I'm sure that there are plenty of wonderful reasons to work for IBM, but for me, it has easily been the worst professional experience of my career.
cons: IBM Marketing consistently demonstrates a complete lack of strategic thinking coupled with constantly changing and competing priorities which lead to every day being a fire drill. Add management's recent decision to co-locate all marketing activities in six cities, and you have a toxic stew of negativity, a lack of accountability and morale that's so low that most people are working on an exit strategy.  For these reasons and many others, I would not recommend working in marketing at IBM.

review_title: Great place to gain experience, not to stay for a long time
job_title: .NET Developer in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Flexibility, different projects and, many interns opportunities if you have time and are eager to pursue them, good work environment (maybe not if you work at some clients), good benefits.
cons: The pros and cons depends on the project you are working on. You can get a project that may not have a good work environment and that have too much stress. In general, IBM makes difficult for you to have a career inside the company. You have to make a good use of you personal marketing.

review_title: A lot of potential and opportunities
job_title: Supply Chain Operations Professional in Bratislava
pros: In IBM you are able to choose your own path. With a good manager who enables you to work on yourself you can choose your own path and since IBM is a large global company it give its employees opportunities to grow and if you work hard and get the attention of the right people you can climb the carrier ledder pretty fast.
cons: There are situations when it depends greatly on your manager if you will grow or not - the IBM strategy is to let the people grow and that is what a manager should do - enable the emplyee to grow - yet some managers decide to hinder the growth of a employee in order to keep him as an experienced veteran on the same position within heir own team.

review_title: Transforming IBM
pros: IBM is a process based company. So, if you are in it you are a process oriented person. IBM acknowledges the onslaught of the disruptive technologies like RPA, Block Chain, Big Data etc, and its investing heavily in it. So, if you are in IBM you get excellent materials to learn and play around with these new technologies.
cons: It is too large for someone to make a mark. There are isolated teams running after their own goals. The collective team approach is hard to achieve. Salary is mediocre but is compensated by the learning   avenues you get.

review_title: Endless opportunities for career development
pros: I appreciate the possibility to continuously expand my skills and invest into education to stay competitive and relevant both to the market and IBM. IBM offers vast of programs paths : Technical, Leadership, HR, Project Management, Consultancy etc to choose and grow your career. One can at any point in time completely change the career path without a need of leaving the company. IBM transformed and employed Agile and Design Thinking into the operations. Finally, IBM makes impact on the local communities where the company operate - I have been part of a pro bono consulting assignment where I could address health care system pinpoints in a medium sized city in India.
cons: Big organization with a lot of rules and complex end to end processes

review_title: Great for freshers, good platform to learn, but recognition for your performance can depend on your luck
pros:
-Good platform to learn
-Some very knowledgeable colleagues
-Very easy and comfortable work timings with no swipe-in or swipe-out rules
cons:
-Management will try to skip your hike/promotion if they get any lame excuse
-Your growth depends completely on your people manager, which can be a bad thing given your circumstances in the project
-Your paycheck will be low unless you move in as a lateral hire
-Very few to no incentives from the company. Even for a gift box, they usually provide something worth 30-40 Rs per head (again, depends on your project)

review_title: IBM is not what it used to be
job_title: Presales Solutions Architect in Chicago, IL
pros: "Some" very good people to work with.   The products used to be good, but now it feels like they should be in hospice.
cons:
Much of the upper-middle and upper management are only trying to get their next promotion.    

The result is that very shortsighted decisions get made and often hurt the products, integrations and the people building/selling them.

MVP is a common phrase now with Product Dev/Mgmt --- this is not referring to Most Valuable Process.   MVP refers to Minimal Viable Product and they rarely meet this MVP requirement.

The amount of middle-management headcount through most of IBM is surprising.    There were 4 mid-tier managers that had no direct reports in our reasonably small territory.  IBM also chose to cut people that were genuinely doing work and adding value instead of repurposing spreadsheets.

review_title: Great company overall, but not for everyone
job_title: Software QA Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Great company for those starting their careers, and with plenty of resources for learning.
Opportunities arise as projects evolve, come and go, one must be ready. 
There is always an expert somewhere in an area you migh need help with.
Things get done (sometimes not cheap or pretty), that's why customers come back.
Decent health insurance and pension.
There is flexibility when needed for personal/family reasons.
cons:
One must be aware of internal politics, this is a 100+ year old machine after all.
Visibility is key to career progress, you must balance this with real work to avoid frustration.
Salaries tend to be on the low end of the industry average (at least for non-managerial positions).
Changes in direction/priorities happen very quickly, one must accept and move on.

review_title: IT Analyst
job_title: IT Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Ability to work from home
cons: I worked in IBM Global Services whose only focus was on cost reduction that was done at the expense of their employees and their customers.  Experienced, knowledgeable, highly competent employees were laid-off and replaced with inexperienced resources from other countries.  As a result, productivity and the quality of work produced suffered.  In Global Services, the only thing that mattered was utilization, and it was not unusual to have quarterly utilization targets of 120%-130%.  Obviously, in order to meet those targets, especially if you had taken vacation or training time, significant, unpaid, overtime was required on a consistent weekly basis.  Employee raises were very infrequent and small.  Unsurprisingly, morale was very low.

review_title: SAP SRM/MM consultant
pros:
- a big company on your cv.
- if you join as an early professional on the foundation scheme you are likely to be working with other students from both similar and diverse backgrounds.
- the staff canteen was spacious
- being able to work from home
cons:
